HEADLINE: Telephone Pact To Alter Rates And Services

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
For Carlos Galvis in Jackson Heights, Queens, the global telecommunications trade agreement signed over the weekend in far-off Geneva may hit quite close to home.
On most evenings, thousands of New York City's Hispanic immigrants flock to travel agencies like the one managed by Mr. Galvis, which also serve as "telephone parlors" where visitors sit in cubicles to call family and friends in Latin America. Mr. Galvis buys long-distance service in bulk, parceling it out minute by minute at prices that while high, are still far lower than what individuals could obtain on their own. 
 Because of the convoluted international telephone economics that the trade pact seeks to simplify, visitors to the phone parlors think nothing of paying about 50 cents a minute for calls that actually cost long-distance carriers a nickel or so to transmit. But if the agreement, negotiated under the World Trade Organization, eventually works as intended, the price of a call from New York to the Dominican Republic may one day cost little more than one to Denver.
"If that happened it would be terrible for the business," said Mr. Galvis, visibly perturbed, as he leaned against the front counter of Biancas Travel on Roosevelt Avenue. "Why would people come here?"
Indeed, people like Mr. Galvis, who have profited from the artificially high price of telephone calls to countries where the governments -- not the marketplace -- dictate prices, would be losers under the trade agreement.
But for United States telecommunications customers -- whether multinational corporations or individual consumers -- the agreement should mean lower prices and better voice, data and video services. American long-distance companies are happy, too, at the prospect of eventually competing in more overseas markets and no longer seeing their international pricing dictated by foreign governments.
The agreement, signed on Saturday by more than 60 nations, is expected to remove many countries' barriers to foreign ownership of telecommunications companies, resulting in greater competition. Though there has been some opposition to it in Washington, Congress is not expected to block it.
"There is great potential benefit to having broad-based global competition," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Consumers Union, the nonprofit publisher of Consumer Reports magazine. "This market has such great potential for competition that openness could yield tremendous savings."
Big corporate customers agree.
The deal could be "terrific for business users," said Brian R. Moir, chief counsel for the International Communications Association, a Washington-based group that represents 500 companies and organizations that spend a total of $35 billion each year on domestic and overseas telecommunications services.
"Competition brings more choice," Mr. Moir said. "It brings higher quality and lower prices."
American consumers and companies spend about $14 billion on international telecommunications services each year. That includes private data lines for computers, as well as old-fashioned telex and even telegraph services. A vast majority of the traffic, though, is plain old telephone service -- about 16 billion minutes' worth in 1995, the last year for which figures were available from the Federal Communications Commission.
The price of those calls is determined to a great extent by what the foreign phone company -- often, owned by a government -- charges for completing them. And so, the per-minute rates vary greatly from country to country and are often artificially high. While a call to France, for instance, averages 81 cents a minute, one approximately the same distance to the West African nation of Cape Verde averages $5.64 a minute.
"There is no reason that international calls should be any higher than domestic calls that cover the same distance," said Diane Cornell, chief of the telecommunications division of the F.C.C.'s international bureau.
International calls headed from the United States cost customers an average of 91 cents a minute, while the price of domestic long-distance calls averages 16 cents a minute, Ms. Cornell said. But the trade agreement should start reducing that disparity soon, she said.
"If this deal goes through, it will have a catalyst effect within a very short time period," Ms. Cornell said, "and will result in very significant competition in other countries, which will have a very direct effect on rates here."
The deal could cause global telephone rates to fall by 15 percent in the three or four years after the pact goes into effect, estimated Tom L. Elliott, a partner at Arthur Andersen, the consulting firm. "Over a 10-to-12-year period, a trillion dollars could be saved by consumers worldwide," he said.
The most important component of international telephone pricing is the fee that carriers from different countries pay one another to connect an international call to a home or business. This fee is known as the settlement rate, or the accounting rate. For American carriers like AT&T or Sprint, those rates range from the 7 cents a minute that some Canadian carriers charge during off-peak hours to the $2.50 a minute charged by the national telephone monopoly of Myanmar, and higher.
Developing countries often defend high settlement rates as necessary to help finance the construction of telecommunications networks within their borders. But Americans tend to see higher rates as trade barriers.
"The settlement rates are not rational," said Jeffrey K. MacKie-Mason, a professor of economics, information and public policy at the University of Michigan. "A lot of them are being driven by protectionist objectives rather than by competitive concerns."
The deal worked out in Geneva does not directly force a reduction in settlement rates. But it does require participating nations to open their communications networks to competition, and United States trade officials and telecommunications experts expect the resulting marketplace forces to drive rates down around the world.
Executives like Jon T. Pojednic can hardly wait.
"For a medium-capacity data line here in the United States we might be paying $300 or $400 a month," said Mr. Pojednic, a telecommunications manager for United Parcel Service of America Inc., which spends about $200 million on telecommunications services each year. "We could be paying as high as two and a half times that in some countries -- in the U.K., for example, in Spain, in France."
And increased competition could do more for his business than simply reduce prices, Mr. Pojednic said. He said that where competition exists telecommunications companies often vie with one another as fiercely to provide good customer service as they do to offer the best prices.
The time between ordering a new telecommunications service and receiving it averages about 30 days in the United States, Mr. Pojednic said, adding that "In the U.K., Spain and France it's anywhere from 8 to 12 weeks."
The deal could also give American companies more flexibility in deciding where to put overseas operations, said Richard S. Christner, a vice president at Mercer Management Consulting. He noted that Britain had already deregulated its telecommunications markets more quickly than France.
"If I'm a financial services company that spends a huge amount of money communicating all the financial transactions and supporting information, the U.K. is a more attractive place to expand and invest," Mr. Christner said. "This is much more likely to level the playing field for decisions on where businesses are going to have attractive opportunities."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ex-Trader at Sumitomo Admits Guilt in Fraud Case
Yasuo Hamanaka, the central figure in a $2.6 billion copper scandal at Sumitomo, admitted he was guilty of forgery and fraud in an arraignment held today in Tokyo, according to press reports. In an arraignment, prosecutors in Tokyo District Court charged that Mr. Hamanaka made the fraudulent transactions to cover up massive copper trading losses that extended over 10 years. When asked to respond, Mr. Hamanaka replied, "that is correct," according to the Associated Press.
Mr. Hamanaka's trial, though, was unlikely to provide answers to the larger question of whether Sumitomo management was at all involved in off-the-book trades. By indicting Mr. Hamanaka on charges of fraud, the prosecutors seemed to drop efforts to probe for misconduct at Sumitomo. [Page 42.]

Small Jets a Cause for Dispute
The bitter confrontation between American Airlines and its pilots' union has some of its roots in an innovation in air travel -- small jets -- that the company wants to use on many shorter routes, replacing turboprop aircraft. While popular with travelers, the jets are seen by many pilots as a way for American to replace larger jets and to assign those flights to much lower paid pilots at American's feeder airline. [1.]

Now that President Clinton has removed the threat of a strike for at least 60 days and started arbitration, American Airlines, which faced heavy losses from a strike, may benefit financially. But whether that help will be permanent remains in question. [48.]

The New Diplomatic World Order
For more than half a century, the United Nations has been the main forum for the United States to try to create a world in its image. But in recent months, leading up to the telecommunications trade agreement reached this weekend, the Clinton Administration has begun to use a recent institution, the World Trade Organization. News analysis. [1.]
 
The Web May Get Faster
Software is in the works that could accelerate the World Wide Web's performance. A group that sets Web standards has demonstrated data retrieval speeds up to eight times as fast as those using current software. [42.]
 
Many Thumbs Down On Hollywood
Major Hollywood studios released 163 movies last year, but only one, "Jerry Maguire," turned out to be a serious contender for the Academy Awards. With most Oscar nominations going to independent films, voters at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences seemed to be implicitly criticizing not only studio movies but also the system that created them. [1.]
 
The Daily Cacophony
The music media industry is becoming a world dominated by tidbits reported fresh every day. Nearly every publication is starting some sort of daily hot line in a scramble to get the first word in, regardless of whether it is interesting, trivial or even accurate. Entertainment. [49.]
 
Who Gave What?
Want to see who in your town donated more than $200 to a political candidate or party? Type in your ZIP code and a Web site called FECInfo provides a list. FECInfo is not alone in recognizing a demand for simplified government data. Numerous groups have benefited by being able to glean the essentials from the oceans of Government data. [45.]
 
Economic Development, on the Net
Cities and states are using the Internet to escalate the competition for new businesses, with a number of economic development agencies boasting on line about their incentive packages. Taking In the Sites. [47.]
 
Markets Closed for Holiday
All financial and commodities markets and most banks in the United States are closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most markets overseas are open.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Charges in Beating at a Bar

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD

 BODY:
Two college students and a third man were charged with beating a 23-year-old man, John Vollrath of North Wildwood, to death outside a bar, the Club Kaladu, here early Saturday, the A.P. reported. The police charged Christopher Short, 20, a student at Penn State University; his brother Adam, 18, a student at Widener University in Chester, Pa, and Joseph J. Mader 2d of North Cape May, whom the police described as an unemployed bouncer.

HEADLINE: TV Woos Viewers With News Of Business

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
They can be found in Times Square, in Wall Street trading rooms and in Fortune 500 executive suites, in bars in business districts and in retirement homes from Florida to California. Those television screens with the ticker tape of stock market quotes sliding lazily across the bottom seem to be almost everywhere these days.
And no wonder. With stock markets booming and almost everybody over 30 worried about retirement, a growing audience of baby boomers, stock and bond traders and retired people is tuning in to programs on stocks, bonds, personal investments and every other conceivable financial topic. 
 A seemingly endless stream of analysts, executives and self-styled gurus appears on shows like "Market Wrap," "Street Signs" and "Power Lunch" on CNBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, and "Capital Ideas," "Digital Jam," "Street Sweep" and "Business Unusual" on CNNFN, which is owned by Time Warner Inc. No matter if the sound is turned off -- the screens flash subtitles showing viewers what the talking heads are saying.
Financial television has grown rapidly in the 1990's as programmers sought to attract the millions of Americans who now make more of their own financial decisions. Viewers are offered a succession of interview programs differentiated mostly by what time of the day they appear and what segment of the market they address.
Many broadcasters on these newer channels are reluctant to say much about their ratings, and Nielsen Media, the television ratings company, keeps its numbers private. CNBC, one of the few that reveals such information, says that it now reaches 61 million homes and that in the last quarter of 1996 an average of 2.3 million homes tuned in each week, up slightly from the prior year. It says, moreover, that its audience in the 25-to-54 age group, which is much sought after by advertisers, grew 24 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996, compared with a year earlier.
A race in December between CNBC and CNN to provide live ticker quotes running across the bottom of their screens highlighted the growing competition in the field. Previously, such quotes had been run only after a 15-minute delay.
CNBC is the grande dame of financial and business television, having started in 1989. CNNFN, which began broadcasting in December 1995, is trying to build on the success of its parent channel, CNN, and its popular "Moneyline" program, anchored by Lou Dobbs, which broadcasts simultaneously on both CNN and CNNFN. These channels have attracted advertisers like the Charles Schwab Corporation and other mutual fund companies that sell investments to baby boomers, the American Express Company and other credit card businesses and auto companies like the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation.
In addition, Bloomberg Business Television, a unit of Bloomberg L.P., has for years broadcast financial and business programming. And last month, Dow Jones & Company and the ITT Corporation joined forces to launch WBIS, a cable channel that broadcasts an eclectic mixture of business and sports programming.
All four channels broadcast their programming primarily in the daytime, and occasionally it can seem inescapable. "I'm struck, as everybody is, by the ubiquity of it," James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, said. "You see it everywhere."
Statistics aside, many business people have come to regard financial television as increasingly important to their professional lives, even though they often gripe about the shallowness of the insights being proffered. Perhaps that should not be surprising, some regular viewers say, since the smartest analysts are too busy making money to make television appearances.
For some investment managers, though, financial television is a great marketing tool. "I think it's a terrific way to get the word out," said Elaine Garzarelli, who runs a research and investment management firm and appears on both CNBC and CNNFN. "If you appear, at least you can get the story straight," Ms. Garzarelli said. In Florida, where Ms. Garzarelli lives, "70 percent of the neighbors watch it all day long," she said.
Some regulars on the shows maintain that appearances on financial television bolster their image with investors. "These kinds of appearances give me credibility," Wayne Angell, chief economist at Bear Stearns & Company and a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said, adding that he liked the fact that CNBC sends a television crew to his office when it wants to put him on camera.
"It's an important outlet for me to show my face to my clients," said John E. Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide Information Services, a financial consultant in New York.
Financial professionals like Mr. Keefe often consider it critical to be familiar with what is being shown on business television. "I check it many times a day," he said.
But even some who appear on the shows are skeptical about the lasting effect of appearances on financial and business television. "An appearance on a major network program such as the 'Today' program or 'Nightline' is much more important than being on these financial shows," said Harold L. Vogel, managing director at Cowen & Company, a New York investment bank.
Mr. Keefe, who worked as an analyst on Wall Street for years, has reservations about the new financial programming. "What I see as a problem, a potential problem, is having every Tom, Dick and Harry money manager come on and recommend stocks. How can some of them talk about any stock whatsoever, from I.B.M. to Pepsi?" he said. "How can any analyst really understand and comment on such very different companies? The guys who probably have the most knowledge and the most business don't go on. They can't take an hour out of their day to go on."
Some critics take an even more jaundiced view. "The problem is they have to fill up dead air," said Allan Ripp, a New York public relations consultant. "Most of the traders who have these things on have the sound turned off."
Clearly, the audience for business programming is growing, although perhaps not as fast as some think. The 2.3 million households that tuned in each week to CNBC in the fourth quarter of 1996 represented only a 4 percent increase from the year earlier, according to George H. Jamison, a company spokesman. But, he added, that number only includes households and does not include the many offices and businesses where screens show the channel. Those outlets probably bump the number up to about 3.2 million, he said.
The channel's most popular show, "Market Wrap," which is on from 4 P.M. to 5 P.M. on weekdays, has about a quarter-million viewers at any one time, Mr. Jamison said, adding, "We get our heaviest viewing in the afternoon."
The rite of passage for financial television, however, is likely to come when the financial markets' joy ride ends and the stock market takes a dive. As Mr. Grant, the newsletter publisher, put it: "People like to watch themselves getting richer. The true test of financial television will be if investors want to watch themselves get poorer."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 19, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about the growth in financial programming on television referred incorrectly to one new outlet. WBIS is a broadcast station, Channel 31 in New York; it is not strictly a cable channel.

HEADLINE: For Remote Bird Species, the Sex of Hatchlings Is No Surprise

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON 

 BODY:
AMONG parents, one question never fails to arouse a lively debate: Which is the preferable sex to raise, boys or girls? While nearly everyone has an opinion on this impossible-to-resolve question, it remains the uncontrollable biological reality of sperm meeting egg rather than parental preference that casts the die for a little Jack or tiny Jill.
One thousand miles off the east coast of Africa, however, on a remote island in the Seychelles, researchers have discovered a bird that is able to produce a male or a female offspring according to its changing needs with uncanny precision. 
 "I was surprised," said Dr. Jan Komdeur, a lecturer in animal behavior at the University of Melbourne in Australia, who discovered the bird's behavior. "But I thought it was a very clever thing." Dr. Komdeur and his colleagues published their study in the Feb. 6 issue of the journal Nature.
In fact, evolutionary theorists have been arguing since early in the century that ideally, parents of any species should adjust the ratio of male to female offspring that they produce, depending upon the evolutionary payoff, or how much it costs to produce a male or female relative to how many young that offspring is likely to produce. But for many years, only wasps and bees showed any indication that they could alter the ratio of male to female young.
Now new studies, including the latest and most striking one with Seychelles warblers, are beginning to show that whether they be rats, birds or bees, when it comes to producing young, parents can sexually discriminate and do.
"This is very big news," said Dr. Patricia Adair Gowaty, an evolutionary ecologist at the Institute of Ecology at the University of Georgia in Athens, calling the study an "instant classic."
Dr. Stephen Emlen, the Jacob Gould Schurman Professor of Behavioral Ecology at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., called the study "awesome," saying: "It's going to raise eyebrows. There are going to be people so astonished by this that they are going to challenge it."
In the Seychelles, the only place in the world where these warblers are found, they live in pairs, each on their own territory. But on the 70 acres of tiny Cousin island, there are not always enough territories for every bird to get a mate and make a home. So many young birds, usually females, stay at home with their parents and learn the tricks of the trade by helping out. They help build nests, defend the territory, incubate eggs and feed newborn chicks.
Helpers are only beneficial when there is enough food on the territory and no more than two such assistants. With more helpers or too little food, they become a liability as they compete with parents and chicks for scarce insect meals. So, the theory goes, parents should produce females when helpers would be useful and males when they would not.
Using DNA tests to determine the sex of newly hatched chicks (both sexes look the same), researchers found that the birds produce young in their natural habitats exactly as theory would predict.
Researchers were also able to carry out an unusually convincing test. They moved pairs of warblers from territories without much food on Cousin to territories with lots of food on the neighboring islands of Aride and Cousine (not to be confused with Cousin, the island of origin) where no Seychelles warblers live. Pairs that had produced mostly or all males on Cousin when they had little food to share suddenly began producing mostly or all females to help out in the more bountiful new territories.
A huge obstacle in studying birds had been the difficulty of telling the sex of chicks. But even in those few species where researchers could tell male and female chicks apart, the deviations from a 1-to-1 sex ratio were so subtle that many doubted if parents were up to anything at all. In fact, the conventional wisdom became that birds were physiologically incapable of any precise control over what sex chick they produced.
Bees and wasps, on the other hand, have long been thought to manipulate the sex of their young.
For example, Dr. John Werren, an evolutionary geneticist at the University of Rochester, studies parasitic wasps that lay their eggs on caterpillars and other insects. Large female wasps that have grown up on a big juicy caterpillar do much better than small females, as they are able to produce many more eggs. Males, on the other hand, do fine whether they are large or small. What researchers have found is that quite logically, when a mother wasp finds a nice big caterpillar, she lays a female. When she finds a puny one, she leaves behind a male.
But in wasps and bees, the method for manipulating the sex of offspring is clear. When a mother wasp wants to produce a male, she lays an unfertilized egg. To produce a female, she fertilizes the egg with her cache of sperm before laying it.
But as for the birds, "how in heaven's name are they doing it?" Dr. Emlen asked. "No one has any idea."
In birds, sex is determined, as in humans, by sex chromosomes. In humans, men carry two different sex chromosomes, an X and a Y, and women carry two X chromosomes. That means every woman's egg has an X chromosome, and the child's sex is determined by the father's sperm, which provides either a Y, for a boy, or an X, for a girl.
In contrast, in birds it is the females that carry the two different sex chromosomes, a Z and a W, while male birds carry two W chromosomes. So it is the female bird and her egg, carrying a Z or a W chromosome, that determines a chick's sex.
While noting that it remains to be seen just how these birds do it, in principle, Dr. Werren said, a bird that can watch her Z's and W's can exercise a lot of potential control over the sex of her young.
The evolution of sex ratios may appear to be an esoteric topic, but Dr. Gowaty said it might be closer to home than it seemed. "One exciting aspect is if we could select for lines of all-daughter or all-son producers, for example, in chicken or in cattle," Dr. Gowaty said. "You know it's been tried for years and years. But you haven't heard about it, right? That's because no one's been able to do it. But wouldn't that be economically wonderful?"
While the Seychelles warblers, also known as Acrocephalus sechellensis, are a far cry from an all-hen-producing chicken, they are an indication that at least some birds have the capacity to produce all or mostly one sex of young under the right conditions.
Dr. Martha K. McClintock, a biopsychologist at the University of Chicago, said the new sex ratio studies might hit close to home in quite another way.
While there is nothing quite so dramatic as the switches seen in Seychelles warblers, evidence is growing in mammals that mothers tend to produce more male offspring when males may be most successful in mating and more females when they are the better bet for producing new generations. That work, she says, speaks to humans as well.
In mammals, in general, the main method for controlling the sex of the offspring appears to be loss: loss of sperm not used in fertilization and loss of fetuses before they are born. What determines the sex ratio, for example in a litter of pups, is the pattern of loss along the way.
Referring to Dr. Leslie Hornig, also at the University of Chicago, Dr. McClintock points out that there are similar patterns of loss in humans. "We all know it's the sperm that determines the sex, but as Leslie points out, there are millions that don't make it. What determines the ones that do?" Likewise, Dr. McClintock said, the natural abortion of fetuses in women happens more often with male than female fetuses, suggesting that women's bodies may be selecting for or against fetuses of different sexes as well.
So while men's sperm have long borne the sole responsibility, women's bodies may have much more control than previously imagined over which sex is ultimately born.
Dr. McClintock summed it up, saying, "Henry the Eighth might have been more right than we give him credit for."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Seychelles warbler, which can choose the sex of its offspring. Pairs that had produced mostly or all males on an island with little food suddenly produced mostly or all females in food-rich new territories. (P. Davey)

HEADLINE: Disney Hall: A Mirage Is Looking More Real

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
A decade after Walt Disney's widow, Lillian, donated $50 million for an architecturally imposing concert hall in downtown Los Angeles, local political, business and cultural leaders say they are finally confident that they will be able to raise enough money to prevent Los Angeles County from scrapping the long-stalled project.
Officials of the county, which owns the site for the Walt Disney Concert Hall, have demanded that another $50 million be raised by July 1. As the city's business leaders commit more wealth and prestige to the drive, organizers now expect to approach $100 million in new contributions by the deadline, said Eli Broad, chairman of Sunamerica, the financial services corporation. 
 Reviving the flagging Disney project after years of indifference has taken on the fervor of a crusade in Los Angeles. It is no longer just about the fate of an important cultural institution and showcase for the Los Angeles Philharmonic. The concert hall is seen as crucial to shoring up a struggling downtown and demonstrating that the city is a world-class center for the arts.
Mr. Broad and a close friend, Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles, decided while on a trip to France in 1995 that continuing to let the Disney project languish "would mean a black eye for the city," said Mr. Broad, who took charge of the money-raising effort last June.
The Mayor has been soliciting potential donors, Mr. Broad said, and both men say they will give $5 million or more from their own pockets. (Mr. Riordan, who is up for re-election in April, is heavily favored to win.)
Other developments are reinforcing the sales pitch. Models of Disney Hall are on public display, at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, for the first time in the six years since Frank O. Gehry, the internationally known Santa Monica-based architect, completed his free-flowing design, which some have compared to a futuristic sailing ship. It helps that Mr. Gehry's new Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, has been drawing rave reviews and was built on time and on budget.
Even so, since Mr. Broad signed on, only two large donations have been announced: $7.5 million from an anonymous donor and $5 million from the Times Mirror Foundation, which deliberated for several months before deciding that confidence was warranted. More of the city's chief executives are joining the campaign, however, and the results of their efforts will be announced later.
"Everyone is quite disciplined and focused now on what needs to happen to make Disney Hall work," said Stephen C. Meier, a foundation spokesman.
Less than a year ago, Disney Hall's prospects seemed much dimmer. The Disney family's gifts had swelled to more than $100 million, with interest, but aside from a $2 million donation from the Parsons Foundation, no additional money had been pledged. And while agencies squabbled over the project, the price tag, originally put at $100 million, rose to $265 million.
Mr. Gehry's design was attacked as too complicated and was blamed for the cost increase. Worried about his reputation, the architect told interviewers that he hated going out in public and might even move.
The county, meanwhile, had gone ahead and spent $100 million to build a seven-story underground parking garage. But an office building and hotel that the garage was also intended to serve are no longer contemplated. And while debt service on the garage will be $4.2 million in the next fiscal year, last month the garage had fewer than 400 customers a day for its 2,334 spaces, said a county management analyst, Don Simpson.
To many people, the floundering of Disney Hall was more proof that Los Angeles is a place where "power is divided into so many subsets that it is very hard to do anything in the interests of the city at large," said Richard Weinstein, a professor of architecture at U.C.L.A. A city battered by riots and natural disasters was taking yet another blow to its pride.
But now even Mr. Gehry is upbeat. "Having Mr. Broad involved makes me feel very secure and optimistic," he said. "He's not going to screw it up."
Zev Yaroslavsky, a Los Angeles County Supervisor, said that Mr. Broad, the founding chairman of the Museum of Contemporary Art, had "tremendous credibility" in the arts and business communities.
Mr. Broad and Mr. Gehry make a curious team. They have "a history," Mr. Gehry said.
About seven years ago, Mr. Broad commissioned the architect to design his home in Brentwood, but he had the house built before the design was completed. "I was very slow," Mr. Gehry said, "and he was very impatient."
"Every time Frank would finish the design," Mr. Broad recalled, "he'd want to improve it."
Their relationship greatly improved, Mr. Gehry said, after Mr. Broad visited Mr. Gehry's new museum in Bilbao last month. "Something happened to him when he saw Bilbao," Mr. Gehry said. "The guy is turned on."
Other visitors to Bilbao from the Disney fund-raising drive, including Andrea L. Van de Kamp, chairwoman of the Music Center, have also come away impressed by the museum.
The striking use of titanium to clad the Bilbao museum has suggested to Mr. Broad that maybe Disney Hall's exterior should also be predominantly metal instead of limestone. Mr. Gehry cautioned that the building was designed with stone in mind. "If they make it metal like Bilbao," he said, "it's going to look like Son of Bilbao."
Supporters of Disney Hall are promoting it as a key component of a revitalization plan for downtown Los Angeles, including a new sports arena and a replacement for the St. Vibiana Cathedral.
A new hall, they say, would also let the Los Angeles Philharmonic sound as good at home as it does on tour. The orchestra's home is now the 33-year-old Music Center's Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, which is widely considered a "second-rate acoustical environment," Mr. Yaroslavsky said.
Mr. Gehry wishes that people would pay more attention to the acoustical advantages and less to his exterior design.
But these days, at least, he is no longer afraid of going out in public. "People are smiling at me now," he said.

HEADLINE: Providence Is Reviving, Using Arts As the Fuel

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 13

 BODY:
On Weybosset Street, Teresa Level is selling works of art on consignment in a small gallery. In a loft upstairs that doubles as a home and production studio, Bob Zolli and his wife, Susan Arundale, are rehearsing songs for a musical they plan to produce in the spring. Around the corner on Empire Street, in a small room that serves as a home and art studio, Chris Horoshak is painting tedious patterns on canvas.
These are the faces of contemporary Providence, a once-gritty manufacturing town now well on the way toward reinvention. They are also the faces of the city's future. 
 These artists are among scores living in the heart of Providence, a square mile of downtown that city officials have turned into an arts and entertainment empowerment zone. Through legislation that went into effect this year, artists and performers from the district pay no state income tax on what they sell; their customers pay no sales tax on what they buy. And in what city and state officials say is the key to the economic redevelopment of the area, the city offers tax breaks to property owners who convert old, unused buildings into residential units.
"Every artist wants to live in lower Manhattan," said Mr. Horoshak, 24, a native of Philadelphia, who pays $250 a month for his cluttered apartment-studio, in a building where he and several other artists share bathrooms and a kitchen in a dormitory-style setting. "But it's difficult to leave a situation like this, where you can live and work in comfort. It's a fantastic place to get momentum."
The arts district is one of the latest projects in Providence, the capital of Rhode Island, to help revitalize a city of 160,000 people that was virtually stilled by a steady migration to the suburbs over the last two decades.
Largely through the efforts of Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., a gregarious Republican-turned-independent who has served 16 of the last 22 years, eyesores like old railroad tracks and abandoned buildings have been cleared out to make way for a spectrum of change. With financial help from the city, state and Federal Government over the last 20 years, old theaters were spruced up, restaurants opened, big hotel chains came to town, the railroad tracks were moved underground, even the rivers running through the city were rerouted to create open space linking the downtown area to two treasures, Brown University and the Rhode Island School of Design, or "Risdy," as it is commonly called.
This spring, ground is to be broken for a mall near downtown that will cover 1.3 million square feet and will be the largest shopping area between Boston and New York. And city officials are trying to lure the New England Patriots football team to Providence from Foxboro, Mass., with plans to build an outdoor stadium.
But what of downtown itself? In recent years, its architecturally ornate buildings had fallen into disrepair. Grand stores that served well-dressed customers in the 1940's and 1950's had long been vacated, and only here and there had new retailers moved in. Interstate 95 cut a concrete swath through the heart of the city.
"We had to look at what resources we had and saw that because of Risdy, we found we had more artists per capita than any other city in America," Mr. Cianci said, revving up. "We had artists, so we'd get more artists. We'd become the Florence of America. Ever been to Florence? It's beautiful. You walk along the street and see glass blowers here, leather crafters there. Rehearsal halls. Painters. Ballet dancers. Everywhere. That's what we want to create here. We could be sister cities."
But Providence is counting on more than additional artists and their customers to revitalize its core. Patricia McLaughlin, the city's deputy solicitor, said city and state officials did not even calculate how much revenue the state might lose through the sales and income tax exemptions, figuring that young artists were not earning enough through sales of their works and part-time jobs to make much of a difference.
Gov. Lincoln C. Almond, a Republican whose vetoes of the tax proposals last year were overridden by the legislature, said that the potential losses were "not determinable" but that they "could be significant."
The key to the legislation, Ms. McLaughlin said, was the tax breaks for developers, which officials figured would lead to investments triggering more shops and restaurants. Buildings in the area are now in various states of rehabilitation.
Joseph R. Paolino Jr., who was mayor from 1984 through 1990 during Mr. Cianci's lone hiatus since 1974, said that his family's company, which owns more buildings in the arts district than anyone else, has plans to develop three downtown buildings to create a total of 30 loft apartments.
"And all those people are going to have to eat, right?" Mr. Cianci said. "They got to shop. They go to movies. Besides 20 movie theaters in the new mall, we're getting seven more movie theaters downtown. I made sure of that."
Mr. Zolli, a former Broadway performer and veteran of the traveling company for "Les Miserables," said artists and performers already living in Providence had "the general feeling this is a boom town." He predicted that hundreds more would respond to the city's welcome mat, the way he and his wife did -- drawn not only by tax breaks but also by the relative proximity to New York, about 180 miles southwest, and by lower costs.
"We were looking in Boston," Ms. Arundale said, "but couldn't find anything in a loft that gave us rehearsal space and living space."
For $1,000 a month, they rent 2,850 square feet that includes three bedrooms, two baths and an office in addition to 1,300 square feet of rehearsal space.
"As artists from New York," Mr. Zolli said, "we were used to doors slamming a lot. Here, everything is an open door."
Mayor Cianci acknowledged that it was more than civic pride pushing him to redesign his city.
"It's staying in office," he said. "You know, Winston Churchill once said that a politician gives people what they want and a statesman gives them what they need. This is the only time in my career I'll be able to make them converge. This distinguishes us as a city, gives us a character of our own."
"Anyway, I'm not finished yet," he continued. "The job's not done. I'm going to run again. Then I'm going to relocate I-95."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Turning downtown Providence, R.I., into a haven for artists is just one of the projects by Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. to make the city attractive again. New tax breaks for individuals and businesses have also helped. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Eastern Europe's Wild Capitalism

 BODY:
When asked why the Albanian Government had not stepped in to end recent pyramid schemes before they swindled Albanians out of hundreds of millions of dollars, President Sali Berisha said his inaction was a sign of the Government's commitment to the free market. Even assuming that ideology, not corruption, explains his Government's failure, Mr. Berisha's view is disturbing. Such a misreading of capitalism has caused widespread misery in former Communist countries, which are still learning that the free market works best when not completely free.
The United States learned this only after decades of scandals and crashes. The first Federal regulations came only after the stock market crash of 1929. The same thing is happening now in most of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet bloc. Albania's wrenching experiences, which have sparked protests that now threaten to bring down Mr. Berisha's Government, followed the collapse of similar Ponzi schemes in Russia, Bulgaria, Romania and Serbia. 
 Russia's experience was typical. In 1994 a gigantic pyramid scheme called MMM took $1 billion from the Russian people before it was finally closed down by the tax police, the only agency with the legal powers to do so. After its collapse, Russia began to set up the Federal Commission for the Securities Market.
That agency currently employs only 100 people, but it is growing and would probably be able to prevent a similar scheme. Regulators, however, warn that some Russian banks and private pension funds, which are not covered by the securities commission, are in danger of collapse.
People who have spent their lives under Communism are particularly susceptible to such schemes. Anyone who idealized capitalism from a distance for decades tends not to be wary of swindlers promising interest rates of 30 percent a month without explaining how such profits are possible. Many people watch in anger as those who thrived under Communism now get rich through shady deals. The pyramid scams seem like equalizers, opportunities for ordinary citizens to get something too. Few people living on $20 a month would not jump at the chance.
Poland, which has suffered no major scandals, was the only newly capitalist country that started out with regulations on investment offerings. It could do so because its economy had been less deformed by Communism than others and it did not need to restructure by essentially starting from scratch and letting anyone bid for investment.
Other nations were more stunted. Some leaders assumed capitalism was simply the opposite of Communism. They knew that overregulation can stifle the economy, but they did not know about the dangers of underregulation. Many of the countries still have little administrative law to help regulators do their jobs. Citizens are accustomed to a system in which the law is ignored and the powerful are free to make deals with their friends, habits that also flourish under unfettered capitalism.
It is urgent for governments to do everything they can to punish fraud and end the widespread practice of ignoring mounting problems. But true protection for investors will probably have to wait for more modern economies. The most important regulation comes from the market itself. Companies and brokers that want long-term business need to behave themselves. So far, few companies in the get-rich-quick climate of Eastern Europe are worrying about their reputation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: New Quiz Show Brings Some Levity to All-News Channel

 BODY:
Fred Bellemore is famous on the Vassar College campus in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for his extensive knowledge.
"I have a reputation," said Dr. Bellemore, an assistant professor of economics. "Not for anything intellectual. For trivia. Sports and television, particularly 'Gilligan's Island.' " 
 So perhaps it was only logical that Dr. Bellemore, 34, would represent the college on a new cable network game show where teams of college faculty and students compete on questions about current events and television history.
At the Columbia School of Journalism, James Carey, 62, was selected for less strategic reasons.
"I was working very late one night and happened to run into an assistant dean in the hall," Dr. Carey said. "He needed someone to compete for Columbia, so I volunteered. To be honest, I don't watch much television."
The new game show, "Remember This," which premiered in October on the all-news cable station MSNBC, is a make over of the long-running "G.E. College Bowl" of the 1960's, with Allen Ludden serving as host. The new show is seen nationally on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays and Al Roker, the weatherman for the "Today" show on NBC, is the host.
Instead of questions on chemistry, geography and literature drawn from the pages of the Encyclopedia Britannica, contestants are tested on politics, journalism and pop culture culled from 250,000 hours of NBC News archival footage. The winner returns to campus with a $1,000 check for the school's scholarship fund.
"Remember This" was developed by Robert Mayer, a former CBS News producer, and Sande Stewart, the creator of "The $25,000 Pyramid" -- as a change of pace from the network's all-news schedule.
"We wanted to create a game show that was fun while also being educational," Mr. Mayer said. College campuses, he added, were good places to find contestants who would be smart enough and might be enthusiastic about trying out for an unknown game show.
Because the producers also wanted to keep down travel costs, MSNBC staff members did most of their recruiting during the fall and early winter on campuses in the Northeast. Besides Columbia and Vassar, they visited Fordham University, the University of Hartford, Swarthmore and some of the CUNY campuses, among others.
On each campus, potential contestants were given a 50-question written quiz on current events. Approximately 30 students at both Vassar and Columbia took the test, and the highest scorers (those who answered at least half the questions right) were selected. Dr. Bellemore and Dr. Carey were the only faculty members at their colleges who took the test; both scored well.
When "Remember This" premiered, the format was professors versus students. But, that soon changed because the faculty teams were winning every game. They often had too many years of television viewing to fairly compete with students born after the Watergate break-in.
Dr. Bellemore and his two teammates, Rishi Bhandari and Darcey Rakestraw, political science majors, crammed for their appearance by testing each other with a trivia book during the trip from their Poughkeepsie campus to the studio on East 106th Street, in a limousine provided by MSNBC.
Although there was also a limousine there was no practice for their Columbia opponents, Dr. Carey and his teammates, Steven Zeitchik and Danna Schoenberg, journalism graduate students.
At the recent "Remember This" taping, the two teams sat behind semicircular wood desks on the set, underneath bright spotlights, and awaited the first question from Mr. Roker.
Turning toward the 10-foot by 10-foot big-screen television to his right, Mr. Roker introduced the first video clip:
"Dateline, Jan. 31, 1968. Take a look as Howard Tucker reports on an embassy under fire. See if you remember this." Then he asked the question: What was the popular name for this attack?
Vassar's Dr. Bellemore buzzed. "Tet," he answered correctly, winning 10 points.
"Next," Mr. Roker quickly continued, "Tet celebrates the following: Vietnamese independence, Buddha's birthday or New Year's Day?"
Mr. Bhandari, 21, of Vassar correctly answered "New Year's Day" -- though he was born seven years after the incident.
"Now, who was the U.S. ambassador headquartered at the embassy? George Bush, Ellsworth Bunker or Lloyd Bucher?" Mr. Roker asked.
The third Vassar player, Ms. Rakestraw, 21, guessed George Bush (incorrect, but perhaps the choice most familiar to her generation).
Dr. Carey jumped in. "Ellsworth Bunker," he said, picking up 10 points for Columbia.
For the rest of the half-hour, news clips were viewed and follow-up questions asked -- and more often than not correctly answered -- on subjects ranging from Jackie Robinson to Dan Quayle to Superman. When the final bell sounded, Vassar was on top 280 to 240. The triumph meant both the $1,000 check for the school, and the chance to try reaching the grand prize round in March for a $20,000 scholarship. So far 16 teams, including Vassar, are in the running.
After the game, in a hallway near the set, the victorious Dr. Bellemore said he felt more relief than excitement.
"For us professors, it's less important to show how much we know, than not letting people find out how much we don't," he said.
His teammate, Mr. Bhandari, agreed: "There's much more pressure on the professors to know the right answers. Especially Dr. Bellemore, since he looks like such a kid."
To Dr. Carey of Columbia, the biggest challenge wasn't the questions themselves, but pushing the buzzer quickly enough and then not freezing up in front of the cameras. "There's very little reaction time," he said. "You know the answer, but suddenly your mind goes blank."
His quiz show appearance came 40 years after another Columbia teacher, Charles Van Doren, became enmeshed in a cheating scandal over the NBC quiz show, "Twenty-One." So Dr. Carey acknowledged the fate awaiting him back on campus.
"I'm sure I'll take a little ribbing from some of the other faculty," he said with a chuckle, before assuming a mock seriousness, "But I don't want to hear anything from them. They didn't volunteer."

HEADLINE: Russia Has Nothing to Fear

BYLINE: By Strobe Talbott; Strobe Talbott is Deputy Secretary of State.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov are scheduled to meet in Moscow on Thursday to discuss ways to strengthen ties between NATO and Russia -- despite Russian objections to the alliance's decision to bring in new members. The chances of progress will be greater if the Russians understand not just the inevitability of enlargement, but the reasons for it.
The decision to expand the alliance began with a question. After the breakup of the Soviet Union and the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact, should there remain, on the landscape of Europe, a military alliance or should NATO retire voluntarily to the ash heap of history? 
 When President Clinton began his first term in 1993, he concluded that an alliance was still necessary because there would continue to be threats to the security of the member states and to Europe as a whole.
He was concerned about several contingencies. One was regional conflict or instability, stemming from ethnic and other tensions arising inside or between European states. Another was an external threat from the South or from the East. Such possibilities may seem remote, but they are not unthinkable, especially in an era when missile technology and weapons of mass destruction are spreading.
Another question then arose: Is NATO itself too much identified with the cold war to cope with new challenges and to take advantage of new opportunities? Should a new alliance be created?
The President decided to adapt the existing alliance for three reasons. First, it is easier and cheaper to build on what already exists than to start from scratch. Second, NATO must remain the anchor of American commitment to the defense of Europe. Third, NATO is a proven force for peaceful integration and democratic development on the continent.
NATO has never been solely a military instrument; it has always served a political function as well. After World War II, the alliance helped Italy and Germany become part of the trans-Atlantic community. It promoted the consolidation of civilian-led democracy in Spain. It spurred reconciliation between France and Germany, laying the ground for the European Union. Its unified command removed the incentive for military competition among West European powers. It helped keep the peace between Greece and Turkey.
In the past, particularly in the 19th century, alliances not only served to wage or deter war, they also helped manage relations among their member states. Insofar as NATO follows in this tradition, the end of the cold war has actually buttressed its rationale -- and should make it easier for those who earlier regarded the alliance as a necessary but temporary evil to see it instead as a lasting good.
While retaining its military capacity and its core identity as a defense treaty, NATO can concentrate increasingly on its political function. Indeed, it can extend that mission to the former member states of the Warsaw Pact.
That consideration was in the President's mind when he faced the most difficult question: whether to enlarge the alliance. There were only two possible answers: yes or no. "Maybe," or "later but not now," would amount to "no," or at least would be taken that way by the Central Europeans.
There were several reasons why the answer had to be yes. Part of NATO's post-cold war mission is to open its doors to the new democracies that have regained their sovereignty. They aspire and deserve to be part of the trans-Atlantic community. All of Europe will be safer and more prosperous if these post-Communist lands continue to evolve toward civil society, market economics and harmonious relations with their neighbors.
The very prospect of NATO membership encourages those trends. In pursuit of their goal to join NATO, a number of Central European states have already accelerated their internal reforms and improved relations with each other.
Conversely, a decision not to enlarge NATO -- thus freezing a post-cold war NATO in its cold war configuration -- would send an unwelcome and unhelpful message to the Central Europeans. It would imply that they are consigned to a permanent buffer zone between East and West.
It would be the height of injustice and irony -- the ultimate in double jeopardy -- if these countries were, in effect, punished for the next 50 years because they had been, very much against the will of their people, part of the Warsaw Pact for the past 50. The resulting sense of isolation and vulnerability would be discouraging and potentially destabilizing.
We must, of course, face squarely the issue of Russia's opposition to NATO enlargement. But we should also recognize it for what it is -- an issue primarily of perception, of political sensitivities, not one of military reality.
The new NATO is not a threat to Russia, any more than a democratic Russia is a threat to the alliance. Enlargement has become a target of convenience for Russian fears and resentments rooted in uncertainties over Russia's post-Soviet identity and role in the world.
Many Russian reformers and democrats, along with some prominent Western experts, warn that enlargement will inflame nationalistic, anti-Western and militaristic forces in Russia.
This danger, while real, is exaggerated and manageable. Alarmism about NATO has more resonance within the Russian political elite than in the population at large. Polling indicates that the average Russian worries far more about domestic issues -- salaries, pensions and crime.
This is not to dismiss the importance of perceptions as a factor in politics and diplomacy. But those Russians who are currently lashing out against an anachronistic stereotype of NATO have it within their power to bring perceptions more into line with reality.
Instead of seeing enlargement as a blow to Russian pride and as a Western vote of no-confidence in Russia's future, they should accept it as part of a larger process of evolution from which Russia itself can and should benefit. After all, Russia, too, has an interest in a stable Central Europe. The Russian people came to grief twice in this century because of wars that originated in precisely that region.
An important part of NATO's opening to the East is its willingness to take account of Russia's legitimate political and security interests. Identifying common interests, common tasks and ways to deepen and broaden confidence-building between the alliance and Russia is a major goal not only of Secretary Albright's visit to Moscow this week but of President Clinton's scheduled summit meeting with President Boris Yeltsin in Helsinki next month.
Cooperation between NATO and Russia, of the sort now under way in the former Yugoslavia, provides a model for dealing with future Bosnias. American forces in Europe today do not spend their time preparing to fight Russian forces in Central Europe. Rather, they train for peacekeeping operations with NATO allies and other partners, including sometimes with the Russians themselves.
Today, at NATO headquarters in Brussels, there is a Russian liaison. We have suggested expanding these exchanges and including Russian officers at all the top levels of the alliance command structure. This kind of interaction with NATO can help the Russian military address its difficulties in trying to modernize.
Some have predicted that enlargement will increase the role of nuclear weapons in European security. The opposite should be true. With the end of the cold war, the alliance has already reduced the number of nuclear weapons in its arsenal by 90 percent. Moreover, if the alliance were not to enlarge, the consequent danger of renewed nationalism and military rivalry in Central Europe would carry with it the potential for nuclear-weapons proliferation.
NATO has already changed, profoundly, beneficially and lastingly. An important part of the new mission of the new NATO is to work with a new Russia in bringing about the transformation of Europe as a whole.

HEADLINE: Caribbean Seeks to Attract More Airlines

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 17

 BODY:
For the Caribbean islands that supply the kind of vacations that Americans crave in the winter, the threat of an American Airlines strike at the peak of the tourist season was a scary reminder that their reliance on one airline could prove as economically devastating as some hurricanes.
American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, controls roughly half of the market for air travel between the United States and the Caribbean. In some places, like San Juan, the concentration is even higher. 
 Moreover, the threat of the strike came at a time when tourism is growing in importance throughout the Caribbean to compensate for the erosion of manufacturing jobs resulting from increased competition under the North American Free Trade Agreement and, in Puerto Rico, the phasing out of tax exemptions for American companies. Tourism accounts for 7 percent of the economy in Puerto Rico, while the United States Virgin Islands and many other small islands rely on it more heavily or almost exclusively.
To try to protect this industry, which last year brought $13 billion to the region, Caribbean governments and tourism officials are taking steps to try to reduce their reliance on American Airlines.
Among the most aggressive efforts have been Puerto Rico's. In San Juan, American Airlines' Caribbean hub, the carrier and its American Eagle subsidiary control 70 percent of the air traffic and employ 2,500 workers. But as part of a strategy to double the economic impact of the tourism industry in the next 10 years, Puerto Rican government officials say they are identifying airlines and charter companies that would like to establish operations here, particularly to serve routes to Canada, South America and the Western and Midwestern United States.
"We're looking for new opportunities in terms of bringing in new airlines and developing new routes that would put us in contact with new markets and new investment," said Jorge L. Davila, Puerto Rico's tourism director.
In the last year, five new carriers have come to the Luis Munoz Marin International Airport here, including the new Pan Am, with flights to Miami and New York; KLM to the Netherlands and Aerolineas Argentinas to Buenos Aires. And officials are negotiating with 13 more. Puerto Rico has committed $360 million in airport expansion and renovations to increase air traffic capacity by 30 percent, port authority officials said. It has also increased hotel capacity, now at 11,200 rooms, by 40 percent in the last four years, Mr. Davila said.
Strikes are not the only concern in the push to diversify. Officials said market share dominance by one carrier also places passengers at the mercy of business decisions like American's move to use Miami as its Latin American hub. That means a flight between Sao Paulo, Brazil, and San Juan takes hours longer because of the need to connect in Miami, possibly deterring many potential visitors.
Efforts to attract more airlines are, of course, restricted by the realities of an industry that finds its best profits in hubs and by the small markets many of the Caribbean islands represent. American, in fact, rose to its current position by taking over the routes of Eastern Airlines, which dominated here until a strike crippled it and it went bankrupt in the late 1980's.
But Francisco Cimadevilla, Puerto Rico's deputy secretary of economic development and commerce, said that sometimes all it takes is aggressive promotion. "Sometimes you go into these board rooms and very knowledgeable, very worthy airline executives may have never taken a look at Puerto Rico," he said. He added that the aim was not to undercut American but to increase airport capacity.
In Puerto Rico, 26 airlines in addition to American operate at the Luis Munoz Marin airport, including major ones like Delta, TWA and USAir, but together they capture only 30 percent of the market. American carries the bulk of passengers, 5.2 million a year, and American Eagle another 1.2 million.
For smaller Caribbean islands with a tourist economy, American is a lifeline -- it controls 80 percent of the seats in nonstop flights from San Juan to other Caribbean islands and nearly half of the seats on nonstop routes from the United States to the Caribbean, according to BACK Associates Inc., a Stamford, Conn., aviation consulting firm.
Air Jamaica, American's closest competition for flights from the United States, controls only 10 percent of the seats to the Caribbean, the firm said. And on many of its Caribbean routes, American holds a monopoly, according to BACK.
These islands' lack of options is not unlike the situation faced by small cities in the United States that also feed into a hub. And tourism officials say that one alternative for the Caribbean is for a group of nine small carriers that serve the area to come together to reduce costs and expand routes. A 1993 study by the Caribbean Tourism Organization, a group based in Barbados that represents 33 member countries, found that those airlines could save about $64 million a year through joint marketing campaigns, fuel purchases and other points of cooperation.
"We're far too dependent on one carrier," said Jean Holder, secretary general of the organization.
The islands' exposure was underscored last Friday, the start of a holiday weekend during the busiest tourism season. Travelers who had planned trips on American were forced simply by the threat of the strike to rebook flights, often adding hundreds of dollars and many hours to their itineraries.
About 40 percent of 24 million visitors to the Caribbean in 1995 came in the winter months of January through April, the Caribbean Tourism Organization said, mostly from North America. With hotels at 80 or 90 percent occupancy, predictions of a catastrophe were heard throughout the archipelago.
"You should never allow yourself to be put in a position where problems with one carrier can have such an effect," said Wylie H. Whisonant, tourism commissioner for the United States Virgin Islands, which are just recovering from Hurricane Marilyn in 1995, a storm that destroyed or damaged most of the hotels in the region. "It really behooves us now to reach out to other carriers, to spread the risk."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
From Skipping Haircuts or Coffee, Some Find Unusual Means for Giving

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
At 66, Juergen R. Goldhagen has let his hair grow, tying it into a ponytail. At first it was for fun, to inject a spark of style, even some Samsonesque vigor, into his post-retirement life. But he soon recognized an added benefit: a year's savings on haircuts could be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help the poor.
Mr. Goldhagen, of Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., was one of the many donors who, by unusual measures or creative calculations, came up with ways to contribute to the fund, which helps seven of the city's oldest and largest charities extend a hand to those who need one. The fund's 85th annual appeal runs through the end of next week. 
 "I started to grow it as a lark," Mr. Goldhagen wrote in a letter accompanying his contribution. "But then I realized by saving on haircuts, I could pass those savings on to you. I used to get a haircut once a month and at $12 a haircut, plus a tip, I save $144 a year, so enclosed is my check for that amount. Whenever anyone asks about the ponytail, I tell them, 'It's for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.' "
In his letter, Mr. Goldhagen said he hoped that others might adopt such a method. "Who knows how much money you might end up getting," he wrote. But his strategy would not work for Alfred H. Lane, whose own method would suffer if he ever got hair in his eyes. Mr. Lane, 80, walks nearly everywhere he goes, always keeping his eyes peeled for spare change and stray dollar bills scattered on the ground.
"As I have done in the past, I am enclosing a check representing the amount of money I have found during this year on the streets and public places of (mainly) New York," Mr. Lane wrote in a letter with his $482.71 contribution. "Since the money was found in public areas, I would like it to be used to help those who have to live in public areas -- the homeless."
For Mr. Lane, who lives in Greenwich Village, walking is a hobby, his way of staying fit and having fun. And he is not alone in turning a hobby into a way to help the needy. "Every year the Pickwick Bridge Club has a 'charity' game when each player donates $1 to a selected charity," wrote Alice Silton, the club's president. "This year we decided to send the $130 to the Neediest Cases."
Ms. Silton, who lives in Purchase, N.Y., said in an interview that club members wanted to help a charity that benefited a broad range of people in need. The group, she said, recognized that the agencies supported by the Neediest Cases Fund have programs that help every type of needy New Yorker, including the homeless and the unemployed, the ill and disabled, children and the elderly. "We wanted something that would appeal to a lot of people," she said. "This covers everything."
Some contributors went without daily extras to give to the fund. "Although I've cut back on a lot this year," wrote Eleanor H. Watts, of Greenwich, Conn., "it seems that eliminating one 'coffee to go' a day -- or 10 indulgent lattes a month -- could benefit someone!" She sent a check for $30.
Other contributions were calculated on a somber note. "I am sending $24 for two reasons," wrote Anika Schwarzwald of Jersey City, N.J. "One, it is twice my age, and two, it is the age my sister was when she passed away last year from cancer. Last time I gave I sent $11, one for every year of my life, but this year I decided to raise the sum because it just feels good to give and know that you are helping someone."
John and Eleanor Fischer of Rockville Centre, L.I., also sent a gift in memoriam. "We send a contribution in honor of the 230 victims of T.W.A. Flight 800 who no longer have the opportunity to support this worthy cause," they wrote in a note accompanying a $230 donation.
 
HOW TO HELP

HEADLINE: China Leaders' Return to Beijing May Mean Deng Has Worsened

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials said today that they believed that the health of China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, had deteriorated significantly in recent days and was the reason for the sudden return to Beijing this weekend of several other top Chinese leaders.
Mr. Deng, who is 92 and has not been seen in public since he visited Shanghai in 1994, has often been reported to be on the verge of death in the last few years. 
 "This could be another one of the false warnings," said one senior American official who monitored internal Government reports about Mr. Deng's health during the weekend. "But there is clearly a lot of activity on the part of the leadership, and there is clearly a belief in Beijing that a bad situation has turned worse."
Another Administration official said, "Clearly he is very sick, but it's not clear how much sicker than the usual very sick."
For years officials in Washington have debated what impact the death of Mr. Deng, whose economic reforms remade China into one of the powerhouse economies of the world, may have on China's succession struggles and its dealings with the United States.
But Mr. Deng has survived for so long that many China watchers and policy makers here routinely say they now believe that the bulk of the transition of power has already taken place. If Mr. Deng dies in the coming months, they speculate, political events in Beijing can be frozen until the next Communist Party congress, in October.
The movements of China's other leaders have long been watched with care by American intelligence officials, because their travels may be the only reliable sign of a sharp deterioration in Mr. Deng's health.
So American officials took particular interest in intelligence reports and press accounts that President Jiang Zemin, who is also the chief of the Chinese Communist Party and the head of the army, abruptly returned to Beijing during a weekend trip to Jiangxi Province, in the center of the country.
At the same time, Prime Minister Li Peng also returned to Beijing hurriedly, cutting short a visit to Guangdong, the booming southern province closest to Hong Kong. The travel by the two leaders was first reported by Reuters.
In Paris today, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said at a news conference, "I've heard some reports from Beijing, but I can't corroborate anything." Other State Department officials said the intelligence reports were sketchy.
Rumors of Mr. Deng's impending death regularly shake the Hong Kong stock market, and on Friday the Hang Seng index fell nearly 1 percent after a newspaper there reported that Mr. Deng had suffered a stroke.
But American officials said they had no independent confirmation of that report, and today investors apparently reconsidered the potential impact that his death would have on the territory's return to Chinese control in four months. Today the Hong Kong market rose fractionally.

HEADLINE: G.M. Is Speaking Out on the Dollar and Other Issues

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Just four years ago, a senior General Motors executive from Detroit appalled a roomful of diplomats and trade negotiators at an embassy dinner in Washington by loudly arguing that the nation's capital did not really matter because it did not manufacture anything.
That attitude, once common at the nation's biggest company, is now fading quickly. As the auto maker builds new factories in Poland, Thailand and Argentina, and as the rising dollar has helped propel sales of foreign cars in America, the General Motors Corporation is becoming much more active on public policy issues. 
 Indeed, the dollar's ascent has underscored G.M.'s change of heart. This winter, G.M. executives were among the first to warn about the bruising effects of the dollar's rise on American manufacturers and to lead efforts to convince Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin that the dollar is too high in currency markets. A dozen years ago, when the dollar was also soaring, G.M. was one of the last big manufacturers to push for Government relief.
At the same time, Louis R. Hughes, the president of G.M.'s international operations, has become an outspoken critic of plans for a single European currency, because he fears it could initially squeeze profits and slow economic growth. The auto maker's Washington office has stepped up its lobbying on issues like global warming, because of worries that new controls could be placed on the worldwide auto industry. And G.M.'s board has just added two directors known for their outspoken but different views on international trade.
Even John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive and a businessman who remains visibly uncomfortable discussing public policy issues, now says that the company will inevitably take more public positions as it expands overseas. There is "no doubt that will happen," he said, pointing out that G.M. strongly favored the United States's renewal last year of China's most favored nation status.
One reason is that G.M. is rapidly expanding its operations in many Asian and Latin American markets where overcoming trade restrictions and winning Government approval for factories are often crucial for success. So G.M. has been turning to Washington for the same support that foreign auto makers have long sought from their home governments.
It is impossible for G.M. to run its worldwide operations "without assuming some responsibility for being a well-informed participant in public policy debates and issues," said Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman.
Current and former G.M. executives cite several other reasons the auto maker is no longer the corporate wallflower on policy issues that it used to be. One simple reason is that G.M. has recovered from its management crisis in the early 1990's, so its executives have more time to spend on longer-term issues.
Another reason is that G.M.'s public policy decision making has shifted away from the financial staff in New York City, where a laissez-faire ethos has long been strong. Decisions are increasingly being made instead in Detroit by Mr. Pearce, a lawyer who made his reputation handling product liability issues in Washington and in courtrooms around the country.
During the mid-1980's, the ambivalence of the New York operations on dollar policy created tensions within G.M. "Back in those days, some of the operating people felt we should have been more vocal than we were," Lloyd E. Reuss, G.M.'s retired president, said.
Marina Whitman, the vice president and group executive for public affairs during much of the 1980's, said that G.M. had lobbied the Reagan Administration vigorously for a weaker dollar after Caterpillar Inc. had begun doing so. But she added, "We may have been a little slow -- I think with 20/20 hindsight, if I had to do it all over again, we might have waded in sooner."
The question now is whether G.M.'s next step will be to seek any restrictions on auto imports. Any such move would break a long corporate tradition of support for free trade.
In the late 1970's, G.M. declined to participate in an attempt by the Ford Motor Company to win protection from Japanese imports, effectively dooming the effort. As recently as February 1993, G.M. pulled out of lawsuit preparations by Ford and the Chrysler Corporation, which wanted billions of dollars in tariffs imposed on Japanese cars allegedly being dumped at unfairly low prices in the United States. Because of G.M.'s action, the lawsuit was never filed.
G.M. has just added two directors with very different views on trade. One of the new directors, George M. C. Fisher, the chairman, chief executive and president of the Eastman Kodak Company, has made repeated use of unilateral American trade laws in trying to break open the Japanese market and restrict the sale of supposedly underpriced Japanese goods in the United States.
While cautioning that he was still learning about the auto industry and had not joined G.M.'s board to be a trade specialist, Mr. Fisher said that he saw some parallels between trade issues facing Kodak and G.M. He contended that the Japanese film market is sufficiently closed to foreign companies that producers there can collect high profits and use the money to buy market share elsewhere.
"A lot of the same arguments apply to the auto business," he said in his first interview after being named to the G.M. board.
Percy Barnevik, the chairman and chief executive of ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., a Zurich-based engineering giant, was also recently named to the G.M. board and is outspoken on trade policy, but with a different emphasis. Having spent his career as a businessman in Switzerland and Sweden, countries with small markets and little ability to threaten trade sanctions, he has strongly supported international limits on unilateral trade laws.
