HEADLINE: Labor Dares Republicans To Cut Its Political Clout

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17

 BODY:
John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, issued a defiant "make my day" declaration today to Republicans in Congress who want revenge on the labor movement for its pull-out-the-stops drive to defeat them in last fall's elections.
"We're going to resist and oppose any efforts that are made toward recriminations for any of the good work we did last year," Mr. Sweeney said at a news conference on the first day of the federation's winter meeting here. "If there is going to be any attempt at retribution, we'll be as out front as we have been on any other issue." 
 The A.F.L.-C.I.O. spent $25 million on its anti-Republican broadcast spots last year, in what many union leaders call their biggest campaign effort ever. Seething Republicans are talking about curbing labor unions' independent spending on elections. Several Republicans have proposed legislation that could cripple such spending by forbidding unions to use a member's dues on campaigns unless he or she had signed an authorization card.
Since the party increased its majority in the Senate and maintained control of the House in the face of the labor effort, some Republican supporters say punishment is sure.
"As is often said, when you set out to kill the king, you better succeed, and they didn't, so they had better watch out," said Paul Huard, chief lobbyist for the National Association of Manufacturers.
But A.F.L.-C.I.O. lobbyists say they are not alarmed, because numerous Republican moderates, shaken by last fall's assault, have told union leaders they intend to remain close to labor.
"They're trying to posture themselves as worker-friendly," said Peggy Taylor, the A.F.L.-C.I.O's chief lobbyist, noting that this could prevent Republican leaders from mustering a majority on anti-labor measures.
"We won't just be playing defense," she added. "There'll definitely be some offense from us."
Labor unions have a long wish list. They hope they can focus on a few issues with such widespread public support that Republicans would block the issues at their peril. Union officials point to what happened last year with labor's campaign for a higher minimum wage: The public backed it so overwhelmingly that Republicans were pushed into approving it.
Dennis Rivera, president of 1199 National Health and Human Service Employees Union, said he hopes one subject that will catch fire in the same way is labor's pet proposal to extend health coverage to the 10 million American children without medical insurance.
Douglas H. Dority, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers, wants labor to go even further this year and push for universal health coverage. "We have a situation where more and more employers are simply cutting off employer-paid health coverage to employees."
Another issue that union officials say could gain momentum would be requiring all employers to provide pensions, even small ones, to all workers. A.F.L.-C.I.O. lobbyists also say they will push for laws to insure that health maintenance organizations provide quality care.
"We want to find a way to get at financial incentives that discourage doctors from providing quality care," said Ms. Taylor.
She said the federation also backs proposals to take Federal money that labor unions say subsidizes the transfer of jobs overseas and use it to build or modernize schools. "A lot of schools are crumbling and are not wired for the Internet," she said. "Teachers like this idea. Parents like it. Construction workers like it. Telecommunications people like it."
A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials said they would support President Clinton's proposals to expand the family leave act, broaden child-care coverage and provide tax credits and deductions to go to college. The federation is asking locals to send letters opposing the Republican drive to add an amendment to the Constitution requiring a balanced budget; it is also planning a campaign against replacing Social Security with a private system.
The executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is refining its legislative agenda as part of a four-day meeting whose main theme is focusing the federation's energies on recruitment. The percentage of the unionized work force has been shrinking for decades, and Mr. Sweeney has vowed to concentrate on organizing to keep labor from sliding into irrelevancy.
He said workers need "a bigger and stronger labor movement, one capable of acting as a counterweight to the corporate forces now dominating our economy."
Mr. Huard, the manufacturers' lobbyist, doubted that labor would be able to take the offensive this year. "My guess is they'll pretty much be reduced to the fire brigade stuff, rushing to stop things they don't like," he said.
Labor's lobbyists are already rushing to stop two Republican proposals. One would make it easier for employers to set up groups of workers to cooperate with management. Labor says this measure will create employer-dominated worker representation, but managers say this proposal will merely foster cooperation to build more efficient companies.
The other proposal would let workers take compensatory time rather than overtime pay. Republicans call this a worker-friendly measure designed to give employees more flexibility, but labor leaders say it is a back-door attempt to force workers to take compensatory time instead of overtime pay when managers know that many workers intent on getting ahead will never take the time off.
Mr. Sweeney said, "We are not about to stand on the sidelines and see labor protections broken down under the guise of flex time or comp time."

HEADLINE: Allied Friction in Korea

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Two critical developments in the last week have once again increased the tensions between North and South Korea. But the events also threaten to deepen the friction between two longtime allies -- South Korea and the United States.
The issue is whether efforts to make peace with and provide aid to economically desperate North Korea will be delayed or halted after the request by a high-ranking North Korean official for asylum in the South and the shooting of another North Korean defector in Seoul, possibly by North Korean agents. 
 While publicly in agreement on how to deal with North Korea, Washington and Seoul have for three years been squabbling under the surface. At times it has seemed that United States relations with South Korea were worse than with North Korea.
In the last few years, the United States has been seeking to engage North Korea, to end its isolation and reduce the risk of a war.
South Korean leaders take the position that it is naive of the United States to try to appease a Communist Government that they say cannot be trusted. The South Koreans also say they believe that Pyongyang's economic woes provide leverage to drive a harder bargain.
Seoul has gone along with Washington's ideas -- like proposed peace talks involving the two Koreas, China and the United States -- but often only reluctantly.
This divergence of views is likely to surface again in the days following the defection and the shooting. It is sure to be on the agenda when Madeleine K. Albright, the new Secretary of State, arrives here on Saturday on a previously scheduled visit.
The United States is hoping that the defection and the shooting will not interfere with efforts to hold the four-party peace talks, and to provide food aid and nuclear reactors to North Korea in an effort to suppress nuclear weapons development there.
But in South Korea, North Korea's actions can provoke such fierce emotions that building a relationship becomes impossible. After North Koreans entered South Korea from a grounded submarine in September, the South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, whipped up an anti-Communist frenzy, and all efforts at better relations were frozen until North Korea apologized.
North Korea, too, to be sure, also balks at reconciliation when it suffers a blow, like the defection on Wednesday of Hwang Jang Yop, the architect of Pyongyang's ideology of juche, or self-reliance.
So far, South Korean officials have taken a moderate stance in the new crisis. Although they have blamed North Korea for the attempted assassination of Lee Han Young, a defector who is being kept alive by a respirator even though his brain has ceased to function, they have not demanded an apology. That could be because the gunmen have not been caught and the police concede that there is at least an outside chance that Mr. Lee, who was known as a womanizer and who was deeply in debt, might have had other enemies who wanted to kill him.
South Korea's Foreign Minister, Yoo Chong Ha, said today that the South would continue to support peace talks to formally end the Korean War. The Hwang defection, he said in a speech at an annual meeting of South Korean diplomats, is just one of many crises that will occur as North Korea continues to deteriorate politically and economically.
"Under these circumstances, the most pressing task is to establish peace on the Korean peninsula," he said.
Still, South Korean officials say some steps, like the announcement of new relief programs for North Korea, will probably be delayed until the air clears.
And, a Foreign Ministry official said, "if something more happens, the Government may have to change the policy regarding the light-water reactors." He was referring to the nuclear plants that will be provided to North Korea in exchange for its dropping the nuclear weapons development program it is suspected of having.
Moreover, fear of North Korea is being kindled here by articles appearing in newspapers about letters that Mr. Hwang wrote or remarks he made in the months before he defected.
He is said to have told someone, for instance, that there are 50,000 North Korean agents in South Korea, including some highly placed in the Government. In one letter, he is said to have written that the North's "fundamental policy is national reunification through the invasion of South Korea" and that it "has no intention of dialogue."
It is unclear whether the statements are all genuine, although some knowledgeable observers think the letters, at least, are real, and were probably leaked by South Korean intelligence officials.
The difference in approach to North Korea between Washington and Seoul stems in part from different internal politics.
Washington favors engagement and aid to prevent a cornered Government from staging an attack on the South in a moment of desperation. Even though North Korea, short of fuel for planes and tanks and spare parts for its weapons, would lose a war, it could extract a heavy toll on the 37,000 American troops protecting the South.
Seoul, too, is officially committed to helping North Korea enough to bring about a so-called soft landing, rather than a sudden collapse that would bring millions of refugees streaming south and jeopardize the increasingly prosperous living conditions in the South.
But that is the policy of the mind. In their hearts, many South Koreans, including Government officials, would love nothing better than for the enemy that has insulted them for more than 40 years to come crashing down -- and the sooner the better.
Perhaps an even bigger reason for South Korea's reluctance is that it thinks that North Korea is trying to drive a wedge between Washington and Seoul. American officials agree that Pyongyang wants to do that, though they insist that the United States would never sell its ally down the river.
Many steps, such as the 1994 nuclear agreement and recent efforts to arrange a briefing on four-party peace talks, are negotiated by North Korea and the United States, with South Korea not present. To satisfy South Korea, which will pay most of the $5 billion cost of the reactors, the nuclear agreement includes a stipulation that North Korea engage in dialogue with the South. But so far, there has been no such dialogue.
The South Korean Government might also have domestic reasons to fan the anti-North flames this time. Both the Hwang defection and Lee shooting have diverted attention from an embarrassing corruption scandal that has already resulted in the arrests of some of President Kim's close associates.
The new crisis also comes as the National Assembly begins a special session at which it will discuss legislation governing the Agency for National Security Planning, the nation's spycatcher.
President Kim's New Korea Party rammed through a new law in December giving the agency expanded powers. Opponents, saying the agency has often engaged in political repression, hope to repeal or revise the law. But the image of North Korean agents with pistols on the loose will make any weakening of the law more difficult.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Abe or Not, Few Give 2 Cents for 1

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
A PENNY lay on the floor by the cash register at Barney Greengrass, the temple to smoked fish on Amsterdam Avenue. "See that penny?" said Gary Greengrass, the latest member of his family to become a loxsmith. "Nobody's bothered to pick it up."
Nobody included Mr. Greengrass, who has as much use for a 1-cent coin as he has for a two-holed bagel. "Some people won't even take it as change," he said. "They don't want anything to do with it. Sometimes, I'll take less from customers, too, so I don't have to be bothered with it." 
 His opinion is common in New York, a place where pitching pennies at the stoop was once part of the landscape. Now, the penny commands even less respect than Rodney Dangerfield. And that raises a question, though it may seem terribly ungallant coming on the heels of Presidents' Day: Might it not be time to do away with those millions of zinc-and-copper likenesses of Abraham Lincoln dotting New York sidewalks uncollected and lining sock drawers untouched?
This is an issue that turns up every once in a while like a bad you-know-what, but goes nowhere. Nonetheless, dumping this almost useless coin -- and rounding off business transactions to the nearest nickel -- is a thought for your pennies that is not likely to go away.
"This coin's days are numbered" is how Representative Michael N. Castle, a Delaware Republican, put it several months ago. Mr. Castle, chairman of the House subcommittee that deals with monetary matters, said he had no idea what that number might be. But he predicted a time when "it will no longer make practical or economic sense to continue producing a coin that does not circulate and whose costs outweigh its benefits."
NEW YORK, one could argue, is particularly ill suited for the penny, a hardy survivor that has carried Lincoln's image since 1909. There is the obvious fact that you can buy nothing with it, unless you know of a candy store that still sells those tiny Tootsie Rolls for 1 cent. But beyond that, the penny can be a source of stress in a city that hardly needs it.
"It's annoying in these places where you have to have the 3 cents, and you don't have it," said Bob Morton, owner of Coin Dealer on West 47th Street. "So you give them another dollar. Now you're carrying around 97 cents."
Did you ever stand at the checkout line of a New York supermarket while a customer fumbled for 2 cents? Not exactly models of patience, those waiting their turn.
You may think 1-cent coins are legal tender, but try getting on a bus with them. "No pennies," fare-box signs say bluntly. The subway is slightly more accommodating. Signs at token booths advise to "avoid using pennies," suggesting that you may use them if you wish. But plunk down 150 pennies during rush hour and let us know if you make it out alive.
In a New York restaurant, leaving pennies for a tip is a sure way to insult the waiter. In food stores, owners "see the penny as a pain," said Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist who represents many of the city's small supermarkets. "It costs them money to process the coins, although there are some benefits," he said. "You can price something at $9.99 instead of $10."
BEGGARS, too, can be choosers in this city. "It's humbler than the poorest of the poor," said Theodore Faro Gross, a writer in Manhattan. "I've seen panhandlers frown on it. I feel apologetic when I accidentally put a penny in a panhandler's hand."
Still, all is not lost for the coin. Mr. Gross has proved that. Seven years ago he founded Common Cents, which collects pennies that schoolchildren have scoured from their apartments and gives the money to community groups. Though still tallying his last annual "harvest" in November, he expects to end up with more than $150,000.
In Washington, an advocacy group with a similar name, Americans for Common Cents, carries the torch for the penny. Mark Weller, the executive director, cites polls showing that Americans see no compelling reason to do away with a coin that is "so embroidered in the social and economic fabric of the country."
O.K., don't expect the penny to be banished any time soon. That much is acknowledged even by an abolitionist like Beth Deisher, who is editor of Coin World, a magazine for collectors published in Ohio.
When she last visited New York, Ms. Deisher said, "I saw pennies in the gutter for block after block." That's how little valued the coin was.
But at the same time, she said, "Americans are quite conservative when it comes to change." No pun intended, she added.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
In terms of managing mutual funds, must youth be served?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
AS the stock market has soared during the last several years, it has often seemed as if the manager of the latest hot mutual fund is barely out of college. Is that a coincidence? Or is youth an advantage when it comes to running money?
The answer, according to a new study published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, appears to be that it is not a coincidence. "We find that younger managers can earn much higher returns than older managers," write Judith Chevalier and Glenn Ellison. 
 Their study, based on performance of growth and growth and income equity mutual funds from 1988 through 1994, concluded that the younger the manager, the better the performance.
"When we control for everything," said Mr. Ellison, an associate professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "we get about three basis points per year." In other words, a 29-year-old manager would be expected, on average, to show a return about three-hundredths of 1 percentage point higher than that of a 30-year-old. And that 30-year-old would do about half a percentage point better than a 48-year-old.
The instinctive reaction of many an older manager, particularly in this bull market, is that such performance may have something to do with risk. Younger managers, having never seen a bear market, may be more likely to swing for the fences. For most of the period covered in the study, that was a very good strategy.
But Mr. Ellison, who is 31, and Ms. Chevalier, a 29-year-old assistant professor of economics at the University of Chicago's business school, say that they have tried to control for such risk taking, and that risk does not appear to explain the phenomenon. In fact, they say, it appears that older managers are more likely to be "momentum" investors, that is, to buy stocks largely because they are going up.
What may explain the difference, at least in part, is that the study also indicates that younger managers with poor performance are more likely to be dismissed than are older managers who do poorly. That could create a selection bias in which poorer young managers are weeded out, leaving only better ones to make it look as if young is better. But the authors say they have adjusted for that, too, and that without that adjustment the advantage of youth appears to be even greater.
It would be interesting to know what the study would have shown in 1987, when managers who took a lot of risk were severely penalized by the crash. But the data for the study came from Morningstar Inc., which was not reporting on the age of managers back then. In fact, it still does not, but it does report on the academic degrees earned by each manager. The authors estimated ages by assuming that the managers were awarded bachelor's degrees when they were about 22.
Using the data on college graduation also let the authors check to see if it matters where a manager went to college. And, they say, it does. They measure the quality of a school by using the average score of its entering freshmen on the Scholastic Assessment Test, or S.A.T., on which scores range from 400 to 1,600 points. They conclude that a manager who attended Princeton (average S.A.T. of 1,355) would be likely to outperform one from the University of Florida (average of 1,145) by about one percentage point a year.
Assuming that is true, they note that it could be explained either by a better education at the elite universities or by a higher quality of entering students. Mr. Ellison, by the way, attended Harvard, while Ms. Chevalier is a Yale graduate.
Will young people from the best schools continue to be the best managers when the market turns down, if it ever does? That is one question this study does not answer.

HEADLINE: Racial Killing Bursts a British Press Taboo

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Stephen Lawrence, 18, a promising high school student of Jamaican parentage, was stabbed to death by a group of white youths cursing him with shouts of "nigger" as he waited for a ride home at a southeast London bus stop on an April night nearly four years ago.
The notorious case, in which five haughty youths with a history of white supremacist agitation have been implicated but never convicted, set off vigils against racism and a series of investigations that proved naggingly inconclusive. 
 Now the case has burst back into public attention, provoking a new outcry about police competence and sensitivity in racial crimes, the rights of defendants to be presumed innocent and the responsibilities of the press.
Last week all five men were summoned to a reopened coroner's jury investigation into the killing, and they invoked their common-law privilege of remaining silent, refusing with defiant chuckles and winks to acknowledge even their names. Then they marched out of the quaint Victorian courthouse amid the dreary tenement blocks of Southwark and sped away in two sedans with three women companions.
After their appearance, the jury returned a verdict of "unlawful killing," saying that Mr. Lawrence had died "in a completely unprovoked racist attack by five white youths."
The jury supplied no names, but the next morning the tabloid Daily Mail did. The newspaper devoted its front page to head shots and identifications of the five white men beneath the underscored headline "Murderers" and a challenge in bold letters: "The Mail accuses these men of killing. If we are wrong, let them sue us."
The tabloid's publication of murder accusations against unconvicted people was strikingly audacious in a country where the press is generally inhibited by official secrecy and libel laws that afford suspects greater protection than in the United States.
"What happened to Stephen Lawrence is a vile and wicked killing carried out by evil racists," said Nigel Pascoe, chairman of the Bar Council's public affairs committee. But he added that "it is not for the press to act as judge and jury."
A number of judges have denounced the newspaper's action, and a spokesman for the Attorney General's office said today that it was exploring a formal contempt of law charge.
Over the weekend, Britain's Channel 4 television station added to the furor by broadcasting a film recorded by a secretly placed Metropolitan Police camera showing one of the five men, Neil Acourt, 21, telling the others that black men should be skinned, dismembered and set on fire.
He then demonstrated a knife attack, in a way that bore a chilling resemblance to how Mr. Lawrence was murdered. Asked at one point by another member of the gang if the killers of Mr. Lawrence weren't "laughing" now, Mr. Acourt smiled knowingly and said, "They are definitely doing that, mate."
The victim's family says it now plans to bring civil proceedings against the men, citing the latest O. J. Simpson trial in California as precedent.
As in the United States, the burden of proof would be less than in a criminal case, dependent upon only "a balance of probabilities" rather than proof "beyond reasonable doubt." British law does not permit a civil case of murder so the most severe charge available to the Lawrences would be assault and battery.
All five men accused are unemployed and have no resources, and so no money damages would ever be recovered even if they were found liable for Mr. Lawrence's death.
But the family feels it is the only way to gain any satisfaction from a police and judicial system it argues is stacked against nonwhite victims. "The value that this white racist country puts on black lives is evident to see since the killing of my son," Doreen Lawrence, the young man's mother, told the coroner's inquest last week.
The inquest, which took only 30 minutes to return its verdict, provided little solace to the family and others anxious to see justice done.
Its decision was seen as symbolizing the widely perceived failure of the police and the courts to assemble evidence against five young men, who come from a racially troubled neighborhood.
In Eltham, a predominantly white middle-class neighborhood of brick semi-detached homes where the five men live and where the killing took place, the few black and Asian families have complained of racial harassment. The Asian merchants who run the newstands and candy stores in the area routinely scrub racist graffiti off their storefronts and say they are regularly taunted by young residents. Mrs. Lawrence said that a week after the killing, a white neighbor verbally accosted her in a parking lot, saying that her son would be still be alive if she had not come to this country in the first place.
Murder charges against two of the five men were dismissed in 1993. The other three were acquitted in a trial a year ago. In both cases, the police said they had found no one willing to testify, only what one high-ranking officer called a "sea of rumor."
Mrs. Lawrence, a teacher, and her husband, Neville, a plasterer and decorator, came to Britain from Jamaica in 1962 and live in Woolwich, a neighborhood with one other black family. A second son now goes to university, and Stephen, a high school senior with a record of academic honors, was planning to go to college to study architecture.
On April 22, 1993, at 10:30 P.M., Mr. Lawrence and a friend, Duwayne Brooks, also 18, were waiting for a bus home to Woolwich when they were set upon by five white men. Mr. Lawrence was stabbed in the chest and the arm and succeeded in running 130 yards before he fell. The attackers ran away, and Mr. Brooks hailed a passing off-duty policeman who summoned an ambulance. Mr. Lawrence died at the hospital from hemorrhaging.
In the hours after the crime, the police collected forensic evidence and searched for weapons but did not make any effort to locate witnesses among the large number of passing motorists, bus passengers and residents who might have seen the incident. The Lawrence family claims that the police were more interested in establishing whether their son was a member of a gang than who his killers might be. On her first visit to the precinct house, Mrs. Lawrence said she gave an officer a list of names of suspects and the officer crumpled it dismissively into a ball.
"My son was stereotyped by the police," Mrs. Lawrence told the inquest.
"He was black, then he must be a criminal, and they set about to investigate him and us. Their investigation lasted two weeks, and that allowed vital evidence to be lost."
Later the police found that potential witnesses were unwilling to speak for attribution, saying they feared retaliation. The Southwark coroner, Sir Montague Levine, characterized the community response this week as "a wall of silence and fear."
Two months after the crime, the police charged Neil Acourt's brother Jamie, 19, and David Norris, 20, with murder, but the inability to persuade any witnesses to testify caused the court to dismiss the charges a month later.
In frustration, the family resorted to an approach used only three times before this century, sponsoring a private investigation that led to murder charges against Neil Acourt, Luke Knight, 20, and Gary Dobson, 21. The principal witness was Duwayne Brooks, who had picked the three out of police lineups.
But it emerged in court that Mr. Brooks had never clearly seen their faces the night of attack and that he had heard rumors of the involvement of the three before he was asked to view the lineups. The judge ruled that his testimony was consequently "contaminated and flawed." All three men were acquitted.
The police have resisted criticism of their conduct of the case.
"The suggestion that any police officer would investigate a murder less competently because the victim was black is an absolute disgrace," said David Osland, the former deputy assistant police commissioner who was in charge of the investigation.
Sir Herman Ouseley, the chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality, is unconvinced.
"This case has added to the sense of mistrust that many in the ethnic minority communities have about the police and the criminal justice system," he said.
Leaders of civil rights groups greeted the action of The Daily Mail warily since the newspaper traditionally has paid little attention to minority communities and had accused civil rights advocates of having "hijacked" the Lawrence killing for their own purposes.
But one official, Trevor Phillips, chairman of the Runnymede Trust, an independent research group on race issues, said he hoped the assistance from an unexpected quarter like The Mail meant that the case was having wider repercussions.
"It gives me hope that unlike America, where two completely different nations live inside one border, it is at least possible for Middle Britain to understand Black Britain's pain and in some way identify with it," he said.

HEADLINE: Where Electronic Money Talks as Fast as It Moves;
Secaucus Corridor Emerges as Nerve Center In the Melding of Computers and Capitalism

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SECAUCUS, N.J., Feb. 17

 BODY:
You can't see it, feel it, smell it, stack it or hoard it in a vault. You can't use it to light a cigar or stuff a mattress. There are no coins to flip or to jingle.
It's electronic money, currency of the millennium, and this corner of northeast New Jersey, through a melding of capitalism, computers and quirks of fate, is emerging as a nerve center. 
 Quietly, this cluster of New Jersey towns just west of the Lincoln Tunnel has become a world hub in the lightning-speed business of switching money from one account to another.
If your checking account is programmed to make your mortgage payment or pay your health club dues, this corner of New Jersey, no matter where in the country you live, is probably where the transaction occurs. If you buy something with an A.T.M. card, the odds are great that part of the approval process will pass through the corridor. If you bank from home, the bank's home page may well have been generated here.
Since the early 1990's, the Secaucus corridor has emerged as a national center for automated teller networks. Four processors, including the NYCE Corporation in Secaucus, are within a few square miles of one another. It has become the national capital of preprogrammed transfers like automatic payroll deposits, which are processed through the New York Clearing House Association and the Federal Reserve processing center in East Rutherford.
When the Fed completes the consolidation of its $1.4 trillion-a-day national interbank transfer system, Fedwire, in March 1998, the area's national presence will rise further still, enough to rival New York City for the first time in the volume of money moved.
"It's not just a New York City market any more," said Elliott McEntee, the president and chief executive officer of the National Automated Clearinghouse Association, a Virginia trade group owned by the banking industry. "New Jersey has become a very integral part of the nation's financial system, and hardly anybody knows it."
For the New York regional economy, that represents a subtle but profound shift in the huge business of money changing, and perhaps suggests as well the emergence of a new kind of disembodied techno-money center utterly unlike New York, or any place else.
There is no monolithic architecture to inspire awe or trust or to proclaim a presence. Like the technology itself, which combines telecommunications, data processing and financial services, the atmosphere of these money-shifting centers is based on what works. At the NYCE control room, utilitarian short-weave carpet covers hollow floors, beneath which cables snake. The lights are dimmed to preclude glare against the banks of monitors.
Where there is no customer contact except through the digital Web, anonymity becomes its own security-conscious virtue. For the 3,000 or so people who work in the corridor, money has been distilled to its essence: the realm of pure numbers.
Yet there are still some human echoes measurable through the electronic flutter.
One can be witnessed every night, like a recurring fever: between 2 and 4 A.M., the percentage of people who try and fail to extract money from automated teller machines -- because they have insufficient cash in their accounts -- inches up.
The shift is small, 1 percent from the average approval rate of 90 percent, said Joseph T. Buscemi, the director of operations at NYCE, the East Coast's largest automated teller network. But given the huge volume of A.T.M. transactions, even a tiny increase in rejections is enough for a country-music jukebox worth of desperation: no money, middle of the night, New Jersey.
The Secaucus cash corridor is partly an intentional secret. The New York Clearinghouse Association, founded in New York in 1853 to handle interbank account settlements, processes $10 billion every day in electronic money. Don't ask where. For security reasons, the company has no address or telephone listing.
Citibank processes 16 million A.T.M. transfers a month nearby, all of its national business, but officials asked that the location not be printed because of security concerns. "We don't want anybody to find us," said Jill M. Considine, the clearinghouse association's president and chief executive officer.
A cultural shift is evident in that kind of talk. If this is indeed an emerging center of postmodern money, it will have its own style. Old money capitals graced themselves with symbols of power, stability and might. But where cash is merely a few flashing lines on a computer screen, edifice is irrelevant.
Dependability is measured by the quality of encryption codes and backup generators and the infrequency of bugs and crashes. The hallmark of success is invisibility.
A.T.M. network employees are not bankers. There are software writers and database analysts who work on how to insert new applications and clients into the network, and telecommunication analysts who are like firefighters, ready to jump when a phone line breaks or a processor goes down. Employees say their work is divided between keeping the transaction flow unbroken and adding to that flow with new services.
"A good day here is a very boring day," said Mr. Buscemi, who ran A.T.M.'s for Citibank before going to NYCE.
The self-deprecation belies growing influence. The Secaucus corridor now handles 85 to 90 percent of the entire national traffic in routine automatic monthly consumer payments and credit, totaling three billion transactions a year.
The corridor is one of four concentrations of A.T.M. processing clusters in the country -- tied with Cincinnati and Delaware behind only Milwaukee -- in national A.T.M. traffic volume, with more than 150 million transactions a month, according to Bank Network News, a trade publication. Elsewhere, processing centers -- banks, networks and data companies -- are more dispersed.
In addition to NYCE, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation runs A.T.M.'s across the country from its center in Rochelle Park, N.J. Citibank and Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, run their entire electronic funds transfer businesses from the Meadowlands area.
It is also an emerging center for electronic authorizations of purchases using A.T.M. cards, known as debit transactions, in which the money is taken directly from the buyer's checking or savings account at the point of sale. The computers at E.D.S. are connected to more than 700 other computing centers, banks, and merchants around the country. As debit purchases grow in number, network traffic will also grow.
The corridor will soon approach New York, the world capital of money flow, in total dollar transactions. Experts estimate that the Secaucus corridor moves more than $600 billion a day in electronic funds. New York easily moves more than $2 trillion every day, mostly in the international transfer business, Wall Street securities transfers and the Federal Reserve's Fedwire.
By spring 1998, when Fedwire, one of the 900-pound gorillas of the digital money business, moves to New Jersey, that balance will tip. The Secaucus corridor's daily total will pass $1 trillion, while New York will slip to $1.5 trillion or less. The decision-making power of most financial institutions remains in New York. What has shifted is the electronic nexus.
How Secaucus found its groove is partly happenstance. When the New York Clearinghouse Association first came to New Jersey in the 1980's, the constraints of computer technology dictated that two mainframe computers operating on what is called a live backup system -- both processing the same information at the same time -- could be no more than five miles apart without a time lag.
New Jersey made sense because it was on a different power grid and telephone system -- both important data processing safeguards -- but also because the emerging technology of money transfer was based on telecommunications. That has long been one of the state's strengths, because of the presence of AT&T, the state's largest private employer and a longtime fount of industrial skills.
By the time E.D.S. came to the Secaucus area in 1989 with the purchase of the ADP Corporation's A.T.M. business, those labor concerns had become paramount. The new owners decided to stay because the skills were here.
NYCE built its first processing center in the early 1990's, during a recession. Space was cheap. The company, owned by a consortium of banks, most based in New York, looked at a map and decided to stay.
The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, was cutting costs, consolidating its operations into just three national processing centers: Dallas, Richmond and East Rutherford.
The resulting cluster of businesses and institutions is like an awkward, uncertain teen-ager. NYCE has nearly tripled its New Jersey work force during the last five years, to 120 employees from 45. But because the banks that own it are so close, and in the same line of work, the company has had to reach out beyond the region for talent.
Industry analysts also say that while the forces that created a New Jersey money center are growing in power, they are also evolving so rapidly that the outcome is unknown. Americans are using A.T.M.'s more all the time, with younger generations leading the charge. That means at least short-term growth.
"My parents would never dream of using an A.T.M., but my children would never dream of stepping inside a branch," said Lawrence W. Cohn, a banking analyst at PaineWebber Inc.
But Mr. Cohn said bank network technology also allows greater volume of traffic with fewer workers, and that with better communication links, proximity to New York becomes less relevant.
"The short run has got to be good," Mr. Cohn said. "The long run is not as clear."

HEADLINE: 5 Admit Roles With Mafia In a Trash Hauling Cartel

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
On the eve of a major racketeering trial, five more defendants have pleaded guilty to state charges that they joined what prosecutors call a Mafia cartel that controlled New York City's billion-dollar-a-year private garbage collection industry.
In plea negotiations for reduced sentences, the defendants, all owners of garbage carting and recycling companies, admitted using "economic retaliation against those who broke the cartel's rules." Another carting executive pleaded guilty to a lesser felony charge that he violated the state's antitrust laws, without admitting a role in the cartel. 
 The six guilty pleas last Thursday whittled the ranks of the defendants to 8 from an original list of 17 owners of carting companies and officials of trade associations.
By pleading guilty to the cartel charges, the five executives now face prison terms ranging from one to four and a half years when sentenced on April 17. But a defense lawyer said some of them could be released after only two months to work programs during the day and incarceration at night in halfway houses.
With the owners of several major carting companies now out of the picture, the focus of the trial, which is to begin today, shifts mainly to three reputed mobsters -- Joseph Francolino, Alphonse Malangone and Frank Giovinco -- who are accused of being the Mafia's garbage industry managers.
Prosecutors have said Mr. Francolino is a captain in the Gambino crime family, Mr. Malangone a captain in the Genovese family and Mr. Giovinco a Genovese family soldier, or member. The men were top officials in three trade associations that prosecutors asserted were used to allocate customers and exact payoffs from independent carters who competed with cartel members.
Lawyers for the three men have denied that they are mobsters. Ronald Fischetti, a lawyer for Mr. Francolino, said the pleas would help his defense because "he will not be thrown in the same pot with 16 others."
Jury selection for the remaining eight defendants is to start today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan before Acting Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder.
Those charged in the case were accused of fixing prices and rigging bids to get the major share of $1.5 billion a year in fees for removing and recycling refuse in New York City. Several of the defendants were also charged with arson and violence in a scheme that prosecutors said inflated trash collection costs for virtually every office building, store, restaurant and private hospital and school in the city.
According to District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan, the cartel operated for 40 years, and in 1995, overcharged customers by about $400 million.
In the aftermath of the indictments, the city created a commission to regulate garbage haulers, and three national carting companies that previously shunned New York began competing for business in the city. Industry experts say the increased competition and the role of the watchdog commission have led to sharp price drops for customers, including an annual $1 million cut at an office tower in lower Manhattan.
On Thursday, after admitting that the cartel flourished for years, the five executives each pleaded guilty to a single felony count of attempted enterprise corruption. They, along with the other defendants in the case, had been indicted on more serious charges of violating the state's Organized Crime Control Act. The act sets a maximum prison sentence of 25 years for people convicted of involvement in a "racketeering enterprise," including a criminal gang, an organized crime family or a business cartel.
The owners who agreed to prison terms and forfeiture of assets ranging from $375,000 to $750,000 are Frank Allocca, 68; Daniel Todisco, 42; Dominick Vulpis, 55; Henry Tamily, 69, and Joseph Virzi, 69.
Without admitting complicity in the cartel, Raymond Polidori, 49, pleaded guilty to a lesser felony of violating the state's antitrust laws. He was placed on probation for five years and agreed to forfeit $250,000 in assets.
All six were banned from holding jobs in the carting industry in New York City and accepting payments from carting companies doing business in the city.
The forfeitures were part of $268 million in assets held by the original 17 defendants and their 23 companies that were frozen under a court order in 1995 and that are subject to seizure by the state if the defendants are found guilty.
"We got a good deal from these pleas," said Daniel J. Castleman, the head of the Manhattan District Attorney's investigation division. "All but Polidori are going to state prison and are disgorging a fair amount of their criminal proceeds.
"It is another indication that the cartel is basically dead."
But Salvatore J. Marinello, a lawyer for Mr. Vulpis, said that under the plea agreements, some defendants might be eligible for work release after two months in prison. "It was a reasonable plea for my client and a good business decision to settle the matter," he said.
On Jan. 27, the former lead defendant in the case, Angelo Ponte, the owner of what was once the city's largest carting company, pleaded guilty to charges that he was a member of the cartel. He faces two to six years in prison when sentenced.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Pay New York Hospitals Not to Train Doctors, Easing Glut

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In a plan that health experts greeted as brilliant and bizarre, Federal regulators announced yesterday that for the next six years they would pay New York State hospitals not to train physicians.
Just as the Federal Government for many years paid corn farmers to let fields lie fallow, 41 of New York's teaching hospitals will be paid $400 million to not cultivate so many new doctors, their main cash crop. 
 The plan's primary purpose is to stem a growing surplus of doctors in parts of the nation, as well as to save Government money. But the payments are manna to New York's cash-starved hospitals, which are struggling to trim the size of their staffs and adapt to the world of managed care.
The plan required no Congressional action and thus was not debated by senators and representatives from other states. But hospital executives around the nation expressed concern that the Federal agency was playing favorites with New York hospitals because of their political connections and financial clout.
The plan was drawn up and proposed by officials of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a powerful industry group. New York's Senators, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, are among the most influential legislators in the country, especially on matters of health policy. And New York -- including its hospital union -- strongly supported President Clinton's re-election last year.
Health-care experts across the country were stunned by the plan, which is officially titled the Medicare Graduate Medical Education Demonstration Project. It was approved by the Health Care Financing Administration, which is part of the Department of Health and Human Services.
"It's an amazing treatment of health care as a commodity -- like grain or milk or meat," said Dr. Alan Hillman, a professor of health policy at the University of Pennsylvania. "I've never heard anything like this before. But I really can't find any fault with it. Maybe this is one of the first rational collaborations between hospitals and the Government."
New York trains 15 percent of the nation's doctors, making it by far the country's leading producer of new physicians. The next largest is California, at 9 percent. The Federal Government finances much of that training through its Medicare program, which pays hospitals up to about $100,000 a year for each resident they train.
Under the new program, 41 hospitals in New York State have agreed to reduce the number of residents they train by 20 to 25 percent over the next six years, resulting in 2,000 fewer residents in the state. In exchange, Medicare will initially continue to pay participating hospitals as if those young doctors were still there, slowly phasing out the payments over the next six years.
The plan is a novel approach to a sticking point in health care: the oversupply of doctors in many specialties and in many parts of the country, which health economists say results in unnecessary tests and procedures and drives up medical costs. Although health experts have been complaining for almost a decade that the country has been producing too many doctors, generous Medicare training subsidies have meant that hospitals continue to churn them out.
"I believe this will be a pathbreaking project," said Bruce C. Vladeck, the administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, who announced the program. "For the first time in 20 years our goals for graduate medical education and the financial incentives will be in line with one another."
Dr. Bruce Siegel, the president of Tampa General Hospital, admitted to envy and some resentment that hospitals in other parts of the country were not involved. "This is a real coup for New York teaching hospitals," he said. "How can we get in on it?"
Dr. Siegel, a former president of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, noted that many hospitals throughout the nation were reducing the number of doctors they trained, too. But without Federal help, he said, "a lot of us are having to cut back on residents and we're suffering the reimbursement implications of that immediately."
Dr. Siegel said that the increasingly powerful health maintenance organizations had pushed hospitals to rely less on residents. He added that as managed care companies were insisting on shorter hospital stays and were reducing the number of hospital procedures, many medical centers were finding they no longer had enough patients to train all the residents they employ.
Mr. Vladeck acknowledged that some Republican Congressmen had complained that the plan had been offered solely to hospitals in New York, but added that demonstration projects are intended to test the strategy and are necessarily somewhat limited in scope.
"If other people think this is a good deal, they have the power to make it more available," he said, noting that Medicare legislation could offer a similar program in other parts of the country. Mr. Vladeck was previously a health-care executive in New York.
The program is voluntary, but 41 hospitals in New York State are participating, including virtually all its major medical centers. Each hospital has agreed either to cut the number of residents by 25 percent over 6 years, or by 20 percent while improving primary care training. During the first year, the hospitals will get as much Medicare money for medical training as they would if they were educating as many doctors as they are now, Mr. Vladeck said. During the second year they would receive 95 percent of that amount, then 85 percent in the third year, and continuing to drop to zero in the seventh year. By then, the hospitals will be paid only for the residents they are actually training.
Hospitals have to decide by Friday how many training positions to offer to new residents who begin on July 1. Officials at the Greater New York Hospital Association predicted that there would be 300 to 400 fewer residency positions in New York's hospitals by next year.
"Under this voluntary demonstration project, participating hospitals will be partly cushioned from financial loss as they reduce the number of residents they train and restructure their training programs to respond to the new marketplace," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. At a news conference at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, hospital executives who had cut short their holiday weekend were glowing at the prospect of newly found Federal funds to ease the transition into the next century. Champagne toasts and thank you's for Mr. Vladeck and Mr. Raske filled the air.
The hospitals' executives said the program would allow them to wean themselves from their dependence on the cheap labor of residents rather than having to go cold turkey. Hospitals currently receive up to $100,000 a year from Medicare for each resident and pay these doctors-in-training $40,000 for a 90 hour workweek. So residents often do tasks that could be performed by less highly-trained personnel or sometimes even machines.
Hospital executives said they might use the Federal funds to hire more physicians' assistants or nurse-practitioners, for example.
"This cushion affords us a revenue base to reinvest into alternative types of service delivery and to upgrade our technology," said LaRay Brown, a vice president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation.
Mr. Vladeck said that while the Federal Government would pay out about $400 million to the hospitals, that is $300 million less than what it would spend if the current system were continued. And in the point of the whole exercise, by the time the program ends the Government will save a substantial sum of money because New York's hospitals will be educating 25 percent fewer doctors each year.
"I think this could be a win-win-win situation," said James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, a research and philanthropic group. "This produces a good outcome for H.C.F.A., a good outcome for New York hospitals and a good outcome for redesigning graduate medical education."

[D7.]

As the stock market has soared during the last several years, it has often seemed as if the manager of the latest hot mutual fund is barely out of college. A new study supports that impression, concluding that the younger the manager, the better the performance. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]

[D9.]

An unusual decision by an Ontario government panel has produced the first unionized store for the Wal-Mart chain, even though a majority of the department store's employees voted against joining the union. [D3.]

Hoping to make peace with book publishers and restore relevance to what many publishers have come to see as an outmoded, costly event, the new owner of the nation's biggest book show -- a unit of Reed Elsevier -- will announce that the publishers trade association has agreed to serve as a co-sponsor of the convention. [D8.]

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
The Cuban Government has invited about 100 American business leaders and celebrities to a $500-a-plate dinner in Havana next week to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the world-renowned Cohiba cigar, Reuters said, quoting a report in yesterday's Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel.
As most Americans are prohibited from traveling to Cuba under a longstanding United States embargo, Cuban officials are tight-lipped about the guest list. But published reports say the movie stars JACK NICHOLSON, DANNY DE VITO, MATT DILLON and ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER may be among those invited.
"It is my understanding that everyone who is going is going legally," said John Kavulich, president of the United States-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a private business group. In the United States, where Cuban cigars are banned, a box of 25 Cohiba cigars, President Fidel Castro's favorite until he stopped smoking, is said to cost more than $800.
The dinner is to be held on Feb. 28 at Havana's famed Tropicana Club, to raise money for Cuba's health-care system, The Sun-Sentinel said. More than 600 guests worldwide have been invited. "To someone who smokes cigars it's like going to the Academy Awards," said Richard Sachs, a Boca Raton, Fla., stockbroker, who declined his invitation. ELAINE LOUIE

HEADLINE: Third World Might Not Welcome Global Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was difficult to miss the irony of Paul Krugman's lengthy dismissal of globalization ("We Are Not the World," Op-Ed, Feb. 13) appearing in the same issue that had a front-page story on the World Trade Organization's upcoming ruling on the "legality" of the Helms-Burton Act. 
 Only a few years ago it would have been impossible to imagine the United States permitting a group of international trade technocrats to strike down an American law, much less a statute alleged to have national security implications. This appears to be exactly the sort of intrusive globalization that Mr. Krugman denies.
He seems also to have missed a number of disturbing developments in globalization technology. These include your recent report on the imminent and controversial launching of numerous spy satellites by several corporations (front page, Feb. 10). These "eyes in the sky" will now allow transnational corporations the kind of detailed global surveillance formerly available only to the superpowers.
The fact is that globalization is here, and new technologies and trade technocracies are providing it a growing political and technical infrastructure. Clearly, this globalization trend could profoundly undermine national sovereignty, as well as individual privacy. Denials like Mr. Krugman's will not make these inevitable problems of globalization disappear.
 
ANDREW KIMBRELL
Exec. Director, Int'l. Center
for Technology Assessment
Washington, Feb. 13, 1997

HEADLINE: Third World Might Not Welcome Global Market;
Elusive Wage Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Feb. 13 front-page article "In Era of Belt-Tightening, Modest Gains for Workers" paints an overly optimistic impression of recent and future wage gains. 
 You report that "nationwide, hourly wages, in current dollars, are rising at an annual rate of 3.8 percent -- about five-tenths of 1 percent above the inflation rate." This figure is from the Bureau of Labor Statistics' highly volatile survey of production and nonsupervisory workers. Other wage series, which are generally considered broader and more reliable, show less wage growth.
The B.L.S.'s Current Population Survey shows that the median weekly wage of full-time workers increased by only 3.1 percent between the last quarter of 1995 and the last quarter of 1996.
More important, the B.L.S.'s Employment Cost Index, which is widely considered the best measure of wage pressures, showed just a 2.9 percent increase in total compensation growth (wage and salary plus fringes) in 1996, barely keeping pace with inflation.
 
ALAN B. KRUEGER
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 13, 1997
 
The writer was chief economist at the Department of Labor, 1994-95.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

DATELINE: RUTHERFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
FOR more than 50 years, Georges de Latour Private Reserve cabernet sauvignon from Beaulieu Vineyard has been the benchmark by which all California cabernets are judged.
But being a benchmark does not always mean being the best. Last year, Orley Ashenfelter, the Princeton University economist, who rates wines using auction prices, produced a new classification of California cabernets. He used Beaulieu Vineyard's Private Reserve as his benchmark, because, he said, it was "the most commonly sold mature premium California wine." 
 Based on auction prices alone, he rated 17 wines higher than the Private Reserve, with Caymus Vineyards' Special Selection at the top; 19 were rated lower. In his previous classification, in 1991, 11 wines commanded higher prices than the Private Reserve.
He insisted that Private Reserve had not declined. It "simply had more competition at the top end of the market," he said.
Other critics have been less circumspect. There is a general perception among them, present company included, that the Private Reserve has slipped in recent years and that the prices commanded by other cabernets reflect not just auction-market hype but also better quality.
The people at Beaulieu Vineyard, in the heart of the Napa Valley, are proceeding on that premise. Beaulieu's wine maker, Joel Aiken, and his staff have vowed to recapture the Private Reserve's pre-eminence among America's red wines.
And they have not confined their efforts to the Private Reserve. With the blessing of its parent company, Heublein Inc., a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan, Beaulieu has added new wines to its line, invested in new equipment and adopted new processing techniques in the vineyards and the cellar. Old vineyards have been replanted and new ones added.
A brochure prepared for the 1988 release of the 1986 Private Reserve, the wine's 50th vintage, noted that it had been made "using the same time-honored methods for over half a century -- fermented in open-top tanks, then clarified in century-old redwood tanks, before slow-aging in American oak barrels."
Georges de Latour Private Reserve had a distinctive taste. Andre Tchelistcheff, Beaulieu's principal enologist from 1938 to 1973 and a consultant until his death at 92 in 1994, described its distinctive taste as "Rutherford dust," referring to the soil in the vineyards around the winery in this community.
But he acknowledged, too, that the taste and smell of the wine derived in a large part from its contact with the American redwood tanks and American oak barrels.
Today, the wine goes directly from the stainless-steel fermenters -- still open-topped -- to a combination of American oak and French oak barrels. One recent morning, Beaulieu's assistant wine makers, Jeffrey Stambor and Robert Masyczek, put together a tasting of four vintages of Private Reserve: 1993 and 1994, made under the new dispensation, and 1975 and 1985, made the old way.
Both of the newer wines were made of 100 percent cabernet sauvignon, as were all of the old Private Reserves, but Mr. Aiken may add other wines for a blend if he deems it necessary. For example, a touch of merlot was added to the 1990.
Neither the 1975 nor the 1985 was at its best. The 1975 had faded, and the 1985, outstanding in its youth, seemed closed-in and somewhat harsh. The 1993 and 1994 could not help but come off well by comparison. To their credit, the newer wines clearly showed their Private Reserve lineage. But they also showed that they were of a different style.
They were lean, intense and elegant. There was always something rustic about the traditional Private Reserve, even though it could hold its own with the world's finest. Occasionally an older Private Reserve might be mistaken for a Chateau Latour, but usually it made no attempt to hide its California heritage.
The newer wines could be said to be more complex and sophisticated.
The first Private Reserve was made in 1936. Mr. de Latour, who founded Beaulieu in 1900, said it was the wine he had been trying to make all his life. After his death in 1940, his name was added to the label.
When the 1986 Private Reserve was released in 1988, Beaulieu offered a tasting of all its Private Reserves, and the 1936 turned out to be one of the stars. It showed its age but was still rich and balanced. When it was first released, it cost $1.45.
Beaulieu's Private Reserve has changed. Change involves risk. Will a more contemporary-style wine win back some of its prestige? Or will it become just another high-quality cabernet, cast from the same mold as a dozen other wines?
Beaulieu has a lot riding on its new Private Reserve. All of its other wines bask to some extent in the glory of the vineyard's principal wine. Which is not to say the company hasn't hedged its bet.
There is a new wine that Beaulieu hopes will make its name among the best reds. Called Tapestry, it is a blend of 75 percent cabernet sauvignon, 17 percent merlot, 7 percent cabernet franc and 1 percent malbec. In other words, a classic Bordeaux blend. With a proprietary name like Tapestry, the blend can be changed from year to year. Appropriately, two-thirds of it is aged in French oak, the rest in American.
Tapestry is a moderately priced wine, about $20, compared with about $40 for the Private Reserve. Beaulieu has two other cabernets: Rutherford, an excellent buy at about $12, and Beautour, at about $9.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Prieure-Lichine 1993. Margaux (Bordeaux). About $20.
 
Rain bracketed the 1993 vintage. It came down in torrents in April and June, just when the vines were beginning to flower. Then, intermittently, it poured again in September and October. It was the perfect condition for a viticultural disaster. O.K., the 1993 vintage in Bordeaux was not great, but it has turned out to be a useful one. Some of the wines are thin, thanks to all that water, but many of the wines are surprisingly good. They are medium-bodied and have good color. And in spite of some rough tannins here and there, they are ready to drink. Prieure-Lichine, which has been getting better and better in recent years, is one of the successes of the year, with its excellent fruitiness and an attractive bouquet. It is a wine to enjoy while waiting for more highly touted vintages to mature. It also offers another example of how unfair it can be to make blanket condemnations of a middling vintage.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases Against Mark Amid New Doubt on the Euro

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a three-year high against the German mark yesterday before retreating as the mark recovered on new doubts about the 1999 schedule for the first stage of European monetary union.
But traders returning from a three-day weekend in the United States said that demand for the dollar remained strong and that the underlying forces pushing the currency higher still seemed in place. 
 "The dollar has gone up really fast, and you'd have to expect a bit of a pullback," said Renato Strauss, vice president for foreign-exchange trading at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York. "Generally, we're still bullish on the dollar."
While American markets were closed on Monday for Washington's Birthday, the dollar traded as high as 1.7003 marks in Europe.
In intraday dealing yesterday, the dollar rose to another three-year high, 1.7050 marks, before settling in New York at 1.6839 marks, down from 1.6885 late Friday.
The dollar also ended lower against the Japanese yen, at 123.88 yen, compared with 124.22 on Friday.
The British pound weakened on lessened expectations for higher interest rates in Britain, falling in New York to $1.6084, from $1.6221 Friday.
Traders said the main theme in currency dealings yesterday was a rebound in the mark, largely over new speculation that the European Union's plan for a single currency in less than two years would be delayed.
That speculation centered on doubts that Italy would qualify under the strict fiscal criteria for joining the initial group of countries that will use the new currency, to be known as the Euro. Although Italy has taken steps to lower its inflation rate and budget deficit, traders said there was rising doubt whether it could sustain the fiscal austerity required to help the Euro plan succeed.
Doubt about Italy's initial participation was reinforced yesterday by Deputy Finance Minister Jurgen Stark of Germany, who said after a meeting of European finance ministers that no decision had yet been made about which countries would participate first. Any doubt about the timetable for the transition to the Euro tends to benefit the mark, the strongest national currency in Europe.

HEADLINE: Spinoff From Digital to Make Software Tools

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation plans to announce today that it is setting up an independent company, Tracepoint Technology Inc. to produce software development tools. The tools will be used to produce programs for computers using the Intel Corporation's Pentium microprocessors and the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 and Windows NT operating systems.
Software development tools allow programmers to write more efficient applications, more rapidly, than they can using only programming languages. Tracepoint's tools are based on the C and C++ languages developed by AT&T. 
 Tracepoint, which will be based in San Jose, Calif., will be majority-owned by Digital and will initially be staffed by about 24 former Digital employees. Sequoia Capital, a venture capital firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., has raised $2.5 million in financing for the entity.
Jay Zager, Digital's vice president of operations, said in a telephone interview that Tracepoint's development tools were originally created at the company's Western Research Lab in Palo Alto for use with Digital's Alpha computer chip and the Unix operating system. Though the tools were included at no cost with the Alpha Unix operating system software, Digital perceived a market opportunity for comparable tools in the Intel/Windows market, he said.
"Digital is not going to be in the business of PC software, so we created an independent entity, got some funding, and will really operate this venture as a stand-alone company," Mr. Zager said. "We believe the time is ripe and the market should be robust. We believe there are about a million C++ programmers out there who should be ripe for this product."
Mark Stevens, a general partner in Sequoia, said he believed that those programmers represented a strong potential market, because only one other company, Pure Atria Inc., produces similar tools. And even Pure Atria is not a direct competitor, Mr. Stevens said.
Donald DePalma, an analyst with Forrester Research, said the spinoff would allow Digital to reap some return on its investment in software technology, while the company concentrates on hardware. "Application development tools are pretty far removed from their core competencies," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip a Bit In Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices edged lower in thin trading yesterday, with many investors reluctant to buy ahead of today's report on consumer prices.
A strong dollar supported bonds early in the session, but when the dollar retreated, bond investors used the slippage as an excuse to sell. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 8/32, to 101 2/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.54 percent, from 6.53 percent on Friday. The Treasury market was closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday.
While recent reports have shown few signs of inflationary price pressures, market participants were taking few chances yesterday ahead of the January Consumer Price Index report, which is scheduled for release today.
The market is expecting a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in the index, with a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in the so-called core rate, which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy.
"Anything stronger at the core will be of concern to bond traders," said Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. A small amount of investor anxiety was priced in yesterday ahead of today's C.P.I. and December trade data, he said.
Still, the economic outlook for bonds has been very bright of late. "Economic growth is decelerating from the eye-popping pace of fourth quarter 1996 and inflation statistics continue to surprise us on the low side," noted Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis.
"Chairman Greenspan has been lucky, but also correct," he said, referring to Alan Greenspan, the head of the Federal Reserve. "Right now the motto at the Federal Reserve is 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it.' "
While many in the bond market continue to weigh the direction of interest rates, others are looking to see if the dollar's rally this year has peaked. A weaker dollar would make American assets like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors.
When the dollar came off a high against the German mark yesterday, Mr. Regan said, it caused "some market participants to think that the dollar, at least on a temporary basis, may have reached a plateau."
The results of the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction came in as expected, with the average rate for a three-month bill at 4.98 percent, down from 5.02 percent last week, with the average rate for a six-month issue at 5.03 percent, down from 5.07 percent.

HEADLINE: Marriott Aims Overseas With Acquisition

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Expanding its presence in the hotel business overseas, Marriott International said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Renaissance Hotel Group, a company based in Hong Kong that operates and franchises 150 hotels in 38 countries.
The acquisition for about $1 billion, which also involves taking over $50 million in Renaissance debt, would more than double the number of hotels run by Marriott outside the United States. The deal would help Marriott cement relationships with international travelers and make it more competitive abroad with the upscale properties of ITT Sheraton and the Hilton Hotels Corporation. 
 "We are now becoming a truly global hotel company," said J. W. Marriott Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Marriott, who added that for the first time in the company's 40-year history it would have hotels in Japan, Italy, China, Russia, India and Turkey.
Marriott operates 1,075 hotels in the United States and 75 overseas, while all but 35 of Renaissance's hotels are outside the United States. Among the hotels that would be run by Marriott after the acquisition are the Renaissance in New York, the Stanford Court in San Francisco and airport hotels in Denver, Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla. Marriott anticipates retaining the Renaissance name.
The Hong Kong company that has majority control of Renaissance, the New World Development Company, has agreed to the acquisition in which shareholders will receive $30 a share in cash, a 19 percent premium over Friday's closing price of $25.125. Renaissance shares closed at $29.75 each yesterday, up $4.625; Marriott shares closed at $56.25, up $1.
The acquisition by Marriott comes about a month after the Doubletree Corporation agreed to pay $890 million for Renaissance, or $8 a share. Doubletree said yesterday that it would not bid against Marriott, but would receive a $15 million breakup fee from Renaissance under terms of its earlier agreement. Doubletree closed at $43.125, up $2.50.
In addition to hotels under the same name, Renaissance runs properties under the New World and Ramada International names. After the acquisition, Marriott will have a total of 10 hotel brands. Current Marriott brands include the Fairfield economy properties and Ritz-Carlton, the luxury chain of which it owns 49 percent, with options to buy the remainder. Renaissance licenses the Ramada name in the United States and Canada.
Following by just a few weeks Hilton's $6.5 billion offer for the ITT Corporation, the Marriott transaction underscores the continuing consolidation of the hotel industry as it has returned to financial health. Although ITT rejected the Hilton offer last week as inadequate, that is not expected to end the matter, and at least one other large hotel chain is also widely regarded to be for sale.
Mr. Marriott said negotiations with Renaissance predated Hilton's recent offer for ITT.
Henry K. S. Cheng, chairman of Renaissance and managing director of New World, said yesterday that "a few bidders were interested in our company," but that Marriott was the most suitable. "We believe Marriott is a better hotel operator than we are. With their management, our hotel properties can perform better in the future," Dr. Cheng said.
Dr. Cheng will join Marriott International's board of directors.
Marriott will finance the acquisition largely through an existing $1 billion revolving credit line and expects to begin a tender offer for all outstanding Renaissance shares within five business days. The company anticipates completing the purchase by the end of next month.
"The acquisition makes strategic sense," said Mark Mutkoski, the senior lodging analyst BT Securities Corporation. "They get all those fee-based management contracts, and in New World, they have one of the largest hotel development companies. And they can improve Renaissance's rate and occupancy as they have Ritz-Carlton's."
Marriott estimates the acquisition will increase its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization by $75 million to $85 million in the first 12 months but it will reduce 1997 fiscal year net income by between 10 and 14 cents a share. However, Mr. Marriott said the company expected strong growth in future years through aggressive hotel expansion and cost savings of at least $15 million to $20 million a year by combining marketing, reservations and administrative systems.
While Renaissance is getting out of hotel management in favor of Marriott, Dr. Cheng said it was not getting out of hotel development. "We have quite a lot of hotels in the pipeline." he said, "especially in Hong Kong and China." Marriott and Renaissance together have more than 350 hotels with 50,000 rooms under development that are expected to open within the next three years.
Asked if he considered it risky to be so involved in China and Hong Kong, which is scheduled to revert to China on July 1, Mr. Marriott deferred to Dr. Cheng.
Noting that he lives, develops and does business in Hong Kong, Dr. Cheng said he had "full confidence" in Hong Kong's future. China cannot reverse Hong Kong's economic policy, he said, because the world is watching and, "If Hong Kong is successful, China is successful." Besides, he added, "China has to make Hong Kong prosperous as a model for Taiwan."
