HEADLINE: Stocks Climb; Dow at High Of 7,067.46

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Continuing to defy the predictions of even the most optimistic bulls, the stock market extended its early-year rally yesterday, rising sharply.
The Dow Jones industrial average -- which had slumbered through much of the session -- awoke in late trading and rose to close up 78.50 points, or 1.12 percent, at a record high of 7,067.46. For the year, the Dow is up 9.6 percent. 
 While much of yesterday's trading activity revolved around a number of high-profile mergers and acquisitions, the late-afternoon rally among blue-chip stocks lifted most indexes, and left many analysts perplexed.
"Today's a tough call," Warren Epstein, director of trading at Richard A. Rosenblatt & Company, said. "The market's up and there's really nothing to speak of. It must be momentum," he said of a market that rose about 80 points in the last hour. "To see the market do something that doesn't make a lot of sense really doesn't surprise me."
Among several analysts, however, there is a growing consensus that heavy cash inflows into mutual funds are driving stock prices higher. While healthy corporate earnings, low inflation and a benign bond market continue to bolster equities, some believe that the influence of hoards of cash is beginning to outstrip other fundamentals.
"There are times in the market where you're not trading statistics, but you're trading momentum," said Raymond Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "The dynamics of current money flows are overwhelming the economic statistics."
The Dow was led yesterday by Philip Morris, up 5 3/4, to 131 1/4, after Bloomberg News reported that American cigarette makers were negotiating to settle health-related lawsuits.
More than two-thirds of the Dow's gains were attributed to Philip Morris and four other companies: Procter & Gamble, J. P. Morgan, Boeing and Merck -- most of which have been among the best-performing Dow stocks this year.
Procter & Gamble was up 4 5/8 yesterday, to 129 1/2; J. P. Morgan was up 2 3/4, to 109 1/2; Boeing was up 2 1/4, to 110, and Merck was up 1 7/8, to 99 1/4.
"The story is we have been narrow, we continue to be narrow and it really doesn't matter because we've had concerted basket buying of these stocks," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. "This is the continuing deployment of funds into the favorite stocks."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also set a record yesterday, closing up 7.81 points, to 816.29. Notable among the S.& P. stocks this year have been financial services issues.
In fact, financial stocks have seen the most impressive gains this year. The S.& P. Financials Index, for example, is up 17.87 percent, far outpacing the S.& P. 500, which is up 10.2 percent.
Even better is the S.& P. Banks Composite, up 18.1 percent, partly because not one of the 27 banks listed in the index has lost ground this year. Even its worst performer, Corestates Financial, is up 6.02 percent.
Financial issues got an extra lift yesterday after H. F. Ahmanson, the nation's largest savings and loan, made an unsolicited offer to acquire Great Western Financial, a deal that would create one of the largest financial institutions in California. Shares of Great Western soared 10 5/8, to 44 7/8, and shares of Ahmanson were up 4 3/8, to 44 7/8.
Several other merger deals made news yesterday. The Evergreen Media Corporation, which owns radio stations nationwide, agreed to buy Chancellor Broadcasting. Shares of Evergreen lost 1 1/4, to 31 1/2, and shares of Chancellor rose 6.25 cents, to 28.
In health care, the HealthSouth Corporation said it would acquire Horizon/CMS Healthcare for nearly $1 billion. Shares of HealthSouth fell 2 1/8, to 41, and Horizon rose 2 1/4, to 16 1/2.

HEADLINE: Gore Informs Labor Of New Restrictions On U.S. Contractors

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore told A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders today that the Clinton Administration would soon issue regulations imposing new restrictions on Federal contracts to companies that violate laws on occupational safety, overtime and union organizing.
The labor movement has pushed for years for restrictions to punish companies that flout laws protecting workers. But it was only after the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last year undertook its largest campaign ever to elect Democrats that Mr. Gore announced the new procurement rules. 
 Under the Administration's new policy, made public by the Vice President at the federation's four-day meeting here, companies' adherence to labor laws is to be taken into account for the first time in the awarding of Federal contracts, and those that have violated such laws could be barred from receiving them.
"We're going to send a message to companies that want to do business with the Federal Government: how you treat employees and how you treat unions counts with us," said Mr. Gore, standing with the federation's president, John J. Sweeney, at a news conference. "If you want to do business with the Federal Government, you'd better maintain a safe workplace and respect civil, human and union rights."
Mr. Gore announced the new policy on a day when he and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, appeared before the federation's executive council in what was widely viewed as a beauty contest between two future Presidential candidates vying for labor's dollars and endorsement.
Mr. Gephardt, who is spending four days in Los Angeles during the labor meeting, pronounced views today opposing the North American Free Trade Agreement that were virtually identical to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s.
He and Mr. Gore appeared to be trying to outdo each other in talking about their concern for working families and their dismay that wages for most workers had lagged inflation.
"Since 1979, American workers have had a 10 percent pay cut, while their productivity has gone up 16 percent," Mr. Gephardt said at a news conference a few hours before Mr. Gore's. "This to me is the core challenge that our country faces."
The Administration's tougher rules for Federal contractors are to be spelled out in procurement regulations that it will soon propose. After that, companies, unions and the public as a whole will have 60 days to respond to the proposal before any final adoption.
Mr. Gore's announcement of those rules, welcomed by union leaders, coincides with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new crusade to unionize millions of more workers and so reverse the long-term decline in unions' membership and power. One of the overriding themes at this meeting is that hundreds of corporations have brought union organizing drives to a halt by flouting Federal law -- for example, by threatening to dismiss workers who support unionization.
Not everyone, though, expressed enthusiasm for the Administration's initiative.
"It's just pandering," Jeffrey H. Joseph, vice president for domestic policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in a telephone interview. "This is rewarding them by saying that under the current labor laws, which have been balanced over the past 50 years, you don't win, and we want to change the rules to stack them in your favor."
Under current practice, Federal contractors are generally reimbursed for all costs incurred in fulfilling the contract. But Mr. Gore said today that as part of the Administration's new plan, contractors would no longer be able to have the Government reimburse them for money they spend fighting unionization drives. Similarly, they would not be reimbursed for money they spend fighting suits brought by Federal agencies charging them with labor law violations.
"The right to organize and the right to strike," Mr. Gore said, "are fundamental rights, and nobody's tax dollars should be spent undermining those rights."
Neither Federal officials nor labor leaders could estimate today how much Federal money was spent to repay contractors for such activities. Nor could they estimate how many companies would be excluded from Federal contracts under the new rules. But union officials did point to a recent study by the General Accounting Office listing hundreds of Federal contractors that had been found guilty of labor law violations.
Among those violations are infractions of occupational safety laws. Federal officials said that under the new rules, they would weigh a company's overall record in complying with safety and other labor laws to determine whether the employer should qualify for contracts.
This is not the first time that Mr. Gore has visited the winter meeting with a promise pleasing to organized labor. At the 1995 meeting, he announced that the Administration would bar the awarding of Federal contracts to companies that hired permanent replacements for striking workers. But a Federal appeals court later overturned that policy.
In any event, some union leaders said they were surprised by how pro-union Mr. Gore's oratory was today.
"Working men and women who are in unions earn more, get better benefits and are safer on the job than workers who are not unionized," Mr. Gore said. "You can say the state of the Union depends in part on the strength of our unions."
But the Vice President was not alone in winning high marks here. Mr. Gephardt, who has now visited the federation's winter meeting 14 years in a row, "was very good," said Arthur Coia, president of the Laborers International Union. "He says the same things we do. He takes the same positions about workers that we do."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Circling the Wagons With a Bid for Great Western

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
For a chief executive, Charles R. Rinehart has long been unusually glum about the prospects of the company he runs. His new recipe for success: buy another company that is in just as bad a position and dismiss thousands of redundant employees.
Mr. Rinehart heads H. F. Ahmanson & Company, the largest savings and loan institution in the country. Late Monday it made an unsolicited offer to buy the Great Western Financial Corporation, the country's second-largest savings institution, for stock worth $6.6 billion. 
 But there is little profit in the traditional savings and loan business of making mortgage loans with money raised from certificates of deposit, and this deal will not change those economics. Nor will it eliminate the tens of billions of dollars in loans the two companies made in the late 1980's to finance California homes now worth far less than the mortgage balances due.
Mr. Rinehart hopes that the combined companies can move more quickly toward being more like banks, expanding offerings to include checking accounts, consumer loans and business services. Most of all, he hopes to close 201 branches, primarily in California, and eliminate $400 million a year in expenses.
Ahmanson declined to say how many people would lose their jobs should the deal go through. But as a rule of thumb, analysts said, since the company declared that it would shed 45 percent of Great Western's annual expenses, the same proportion -- or 6,300 of its 14,400 jobs -- will disappear.
In a very unusual tactic, all of those job cuts would come at the expense of Great Western employees. In a voice-mail message to Ahmanson employees yesterday, Mr. Rinehart said that none of them would lose their jobs or receive reduced responsibilities as a result of the acquisition. The policy in most mergers is to choose the best person from either company for each job.
"We felt we had to dance with the ones that brung us," Mr. Rinehart said yesterday, adding that most companies do not do enough to motivate and reward their employees.
If consummated, the deal would combine two institutions that financed the construction of many of the sunny suburbs that blanketed Southern California after World War II. Ahmanson's Home Savings of America built monolithic, mural-clad bank branches amid the new developments. Great Western emphasized cowboy imagery in its ads, with John Wayne and later Dennis Weaver as spokesmen.
But as it did for the cowboy, the sun is setting on the savings and loan. Both Great Western and Ahmanson are making far fewer new mortgage loans than they used to. Perhaps the best indicator that an era has ended: Two weeks ago, Great Western said it would end its cowboy ads and dismiss Dennis Weaver so it could have a more modern image.
For most of the last two decades shares of the two savings companies have traded within about $1 of each other. But in the last year, Ahmanson has surged ahead. On Friday, Ahmanson shares closed at $40.50, 18 percent more than Great Western's share price of $34.25.
The gap reflects the rising confidence of investors in Mr. Rinehart and Ahmanson's strategy and their increasing frustration with the slow progress made by Great Western under its chief, John F. Maher.
"Ahmanson's management has shown they are very smart, very aggressive and interested in increasing shareholder value above all else," said Thomas O'Donnell, an analyst with Smith Barney. He praised Ahmanson's cost-cutting, stock buyback plan and purchase of 61 former First Interstate Bancorporation branches that were sold after that bank's acquisition by Wells Fargo & Company.
Investors have criticized Great Western for being slow to cut costs.
The increase in the relative price of Ahmanson's stock helped give it the power to make an offer that Great Western should find too good to refuse. Ahmanson offered to exchange 1.05 of its shares for each share of Great Western. Based on Ahmanson's stock price Friday, that made the offer worth $42.53 a share.
Wall Street embraced the prospects of a merger, running Ahmanson's stock up by $4.375, to $44.875. That means its offer to Great Western shareholders is now worth $47.11 a share. Great Western's stock jumped $10.625 a share, to $44.875.
The success of Ahmanson's bid will largely turn on whether other companies emerge with higher bids for Great Western.
In theory, Great Western represents the best way for a big banking company to enter California. But many analysts and investment bankers feel that the huge weight of the low-yielding mortgages on Great Western's books will ultimately scare off most big banks.
Most eyes on Wall Street turned to Washington Mutual Inc., the acquisitive savings institution based in Seattle. When the company moved into California last year by buying American Savings Bank, Washington Mutual's chairman, Kerry Killinger, said it would like to buy more California companies.
Analysts read that as a none-too-subtle reference to Great Western. Yet it would take a leap for Washington Mutual to outbid Ahmanson.
It could close some duplicate branches, but Great Western has more overlap with Ahmanson. Moreover, Mr. Killinger has said that any acquisition must raise per-share earnings by 10 percent in the first year. Analysts said that the price he would have to pay to outbid Ahmanson would not meet that target.
A spokesman for Washington Mutual said only that the company wanted to continue to grow in California and was studying its options.
Most analysts said yesterday that it was unlikely Great Western would remain independent because the pressure from shareholders to sell to someone would be too great.

HEADLINE: Moving to Insure Preservation, 2 States Sign Deal for Sterling Forest

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
New Jersey and New York signed a landmark agreement yesterday with the owner of Sterling Forest, a largely undeveloped 17,500-acre natural refuge, to acquire more than 90 percent of the land for $55 million, guaranteeing that the pristine acreage will not be developed.
The $5 million down payment for the property was provided by the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for the Hudson Highlands, said Michael F. McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, who signed the agreement with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. 
 The fate of the land, which provides drinking water for the northern part of New Jersey, had been undecided for more than a decade until last October, when the Senate passed a bill that would help finance the preservation of much of the forest, which lies about 40 miles northwest of Manhattan and straddles both states. The bill allocated $17.5 million to help buy the land from a private owner who otherwise might have developed it.
The owners, the Zurich Insurance Group of Switzerland, had planned to develop office buildings, shopping centers, golf courses and a community of 13,000 homes, but agreed to sell the land to the Trust for Public Land and Open Space Institute provided the deal could be worked out by the spring of 1998.
"The preservation of Sterling Forest is finally within our grasp," Governor Pataki said in a statement. "But there is still much to be done. I remain firmly committed to complete the Sterling Forest acquisition, so we can insure that we protect and preserve this natural jewel."
Closing the deal will require an additional $21 million in public and private financing to supplement the $34 million already pledged for the purchase, including $10 million from New York and New Jersey.
This spring, Congress will consider a second appropriation of $8.5 million for the forest.
"I have always said that protecting Sterling Forest is both the right environmental choice and the best economic policy," Governor Whitman said in a statement. "We can contribute a few million dollars to help protect drinking water today and gain a magnificent new park."

HEADLINE: Casino Development Panel Tightens Its Property Rules

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Since casino gambling started in Atlantic City two decades ago, it has been touted as the key to the city's revival. In fact, the State Legislature imposed a tax on casino revenue to pay for new housing for the city's predominantly poor residents.
But fulfilling that promise has been troublesome from the start. Critics have long insisted that the city's housing has been the loser, even though the agency created by the state to reinvest the tax money has had millions of dollars to spend. 
 That criticism has increased in recent months with the disclosure that even though the agency, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, had helped to underwrite the construction of 2,700 housing units over a decade, it had also helped to pay for the construction of 5,000 casino hotel rooms over a four-year period.
Stung by that criticism, the reinvestment agency voted overwhelmingly yesterday to tighten its rules for condemning private property for new casino-related development. But longtime critics of the agency noted that the agency also exempted the property involved in court cases, which prompted the new rules in the first place.
"This is a guilty statement and a public relations ploy by the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority," said Glen Zeitz, the attorney for Vera Coking, the owner of a vacant two-story building that sits in the shadow of Trump Plaza. The authority originally condemned the building along with Sabatini's Restaurant and the Golden Isle Pawn Shop The owners of the three properties are among those now challenging condemnation actions in court. "They are trying to defuse the anger here over how they have acted toward my client and others and in the process they are discriminating against my client," Mr. Zeitz said.
James Kennedy, the executive director of the 15-member board of the authority, said that what is now explicit in the rules had been implicit all along.
Specifically, if businesses are displaced by condemnation, the new procedures require that space be provided for them in new casino-related construction or in commercial or residential space built elsewhere. The new rules will also require that the board determine that property to be condemned is "essential" to the development and that the construction would result in a more effective use of the land.
"The fight is over how do you have this kind of explosive growth in the casino sector and at the same time protect the integrity of the community," Mr. Kennedy said. "We have done a lot to redevelop the city but clearly it's not enough. There continues to be such a disparity between the wealth of the casinos and the poverty in the city but it has come light years since the 1980's."
Underlying the 1976 referendum that approved casino gambling in the state were public promises that it would also rebuild the blighted resort town., create jobs and fill state tax coffers.
Barely five years afterward, the State Legislature acknowledged that the original law had proved ineffective in producing money for new housing in the city and created the reinvestment authority. That measure also gained broad support by allowing some of the funds to be used for specific development projects in southern New Jersey after 5 years and in northern New Jersey after 10 years.
Fueled by more than $4 billion in proposed new development by casinos, Atlantic City is on the verge of its largest expansion since the first casino opened in 1978. With an eye toward capturing more overnight visitors than day trippers and more conventions than in the past, the city is building a new convention center and an adjacent hotel.
Over the years, the tension over how the reinvestment board uses its condemnation powers and how it spends the money it collects has been complicated by the fact that the 14 casinos get to chose 2 of the 15 members of the board as well as having a final say over how the agency spends the money they are assessed. Consequently, Mr. Kennedy said, the casinos' representatives on the board and the "public members" of the board do not always agree on how to spend the money.
"Our performance as a board so far is incomplete and the city is still very much a work in progress," said Atlantic City Mayor James Whelan, who also sits on the board.
Federal Census data show how the city's housing stock has changed between the dawn of casinos in 1978 and now. In 1980, Atlantic City had a population of 40,199 and 21,520 housing units, and the 1990 census said it had a population of 37,525 and 21,626 housing units. In 1980, there were 198 boarded-up buildings, and the 1990 census counted 505.
Although replacement construction has lowered the percentage of pre-1940 buildings from 55.3 in 1980 to 36.7 in 1990, the percentage of housing units classified as "overcrowded" by the Census Bureau had risen to 8.8 from 5.7.
In the Westside and Venice Park communities of neat, single-family homes, Lillian Bryant and other homeowners are in a court fight over state plans to condemn their homes to build a covered roadway to a parcel owned by Mirage Resorts. They, too, would not be covered by the proposed new regulations.
Standing on the street named after her father, Horace J. Bryant, who in 1969 became the first black member of a New Jersey governor's cabinet, Ms. Bryant called the rules "hypocritical."
"They haven't passed a law here where citizens can't vote but casino buildings can," she said. "But they are getting close to that point."

HEADLINE: Japan's Global Trade Surplus Declines

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus plunged 91.7 percent in January from the same month a year ago, the Finance Ministry said today.
Japan's global trade surplus fell to 5.2 billion yen ($41.9 million), its lowest since 1985 and the 26th consecutive monthly fall. An 81.6 percent rise in the surplus with the United States was almost offset by a sharp decline in the surplus with Asia. 
 The yen's 14 percent depreciation against the dollar between August and January drove up import prices of oil, lumber and other materials, helping to shrink the surplus, a ministry official said. It also bolstered auto exports -- including those to the United States, which rose 77.5 percent in January, accounting for much of the surplus with the United States.
Analysts said that adjusted for seasonal factors, the overall surplus was 643.36 billion yen, up 25.6 percent from the prior month.
The dollar was little changed at 124.08 yen after the release of the report, compared with 123.88 yen in late New York trading on Tuesday. Economists had forecast that the overall surplus would be 26 billion yen.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Leader Says 'Cowards' Are Welcome to Leave

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Feb. 18

 BODY:
In another sign that North Korea might accept the defection of a top official, that country's Communist leader, Kim Jong Il, said in an official radio broadcast on Tuesday that "cowards" were welcome to leave.
"As the revolutionary song says: 'Cowards, leave if you want to. We will defend the red flag of revolution to the end,' " Mr. Kim was quoted as saying in a Radio Pyongyang broadcast that was monitored in Tokyo. 
 Meanwhile, North Korea has agreed to attend a briefing by the United States and South Korea on proposed peace talks aimed at formally ending the Korean War, a South Korean Foreign Ministry official said today. He said North Korea had informed the United States that it would propose a date for the briefing after the United States announced its package of food assistance for the North.
North Korea had agreed to attend the briefing in January but had put it off while it negotiated to get 500,000 tons of grain from Cargill, the American agribusiness giant.
The remark by Mr. Kim, the announcement about the briefing and assertions in the last few days by United States and South Korean officials that they still intend to supply food to North Korea raise the prospect that the defection, as well as the shooting here on Saturday of another North Korean defector, might not seriously derail efforts to improve relations on the Korean Peninsula.
That would represent a significant change from last fall, when the incursion into South Korea of commandos from a North Korean submarine threw all efforts at building a relationship off the track for months until North Korea expressed regrets.
"The political will on the North and South Korean side seems to be different," said a Western expert, who spoke on Tuesday on condition that he not be identified. "It seems that both are trying to prevent the same thing from happening again." But he and others cautioned that relations on the Korean Peninsula were volatile and moods could shift abruptly.
Some doubt began to emerge on Tuesday that the shooting of Lee Han Young, a prominent defector, was carried out by North Korean agents in retaliation for the defection last week of Hwang Jang Yop, the official who was the architect of North Korea's ideology of juche, or self-reliance. Mr. Lee is now brain dead and is being kept alive by a respirator.
A bullet used in the shooting of Mr. Lee might not have been fired by a Browning pistol, the type favored by North Korean agents, the authorities here said. Also, officials said the apartment in which Mr. Lee was staying had received a mysterious phone call asking his whereabouts a week before Mr. Hwang's defection.
There has been some speculation here that North Korea is preparing to accept the defection of Mr. Hwang, who is now in the South Korean Consulate in Beijing, so that the North would not jeopardize the food and other economic aid that it desperately needs. The South Korean Foreign Ministry official said today that there is no linkage between talks about food aid and peace talks and the resolution of the defection issue.
A senior American offical said on Tuesday that there was no connection between North Korea's actions involving Mr. Hwang and the provision of food aid to the North. American officals say that there is likely to be an increase in the amount of food aid from $6 million to $10 million.
North Korea, which is facing large-scale hunger, probably realizes that persuading China to prevent Mr. Hwang from leaving for South Korea or a third country would be difficult.
Still, China, which is trying to maintain good relations with both North and South Korea, has not indicated what it will do, so it is possible that Mr. Hwang, who just turned 74, will be stranded in the consulate for quite some time.
North Korea, which initially insisted that Mr. Hwang had been kidnapped by South Korea, first indicated that it might accept his defection on Monday, when the official North Korean press agency quoted an official as saying, "If he sought asylum, it means that he is a renegade and he is dismissed."
But that message was delivered only to foreigners. Kim Jong Il's statement on Tuesday was broadcast within North Korea. The statement did not mention Mr. Hwang's name or the fact that he had defected, but it could be laying the groundwork for such an announcement.
"It sounds like they are starting the process of rewriting history and casting Hwang as Judas," the Western expert said. "They are preparing their public for the news that the guy they revered for so many years is now the devil incarnate."
The police are investigating Mr. Lee's private life, because he had huge debts and many lovers, which might have provided a motive for someone to try to kill him. But South Korean officials say North Korean agents are still the primary suspects.

HEADLINE: A Market's Inner-City Success;
Pathmark and Brooklyn Group Both Profit as Partners

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
The revelation came to Roderick B. Mitchell nine Christmases ago, when his supermarket company in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was bleeding cash. And the first clue was Engelbert Humperdinck.
At a checkout counter in the company's Pathmark on Fulton Street, in the heart of one of the city's largest black communities, were collections of Humperdinck holiday tunes, displayed in a huge but untouched cassette carousel. 
 "I went berserk," said Mr. Mitchell, who had just become chairman of the then-struggling Restoration Supermarket Corporation, a novel joint venture between a grocery chain and a neighborhood development group. "I mean he's a great singer, but it's just not relevant here. Some things were very off-center."
Today, the market is tailored to the neighborhood's African-American and Caribbean customers, the shelves stocked with West Indian spices and the produce section with mango, papaya and sugar cane.
Now, after a decade of streamlining and soul-searching, the supermarket is one of the top performers in the 144-store Pathmark chain, with reported 1996 sales of $30.5 million and record operating profits of $1 million. It is the city's seventh-largest black-owned business.
The ultimate success of the 1977 joint venture between Pathmark Stores Inc. and the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation helped lay the groundwork for the supermarket industry's slow but steady return over the last decade to the inner-city neighborhoods of New York and other major cities, economists and supermarket retailers say.
But that partnership, a national symbol of what could be done to spur economic growth in poor neighborhoods, had an impact far beyond supermarkets. It was a model for nonprofit community development groups that desperately needed private capital and, as it turned out, a profitable lesson for private companies that discovered a new entree into untapped markets.
"There is an incredible burst of movement and growth around the country and a whole new generation of people in the private sector who see how good this is for the corporations," said Bennett Harrison, a professor of urban political economy at the New School for Social Research. "They see that without the neighborhood groups, they'll get blown out of the water, lose their shirt. They've read Tom Wolfe three times and are afraid of getting off at the wrong exit."
In Bedford-Stuyvesant, Pathmark Stores, a division of the Supermarkets General Corporation, saw there was money to be made in the inner city. But it would take a different approach, and the company learned new business practices from the development group: how to stock the shelves with more relevant products, how to prevent pilfering and, perhaps most important, how to promote a white-owned corporation from Woodbridge, N.J., as a friend of Bedford-Stuyvesant.
"The issue was how can we do this transaction without squandering our shareholders' money?" said Leonard Lieberman, a former chairman and chief executive of Supermarkets General who headed its Pathmark division when the Brooklyn deal was made. "We needed to maximize the number of customers who saw this as their own store, not an interloper store."
To reduce its risk, Pathmark made the community, with Restoration as the proxy, the majority stakeholder in the company. Pathmark proposed a joint venture, giving Restoration a two-thirds share and Pathmark a third and operating control. Restoration agreed.
Restoration, which was founded in 1967 to revive the troubled central Brooklyn neighborhood and was seeking to create jobs, urged the company to hire employees from the neighborhood. Pathmark agreed, realizing that the presence of local workers in the store would raise the stakes for the residents.
"We figured that when a 15-year-old kid went to steal a box of cookies, maybe a neighbor would say: 'Don't steal that. This is our store,' " Mr. Lieberman said. "And the dream turned out to be accurate."
But it was not until 1991 that the Brooklyn supermarket, which had reported heavy losses year after year, could produce a balance sheet with no red ink. And for Restoration, the venture was an example of how a nonprofit group learned to act like a business, like a Pathmark.
After Mr. Mitchell, who became president of the development group and its supermarket company in 1988, stumbled on the Engelbert Humperdinck display that year, he ordered an overhaul of the inventory. He sent his staff to the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant to see what customers were buying at greengrocers.
When the development group discovered that teen-agers were loitering outside the store, it created jobs for them, as part of a "Pathmark courtesy crew" to assist customers. Restoration also computerized the pricing system and preached efficiency to store managers.
"We began to manage the things we owned as if we owned them," said Mr. Mitchell, who is 41 and lives in Harlem. "Before, I think we were looking at it from a standpoint of this being, how shall I phrase it, more of a social services institution."
The mission of the Bedford-Stuyvesant group, and of the nation's 2,200 other community development corporations, nonprofit associations that first emerged in the late 1960's, is to build capital from commercial enterprises, using the revenues to infuse the economy with local businesses and to finance neighborhood social services. Many of the groups have focused on supermarkets as a way to stimulate local growth and reverse a national trend of inner-city supermarket flight.
New York City's zoning rules make it difficult to open large supermarkets, so regional chains have been slow to enter. But elsewhere, chains like Vons Companies on the West Coast, Safeway and Giant Foods in Washington and Finast Supermarkets in Cleveland are advancing quickly into urban terrain, often as partners with community development groups, according to the Food Marketing Institute, a trade association in Washington.
For Pathmark, which runs 18 stores in New York City and has opened dozens of inner-city stores in New Jersey and Philadelphia since it began operating in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the Brooklyn venture was a wrenching decision. The chain had run stores in the city since 1965, but none was in what a company spokesman called the "inner, inner city."
"Everybody was very jumpy," Mr. Lieberman recalled. "There was a huge internal fight within the company between a few of us who felt strongly that this was a community that had to be served and the majority who were saying, 'What are you talking about?' "
Restoration, founded in 1967 by Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits as the nation's first community development corporation, had started a number of businesses, primarily in real estate and mortgage lending, but none was particularly profitable, and the group was struggling to attract a national supermarket chain.
"At the time, we were not looking for a Pathmark," Mr. Mitchell said. "We were looking for anybody to come in. We couldn't convince anyone to locate here. The perception of Bed-Stuy was, and is, that of a frontier town -- you know, of shoot 'em ups and drugs and that type of thing."
Despite Pathmark's initial ambivalence, the Bedford-Stuyvesant supermarket turned out to be among the most productive in the chain and Restoration's most profitable enterprise. The volume of sales in the 20,000-square-foot supermarket, half the usual size of a Pathmark but lying in a densely populated neighborhood of 300,000 people, more than compensated for the extra costs of such things as insurance and security, a result that was similar in many other inner-city stores.
The turning point for Restoration, said Mr. Mitchell, was shedding the nonprofit mentality, learning to become obsessed with the bottom line. There was a time, he said, when Restoration was a somewhat passive partner in the supermarket venture, letting Pathmark, the minority shareholder, call the shots.
But beginning with Restoration's insistence on new inventory, it has become more aggressive and more savvy than Pathmark may have expected.
Mr. Mitchell said that in 1990, Pathmark expressed interest in opening another supermarket with Restoration in Brooklyn, but then excluded the development group from plans to open a store at Atlantic Center, a new retail center less than two miles from the Bedford-Stuyvesant store.
"Let's say that we were extremely disappointed," said Mr. Mitchell, noting that he feared that the new store, which opened last November, would take a bite out of his business. "We felt that was not the way a partnership should work."
Pathmark officials do not rule out the possibility of Restoration's getting a share in the Atlantic Center store, and they insist Pathmark will pursue future ventures with the development group. Harvey Gutman, Pathmark's senior vice president for retail development, said, "We treasure our relationship with Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation."
Mr. Mitchell did not suggest the partnership was falling apart, but, referring to the Atlantic Center supermarket, he said: "The negotiations will stay on until we get our share, even if it means legal action. Our store opened an entire market for Pathmark, and now all of the sudden, Pathmark is the darling of New York City. The logic is we want to protect our asset.
"This is strictly a business negotiation; it has nothing to do with social good. We're talking about cash."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 20, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday with an article about the success of a Pathmark supermarket in Brooklyn mislabeled the amount of the store's net income. The figures were in the thousands, not millions.

Charts: "It Pays to Shop Around"
One of the things a large supermarket can bring to a neighborhood is lower prices than those offered by smaller markets and bodegas. The following items were bought by Ieola Bakr, a Bedford-Stuyvesant resident, on a recent shopping trip to the Parhmark at 1406 Fulton Street. Also listed is what similar items cost at four local grocery stores. The others are: P.W. Fruit, Vegetable and Grocery, 1411 Fulton Street (a greengrocer); Met Foods, 1308 Fulton Street; Nostrand Deli & Grocery, 479 Nostrand Avenue (a bodega), and Key Foods, 245 Malcolm X Boulevard. HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Hewlett-Packard Profit Up 15%, Exceeding Estimates

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose more than 15 percent, exceeding a consensus forecast of Wall Street analysts, who had expected the company's results to be flat.
Hewlett-Packard attributed the strong results to improved cost and expense management, which allowed earnings to grow faster than revenue. But the company cautioned that growth in orders was lower than it had hoped for, partly as a result of the strong dollar and sluggish overseas markets. 
 It also said that the current quarter presents a tough comparison with the comparable period last year, when orders grew 22 percent and revenue rose 33 percent.
For the first quarter, which ended on Jan. 31, Hewlett-Packard earned $912 million, or 87 cents a share, up from $790 million, or 75 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue grew nearly 11 percent, to $10.3 million from $9.3 million.
Analysts had expected Hewlett-Packard to report earnings of 75 cents a share, according to a survey by First Call.
The computer and technology company, which is based in Palo Alto, reported its results after the stock market closed. Hewlett-Packard shares closed at $52.1875, up $1.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange. In after-hours trading, the shares were as high as $51.375.
"It looks like they achieved their earnings performance by successfully resisting pressure on cost of sales and really continuing a relentless vigilance with regards to expenses," said Daniel Kunstler, an analyst with J. P. Morgan. "Both were apparently more than sufficient to offset the challenges to top-line growth, which were glaringly apparent this quarter with revenue growth of only 11 percent."
Hewlett-Packard said orders for the quarter were $11 billion, up 9 percent from $10.1 billion a year earlier. The company said that without the effects of currency-exchange rates, its order growth would have been roughly two percentage points higher. Orders rose 7 percent, to $4.2 billion in the United States, while foreign orders grew 9 percent, to $6.8 billion.
"Nine percent year-over-year growth was below our plan, but not by much," Robert Wayman, Hewlett-Packard's chief financial officer, said in a conference call. "Remember, we're comparing to a quarter last year in which orders grew by 29 percent." The previous year's period also included sales of disk-drive mechanisms, a business that Hewlett-Packard is no longer in, he noted.
Sales of personal computers and servers increased, but those of work station products declined. Laser printers saw moderate growth, and while the number of ink-jet printers sold increased, there was a shift to lower-priced models that moderated revenue growth. Test and measurement equipment, as well as medical equipment, showed moderate increases.
"Our challenge is to sustain momentum in the fast-growing parts of our business, while improving growth where it has slowed," Lewis Platt, Hewlett-Packard's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "Clearly, economic conditions in some major markets are sluggish, and we expect an extremely challenging competitive environment in the months ahead."
Mr. Kunstler of J. P. Morgan said the company faced challenges to maintain earnings growth because so much of its increase in revenue was coming from low-margin products like personal computers and printers. "H.P. is stressing product areas that are ever more subject to price erosion," he said. "And H.P.'s absolute dimensions make year-to-year comparisons ever tougher as time progresses."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 21, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the first-quarter earnings of the Hewlett-Packard Company misstated the company's growth rates in revenue and orders for the quarter a year ago. Orders grew 29 percent, not 22; revenue grew 27 percent, not 33.

HEADLINE: Report Foreign Guests? French Tempers Flare

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Even by the standards of an angry, sullen France, an unusual uprising is in the making: hundreds of French actors, film directors and cartoonists have said they are ready to go to jail if a new immigration bill is passed.
More defiant still, many Government officials have publicly announced that they would ignore the proposed law. Among them are influential groups like the national association of French mayors and a number of judges and magistrates. 
 At issue is a Government bill, due to be discussed in Parliament on Tuesday, that aims to tighten measures to prevent illegal immigration. The portion of the bill that has caused particular outrage among the intelligentsia would oblige the French to inform the authorities of the movements of visiting foreigners who are on special guest visas, staying in French homes.
Some foreigners would be exempt, including visitors from Europe and industrial countries like Japan and the United States, but visitors from a long list of countries, among them many in Africa and the Middle East, are designated as targets of the new law.
Officials have made it no secret that behind the new immigration bill lies the fear that all mainstream political parties share of the growing extreme-right position of the National Front.
The Front, with its strident anti-foreigner platform, blames immigrants for France's record unemployment, and in recent local elections it won control of a fourth town in southern France.
Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre, who proposed the bill, is known to see it as a means of preventing the extreme right from further using the immigration issue to gain support.
Critics have likened the proposal to the repressive policies decreed by the wartime Vichy regime that required the French to register Jewish residents with the police. Many critics of the current proposal, including more than 130 magistrates who have signed a protest, have called it a dangerous flouting of civil liberties.
"This law would transform all citizens into police informers," said Dan Franck, a writer and a coordinator of a protest demonstration planned for Saturday.
The bill has in fact been before Parliament since mid-December, but it only turned into a major political issue in the last week when nearly 60 film makers demanded to be prosecuted.
"We are guilty, every one of us, of harboring illegal foreign residents recently," they said in a statement. "We ask to be investigated and put on trial."
This stand has since mushroomed into a campaign encompassing thousands of actors, writers, musicians, scientists, lawyers and members of other professions who are signing petitions and calling on others to disobey the law if it passes Parliament. Others are offering to take in illegal immigrants or say they have already done so in defiance of the Government's plan.
More than 50 cartoonists signed a statement demanding that they be investigated and tried for "harboring illegal aliens." The cartoonists contributed to a special supplement filled with protest cartoons published this week by the liberal daily newspaper Liberation.
The issue in recent days has dominated public debate, filling newspapers and magazines and leading to lengthy and fiery arguments on television.
In keeping with French tradition, a countermovement is already on the way, accusing the protesters of grandstanding.
In an article headlined "The Petitioning Intelligentsia," the conservative newspaper Le Figaro said today that members of the intellectual and social elite, who had no special answer to anything, signed petitions because they would hate it if their name did not appear, because they want to please some friend or because they want to seem plugged in.
Prime Minister Alain Juppe has said that the bill on one hand would provide proper residence papers to some categories of undocumented foreigners but that it would also give the Government the means to "tackle the very real network of illegal immigration that exists in France."
These networks, a Government official said, make use of a 1982 decree that requires foreigners who apply for a visitor's visa but have no proof that they possess money or hotel reservations to get an officially stamped affidavit, a so-called certificate of accommodation, from a French host.
The official said some hosts had asked for such certificates 40 or 50 times a year, because they were involved in immigrant smuggling. One host, for example, asked 42 times last year for affidavits for guests from Romania, he said.
The new bill proposes that French hosts who have foreign guests on such special visas must inform the town hall when their guests leave the host's home.
This apparently small change in the law would permit the Government to compile computer records on the movements of foreigners from developing countries, who are considered the most likely to stay behind when their visitor's visa expires.
It is this minor change that has caused the outcry. Mr. Juppe, apparently most taken aback by the calls for civil disobedience, has said he is willing to accept amendments, as long as the objective "to fight fraud" remains intact. Some amendments are already being discussed.
"We say we want to fight the far right, and we end up using their tactics," said Jean-Pierre Boucher, a judge who is circulating a petition being signed by magistrates.
National Front leaders appear to be rubbing their hands over the melee. The Front issued a statement today saying it was calling for a national referendum on immigration, something it apparently sees as a fair gamble.
Results published today by one independent opinion poll said 59 percent of those questioned were in favor of the Government's immigration bill and 58 percent opposed the calls for civil disobedience.

HEADLINE: Township Looks Warily at Energy Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: LACEY TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
For a generation, the gray Oyster Creek nuclear power plant, with its towering needle of an exhaust stack, has dominated the forest of scrub pines at the southern end of town.
More important for homeowners, Oyster Creek has been a tax bonanza since it was built in 1969, producing millions in energy tax revenues and guaranteeing modest property taxes for the ranches and bungalows packed along the salt-water inlets and lagoons of Barnegat Bay. 
 In 1997, Lacey Township will get about $9.5 million for Oyster Creek, nearly 60 percent of its town budget of $16.1 million. But that aid is already down -- $1.3 million less than in 1996 -- and the town administrator, Jorge A. Rod, is concerned that the aid will decline still more in coming years if Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to cut New Jersey's energy tax rate by nearly 50 percent is adopted by the Legislature.
Nor is Mr. Rod alone in his sour mood. Lacey Township is one of the biggest beneficiaries of about $1 billion in taxes that New Jersey charges electrical and natural gas companies for all the poles, wires, pipelines, generating stations and other equipment in the state's 567 communities. For years, Trenton has annually returned the bulk of these revenues to the communities, and they have become the second-largest pot of money available for municipal budgets, after local property taxes.
For Mrs. Whitman, a champion of state income tax cuts and property tax stability, the plan is a tricky high-stakes juggling act. She wants the energy tax cut for two primary reasons. She says that the existing tax is one of the nation's highest, impeding the state's ability to attract new industries and their jobs.
In addition, when the state starts deregulating sales of electricity in 1998, she wants the same tax rate applied to in-state utilities and out-of-state suppliers. The out-of-state suppliers are exempt from the current tax, the Gross Receipts and Franchise Tax.
In place of the current tax, which has a rate of about 13.5 percent, she has proposed extending the state's 6 percent sales and use tax to retail sales of electricity and natural gas and creating a new 1 percent corporate net income tax on all companies making retail sales of power in the state after deregulation.
Cutting the rate to 7 percent could reduce overall annual tax revenues by $361 million, the Whitman administration has estimated. But to prevent major cuts in aid to the towns and to eliminate the corresponding political risk of causing major increases in property taxes, Governor Whitman has proposed an additional temporary energy tax of 6 percent in the first two years of the new tax.
Starting in the third year, the temporary tax would be phased out over five years. Whitman administration officials say the interim tax will not be needed after seven years because the lower energy tax will spur economic growth, thereby increasing energy sales and offsetting the revenue lost from cutting the existing tax.
Municipal officials say their economic forecasts are not so rosy. They want a guaranteed amount written into new legislation for the Governor's package.
For many state residents, the proposed changes probably seem arcane. The energy tax is largely invisible to them, tucked into the welter of numbers in their monthly utility bills.
In a sense, Mr. Rod's complaints are an opening move in a campaign by New Jersey towns to emerge unscathed from Mrs. Whitman's proposed changes. The $1.3 million cut that Lacey Township now faces is linked to the tax system's complex distribution formula and not to Mrs. Whitman's plan.
But the towns have already started lobbying for guarantees against any big losses in coming years.
For Lacey Township, Mr. Rod says the cut this year leaves him with two bitter options: a 2-cent increase in the town's minuscule property tax of 11 1/2 cents for each $100 of property value, or dropping plans for new police cars and town trucks, ending the town's $500,000 payment to the school system, paving fewer dirt roads around town and maybe laying off some workers.
"We'll have barely enough money to operate," Mr. Rod complained. "We have this atomic plant, and people will never understand how we get stuck with this cut."
The tax stakes for Lacey are greater than for any other town in the state because the aid represents a far higher share of its town budget, even though some communities, like Newark and Jersey City, get far more in total dollars. Since 1950, Lacey has grown from a sleepy coastal fishing village of about 1,000 people in Ocean County to a middle-class community of about 24,000.
The state's Gross Receipts and Franchise Tax has existed since the early 1900's, and in the last couple of years it has produced more than $1 billion annually. Until the early 1980's, the state returned all the money to the towns because state law prohibits them from imposing property taxes on state-regulated utilities. But then the state began skimming some of the proceeds for its own budget. By the early 1990's, the state was taking $232 million a year.
After the towns complained, the Legislature in 1992 guaranteed them $685 million a year, plus what was called "surplus" revenue. In 1995, the surplus was $97 million and the towns got $782 million. But for 1996 and 1997, the surplus has dropped to $45 million, leaving the towns with $730 million each year.
The State League of Municipalities, which represents New Jersey's 567 towns, has already started talks with the Whitman administration and legislative leaders about whether the state should guarantee the $685 million or $730 million in aid.
"It's the highest legislative priority for the league," said its assistant executive director, William G. Dressel Jr. "We need assurances the money's going to be there."
The league's goal "will be to keep the municipalities as whole as possible," Mr. Dressel said.
The anxieties in New Jersey are singular in the metropolitan region. Municipalities in New York can impose their own property, sales and gross receipts taxes on utilities. Connecticut's municipalities can levy property taxes on them.
But the local taxes have risks. In November, a New York state judge ruled that the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island had been overtaxed from 1982 to 1994 and ordered that Suffolk County, the town of Brookhaven and a local school district refund up to $1.1 billion to the Long Island Lighting Company. The ruling has been appealed.

(Sources: New York State Department of Taxation and Finance; Energy Association of New York State; New York Conference of Mayors; New Jersey Department of Treasury; Connecticut Department of Revenue Services)

HEADLINE: Giuliani Names Campaign Chief

 BODY:
Fran Reiter, who has become one of the most loyal and trusted members of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's inner circle, was named yesterday as the manager of Mr. Giuliani's re-election campaign.
Ms. Reiter, who has served as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and Planning since last April, will relinquish her post in the next two weeks and run the day-to-day operations of the Mayor's as-yet unannounced candidacy. She had previously held the job of Deputy Mayor for Community Development. 
 Mr. Giuliani had earlier said that the job of running the campaign would go to Peter J. Powers, the Mayor's closest friend and former first deputy mayor, who had run Mr. Giuliani's first two campaigns. But Mr. Powers, who joined a money-management company last fall, now says he is too busy in his new position to deal with daily operations and will instead become campaign chairman, an advisory post.
Mr. Giuliani has not yet settled on a replacement for Ms. Reiter.

HEADLINE: Real Estate Dynasty Is Nearing the End

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A real estate dynasty that was founded on a handshake by Benjamin Swig and Jack Weiler during the Depression and that grew into a $1 billion empire, including some of the finest hotels and office buildings in New York and elsewhere, is expected to end this week with the sale of its most prestigious properties.
The descendants of the late Mr. Weiler -- who have recently engaged in a bitter courtroom battle with the Swig family -- are selling their stake in three of the partnership's best Manhattan properties, including the swooping, 50-story W. R. Grace Building on 42d Street at Avenue of the Americas. 
 The buildings are being sold to TrizecHahn Office Properties for about $220 million, according to executives and real estate brokers familiar with the deal.
The sale marks the first foray into a now vibrant real estate market in Manhattan for TrizecHahn, the second-largest real estate company in North America.
But the sale also signals the Weilers' exit from an industry in which the family's patriarch was a leading figure and a major philanthropist until his death in 1995.
The Weilers are also selling two buildings in San Francisco and another property in Houston to the Swigs, for an undisclosed price.
The Swig family's company is based in San Francisco, where it co-owns the Fairmont Hotel chain and operates about 11 million square feet of property. The Swigs would own the buildings in Manhattan in partnership with TrizecHahn, which will take over management and leasing.
Six months ago, the descendents of Jack Weiler and Benjamin Swig, who worked together for decades without benefit of a written partnership agreement, were embroiled in a fight for control of the dynasty. Now, the Swigs will continue as a real estate owner and operator, while the Weilers leave the business.
Shifra Bronznick, executive vice president of Swig, Weiler & Arnow Management Company and a spokeswoman for the Weilers, confirmed that the Weiler family expected to complete the sale of their interests to TrizecHahn by the end of this week, though she declined to name the price.
"It is a win-win-win for all the parties involved," Ms. Bronznick said. "The members of the Weiler family will enjoy the liquidity that will allow them to pursue their independent interests. The Swig family will have an excellent new partner."
The upbeat talk contrasts sharply with the language of a lawsuit filed in State Supreme Court last year by the Weilers that sought to dissolve the 60-year partnership. The suit said that the Swig family's "precarious financial situation" jeopardized the financial health of the properties.
In a counterclaim, the Swigs said that the Weilers had refused to distribute millions in profits and attempted to sabotage the Swigs' efforts to obtain a $35 million loan.
Benjamin Swig and Jack Weiler, who met and formed their partnership in 1936, had no such problems as they jointly bought a string of properties across the country, with Mr. Weiler managing the buildings in Manhattan, while Mr. Swig oversaw the rest.
"The whole thing ran on a handshake," said one real estate executive who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But it got to the point where the handshakes didn't mean as much to the kids and it broke down."
Laurie Ludwick, a spokeswoman for TrizecHahn in Toronto, said the company had a purchase agreement with the Weilers, although the transaction had not closed. "It's a good step forward in our plans to acquire office properties in the United States," she said. "We see lots of opportunities for growth."
When the deal is finally completed, TrizecHahn will have nearly 50 percent of these properties: the Grace Building, a 1.5-million-square-foot tower that is known as a "trophy" property because of its prestigious tenants and spectacular views of the city; the World Apparel Center at 1411 Broadway, at 38th Street, one of the most desirable buildings in the Garment District and a center for the women's sportswear industry, and a smaller building at 1460 Broadway, at 41st Street.
The transaction takes place as the real estate market in Manhattan is recovering from a deep recession in the early 1990s, when property values plummeted and vacancy rates soared. But the price for midtown office buildings jumped to $168 per square foot last year, up 53 percent from $110 in 1994, according to CB Commercial Real Estate Group. Suddenly, buyers who had fled the New York market a few years ago are wrestling for the best properties.
TrizecHahn, which has a $1.4 billion war chest for acquisitions, won out in the bidding for the Weiler interests over PaineWebber Properties and developer Bernard Mendik, working with investor Robert Bass, according to real estate brokers.
"The universe of investors seeking properties in midtown has increased by over 100 percent in the last 12 months, with the most notable interest coming from offshore investors and real estate trusts," said Scott Latham, a broker with CB Commercial.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The W. R. Grace Building on 42d Street is changing hands. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German Views and U.S. Data Fail to Cut the Dollar's Value

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher yesterday, overcoming efforts by German central bank officials to slow its rise, and taking in stride a larger-than-expected United States trade deficit.
Hans Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank's president, said in a newspaper interview that he hoped the dollar's rise against the mark was at an end. His comments came after the bank's monthly report for February said the dollar had fully recovered from the lows it suffered in 1995. 
 The report and remarks weighed on the dollar in early trading. But a later report quoting a Bundesbank council member, Ernst Welteke, as saying that a dollar level between 1.70 and 1.75 marks would not risk importing inflation into Germany lifted the dollar later in the day.
Confusion over the dollar's near-term direction made trading choppy. "There's a fear it's not going to go much higher in the short term because of Bundesbank comments, but nobody's willing to short it because they feel in the medium term, dollar- mark can push higher," said Ian Gunner, a Chase economist.
The dollar was hurt late in the day by news that the trade deficit rose to $10.29 billion in December from a revised $7.94 billion in November. The market expectation had been $9.9 billion, but the figures were considered within the range of forecasts. The Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of a percent.
The dollar settled at 1.6963 marks late in New York yesterday, off a low in Europe of 1.6806 and up from 1.6839 marks late Wednesday. It fetched 124.46 Japanese yen, up from 123.88. The British pound rose to $1.6161 from $1.6084.
The dollar, a haven in times of instability, was also driven higher by the announcement of the death of China's leader, Deng Xiaoping.
Neither set of United States economic data was seen as good news for the dollar, with soft inflation figures taking pressure off the Fed to raise interest rates. But analysts said sentiment remained bullish. "The U.S. data showed a largely-as-expected deterioration in the trade position and further evidence of the subdued nature of inflation," Jeremy Hawkins, of the Bank of America in London, said. "This should tend to support the asset markets and leave the dollar little changed."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Ease, Ignoring Good Price Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday, despite a report of consumer prices that showed inflation under control.
The bulk of the selling came from continuing fear that a robust economy and low inflation would eventually push prices and rates higher, traders and analysts said. Despite recent data showing inflationary pressures at bay, traders said they expected limited gains over the near term unless there is more evidence that job and wage growth is slowing. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 13/32, to 100 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.57 percent, from 6.54 percent Tuesday.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in January, below estimates of three-tenths of 1 percent. Such a report would typically drive prices higher, but yesterday's bullish news had largely been priced in following last week's producer prices report, which showed an unexpected drop.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that "on a monthly year-over-year basis, the C.P.I. actually declined to 3.0 percent from 3.3 percent, an unusually large drop in this statistical measure for this stage of the economic cycle, though it is likely temporary."
The report, he said, "gives the Fed considerable latitude to keep monetary policy on hold at its March 25 policy meeting should upcoming statistical data prior to that date continue in the most recent mode, although the Federal Open Market Committee is highly likely to maintain its current bias toward tightening."
Today the market turns its attention to reports on housing starts and initial jobless claims and a survey of regional business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Housing starts in January are expected to bounce back from the weather-depressed December level, although the gain is expected to be only about half of the previous month's decline. But the attention, he says, will be equally, if not more riveted, on initial claims, which plunged to a conspicuously low 309,000 last week. An increase is expected, but the four- week average will be scrutinized to see if the declining trend continues.
And the market is now beginning to cast a wary eye toward Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony next week, in which he is likely to provide some clues as to his and the Federal Open Market Committee's current thinking on the economy.
"With the good inflation news now behind them, and the uncertainty of Greenspan's testimony in front of them," Mr. Fine said, "market participants have begun to pare positions in preparation for any eventuality," which is what some people think was the primary reason behind the selloff after the favorable price data. "After all, few would want to carry a significant position into the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony and subject themselves to tape bombs."
The Treasury, meanwhile, announced yesterday the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions next week, which consist of the sale of $17.5 billion of two-year maturity notes on Tuesday and $12.5 billion of a new five-year note on Wednesday. In when-issued trading, the two-year was offered at a price to yield 5.81 percent and the five-year at 6.10 percent.

HEADLINE: Union Chiefs Vote to Oppose Expansion of Free-Trade Pact Unless It Is Modified

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Putting the labor movement on a potential collision course with President Clinton, A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders voted today to oppose extending the North American Free Trade Agreement to other countries unless it includes protections on labor and the environment that the Administration has previously rejected.
The labor leaders approved a resolution saying that Nafta has hurt American, Mexican and Canadian workers and that other countries should not be added to the accord unless strong labor and environmental guarantees are included in the main agreement, rather than in a side agreement that Congress could dilute. 
 "The labor movement's strongest disagreement with the Clinton Administration in the first term was over Nafta," John J. Sweeney, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said. "Our position has not changed in terms of what we are fighting for in the Nafta agreement. We will continue to fight over labor standards, human rights and environmental protection."
The combative stand by the 54-member executive council, at the federation's winter meeting here, recalled the battles when Mr. Clinton pushed the accord with Canada and Mexico through Congress despite labor's fervent lobbying.
"American, Mexican and Canadian workers have all suffered because of Nafta," said Jay Mazur, chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s trade subcommittee and president of the Union of Needletrade, Industrial and Textile Employees. "We should rethink Nafta and adjust it so that at the very least no future trade agreement should be signed without incorporating strong worker rights and strong enforcement mechanisms for such rights."
One of labor's complaints is that stronger enforcement mechanisms come into play under Nafta when Mexico violates commercial laws, on trademarks, for instance, than when it violates labor laws.
The resolution was approved a day after two possible Presidential candidates in 2000 -- Vice President Al Gore and Richard Gephardt, the House Democratic leader -- staked out contrary positions on trade while appearing before the labor leaders.
Striving to show that there was no ideological daylight between him and labor, Mr. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said he would oppose extending Nafta to other nations unless there were stronger worker and environmental protections.
"We should not simply extend a treaty that in my view is not working properly," Mr. Gephardt said. "In a way, Nafta has validated a governmental and business system that does not allow workers to have the ability to get paid and compensated for their hard work."
Praising Nafta, Mr. Gore voiced confidence that the Administration and the labor movement could work out their differences.
Mr. Gore said that wages in Mexico were hurt not by Nafta, but by the economic downturn caused by the peso's devaluation.
He said that "the impact of Nafta has been quite positive" in all three countries if the effects of the devaluation are separated out.
He said any accord adding other countries to the agreement should include labor and environmental protections, but added, "The precise form that it takes will have to be worked out over time." In the past, the Administration has rejected labor's demand that labor and environmental guarantees be included in the main agreement.
The Administration's trade policy came under heavy criticism while Mr. Gore appeared here. According to labor leaders, Stephen P. Yokich, president of the United Automobile Workers, put Mr. Gore on the defensive at Tuesday's meeting by asserting that last year's $165 billion merchandise trade deficit showed that Mr. Clinton's trade policy was a failure. Not only that, he asserted that the President's trade policies were wiping out American jobs and bleeding some unions to death.
The debate over Nafta comes shortly before Congress is expected to take up legislation that would give Mr. Clinton fast-track authority to negotiate with other countries to join the trade agreement. With such authority, he can negotiate an agreement, and Congress then has to vote it up or down, without being able to pick it apart with amendments.
In approving a series of resolutions, A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders reiterated their endorsement of Mr. Clinton's embattled nominee for Secretary of Labor, Alexis Herman. The federation called for immediate hearings on her nomination, praising her "commitment to a working families agenda and her superb ability to advance such an agenda."
Their resolution said, "It is unfair to working families to have the principal Federal department responsible for worker protections to be singled out and held hostage."

HEADLINE: Two Reports Show Inflation Is in Check

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Two more economic reports showed that inflationary pressures remained at bay last month.
The Labor Department said today that consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in January, below the consensus forecast of three-tenths of 1 percent, as food prices fell and price increases for energy moderated despite a 4.8 percent jump in the cost of natural gas -- the largest monthly rise since record-keeping began in 1952. 
 Consumer prices at the core level, which excludes food and energy, also rose one-tenth of 1 percent, below expectations of an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent.
In December, consumer prices grew three-tenths of 1 percent. The increase in December's core rate was revised upward, to two-tenths of 1 percent from the gain of one-tenth of 1 percent reported originally.
During all of 1996, prices rose 3.3 percent, up from 2.5 percent in 1995. The core rate increased 2.6 percent, slower than its increase of 3 percent during 1995.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said that Americans' weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, fell 2 percent in January -- the largest decline since August 1973. Earnings had risen eight-tenths of 1 percent in December. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations.
Average weekly hours worked decreased 2 percent in January, while average hourly earnings rose one-tenth of 1 percent.
The two sets of data followed other recent indications that inflation was under control. The Government said last week that producer prices decreased three-tenths of 1 percent in January -- the first monthly decline in more than two years.
Another report issued a week before that showed that average hourly earnings, calculated as part of the monthly employment report, rose only 1 cent in January, to $12.06.
"We're in a sweet spot," said Scott Brown, an economist at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. "The economy is growing moderately with little sign of inflation."
The reports suggested that the Federal Reserve has little reason to raise interest rates. John Silvia, chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments, said before today's reports that "we've had wage increases and some productivity increases, but we haven't had overall price increases."
Last week, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, Gary Stern, acknowledged that policy makers at the Fed "haven't seen an uptick in core inflation."
Still, he said in a speech, with the economy near what the Fed defines as full employment, employers are finding it "increasingly difficult to hire and retain" workers, making it "hardly surprising" that wages are creeping up.
Despite the favorable price data, bond prices fell today. The statistics for January were outweighed by concern about the future impact on inflation of the low jobless rate and continued economic growth.
By category in January, energy prices, which account for about 7 percent of the Consumer Price Index over all, increased eight-tenths of 1 percent, including the 4.8 percent jump in natural gas prices.
Elsewhere in the energy sector, the American Automobile Association said on Tuesday that retail gasoline prices fell during the last month, the first decline in five months. A 16 percent drop in the price of crude oil since Jan. 8 helped spur the decline.
Food prices, which account for about 16 percent of the index, decreased three-tenths of 1 percent, the largest drop since June 1993, as prices of fruits, vegetables, dairy products and beef fell.
Recent reports from the Agriculture Department suggest Americans are not likely to pay more for beef in coming months. Ranchers shipped a record number of cattle to feedlots in January, Government figures showed, a sign that plentiful beef supplies and favorable prices await consumers this spring.
The increase, the sixth in the last seven months, has come as corn prices have fallen more than 50 percent from last summer. That allows feedlot operators to make a profit on cattle, which are fed a protein-rich diet of corn for four months before they are sent to market.
The Commodity Research Bureau index, a gauge of inflation, has risen about 2.5 percent since Jan. 31. However, the Goldman, Sachs & Company industrial-metals commodity index has declined 1.7 percent since Jan. 31.
Today's consumer price data also showed that transportation costs fell two-tenths of 1 percent in January, as airline fares dropped. Entertainment costs were unchanged, the cost of medical care grew two-tenths of 1 percent, housing costs rose three-tenths of 1 percent and apparel costs increased four-tenths of 1 percent.
