HEADLINE: Stocks Fall As Volatility Continues

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices held steady for much of the day yesterday before slipping in late-afternoon trading in yet another demonstration of how a big bull market can swing wildly.
The volatility of the last couple of days -- in which the market has seen two 60-point swings in the last hour of trading -- is characteristic for a stock market that is bulging beyond belief, analysts said. 
 "You're going to have volatility like you've never seen before," Ralph Acampora, a market analyst with Prudential Securities, said. "There's a lot of nervousness out there. People are trigger happy. There's a lot of program trading and a lot of rotation out there."
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 47.33 points, or nearly seven-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 7,020.13. And the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 3.80 points, about five-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 812.49.
Part of the market's downturn was attributed to a weak bond market, which shrugged off a report from the Labor Department that showed the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent last month, after a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in December, another indication that inflationary pressures are tame. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.57 percent, from 6.54 percent on Tuesday.
"We had some good inflation news and the bond market went down, not up," Hugh Johnson, an investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation, said. "That led me to believe that long-term interest rates had declined as much as they are going to decline. I think that more than anything was noticed by portfolio managers."
Analysts said that stock prices might have also been affected by Government figures that showed that the United States trade defecit surged 29.6 percent in December. Weaker exports, caused in part by a stronger dollar, might be some indication that the economy could grow slower than anticipated in the future.
Still, stock prices were stable until late in the day, when the Dow plummeted 60 points, before recovering some of its loss. Among the losers were: Procter & Gamble, American Express and I.B.M. Procter & Gamble was down 2 3/8, to 127 1/8; American Express lost 1 7/8, to 67 7/8, and I.B.M. fell 1 5/8, to 143 5/8. Philip Morris was one of just six gainers, up 1 7/8, to 133 1/8.
While several other large-capitalization stocks were hit -- First Union was down 3 1/8, to 92 1/2, and BankAmerica fell 1 3/4, to 120 7/8 -- analysts noted that the market held up well yesterday, recovering from what could have become a rout after the market slipped.
Technology stocks were buoyed early in the session by Hewlett-Packard, which released better-than-expected earnings after the market closed on Tuesday. Shares of Hewlett-Packard, the most actively traded issue yesterday, rose 4 9/16, to 56 3/4.
The rise in the technology sector bolstered the Nasdaq market, before it retreated to end down 0.21 point at 1,365.58. One indication of the market's strength yesterday was the advance-decline line on the New York Stock Exchange, where winners just barely edged losers, 1,293 to 1,285. Volume on the Big Board was 520.9 million shares.
Yet with the S.& P. up nearly 10 percent this year and Dow up almost 9 percent, analysts said that they expect this year's rapid pace to slow considerably.
"Common sense says we're in for a spell, either a correction or an extended period of consolidation," Mr. Johnson at First Albany said. "You don't have to be a market analyst to know that."

HEADLINE: Europe's Rail Freight on New Path;
Revamping With Technology, Competition and U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Feb. 19

 BODY:
You wouldn't think Europe could learn anything about running railroads from the United States. Europe has the bullet-like TGV's and tilting trains; the United States has Amtrak.
But while it is true that European passenger service is a heavily used showcase of comfort and speed, freight shipping is another world entirely. Borders are bottlenecks where shipments must be hauled off one train and put on another to accommodate changes in track gauge; there are three widths in Europe, not to mention seven electrical standards and a jumble of signal systems. Featherbedding is still common. And customers can be few and far between: rail's share of total freight movement in Britain has slipped to just 6 percent, measured by tonnage and distance, compared with 41 percent in the United States. 
 In short, the painful shakeout that reshaped the American freight industry in the 1980's has not yet happened in Europe.
"It's like the United States 10 years ago," said Matty Vanderbroek, a rail specialist in the London office of Mercer Management Consulting, a transport consulting firm.
But now that Europe is preparing for economic unification, its planners and government leaders are playing catch-up in a big way, taking more than a page or two from across the Atlantic. They are introducing new rail technology, such as so-called intermodal systems that move containers by road and rail. They are breaking up old inefficient state rail monopolies into commercially viable pieces. And in an increasing number of cases, they are even opening the door to outside competition -- including American companies.
The early arrivals include the Wisconsin Central Transportation Corporation, a specialist in turning around troubled freight companies, which joined several partners to snap up Britain's freight system in 1994, when the Government sold off its nationalized rail service. Also here are the CSX Corporation, the giant Richmond-based rail and shipping company, and its Sea-Land subsidiary, which are in joint ventures with the Europeans to introduce American-style freight shuttles. And Mercer Management, which is based in Boston and is a unit of Marsh & McLennan, was sought out by the European Union for its advice on rail freight deregulation.
Indeed, the Americans are bringing not only a new infusion of capital but also a rich trove of expertise.
Asked about the contribution of American partners like CSX, Rene Holdert, a spokesman for NS Cargo, a Dutch freight company, could only marvel. "The whole administration has changed," he said. "It's now all computerized: the trading and tracing of rail cars, for example, so you can always find a car for a client, even if it's very late. Under the old-fashioned national systems, with phones and faxes, you relied on offices, and they were often empty late at night."
Because of all the changes, both imported and home grown, "the whole system, beginning with the infrastructure, is starting to move," said Maria Lahaye-Geusen, an economist at Kombiverkehr, a company in Frankfurt set up by the German trucking industry to develop combined rail and road services.
For all this, that movement is not going to come smoothly. Europe's powerful labor unions are fighting a rear-guard action that guarantees many tense moments and more than a few costly disruptions. Earlier this month, for example, rail workers in France staged a daylong strike to protest Government plans to restructure the unprofitable state-owned SNCF line.
The underlying catalyst for change is the realization that Europe simply cannot afford any longer to have such a costly and inefficient freight system.
In 1994, according to European Commission figures, the cumulative debt of Europe's railways came to $135 billion, an amount that has grown since. In France and Italy, railway debt was equivalent, respectively, to 2.6 percent and 5 percent of gross domestic product.
To be sure, much of that debt came from the generous financing of passenger service, which has benefited disproportionately from upgrades to the rail system. But at least the passenger lines attracted more and more customers.
With the decline of European heavy industries like coal and steel, however, major bulk freight customers were lost to the railroads. At the same time, European manufacturers of everything from cars to computers have been desperate for lower transport costs, to remain competitive in an increasingly global economy. Many turned to the army of new trucking companies from formerly Communist Eastern Europe that flooded the West, offering dirt-cheap rates, particularly in Germany and Austria.
Meanwhile, as governments scramble to cut spending to meet the requirements for a single European currency, the days of endless rail subsidies are fast dwindling.
"Subsidies have to be stopped and rail operators have to keep up their own socks," said Mr. Vanderbroek at Mercer Management.
Late last year, the European Commission's senior transport official, Neil Kinnock, the former head of Britain's Labor Party, warned the 15 member governments that future rail assistance would be subject to commission approval, as subsidies to airlines and other industries already are, and that restrictions would affect freight and passenger lines equally. Beginning in 1998, Mr. Kinnock said, railway subsidies would be authorized only if accompanied by strict cost reduction proposals.
Anticipating such an end game, several countries, including Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands, have cut up their national rail systems into divisions for passengers, freight and the maintenance of infrastructure like tracks and signal systems. France plans similar steps, despite the union resistance.
Railway executives and government planners acknowledge that much remains to be done. But already the first fruits of change are evident. After watching rail's share of total freight movement in the region slump by half in 20 years, to 16 percent, the railways have stanched the hemorrhaging of freight to trucking. (They have been helped by growing public concern over the trucking industry's contribution to highway congestion. To curb environmental damage, some countries have imposed weight restrictions on trucks.)
In some cases, the railroads are even clawing back business, most notably in the intermodal sector.
Britain is ahead of the curve in not only dividing up its national rail freight service into regional companies, but in then selling the lot off to the investor group led by Wisconsin Central. In December, the Government named Wisconsin Central the preferred bidder in the proposed privatization of Rail Freight Distribution, the company on the British end that operates freight deliveries through the English Channel tunnel.
"In total, what we purchased was profitable; it wasn't a basket case," said Tom Power, Wisconsin Central's chief financial officer, who helped engineer the deal for the regional companies, now known as the English, Welsh and Scottish Railway.
Lack of investment in recent years, Mr. Power said, helped cause rail's share of the freight market to slip. Also to blame were sluggish marketing and rates that he said were roughly double those in America.
Wisconsin Central, which is based in Rosemont, Ill., hung on to most of its British management, but added several American marketing experts to instill more aggressive selling techniques. To bring prices down, it made big equipment investments, including the purchase of 250 locomotives that the General Motors Corporation will deliver over the next 10 years. In placing the $407 million order, it snubbed expensive European suppliers.
"You've got to get the costs out," Mr. Power said.
The Europeans are still trying to get the costs out when it comes to incompatible operating systems, particularly differences in track sizes.
Thus, when Adam Opel, the G.M. unit in Germany, ships components to its plants in Spain, the trains must halt at the French-Spanish border while the rail car bodies are shifted to different undercarriages.
To gradually overcome national boundaries, Mr. Kinnock of the European Commission recently appealed for the establishment of international "freight freeways," which would be as open to international freight traffic as Europe's highways are to trucking. Some rail companies and shippers are already seizing the initiative.
In 1994, Sea-Land joined partners in Germany and the Netherlands in a joint venture called European Rail Shuttle that operates freight service between the port of Rotterdam and industrial regions of Germany and northern Italy. Such shuttles, which are cheaper to operate because they transfer trains back and forth between two destinations without having to shuffle the rail cars, also allow the railroads to drop costly branch lines that generate little traffic and make better use of main lines.
Six days a week now, hundreds of truck-size containers filled with products for export are hauled from Milan to huge docks in Rotterdam, while similar mountains of containers ride 50-car shuttle trains back across the Alps to Milan.
Last year, Sea-Land's parent company, CSX, teamed up with NS Cargo, the Dutch freight company, and the freight division of Deutsche Bahn, the German national railway, in a similar joint venture called NDX to establish rival shuttle services. In January, NDX started a Rotterdam-to-Munich shuttle, and in April it will inaugurate a line from Hamburg to Milan.
Cees Van Elk, the marketing director for NDX, said the shuttle's rates were "certainly competitive with trucks," and from 10 to 20 percent lower than the cost of delivering individual containers by rail.
European competitors are quickly following suit. In Germany, Kombiverkehr, the trucking cooperative, operates shuttles between German cities and industrial belts around Milan and Barcelona, Spain.
"We're using intermodal wherever it's expedient, and price isn't everything," said Heino Bultmann, director of railway freight for the giant German shipping group, Danzas.
Big customers with a choice of carriers agree. Benetton, the apparel company that ships clothing from factories in northern Italy to outlets in about 120 countries, has been gradually increasing the amount of products shipped by rail and truck combination. By last year, that method accounted for about 52 percent of the 700 containers Benetton ships every day.
Intermodal costs are "more or less those of trucking," said Giancarlo Chiodini, Benetton's director of logistics, adding that rail freight had the additional advantage of being less subject to weather conditions and traffic jams. "It's become a philosophy with us," he said.
That philosophy is bound to spread as the changes brought by the private sector filter through Europe, said Mr. Power of Wisconsin Central.
"The customers will be so much better off," he said. "Governments don't know how to run railroads."

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Campaign Against Youth Crime

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Signaling the new emphasis of his anti-crime measures in a second term, President Clinton today visited a city that has seen an impressive reduction in juvenile crime statistics and declared that the battle against youth crime "has got to become our top law-enforcement priority."
Pointing to population trends, Mr. Clinton said United States school enrollment had swelled to 52 million and was running above baby boom levels, numbers that he said could hold the potential for a youth crime epidemic. 
 "So we know we've got about six years to turn this juvenile crime thing around or our country is going to be living with chaos," he said in an address at the Boston campus of the University of Massachusetts. "And my successors will not be giving speeches about the wonderful opportunities of the global economy; they'll be trying to keep body and soul together for people on the streets of these cities."
Mr. Clinton also urged Congress to approve a $495 million two-year campaign against youth crime. The program would include $200 million in grants to allow localities to hire new prosecutors for juvenile crime and develop task forces to fight gangs, $60 million to finance 1,000 new after-school programs and $75 million for anti-truancy and crime prevention programs.
The President called for expanding controls on handguns so that youths who turn 18 and have juvenile records of violent crime are blocked from buying handguns. Adults who commit felonies are prohibited from possessing firearms, but juvenile records are not scrutinized in such purchases.
And he proposed changes in law to make it easier for prosecutors to fight gangs through increased penalties, new authority to seize property in crimes of violence, racketeering and obstruction of justice and an easing of the burden of proof in certain car-jacking cases and Federal racketeering cases.
Mr. Clinton highlighted his proposals in a city that has had marked success in fighting juvenile violence. From 1990 to 1995 juvenile homicides in Boston fell by 80 percent and no juvenile has been killed by gunfire here since July 1995. From 1993 to 1995, the juvenile arrest rate for aggravated assault and battery with a firearm dropped 65 percent.
Police and public officials attribute the improvement to innovative and inexpensive strategies like one in which probation officers team with police officers to visit the homes of youths on probation to insure that they abide by their curfew and probation terms. Like New York, Boston has also focused on enforcing statutes against graffiti, truancy, noise and other so-called quality-of-life crimes in cutting the crime rate.
City officials also intensified their focus on gangs and guns after computer-aided research from Harvard University found that three-quarters of juvenile killers and their victims had been involved with gangs and that the authorities could identify firearms dealers who made significant numbers of illegal gun sales to young people.
"We know that if this can be done in Boston, "Mr. Clinton said, "it can be done in every community, in every neighborhood of every size in the United States. And we ask the United States Congress to do what you've done here in Massachusetts: cross all party lines, throw politics away, throw the speeches in the trash can, join hands. Let's do what works and make America the safe place it has to be."
Congressional Republicans have proposed a three-year program against youth crime, a $1.5 billion plan that would give grants to state and local governments for applying adult penalties to the most dangerous, violent juveniles. The grants could be used to build or expand juvenile detention centers to develop alternative sanction programs.
But Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said Boston's experience showed that youth crime could be attacked through community policing and other community-based programs.
"It's not just about building more prisons or toughening law enforcement or providing more cops," Mr. McCurry said. "It's also about a strategy of engagement in the community so that young people understand that adults care about their lives and are holding them accountable to more civil norms of behavior."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Grew Sharply Last Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in December, bringing the imbalance for the full year to $114.2 billion, the largest gap since 1988, the Commerce Department reported today.
Lower exports and higher imports contributed about equally to the December expansion, which analysts said partly reflected the sharp rise in the international value of the dollar. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the finance ministers of other major countries began an effort earlier this month to restrain the dollar's rise. 
 The strong dollar makes foreign goods more affordable for American consumers but makes this country's products less competitive abroad. Detroit's auto makers have been complaining about inroads into their markets made by Japanese producers who are taking advantage of the cheaper yen to keep prices down.
Today's report, though unlikely to prompt even a subtle policy response, nevertheless did put a fresh focus on the question of how the trade sector will affect the economy's performance this year. Exports, though accounting for only about an eighth of United States economic activity, have long been a big contributor. But growth in exports slowed to 6.2 percent last year, half the 1994 advance.
"This is probably the biggest wild card," William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, said. "When the gap is widening, it's a drain on incomes" that has a dampening effect similar to a tax increase.
Largely reflecting a swing in the trade account, magnified by statistical deficiencies, Goldman, Sachs projects a 1.8 percent increase in economic growth for the current quarter, compared with 4.7 percent in the final three months of 1996.
The research department at Merrill Lynch said trade was currently having a negative impact on the economy and its impact would be "neutral at best through the rest of 1997."
Mr. Rubin, after publicly supporting a stronger dollar for months, announced earlier this month that he felt the dollar had risen far enough. The latest trade deficit figures were unlikely to affect that position, analysts said.
The Government tally showed the December deficit swelled to nearly $10.3 billion from a November total that was revised downward to $7.9 billion, or $500 million less than the department initially reported.
Imports of goods and services surged to a record $81.7 billion, $1.2 billion higher than in November, the bulk of the increase going for crude oil and petroleum products. This reflected both greater volumes and higher prices, the latter, at least, subsequently subsiding.
Exports, which hit a record in November, eased $1.1 billion, much of the decline reflecting lower foreign sales of soybeans and corn at the end of a year when early prospects of tight supplies gave way to bountiful harvests.
But even as the overall deficit widened by nearly 30 percent in December, there was a narrowing with both China and Japan, the sources of much of this country's trade friction.
The gap with China shrank $400 million, to $2.6 billion, in December, while surging 16.9 percent for the year, to $39.5 billion, or slightly higher than with Canada and Mexico combined. The United States buys more than four times as much from China as it sells there and exported slightly less last year to China than to Australia.
In June, Congress will be called upon to extend China's trading rights for another year, a process not now expected to prove difficult but that is nevertheless likely to at least be deferred until after China's takeover of Hong Kong at midyear.
As for Japan, the American deficit edged down a slight $50 million, to $4.3 billion, in December but shrank markedly for the year. The 1996 deficit was $47.7 billion, or 19.4 percent below the 1995 total. This was the second consecutive decline, and the smallest gap since 1991.
Unlike the aggregate statistics, those for individual countries are not adjusted for seasonal variation, nor do they include services, which generally offset a large part of the deficit in merchandise.
The Coalition of Service Industries estimated that travel, transportation, royalties and other services generated a United States surplus last year equal to about 40 percent of this country's goods deficit with Japan but only about 2 percent of the goods deficit with China.
The overall deficit with Canada widened in December by $600 million, to $2.3 billion, while the deficit with Mexico was halved, to $700 million.
For the full year, however, the shortfall with Mexico climbed to a record $16.2 billion, a development seen by critics as a failure of the North American Free Trade Agreement and by the Clinton Administration as temporary fallout from unrelated Mexican economic problems, including peso devaluation in late 1994. The devaluation spurred a severe recession, which drastically cut the market for American imports.
Michael Strauss, chief economist for Sanwa Securities in New York, was not bothered by today's report, declaring that the dollar's strength "has not had a dramatic impact" on trade flows and contending that a resurgence of exports would risk excessive demand pressures in this country.
But Lawrence Chimerine, managing director and chief economist for the Economic Strategy Institute, took a dim view of what he called a "largely structural" trade deficit that is likely to rise another $10 billion to $15 billion this year.
He said that the deficit with Japan had bottomed out, that the gap with China was still rising rapidly, that European growth remained sluggish and that the nation's oil bill would keep rising.
He concluded that 1997 looked "awfully bad on trade."

HEADLINE: Unions Woo Business District Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
As business improvement districts multiply around New York City, they have become a target of union organizers, who complain that the workers hired by some districts to sweep sidewalks and empty trash cans are underpaid and unfairly treated.
Employees of one of the largest and most visible districts, the Grand Central Partnership, are to vote tomorrow on whether to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which has mounted a campaign to woo workers at two-thirds of the 34 districts in the city. 
 Officials of the districts, which use assessments collected from businesses to finance cleanup efforts and security, say they pay the going rate for their unskilled workers. If union efforts succeed in pushing up wages, they say, some districts will probably cut back or even shut down.
Labor leaders want street sweepers to receive at least $12 an hour, asserting that many get only $6 or $7 and cannot support their families on that. They are particularly angry over the wages because they believe much of the work done by the improvement districts should be performed by unionized city sanitation workers, who earn two or three times as much.
The union battle is not the first controversy to arise from the proliferation of business improvement districts in the city. Some community leaders have questioned whether the districts in effect create two classes of neighborhoods, with wealthier areas paying for private services while poorer neighborhoods must rely on city government. And two years ago, the Grand Central Partnership lost a Federal grant after being accused of having its workers harass and intimidate homeless people.
While wages appear to be the overriding issue in the union fight, some of the more than 500 workers at improvement districts in the city complain that they are exploited and accorded little respect. They say that, even on frigid days, they are prohibited from wearing coats over their sweatshirt uniforms. And though they often have to pick up syringes or handle trash bags holding chemicals, they say the gloves they are given are too thin to protect them.
"They treat us like children," said Sean Dancy, who has been a sweeper for the Grand Central Partnership for five years. "They yell at you if they think you haven't cleaned your route properly. They made promises that they'd buy us boots, and then we had to buy boots ourselves. They told us they'd give us raises, and then the raises often didn't come through."
So far, the teamsters drive has met with limited success. The union has won only one vote at a BID, gaining a 44-to-6 majority at the 34th Street Partnership in December 1995. The teamsters have lost unionization votes in BID's that cover Fifth Avenue, Eighth Street, 14th Street, 125th Street, the Fashion Center and Metrotech in Brooklyn.
Workers who voted against the union cited a variety of reasons: they did not want to pay union dues, they disliked the teamsters' reputation or they feared that their business district might contract out their jobs if a union was voted in.
But labor organizers complain bitterly that management has often acted illegally to keep the union out, dismissing workers who support the teamsters, interrogating workers about whether they back the union and threatening workers that they might lose their jobs if the teamsters were voted in.
Workers at the Grand Central Partnership, a BID surrounding the rail terminal, voted 25 to 24 last winter against the union. But the partnership agreed to allow a new union vote this week after the teamsters complained to the National Labor Relations Board that management had repeatedly threatened workers.
The board has charged several BID's with illegal dismissals and intimidation, and the cases are pending before administrative law judges.
For their part, executives at the improvement districts contend that the union's wage demands are unreasonable. Dan Biederman, president of the Grand Central Partnership, which has a budget of more than $10 million a year, said: "Property owners have voluntarily set up BID's and want to make their contribution to improve the quality of life in New York. But they do not want to pay for an effort that will cost two or three times as much."
The teamsters have not made organizing the Times Square BID a priority because the district's workers are recovering alcoholics and drug addicts in a rehabilitation program.
Rob Hill, the teamsters official heading the organizing drive, holds out the contract won at 34th Street as a model for what business improvement district workers can achieve by unionizing. In July 1998, the contract will lift all 34th Street workers with two years' experience to $11.50 an hour, almost doubling the wages of workers who started six months ago at $6 an hour.
"The union has made a big difference," said Allan Simpson, a Jamaican immigrant and sweeper who voted in favor of the teamsters at 34th Street. "Before, they often said they didn't have money in the budget for a raise, but that has changed. We won a better medical plan and an education plan."
Mr. Biederman, who heads not just the Grand Central BID but also the 34th Street and Bryant Park districts, denies that the 34th Street workers have gained a better deal than those at Grand Central. He said the Grand Central workers start at $6 an hour, jumping to about $8.50 after two years and $10 or more after five. They also receive a $500 Christmas bonus, about $300 a year in subway tokens and contributions to a pension fund.
"We know what the market is because every day, we have guys begging us to work at $6 an hour," Mr. Biederman said.
Teamsters union officials acknowledge that sweepers in Mr. Biederman's districts are better off than some others. For example, workers in the 125th Street, the 14th Street and the Eighth districts often earn less than $7.50 an hour after two years.
Those three districts, along with 15 others, including Metrotech and Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, have hired the same contractor, Atlantic Maintenance, to do their cleaning. In December, workers at all 18 Atlantic Maintenance districts voted together and rejected the teamsters.
The teamsters are challenging the results, contending that the management systematically intimidated workers.

HEADLINE: Leo Rosten, a Writer Who Helped Yiddish Make Its Way Into English, Is Dead at 88

BYLINE: By MARGALIT FOX 

 BODY:
Leo Rosten, the writer, scholar and language maven who introduced millions of Americans to the deep lexical pleasures of chutzpah and shlemiel and kibitz and nosh, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.
Mr. Rosten, who wrote dozens of works of fiction and nonfiction in a career that spanned more than six decades, was best known for his books celebrating Jewish language, humor and culture, including "The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N" (1937) and "The Joys of Yiddish" (1968). 
 "The Joys of Yiddish" was a fat lexicon of expressions that had elbowed their way into ordinary English idioms, endearments, epithets and jokes. As Mr. Rosten described the book's purpose in his introduction: "It illustrates how beautifully a language reflects the variety and vitality of life itself; and how the special culture of the Jews, their distinctive style of thought, their subtleties of feeling, are reflected in Yiddish; and how this in turn has enhanced and enriched the English we use today."
Over the years, "The Joys of Yiddish" has become the de facto standard reference work on the language, serving as a bridge between the world of Mr. Rosten's forebears and that of the more assimilated readers of our own age. Although the book quickly became a best seller, the critic Irving Howe kibitzed Mr. Rosten in The New York Times Book Review for uprooting Yiddishisms from their larger cultural context and for shlepping out Borscht Belt humor that was already old in his grandparents' day.
"Let Howe write 10 jokes and let me write 10 jokes, and you'll see the difference," Mr. Rosten countered.
But in the end, it was Mr. Rosten's mother -- who then? -- who had the last word. When "The Joys of Yiddish" was published, she telephoned her son the writer. "You have saved Yiddish," she told him. "A leben auf dein keppeleh" -- a benediction that translates literally as "a life on your little head."
What united Mr. Rosten's output was his finely tuned ear for language in all its richness. In his books, he guided readers through the nuanced worlds of meaning that lie hidden beneath a joke, an idiom or a vocal inflection. And what he revealed was nearly always good for a laugh.
"Humor is an indication of a wholeness of character structure," Mr. Rosten said in a 1981 interview. "Indeed, I would say that one of the requirements for sanity is a sense of humor -- and its absence is crippling."
Mr. Rosten's delight in the comic possibilities of language was nowhere more evident than on the lips of his most famous creation, Hyman Kaplan, whom critics have compared to the comic characters of Dickens and Shakespeare. Inspired by a former night-school student from Mr. Rosten's own teaching days, Kaplan, a Mr. Malaprop by way of Ellis Island, embodied both the perils and the pride of the immigrant experience. Hyman Kaplan made his debut in 1935 in a series of New Yorker stories; the stories were later published in book form under the pseudonym Leonard Q. Ross.
Plump, middle-aged and possessed of a warped linguistic brilliance, the pompous Hyman Kaplan sat front and center in the beginners' class of the American Night Preparatory School for Adults, where he signed his name in a barrage of asterisks and ritually tortured his long-suffering teacher, Mr. Parkhill, with his compound fractures of English. The most famous "tree American wriders," Kaplan announced proudly in class, were "Jeck Laundon," "Valt Viterman" and "Mocktvain" (the author, for the unenlightened, of "Hawk L. Barry-Feen").
Reviewing the book in The New York Times Book Review in 1937, Robert Van Gelder noted that Kaplan "overrides all conventions and even the laughter of enemies, twisting the language of Shakespeare and Milton to his will as casually as we might twist the language of Confucius -- if we knew enough about it to catch hold of it at all."
Leo Calvin Rosten was born on April 11, 1908, in Lodz, Poland, the son of Samuel and Ida Freundlich Rosten, and immigrated with his family to the United States in 1911. Reared in Chicago, he was the product of the immigrant, working-class Jewish milieu that was home to a generation of Hyman Kaplans. A voracious reader with a wide-ranging intellect, the young Mr. Rosten set out to be a political scientist. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Chicago in 1930 and his doctorate from the same institution in 1937, followed by postgraduate study at the London School of Economics and Political Science.
In a 1981 interview, Mr. Rosten recalled the "passion for clarity" that first attracted him to the social sciences: "Sooner or later I would have been driven by the need to find out something . . . about how people act, why they do what they do, how society is organized, why there are wars and depressions, murders and prejudice and fanaticism." He added: "It wasn't enough to say, 'These are things I don't understand.' I had to try, at least, to understand them."
As a young doctorate in the teeth of the Depression, Mr. Rosten was forced to abandon his scholarly career temporarily and take a night job teaching English to new immigrants. There, he encountered a student -- a man named Kaplan -- who would inspire one of the most memorable comic figures of 20th-century fiction.
"I walked out of that first night's class in a daze," Mr. Rosten said in 1937. "That man Kaplan had taught me a great deal. I thought the conjugation of verbs meant saying, 'Drink, drank, drunk.' I asked Kaplan to conjugate 'fail,' and he said, 'Fail, failed, bankrupt.' I was stunned."
The indomitable Kaplan reappeared for two sequels, "The Return of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N" (1959) and "O K*A*P*L*A*N! My K*A*P*L*A*N!" (1976). In 1968, "The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N" was briefly reincarnated as a Broadway musical, staged by George Abbott and starring Tom Bosley, which opened to pleasant if unspectacular notices.
Mr. Rosten's other books include "The Washington Correspondents" (1937), a study of the Capitol press corps; "Hollywood: The Movie Colony, the Movie Makers" (1941), one of the first sociological examinations of the film industry; the mystery novels "Silky" (1979) and "King Silky" (1980), and "The Joys of Yinglish" (1989). Mr. Rosten was also the author of numerous screenplays, including "All Through the Night" and "Sleep, My Love."
During World War II, Mr. Rosten held a variety of Government positions, including deputy director of the Office of War Information and chief of the Office of War Information's motion pictures division, and in the late 1940's worked for the Rand Corporation. He also taught at Yale, Columbia and the New School for Social Research, and in 1960 was a Ford visiting professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley.
Mr. Rosten's first marriage, to Priscilla Ann Mead, ended in divorce. He is survived by two daughters from that marriage, Margaret Muir of Bowdoinham, Me., and Madeline Lee of New York City, and six grandchildren. Mr. Rosten's second wife, the former Gertrude Zimi, died in 1995; a son from his first marriage, Philip, died last year.
Surveying his career in 1981, Mr. Rosten seemed untroubled by the inability of critics to find a single literary pigeonhole that would contain his ecumenical interests: "I remember a literary agent once scolding me, saying that I was foolish to spread myself over so many fields. He said, 'The critics don't know what to call you: a novelist, a social scientist, an essayist, a humorist, a social commentator.' I said, 'That's their problem.' "
 
From a Language Maven, the Wry Wisdom of a Culture
Leo Rosten described "The Joys of Yiddish" (McGraw-Hill) as "A relaxed lexicon of Yiddish, Hebrew and Yinglish words often encountered in English, plus dozens that ought to be, with serendipitous excursions into Jewish humor, habits, holidays, history, religion, ceremonies, folklore and cuisine; the whole generously garnished with stories, anecdotes, epigrams, Talmudic quotations, folk sayings and jokes -- from the days of the Bible to those of the beatnik." Some abbreviated entries follow:
 
GOTTENYU! "Dear God," "Oh dear God" or "How-else-can-I-describe my feelings!" Gottenyu! is an exclamation that is uttered with affection, despair or irony, to lend force to a sentence by adding fervor to sentiment.
It is a warm, informal, personal way of enlisting God's attention, not invoking his aid. Nor does it describe the Lord in any way.
It is a colloquial epithet used, for the most part, without really meaning God, per Se (I guess I must capitalize Se here). "Were we happy! Gottenyu!" "Gottenyu! -- you never saw such a mess!" "Was I scared? Miserable? Oh, Gottenyu!" A common phrase is "Zeeser Gottenyu," "Sweet God."
A charming dictum has it that, under stress, Jews explain, 'Oy, Mamanyu!" When stress becomes fear they cry, "Oy, Tatenyu!" ("tata" being father). And when things really get tough, Jews cry, "Oy, Gottenyu!" Note the realistic stratification of power.

SHLEP 1. To drag or pull or lag behind. "Don't shlep all those packages; let the store deliver them." Pick up your feet; don't shlep."
2. To stall, drag one's heels, delay; to move or perform slowly, lazily, inefficiently. "At the rate you're shlepping along, we'll never finish."
Mrs. Hoffenstein, visiting London, went shopping at the famous confectioners, Fortnum & Mason. She brought jars of marmalade, biscuits, tins of cookies and candies, to take back to her hotel.
"And where," asked the striped-trousered salesman, "shall we deliver these, madam?"
"Don't bother. I'll carry them."
"But madam, we'll be happy to deliver this order --"
"I know, but I don't mind, I'm from the Bronx."
"I understand, madam," said the clerk, "but still -- why shlep?"

YENTA Pronounced YEN-ta, to rhyme with "bent a." Yenta, I am told, was a perfectly acceptable name for a lady, derived from the Italian gentile -- until some ungracious yenta gave it a bad name.
1. A woman of low origins or vulgar manners; a shrew; a shallow, coarse termagant. "She is the biggest yenta on the block."
2. A gossipy woman, a scandal-spreader; a rumormonger; one unable to keep a secret or respect a confidence. In this sense, men are sometimes described as yentas.
Two yentas meet in Miami.
"So tell me, Molly, have you been through the menopause?"
"The menopause? I haven't even been through the Fontainebleau yet."
One of the more amusing buttons worn by the button-happy hippie young reads: MARCEL PROUST IS A YENTA.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Japan Rewards Borrowing, And the Yen Keeps Falling

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
There's a reason the Japanese yen comes across as the weakling of the currency markets these days: Japan, with its struggling economy, frail stock market and cheap funds, has become a place to borrow, not invest.
"Here in Japan you are in an extraordinary situation, and that extraordinary factor is that money is free," said Jesper Koll, an economist at J. P. Morgan Securities Asia. With rock-bottom interest rates essentially offset by inflation, money has been a free commodity, Mr. Koll said, quickly adding: "As a result, it is flowing out of the country. Are we not now just witnessing the making of another bubble?" 
 So while some in the United States are preoccupied with how strong the dollar should be, here in Japan the headache of the moment is how weak the yen will get.
Every few days, a Japanese official frets over the decline of the yen, which, in percentage terms, traveled twice as far against the dollar in January as it had moved on average each month last year.
Yet, Japanese officials might be relieved that investors have only recently acted on an increasingly legitimate reason for a weaker yen: the gap in interest rates between their country and the United States.
People are pumping money out of Japan in search of higher yields, fueling stock and bond markets in New York and elsewhere, several economists here say. Investors come to Japan to raise funds, then convert their yen borrowings into dollars. When such activity turns into a flood, the yen's value slides.
Investments from Japan in dollar assets more than tripled last year, to about $43 billion. But many economists and analysts say that those figures dwarf the amount of yen borrowing, much of which cannot be traced when funds are raised in yen in Europe.
Such borrowing could run as high as $40 billion to $60 billion a month, Mr. Koll said. Partly as a result, he said, the yen could plummet to 160 against the dollar or beyond. The yen settled here today at 123.64 to the dollar.
Of course, there have been fears of a yen collapse before. Early last summer, a pattern of deterioration in Japanese trade figures alarmed some central bank officials, who worried that investors might react rashly, dumping yen and bringing about a collapse of the currency.
The yen certainly weakened, along with a decline in Japan's current-account surplus, the broadest measure of trade, but there was no free fall.
Some economists now suggest that given the state of the economy the yen may be headed toward a resistance level of 130 to the dollar. [In New York late Wednesday, the yen declined to 124.46 to the dollar.]
The role of interest rates becomes crucial. Japan's official discount rate, the interest rate the central bank charges commercial banks for overnight funds, stands at a record low one-half of 1 percent, and the rate for overnight funds secured with bonds has often hovered below that level. Factor in an inflation rate in Japan of one-half of 1 percent, and borrowed funds here are in theory not merely free, but offer a dividend.
By comparison, 10-year United States Treasury instruments have been yielding 6.25 to 6.5 percent, so that over the last year, a cross-border investor borrowing under long-term arrangements with Japanese banks has made a nice profit, not even counting foreign-exchange gains when switching back from dollars to yen to repay the loan.
When rates in Japan were lowered in September 1995, economists expected the easy monetary policy to be temporary, lasting just long enough to help the ailing Japanese banks pull themselves out of a morass of bad debt.
But the policy has largely persisted, and now, any rise in interest rates could crush the chance of economic recovery. So economists say that in the near future they do not expect a rate increase, which would be one of the few effective ways to begin stemming the yen's decline. If interest rates remain low, investors are more likely to turn to Japan as a steady source of cheap funds.
Asset prices in Japan remain remarkably high by international standards. Still, certain prices may be equalizing a bit between what is charged in New York and in Tokyo. Take, for instance, the Big Mac index, an idea introduced by The Economist magazine and that has caught on somewhat with practicing economists.
The equilibrium exchange rate, known as purchasing-power parity, is the rate that in theory makes the price of a Big Mac, McDonald's namesake hamburger, the same in the United States as in Japan. These days, a Big Mac in Tokyo costs 280 yen. At today's exchange rate, that makes its dollar cost $2.26, well below the price of a Big Mac in mid-Manhattan, which can run $2.89. So as far as the Big Mac is concerned, the yen has fallen far enough.
Yet some economists say that if Japanese policy makers want to stimulate the economy, they have few options but to let the yen slide.
"The only thing they can do is push the yen weaker," said Richard Koo of the Nomura Research Institute.
The problem is that a weaker yen increases exports, crimps imports and could ultimately raise the current-account surplus, the bounty earned when a country exports more than it imports. While the increase in Japan's trade surplus plummeted in January, exports were strong, suggesting that the surplus may soon widen again. That would probably lead to a stronger yen and risk new trade friction with the United States.
"We've been on this route before," Mr. Koo remarked. "Now, Japanese Government officials realize how dangerous all this can get."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Consumer Prices Rise, But Earnings Fall Sharply
The Labor Department said that consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in January, below the consensus forecast of three-tenths of 1 percent, as food prices fell and price increases for energy moderated. The department also said that Americans' weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, fell 2 percent in January -- the largest decline since August 1973. [Page D4.]
 
G.M. May Sell Two Big Units
General Motors is considering selling up to 20 percent of its huge automotive electronics and auto parts units. G.M. is in the process of adding its Delco Electronics Corporation to its Delphi Automotive Systems unit to form the world's largest auto supplier, with revenue of approximately $32 billion. [D2.] 

Labor Wary on New Trade Deals
A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders voted to oppose extending the North American Free Trade Agreement to other countries unless it includes protections on labor and the environment that the Clinton Administration has previously rejected. [D3.]
 
A New High-Tech Fraud
In what the authorities describe as a fraudulent new high-technology scheme, telephone and Internet marketers are joining with telecommunications companies in emerging nations to bilk unsuspecting consumers around the world. [B1.]
 
2 Big Ad Agencies End Feud
True North Communications of Chicago and Publicis of Paris, two big ad agencies, agreed to end a long and bitter dispute over the dissolution of a global business alliance.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Goldman Names Vice Chairmen
Goldman, Sachs, the venerable Wall Street investment-banking firm, continued the gradual broadening and revamping of its top management by naming two new vice chairmen. [D4.]
 
Fed Approves New Banking Rules
The Federal Reserve approved rules that would make it easier for banks to offer new products and to buy other financial institutions. [D3.]
 
Compaq Plans $1,000 Computers
Compaq Computer plans to announce that with the help of a new Cyrix chip, it is entering the market for personal computers priced under $1,000. [D3.]
 
WMX to Sell Servicemaster Unit
WMX Technologies said that it had agreed to sell the 19 percent stake it holds in Servicemaster back to the company. [D3.]
 
Venezuelan Airline Appears Doomed
Protracted efforts to salvage Viasa, the troubled Venezuelan state airline, appeared all but doomed, after Venezuelan officials announced that they would spend no more money to save the company. [D20.]
 
Detroit Newspapers Make Offer
The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News told workers who have been on strike for 19 months that former strikers would get their old jobs back only as vacancies occurred at the two newspapers. [A16.]
 
Stocks Fall in Late-Day Selling
Stock prices held steady for much of the day before dropping in late-afternoon trading in yet another demonstration of how a big bull market can swing wildly. [D6.]
 
Treasury prices fell, despite a report of consumer prices that showed inflation under control. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.57 percent. [D18.]

HEADLINE: U.S.-Europe Talks as Cuba Deadline Nears

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
With only hours to go before before a legal deadline, Clinton Administration officials said today that they were engaged in last-minute negotiations with the European Community to find a diplomatic solution to an increasingly bitter argument over America's trade embargo on Cuba.
The Europeans agreed last week to delay until Thursday the appointment of a panel of judges at the World Trade Organization to hear their challenge to American efforts to penalize foreign companies that do business with Cuba. 
 In response, the United States has threatened to invoke a "national security exemption" to short-circuit the European Union's effort to have the Helms-Burton Act declared a violation of international trade law.
The exemption would declare that Cuba is a threat to the security of the United States, and as a result the economic sanctions against Cuba are not trade actions that the trade group is competent to judge.
It could come as early as Thursday, a senior Administration official said today, but it may be delayed if negotiations with Europe make considerable progress.

HEADLINE: With Polite Nod to One Another, Democratic Field Uses Forum to Attack Mayor

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Seeking to stand out in a blurred and crowded field, the four Democratic mayoral prospects used a campaign forum yesterday to pummel Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- but not each other. They disparaged his personal ethics, the decline of city schools and Mr. Giuliani's efforts to cut the welfare rolls.
For 90 minutes, before a breakfast audience of business executives and political leaders, the candidates, Fernando Ferrer, Ruth W. Messinger, Al Sharpton and Sal F. Albanese, tried to outdo one another with at times caustic attacks on the Mayor. Counseled by party leaders not to criticize one another, each asserted that he or she was the best candidate the Democrats could field against the Republican Mayor. 
 Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, contended that Mr. Giuliani "as a prosecutor would not tolerate Rudolph Giuliani the Mayor." Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said the Mayor has "ignored the needs of New Yorkers and followed his own whims and the wishes of a powerful few."
Mr. Albanese, a Councilman from Brooklyn, said Mr. Giuliani had "long ago gone over to the dark side" in accommodating the needs of campaign contributors. And Mr. Sharpton, a minister and civil rights leader, said Mr. Giuliani was Mayor only of "a part of the city."
The debate, sponsored by The New York Post, was unusually early in the political cycle -- the primary is in September -- and presented the candidates a welcome opportunity for attention. Given that the audience members at the Sheraton New York in Manhattan were mostly reporters and politicians, all the candidates came exceptionally well prepared. Mr. Ferrer read from notes as he offered detailed answers to questions. And an aide to Ms. Messinger gave reporters in the audience a handout on Mr. Giuliani's crime record the moment Ms. Messinger answered a question on the subject.
But the forum also served again to illustrate the difficulties facing the field as a whole, as well as the individual candidates. Most strikingly, each of the candidates found their effort to stand out complicated by pressure from Democratic leaders to avoid a cantankerous primary that might lead to Mr. Giuliani's re-election. As a result, by the end of the debate, the leading contenders made no obvious progress in distinguishing themselves.
Mr. Ferrer, Ms. Messinger and Mr. Albanese watched with evident frustration as the lively Mr. Sharpton grabbed the spotlight with comical, if pointed, rejoinders. Mr. Sharpton's competitors, all career elected officials, tended to speak in jargon little known beyond governmental circles. Thus, while Mr. Ferrer spoke about "Tier 2" housing and Ms. Messinger recounted visits to "E.A.U.'s" -- the Emergency Assistance Units that are part of the city's homeless system -- Mr. Sharpton spoke to the unseen television audience, such as when he delivered a description of the racial makeup of the Giuliani administration. "This administration is like the Rocky Mountains," he said. "The higher up you get, the whiter it gets."
At City Hall, Mr. Giuliani asserted that the debate demonstrated the weaknesses of his challengers. "It was notoriously absent with regard to new ideas, new thoughts, new proposals," he said.
In an obvious effort to further muddle the Democratic contest, Mr. Giuliani, who did not watch the forum but had it described to him, proclaimed Mr. Sharpton "far and away the winner." His remarks seemed intended to keep attention on the long-shot Mr. Sharpton, while obscuring Mr. Ferrer and Ms. Messinger.
The debate had several memorable moments. At the prodding of one of The New York Post questioners, all four candidates said they supported the official recognition of marriages between homosexuals.
Further, if history is any guide and civility goes by the wayside as the primary approaches, there was a strong indication of how the campaign might unravel. That came when Mr. Ferrer discussed how the murder of a police officer last year prompted him to abandon his life-long opposition to the death penalty.
"Politicians are, as you know, not made of wood," Mr. Ferrer said, explaining the shift. "You react and respond to things as they come."
Ms. Messinger responded with a clear if implicit criticism of Mr. Ferrer. "I'm an opponent of capital punishment and a supporter of a woman's right to choose," she said. "Those are moral positions. And I don't change my moral positions."
It was clear that Mr. Ferrer and Ms. Messinger were more than ready to do what they could to score points at Mr. Giuliani's expense. Mr. Ferrer invoked newspaper reports about the influence of two lobbyists who are among Mr. Giuliani's closest advisers, Raymond L. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, and Herman Badillo. "As Mayor," Mr. Ferrer said, "Rudolph Giuliani has failed New York as a moral leader."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Democratic mayoral candidates, Al Sharpton, Fernando Ferrer, Sal F. Albanese and Ruth W. Messinger, at a campaign forum yesterday at the Sheraton New York in Manhattan. Their efforts to stand out at the forum were complicated by pressure from party leaders to avoid an unfriendly primary. (Associated Press)

Following are excerpts of remarks by the four Democratic mayoral candidates at a forum yesterday sponsored by The New York Post.
 
RUTH W. MESSINGER
"Every morning in Rudy Giuliani's New York, 90,000 children wake up knowing there isn't even a seat waiting for them at school. Our neighborhood cops are vanishing from the streets. New York's unemployment rate is 41 percent above the national average.
"That is Rudy Giuliani's New York. And it is a disgrace. He has ignored the needs of New York and followed his own whims and the wishes of a powerful few. Let me be specific: Rudy Giuliani was ready to hand George Steinbrenner $1 billion he didn't need for a stadium we don't need. But he didn't hesitate to cut $1 billion desperately needed by the schoolchildren of this city."
 
FERNANDO FERRER
"Rudolph Giuliani as a prosecutor would not tolerate Rudolph Giuliani the Mayor. As Mayor, he has permitted his closest advisers to lobby the very agencies that they are advising him about.
"As mayor, I will not permit any person that appears before any city agency as a lawyer or lobbyist to take part in any governmental decisions or participate as an adviser to me. Why hasn't Rudy Giuliani closed these loopholes? Because he is beholden to Ray Harding, whose Liberal line made him the Mayor in the first place."
 
AL SHARPTON
"Rudy Giuliani is the Mayor of part of the city. I'm running because we need a mayor who understands and will service the entire city. I'm running because there are students who went to school in September of last year, and 91,000 of them could not find classroom space.
 "We must have sane limits, but we should never turn away a homeless person if we can provide them with a bed and a plate. We should try to build them more affordable housing."
 
SAL F. ALBANESE
"It's time to reform the way political campaigns are financed and end the corrupting influence of big money on democracy. The way campaigns are financed at best blunts, and at worst corrupts, the will of officeholders, to serve at the interest of all the people, and not in favor of the interest of few people who are large campaign donors. This is the dark side of democracy -- where words are graciously given to all, but most access is reserved for a few. The present Mayor has long ago gone over to the dark side. I don't merely talk about campaign reform. I work at it."

HEADLINE: In Move Aimed at Helping Defector, North Korea to Get Food Aid

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Feb. 20

 BODY:
South Korea and the United States say they will provide $6 million and $10 million of food aid to North Korea, respectively, in actions that could help lead to a resolution of the impasse over a high-ranking North Korean defector.
Some people familiar with the situation say that prospects are brightening that the defector, Hwang Jang Yop, will be able to come to Seoul from Beijing, where he has been holed up in the South Korean Consulate seeking asylum since Feb. 12. 
 But South Korean officials said progress in the negotiations was slow.
"We are neither pessimistic or optimistic," said a senior Government official. He also expressed concern that the death on Wednesday of the Chinese leader, Deng Xiaoping, will delay or otherwise affect the negotiations over Mr. Hwang.
South Korea has said it will not publicly discuss details of its negotiations with China, for fear of angering Beijing. But officials here described as "groundless" a report by Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper, that China and South Korea had already reached an agreement "in principle" to let Mr. Hwang leave.
China, which wants to maintain good relations with North and South Korea, has been in a delicate position regarding Mr. Hwang and has said that resolving the problem would take time.
After first insisting that Mr. Hwang had been kidnapped, though, North Korea has now made statements saying he is a "renegade" and implying he could leave. If those public statements truly reflect North Korea's stance, then China will have found an opening and could move swiftly, some officials said.
South Korean officials insist the question of food aid is not linked to that of Mr. Hwang and was under discussion well before his defection. But South Korea's decision to go ahead with its aid could hasten North Korea's acceptance of Mr. Hwang's defection, the senior official said. "We think it will help create a favorable atmosphere for North Korea," the official said.
The food aid appears to be part of a general effort by the North and South to quickly resume programs aimed at improving relations that had been in danger of derailment after Mr. Hwang's request for asylum and the shooting here last Saturday of another prominent defector, Lee Han Young, which South Korean officials suspect was carried out by North Korean agents in retaliation for the Hwang defection.
This morning South Korea announced that it would provide $6 million in assistance to North Korea through the United Nations, up from the $3.2 million it gave last year. The announcement followed one by the United States in Washington on Wednesday that it would donate $10 million, up from $6.2 million last year.
Both aid packages will go toward helping relieve widespread starvation in the Communist nation that has been brought about by severe floods, the loss of aid after the Soviet Union collapsed and a general economic breakdown.
North Korea has also agreed once again to attend a briefing by South Korea and Washington on proposed peace talks aimed at formally ending the Korean war, American and South Korean officials said.
Moreover, a South Korean Foreign Ministry official said a team would be sent to North Korea about March 1, one week later than initially planned, to survey the site where two modern nuclear plants will be built in exchange for Pyongyang's abandonment of the nuclear weapons program it is suspected of having but has not acknowledged.

HEADLINE: CHINA AFTER DENG: IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Sees Few Changes in Chinese Relations

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The death of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, had been expected for so long that officials in the Clinton Administration said today that it would prompt few drastic changes, if any, in how America handles one of its more important and difficult diplomatic relationships.
At the same time, the death of Mr. Deng and the possibility of political uncertainty in its aftermath raised concerns here about the direction China will take -- even as American policy enters a new phase of potential confrontations, from China's takeover of Hong Kong to its entry into the World Trade Organization to its selling of nuclear technology. 
 It was a measure of underlying concerns that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who was in London discussing China and Hong Kong with the British Foreign Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, when the announcement of Mr. Deng's death came, expressed hope for a smooth transition of power. She did so even though Mr. Deng had, by all appearances, already passed most of his vast powers to China's President, Jiang Zemin.
"It would obviously be a great advantage to the Chinese, as well as all of us, if there were a smooth transition," Ms. Albright said.
President Clinton expressed sadness at the death of Mr. Deng and joined other world leaders in paying tribute to the Chinese leader's efforts to open China's economic system and thus its diplomacy to the rest of the world, including the United States.
"China today plays an important role in world affairs in no small part because of Mr. Deng's decision to open his country to the outside world," he said in a statement released as he visited Boston.
While Mr. Clinton's first term in office was marked by an uneven and awkward relationship with China, his second term was just beginning to show signs of improving relations. He used his statement to reassert the importance his Administration attaches to its efforts to encourage China to continue to open up.
"The continued emergence of China as a great power that is stable politically and open economically, that respects human rights and the rule of law and that becomes a full partner in building a secure international order is profoundly in America's interest," the President said.
Had Mr. Deng's death come a few years ago, when his control within China's Communist Government remained supreme, there would most certainly have been greater anxiety over the possibility of a convulsive transition. But as his health waned and he retreated from the public eye in the early 1990's, Mr. Deng anointed Mr. Jiang, who now holds the titles of General Secretary of the Communist Party, state president and leader of China's armed forces.
In that sense, Mr. Deng's death did not signal any immediate changes in China and thus automatically trigger a review of American policy, Administration officials and academic experts said today. As word of Mr. Deng's death spread, officials at the White House and the State Department sought to play down its potential ramifications on American policy.
One Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, "the significance of this is very easy to overstate."
As if to make the point, Mr. Clinton kept to his plans to play some golf this afternoon after returning to Washington from Boston.
But other officials and experts on China said Mr. Deng's definitive removal from the political scene could result in internal jockeying. It could also freeze progress on a number of issues until the Communist Party's 15th Congress in the fall, where Mr. Jiang is expected to consolidate his power by recasting the leaders around him in new roles.
Some of the officials and experts said that Mr. Jiang could soon have the freedom to act more boldly, perhaps even making gestures to the United States as he and President Clinton prepare to exchange state visits starting this year.
Others said Mr. Deng's death could prompt a reassessment, including one of Mr. Deng's record itself. Still others said it could strengthen the hand of China's hard-liners opposed to the relative openness and moderation of Mr. Deng's years at the helm.
The United States has expressed hope that some of the issues facing relations with China -- including an agreement by China to open its markets enough to the join the World Trade Organization and a warming in relations with Washington through, say, a gesture on the human rights front -- will be resolved sooner rather than later. Progress in these areas would bolster the Administration's efforts to engage China with what Ms. Albright has called a "multi-faceted" policy.
The President's statement reflected, indirectly at least, some of the tensions inherent in that approach. Mr. Clinton made only passing reference to human rights, one of the most contentious disputes with China, and did not take on Mr. Deng's darkest legacy: the violent crackdown on pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
Ms. Albright only addressed the human rights issue after it was brought up in questioning by reporters. "For many people, it will be a mixed assessment," she said of Mr. Deng's legacy.
At least for now, Ms. Albright still plans to visit Beijing on Monday on the last stop of her first foray overseas as Secretary of State. In keeping with past practice when its leaders died, the Government in Beijing announced that it would not not invite foreign dignitaries to Mr. Deng's funeral. That at least spared the Clinton Administration any potential handwringing over whom to send.

HEADLINE: Detroit Papers' Rehiring Policy Angers Unions

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
The Detroit newspapers held out an olive branch yesterday to the six newspaper unions that proposed over the weekend to end their 19-month strike. But the papers did not offer the only thing the unions wanted, an assurance that the strikers could go directly back to work.
Instead, Detroit Newspapers Inc., the management arm of The Detroit Free Press, a Knight-Ridder newspaper, and The Detroit News, a subsidiary of the Gannett Company, said that former strikers would get their old jobs back only as vacancies occurred at the two newspapers, which have continued to publish with replacement workers since the strike began in July 1995. 
 Although the papers' position on returning workers had been well known, the unions reacted angrily yesterday, and said they would continue the advertising and readership boycotts that they conducted throughout the strike.
In a statement, Detroit Newspapers said strikers wanting to go back to work would be placed on a preferential hiring list, and would be rehired on a seniority basis according to their pre-strike job classifications.
In addition, a job retraining and relocation fund of about $2 million would be created to help former strikers whose old jobs have been eliminated or who want to seek employment at other newspapers.
"This is clearly an offer made with reconciliation in mind," said Robert H. Giles, publisher of The News. "We believe it represents the kind of creative solution that many community leaders have called for, and our genuine hope is that the unions will want to work with us in this endeavor."
In the absence of an immediate offer of employment for all 2,000 strikers, however, the unions were in no mood for reconciliation.
"My reaction is that this is a kind of artful effort to put a nice face on a response that says 'drop dead' to the workers," said Samuel C. McKnight, the lawyer for the Detroit Metropolitan Council of Newspaper Unions. "If what they are doing looks like, walks like, talks like, feels like and sounds like a lockout, that's what it is, and I'm disappointed that they didn't accept our effort at reconciliation."
About 2,500 reporters, editors, press operators, drivers and other newspaper workers struck over job cuts, wages and work rules on July 19, 1995, and about 2,000 remained on strike until Friday, when the first of the six unions announced the back-to-work decision.
The move was described at a strategic shift aimed at making the papers liable for back wages and benefits for each day the strikers' old jobs are denied them. The papers would be liable for back pay if a National Labor Relations Board ruling, expected later this year, supports a union contention that the strike was prompted by unfair labor practices. If the board agrees with the employers that the strike was over economic issues, no back pay will be due.
Mr. McKnight said yesterday that the unions would "do everything in our power" to force the papers to accept a blanket recall of all strikers. "If we can't have jobs with dignity and jobs that we consider our own," he said, "we are going to do everything we can to hurt these papers -- and frankly, we don't think this community wants these papers."
The unions can point to a 30 percent decline in the weekday circulation of the two papers, along with reduced advertising sales and millions of dollars in losses for both companies since the strike began.
But The News and The Free Press showed a profit in the last quarter of 1996, Mr. Giles said, and still had a strong readership base, particularly on Sunday, when the two papers publish a combined edition.
"If you look at our Sunday circulation of about 825,000, that translates into about two million readers who have cast their votes with us in this community," Mr. Giles said.
The publisher appealed to the unions to end economic warfare against the papers, saying, "We believe that the end of the strike, which is effective today, is the signal that the community is looking for to put this ordeal behind them."

But there was anger from the unions, including the Newspaper Guild of Detroit, headed by Louis Mleczko, right. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: New York Jury Convicts Three Venezuelan Bankers of Defrauding Depositors

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
A Manhattan jury convicted three Venezuelan bankers yesterday of defrauding South American depositors, supporting the District Attorney's contention that international banking cases can be tried in New York even when the primary crime is committed outside the country.
Orlando Castro Llanes, once the head of a Venezuelan financial empire, was convicted of engineering a scheme to steal millions of dollars from Venezuelan depositors to prop up his failing businesses. His son, Orlando Castro Castro, and grandson, Jorge Castro Barredo, were also convicted of bank fraud and grand larceny. 
 The case, which was closely watched in Venezuela, drew attention in New York mainly because of the questions it raised about whether the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, should be prosecuting crimes that were committed outside the United States.
Defense attorneys repeatedly argued that New York prosecutors had no legal right to try foreign citizens for acts that took place outside the United States. But Mr. Morgenthau said the defendants had used New York banks as part of an elaborate scheme to defraud depositors. Arguing that the New York banks were an important element of the fraud, Mr. Morgenthau said his office had a responsibility to protect the integrity of the city's banking system.
"This case once again demonstrates our commitment to safeguard the city's role as the financial capital of the world," Mr. Morgenthau said after the verdict. "Individuals who perpetrate fraud through financial transactions in New York will be held accountable."
Mr. Morgenthau has said that he charged the three bankers after receiving information about their activities from the Federal Reserve Bank in New York. He also said the Venezuelan government had asked for his assistance when the Castros left their country after the collapse of their banks.
Richard Preiss, the prosecutor who tried the case, charged that the Castros misled Venezuelan depositors into believing their money would be safely invested in a United States-regulated bank in Puerto Rico. Instead, prosecutors said, the bankers lost the money through risky trading and stole to support their failing businesses and extravagant lifestyle. The Castros used New York banks to transfer their depositors' funds from Venezuelan bolivars into dollars.
The scheme cost depositors more than $15 million, prosecutors said.
The defense lawyers said after yesterday's verdict that they would appeal the case.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Deng Xiaoping, 92, Dies; Leader Transformed China
Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader and the architect of economic reforms that transformed the world's most populous nation, died in Beijing. He was 92. Mr. Deng, a wily pragmatist and unyielding authoritarian, was the last of a generation of leaders who shared the hardships of forging the Chinese Revolution. He is succeeded by Jiang Zemin, 70, China's President and General Secretary of the Communist Party. A1
 
United States officials said they doubted that the death of Mr. Deng would lead to any drastic change in the relations between the United States and China. A1 

Mr. Deng's death raised uncertainties in Hong Kong and Taiwan. He was seen as a defender of Hong Kong's autonomy against the harder wing of the Communist Party. Many Asian experts said the Chinese nationalists would put Taiwan at the center of any power struggle in the era after Mr. Deng. A11
 
Mexican Arrest Shocks U.S.
United States officials were surprised by the arrest of the head of Mexico's antinarcotics program, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, on charges of collaborating with drug traffickers. Just days earlier, he had been given a detailed briefing on what the United States knows about Mexico's cocaine cartels. A1
 
'Eurocrats' Just Can't Win
The European Court of Human Rights declined to overturn prison sentences imposed by Britain on three people for causing bodily harm through consensual sado-masochistic activities. Hours later, the European Parliament, an elected body, blamed the European Union's bureaucratic laxity for the outbreak and spread of mad cow disease. The "Eurocrats" were criticized both for meddling too much and for not doing enough. A3
 
Extradition Alternative Sought
Israeli and American officials are looking for ways not to extradite Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook to Israel. Lawyers for Mr. Abu Marzook, a leader of the Palestinian Islamic group Hamas who is being held in a New York jail, said they had heard rumors of such discussions but had not been contacted directly. Israelis fear that trying him in Israel might provoke terror attacks. A14
