HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Reports of Mild Economic Advances Raise Inflation Jitters

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The release of moderately favorable economic reports by the Government yesterday raised investor concern about inflation, and the prices of Treasury securities dropped for the third day in a row. A decline in the dollar and a selloff in Treasury futures contributed to the steep drop in bonds in the afternoon.
The price of the 30-year bond plunged 31/32 , to 99 23/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.65 percent, from 6.57 percent on Wednesday. In the last three sessions, bond investors have lost nearly $16.25 for every $1,000. 
 Investors wasted little time selling some of their securities after reports of a smaller-than-expected increase in weekly claims for unemployment benefits and of a small rise in housing starts. Those reports indicated that the economy was still growing at a solid clip, and while inflation remains under control, market participants are aware that the Federal Reserve, in debating interest-rate policy, has shown concern about the strength of the labor market.
In the futures market, where investors buy contracts based on what they think the future value of Treasury securities will be, traders said late selling sent the March bond contract down to a price of 113 before buyers who were looking for value emerged and kept the contract from breaching that key support level.
But the drop in the futures market, along with the slide in the dollar, hurt trading of the current Treasury issue, as the markets seemed to be feeding off each other's weakness.
Last week the number of first-time applicants for unemployment insurance rose by 1,000, to 309,000, according to the Labor Department; that was a much smaller increase than the 14,000 gain that analysts had predicted. Housing starts, meanwhile, increased 2 percent last month to an annual rate of 1.35 million units, which was lower than the 6.1 percent increase that had been expected.
"Over all, the data continue to indicate moderate economic growth and low inflation, a trend we expect to continue well into 1997," Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, said.
But bond investors apparently interpreted those numbers as potentially inflationary, and the market's losses were extended after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported surprising strength in an index of general business conditions.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch, said that while there was a window of opportunity for the bond market to rise this month, "we think the window is closing fast, as we expect upcoming economic data to come in strong."
Mr. Palash said he also expected to see strength next week in the report on orders for durable goods and in two weeks in the report on February employment.
He said bond investors also might be on edge next week waiting for Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, to speak before Congress about economic conditions.
In "when issued" trading before next week's Treasury auctions, a two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.86 percent, up from 5.81 percent on Wednesday, while a five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.17 percent, up from 6.10 percent the day before.

HEADLINE: A Telling Birthmark For Businesses;
Researcher Says How C.E.O.'s Act Is Linked To Order in the Family

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
It is a classic management problem. A company is rolling along, unaware that the bumps it is hitting signal the need to change the way it does business. It isn't really broke, the chief executive thinks, so there's no need to fix it. A little tinkering will do the trick.
But as company after company -- from Eastman Kodak to General Motors to I.B.M. -- has shown, that way lies disaster. 
 The mystery is why so few smart, worldly wise chief executives see the need to foment a corporate revolution before disaster hits.
Frank J. Sulloway has a theory: Too many first-born men rule the nation's corporations. First-born children, he thinks, based on 26 years of research, are authoritarian conformists, assiduously interested in preserving the status quo. Later-borns are more adventurous and receptive to innovation.
"Whenever something really drastic is required, it's always more difficult for a first-born to do it," said Mr. Sulloway, a science historian and research scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has amassed a huge data base that he says proves his point statistically. "That means they'll be doing it later than they should."
"Strategy," he said, "is something that later-borns ought to be superior at compared with first-borns, who are in turn more adept at managing than at strategic overhauls."
Mr. Sulloway, who -- no surprise -- is the third of four children, ignited something of his own revolution last fall when he published "Born to Rebel: Birth Order, Family Dynamics, and Creative Lives" (Pantheon). In it, he argued that birth order was the most reliable predictor of openness to innovation and social change.
That conclusion was based on Mr. Sulloway's analysis of a data base he built of 6,566 people who participated in 121 political and scientific upheavals, including the French Revolution, the emergence of Darwin's theory of evolution and the Protestant Reformation.
To determine who is most likely, in any era, to challenge the established wisdom, he studied as many as 256 characteristics, like age, religion, class, education and travel experience.
"Birth order was the best predictor," he discovered.
While he has not systematically studied business executives, Mr. Sulloway said the message for companies was clear.
People who select chief executives, he contends, would do well to consider candidates' birth order, among other variables, especially if radical change is required. And he thinks corporate boards probably have too high a proportion of first-borns, too, adding to the chief executive's tendency to delay needed change.
To later-borns who are tired of seeing their older siblings rule so many roosts, meanwhile, Mr. Sulloway's work offers an encouraging note -- if, as some management experts think, the authoritarian management model has had its day.
"If command-and-control management is out, it's great news for later-borns," Mr. Sulloway predicted. "They'll move up in the corporation." And that would be good, he said, because later-borns in general are more agreeable than their eldest siblings, less defensive about errors, less territorial and more sympathetic to underdogs and underlings.
His notion that birth order -- and the ensuing dynamics among parents and children -- shapes personalities, who then shape history, is a variation on previous birth-order research, which some social scientists consider dubious.
Mr. Sulloway offers his own cautions. His research showed that two characteristics other than birth order were nearly as important as predictors of the propensity to rebel: "Age and the social attitude of the family, and hence your own social attitude." Younger people tend to be more open to the new because they have less stake in the established, Mr. Sulloway said, and children tend to draw social attitudes from their parents.
Even so, one key factor can disrupt the pattern, he said -- a bad relationship between a child and his parents. Nor is his analytical framework fail-safe: the behavior of 15 percent of the population defies explanation.
Mr. Sulloway's caveats, however, did not stop the potshots. Writing in The New Republic, Alan Wolfe, a sociology professor at Boston University, credited Mr. Sulloway for "establishing the importance of birth order," but questioned his objectivity and criticized him for relying on the assumption that family dynamics have been stable throughout history. Mr. Wolfe's scorching review branded the book "powerful rhetoric" and "bad science."
In any case, people are buying the 653-page tome. It is in its fourth printing, with 56,000 copies in circulation.
Despite the limits of his research, Mr. Sulloway thinks his work has relevance for spheres he has not studied closely, including business. "I can say a lot about people I don't know personally," he said. His analyses take off from a person's position as a first-born or later-born but go deeper into family dynamics, considering variables like sex, the number and sex of siblings and the age spacing between them.
At the recent World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, the panel Mr. Sulloway led on his work was standing room only, packed with believers and skeptics alike. Lester Thurow, the M.I.T. economist and former dean of its Sloan School of Management, was on the panel. "It's all very fascinating," Mr. Thurow said later, "and, like 'survival of the fittest,' on some level it just seems right. But there are always exceptions, so it's too conditional. You can't use it to make decisions."
Besides, Mr. Thurow pointed out, just because later-borns tend to rebel does not mean that they discriminate between good and bad revolutions.
Until the forum meeting, Mr. Sulloway's work had hardly registered in the business world. He has not heard from any corporations. "I'm quite surprised, because of the implications of the book regarding the adaptability to change," he said.
But that itself may change. Nan-b de Gaspe Beaubien, president of the Institute for Family Enterprise in Canada, is exploring additional research with Mr. Sulloway. John O'Neil, another forum panelist who is president of the Center for Leadership Renewal, a consulting and training firm in San Francisco, said he would help Mr. Sulloway determine whether his work could have practical use in corporations.
Meantime, between media interviews, Mr. Sulloway is starting on the task unsystematically, mainly in response to inquiries. At the request of The New York Times, he examined biographical material and news reports about three executives -- Louis V. Gerstner, the chairman of I.B.M.; Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner Inc., and Albert J. Dunlap, the chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation.
Fittingly, Mr. Gerstner, the second of four sons, has overseen dramatic changes at both RJR Nabisco and I.B.M. Both involved cultural revolutions, but with distinctly different characters. At RJR, he reined in a free-wheeling corporate culture and managed to pay down a stupendous debt load without selling many assets. At I.B.M., he freed a stodgy bureaucracy.
The contrast showed his adaptability, Mr. Sulloway said, a trait of later-borns that pops up many times in Mr. Gerstner's career. The linchpin of Mr. Gerstner's prescription for I.B.M. -- customer focus -- is a distinct turnaround from I.B.M.'s recent past and equally telling. "By making an effort to learn about his customers' needs, rather than dictating to them from a position of technological superiority, he emphasized the later-born's ability to identify with their peers," Mr. Sulloway said. "Later-borns like to get out there -- to find out what employees think and what customers think."
Mr. Levin, the third of three children, also fits the mold. "Typical of later-borns, he is soft-spoken -- an ordinary guy with a relative absence of charisma," Mr. Sulloway said. "He combines an easygoing personal style with surprising tenacity and a marked penchant for risk-taking." Some recent evidence: Time Warner's purchase of the Turner Broadcasting Company, even while Mr. Levin struggles to get Time Warner's existing fiefs to act as one company.
Also predictable for a later-born, Mr. Sulloway said, is Mr. Levin's record as a contrarian, a man of ideas and strategy. Those traits came to light in the mid-1970's, when he put Home Box Office on satellite, a breakthrough at the time. More recently, it is reflected in his commitment to cable television, no matter the potential for near-term losses and pressures to sell cable properties to pay down the company's gargantuan debt.
Mr. Dunlap is a more complicated case. Renowned for his ambition, aggression and arrogance, Mr. Dunlap in many ways epitomizes a first-born, which he is. In masterminding his corporate restructurings, most recently at Scott Paper and Sunbeam, he has decimated the work force. Proud of being tough-minded -- he called his book "Mean Business" -- he makes huge demands on minions.
But he is also an iconoclast, caring little about the established order, which seems out of step with his family position.
Mr. Sulloway is quick to explain. "In many ways, Mr. Dunlap's brash temperament -- which is extreme even for a first-born -- makes him something of a nonconformist, one who cares little for corporate authority precisely because he is so taken with himself," Mr. Sulloway said. "If Dunlap is a rebel, it is out of arrogance rather than empathy for the underdog, and hence a result of love of domination rather than a liberating resentment against it." He chalks up Mr. Dunlap's behavior to his troubled relationship with his family, which has been widely chronicled.
Despite its ring of generalization or pop psychology, detailed birth-order analyses could help boards choose chief executives, once they have blocked out the characteristics needed to do the job, Mr. Sulloway suggests. And board nominating committees, too, might do well to include people who vary by birth order, not just industry background and expertise, he said.
The idea is not so crazy. "When I interview candidates, I ask questions that get at their early background, including the number of their brothers and sisters," said Michael A. Wellman, managing director of the New York office of Korn/Ferry International, an executive recruitment firm. "It's another part of the subjective information we use to get a handle on them." However, he said it, like body language, was less important than things like industry knowledge, experience, management style and reputation.
Mr. O'Neil, the leadership consultant, has a less grand view of how Mr. Sulloway's research may help.
"Family is a place where a lot of people get stuck," he said. "We get stuck with family stories, and they get embedded in our behavior. Sometimes that can hurt us. This may help us think through how we view our roles and how we write our next chapters."

HEADLINE: Friend and Foe in Korea

 BODY:
It is worrisome when American diplomats complain that dealing with South Korea, a traditional ally, has grown more frustrating than dealing with North Korea, a dangerous and unpredictable foe. Such complaints are not meant literally. But only North Korea can profit from the tensions Seoul has recently been introducing into its relations with the United States. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to South Korea this weekend provides a timely opportunity to set matters straight.
It now looks as if Seoul's on-again, off-again cooperation with Washington will survive the latest crisis in the peninsula, which was set off by last week's defection of a high-level North Korean official to the South Korean Embassy in Beijing. With North Korea apparently heeding Chinese advice to tone down its threatening rhetoric over this humiliating incident, the South has decided to continue its recently resumed participation in American-sponsored nuclear conversion and famine relief efforts. On Thursday, Seoul promised a new installment of food aid through the United Nations. 
 But South Korean officials have seized upon the incident to question, yet again, the premise that the safest way to deal with North Korea is to encourage a modicum of stability and greater interchange between the North and the outside world. Instead some southern policy makers seem to prefer pushing the wobbly northern regime toward total breakdown, a course filled with danger. A sudden collapse of North Korea could be accompanied by a huge outpouring of desperate refugees and military adventurism, including possible attacks against the 37,000 American troops based in South Korea.
To guard against such an eventuality, Washington has designed a prudent policy that combines military preparedness with efforts to reach out to the North diplomatically and economically. Those efforts include a program designed to replace the North's current nuclear power reactors, whose byproducts can potentially be diverted to bomb-making, with a safer design, along with offers of famine relief and efforts to negotiate a formal peace treaty ending the Korean War.
Unfortunately, South Korea, which claims to support Washington's approach, has often thwarted its application. Seoul has repeatedly suspended its participation in the nuclear, anti-famine and diplomatic efforts to protest northern actions it characterizes as intolerable provocations. Washington suspects that the South has been deliberately inflaming North-South relations for domestic political ends, fanning manageable incidents into major crises to distract attention from the financial scandals and political problems afflicting the Seoul Government.
Ms. Albright arrives in Seoul tomorrow at a time when increasing signs of instability in the North make it vital and urgent for the United States and South Korea to coordinate their policies closely. In previous stops of this, her first foreign journey as Secretary of State, she has been admirably straightforward about raising sensitive diplomatic issues. She should make clear to her South Korean hosts that Washington now expects them to keep domestic political concerns from disrupting the only realistic approach to the northern danger.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Inched Up 2% For January

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Construction starts on homes and apartments rose 2 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today, a smaller-than-expected increase that could signal that the real estate market is cooling after its strongest year in two decades.
Housing starts rose in the West, partly reflecting a recovery from December's harsh weather. They increased in the Northeast but declined in the South and the Midwest. 
 Analysts had expected the January report to show an increase of 6.1 percent. The 2 percent increase brought the annual rate of housing starts to nearly 1.4 million units.
In December, starts had declined sharply, although the Commerce Department today revised the data to show a slightly smaller decrease, of 11 percent instead of the 12.2 percent reported originally.
In a separate report today, the Labor Department said the number of American workers applying for state unemployment benefits edged up last week, rising by 1,000, which was lower than expected, to a seasonally adjusted 309,000. The four-week moving average of claims, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, fell to 318,250, from 325,500 the previous week, the lowest level since Aug. 17.
The report was another indication of labor market strength. Some economists and participants in the financial markets have expressed concern that robust job creation may accelerate inflation.
"We will have to watch claims in the coming weeks to see if this is one of the first signs of overheating in the labor market," Carol Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities International Inc., said.
Taken together, said Arthur Qua, an analyst at Daiwa Securities America Inc., today's figures on the labor and housing markets showed "the economy is still growing at a pretty good pace, though inflation remains under control."
As for the housing report, some analysts warned against trying to glean much insight from the January data, which tend to be more volatile than those of other months because of winter weather and the start of the year. "It's hard to give the data much credibility," Scott Brown, an economist at Raymond James & Associates, an investment firm in St. Petersburg, Fla., said.
Looking at the year as a whole, Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said that "we expect housing to be a drag." She added, "It'll be hard to best '96," when sales of new single-family homes were the strongest since 1978.
 Nevertheless, builders are increasingly optimistic, according to a survey by the National Association of Home Builders. The trade group's housing market index gained 2 points in February, rising to 54 from 52 the month before and higher than the readings in December and November, meaning the number of positive responses from builders slightly exceeds negative responses.
Today's Commerce Department report showed that permits for new housing construction, a gauge of future building activity, fell 1.9 percent in January to an annual rate of nearly 1.4 million units after having increased three-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Housing starts totaled 1.35 million. By category, starts of single-family homes increased 10.2 percent in January while those of multifamily homes fell 23.9 percent.
Starts rose 29.9 percent in the West, to 344,000 units, and 22.2 percent in the Northeast, to 165,000 units, the highest level since November 1994. They declined 13.2 percent in the Midwest, to 256,000 units, the lowest in two years, and 6.8 percent in the South, to 585,000 units.
After exceeding 8 percent last year, the average rate on a 30-year fixed loan has settled down. It averaged 7.82 percent in January, compared with 7.60 percent in December, according to an analysis by Bloomberg News. That put the average principal and interest payment on a $100,000 loan at $721.26 last month. Those figures do not include tax, fire insurance or escrow costs.
Last week, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage declined to 7.65 percent from 7.74 percent.

HEADLINE: Those Who Left Recall Deng With Gratitude

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
When Sue Ann Jung's family left China 18 years ago, they were among the first to benefit directly from the open-door policies of Deng Xiaoping after he consolidated his power in 1978. So yesterday, a day after Mr. Deng's long-anticipated death, Ms. Jung, 30, recalled what her parents used to tell her as she grew up in New York City.
"I remember what my mom said: 'Only because of Deng we could leave China,' " said Ms. Jung, a manager of the Eighth Avenue Auto Store in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. "We thank him. He did a lot over the years he was ruling." 
 But she added: "You know, that thing, Tiananmen Square. They were wrong. They went too fast."
Her thoughts were echoed yesterday throughout the city's Chinese communities, some of which were created or have prospered as a direct result of Mr. Deng's policies. From Manhattan's Chinatown to Flushing in Queens, to Sunset Park in Brooklyn, many acknowledged that while they abhorred the Tiananmen crackdown, they credited Deng with bringing China into the 20th century.
The similar reaction among those from China -- from the elite students who left after Tiananmen in 1989 to those eking out a living in sweatshops and restaurants -- perhaps reflected something fundamental that the immigrants have in common: many of them owe their presence in this country to Mr. Deng, either directly because of his policies or indirectly because of the conditions his policies created in China.
Had it not been for Deng, New York City might not have the booming Chinese communities that have fueled the economic growth of several areas of the city. Historically, Hong Kong and Taiwan were the source of New York's Chinese immigrants. But between 1990 and 1994, mainland China accounted for 79 percent of the Chinese immigrants to New York City, according to the Department of City Planning.
Many students who left China after the crackdown in Tiananmen, which Mr. Deng is said to have ordered, have settled in northeast Queens, said Paul Lo, a Taiwanese real estate agent and the owner of A. O. Realty in Queens. After saving money, many have begun buying houses in the area because it has the highest-ranking public schools in the city, he said.
A banker in his late 20's, who bought a house in the area but works in Manhattan, said he left China two months after the killings at Tiananmen to pursue graduate studies in the United States. He said yesterday that he learned of Mr. Deng's death while listening to National Public Radio on Wednesday afternoon.
"When I was in China, he actually opened the door to the outside world," said the banker, who asked that his name not be used because he still has relatives in China. "Without Deng, I don't know what China would be economically."
But he said that Tiananmen was a blot on the leader's career. "That was a big mistake he made, to use force to crack down. I really like the system here -- the Congress, the President.
"There is no such thing as a paramount leader," he added, using Deng's title toward the end of his career.
In 1979, only a few years after President Richard M. Nixon and Mao established relations between the United States and China, Mr. Deng started sending students to this country. Many, like Zai Liang, now a sociology professor at Queens College, chose to stay.
"Clearly, the educated group, without Deng, would not have come here," Mr. Liang said. "The other group, it's very hard to say."
Mr. Liang was referring to the recent waves of poor, uneducated Chinese, many from the province of Fujian, who have come to New York in recent years, some illegally. It is not completely clear what drew them to the United States, Mr. Liang said, but one factor may be Mr. Deng's economic reforms, which have made many rich but driven out others to seek their fortune outside China. The rising cascade of such immigrants has given birth to new Chinatowns in Sunset Park and another Brooklyn neighborhood, Homecrest.
In Sunset Park yesterday afternoon, in three-story brick buildings along Eighth Avenue between 51st and 60th Streets, many Chinese immigrants could be seen reading about Mr. Deng's death in Chinese-language newspapers, or talking to one another in restaurants, fish stores and green grocers.
"Deng was a good guy," said Jimmy Hu, a salesman at Lee's Furniture Store. "I came here 15 years ago when I was 30. I've no interest in going back to China. My family is here. Why would I want to go there? Deng was a nice guy. China is very good."
Xi Bo Chen, 81, who said he was a farmer in China, merely laughed when he was asked what he thought of Mr. Deng's legacy. But he volunteered, "Can't go back." Because Mr. Deng had left the political spotlight a few years ago and groomed a successor, Jiang Zemin, Mr. Liang, like others interviewed yesterday, said they were optimistic about China's future.
"I wasn't particularly upset by the news because China is not going to change so much, in my opinion, because the structure is there," Mr. Liang said. "Deng's death will make China's political reforms a little bit easier."

HEADLINE: 'Bit Actor' to Star in a New Role: Mr. Chairman

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
As the senator for sale in the 1993 film remake of the Broadway classic, "Born Yesterday," Fred Dalton Thompson warned an influence-peddling tycoon, "You are making a terrible mistake treating me this way."
Now, as an authentic Republican senator from Tennessee, the lawyer turned lobbyist turned actor turned politician may get to deliver the same sort of line for real. 
 As the new chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, Mr. Thompson has the White House on the defensive as he prepares for what could become the most expensive investigation in Congressional history: an inquiry into fund-raising illegalities in the 1996 Presidential campaign and beyond.
But even before Mr. Thompson appears front-and-center on national television when the hearings begin, he is embroiled in a political fight in which even the support of some in his own party is suspect. And although he says, "I don't think people are treating me badly," he does not seem to like it one bit.
The man who has promised to be fair to both parties in uncovering the seamiest side of American politics and who has seduced the media with his powerful presence and melt-in-your mouth charm has been attacked by Democrats for wanting too much money, too long an investigation and too much focus on President Clinton's fund raising.
Even some Republicans are grumbling that Mr. Thompson's $6.5 million budget request is too high and that his accommodation to Democrats' demands to include possible transgressions by Republicans is taking things, well, a bit too far.
"I'm concerned about the direction this is going in," Mr. Thompson said in a conversation in the Capitol. "Maybe we've just gotten off to a little rocky start and things will settle down."
But with all the hype and the hand wringing over the still-unscheduled hearings, the man who once dressed up as Superman in the movie "Barbarians at the Gate" understands just how fickle his audiences can be.
"You know how it is in this country, and especially in this town," Mr. Thompson said. "There are tremendous quick buildups and tremendous quick takedowns. There are going to be good days and bad days. There are going to be missteps and mistakes and misquotes. There's nothing you can do about it, so you might as well relax and not enjoy it."
Of the Republicans who are not keen to see their own campaign finances investigated, the Senator said, "There are some, I'd say a few, who are very concerned and who are not bashful about making their concerns known."
 
Political Savvy And Determination
Mr. Thompson's fans describe the 6-foot, 6-inch, 240-pound Senator as a larger-than-life good ol' boy whose ribs-and-cornbread vernacular masks political savvy and a determination to forge a serious overhaul of campaign spending laws if the investigation succeeds.
"He's tough, straightforward, methodical," said Howard H. Baker Jr., the godfather of Tennessee Republicans who first brought Mr. Thompson to Washington in 1973 as the minority counsel to the Senate Watergate Committee. "The last thing on earth he is is naive."
But Mr. Baker concedes that Senator Thompson might be getting a bit too independent for his own good.
"He's way out on a limb," Mr. Baker said of his protege. "I've had some passing experience with that. There were times when I walked through the cloakroom and people would barely speak to me."
Mr. Thompson's political foes consider him a partisan grandstander who votes with the conservative wing of his party most of the time, who spent years in Washington as a well-connected lawyer and lobbyist for the teamsters union pension fund and companies like Westinghouse and Toyota and who may use the investigation as a springboard for a Presidential bid.
Democrats also may try to exploit the fact that he has been a very successful fund-raiser, raising large amounts of money from tobacco, pharmaceutical and chemical interests.
"If there's one thing I've learned since coming to Congress, it's never to make assumptions about the good ol' boys," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat. "I have a great respect for the Senator, but the soft approach and the easy talk is designed to put you at rest before the attack begins."
Although Mr. Thompson has not said it directly, he is determined to avoid the fate of his Republican colleague from New York, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who saw his poll ratings plunge after his acerbic, partisan questioning of witnesses in last year's Whitewater hearings.
"There's simply no reason to assume at this stage of the game that I am going to be dumb enough to carry on a set of hearings that are going to degenerate into rank partisanship or unfairness," Mr. Thompson said at a recent hearing of the Rules and Administration Committee, which has jurisdiction over his budget.
 
Making Clinton The Top Priority
Despite the Senator's nonpartisan patina, patches of partisanship show through.
Shortly before the President gave the first news conference of his second term last month, Mr. Thompson upstaged him with a much-advertised speech on the Senate floor about the investigation, forcing Mr. Clinton a few hours later to answer questions about Mr. Thompson's remarks.
At one point in his speech, when Mr. Thompson was discussing President Richard M. Nixon's fight for executive privilege in the Watergate scandal, he slipped -- inadvertently or not -- and said "Clinton" when he should have said "Nixon."
Mr. Thompson has made clear that his top priority is uncovering possible wrongdoing by Mr. Clinton, not the Republicans.
"I make no apologies for listing that first," he said at a meeting of the Governmental Affairs Committee last month. "If we have a murder and a jaywalking, we maybe ought to look at the murder."
Mr. Thompson arrived at his initial budget request of $6.5 million for the investigation without consulting a number of powerful Republicans, including Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the chairman of the Senate Rules Committee.
Mr. Warner declined to discuss the matter, and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Republican whip, smoothed over Mr. Warner's displeasure, saying only, "It's a much larger request than what John Warner has seen in the past."
Even when adjusted for inflation, the Watergate inquiry cost $6.9 million, Whitewater $1.8 million.
 
Mixing Praise With Caution
While praising Mr. Thompson, a 54-year-old onetime prosecutor, some Republicans also note his relatively junior status.
"I haven't heard anyone suggest he step aside and a more senior figure or a better prosecutor take over," said Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana. "There is confidence he's a good man. But that doesn't mean the Republicans are going to give him carte blanche."
And Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania said, "I don't think either side has done the necessary things to determine how long it's going to take, how many witnesses will be called and what we are going to look for."
Undaunted, Mr. Thompson has not backed down from his agenda.
"I will not relent," he vowed when a handful of Democrats asked him at a Rules Committee hearing earlier this month to accept a more modest initial budget of $1.8 million and a one-year deadline.
 
Dueling Images: Lawyer or Farmer?
After Watergate, Mr. Thompson once said about Washington, "I never wanted to go there again." But that was before he decided to move here to set up shop as a lawyer with a heavy lobbying practice.
Still, in his 1994 campaign for Vice President Al Gore's Senate seat, Mr. Thompson had no problem casting aside his late-model Lincoln and his lawyer suits, leasing a red pickup truck and donning jeans, work shirts, cowboy boots and a belt with a silver buckle the size of a salad plate.
His opponent, former Representative Jim Cooper, portrayed him as a "a Gucci-wearing, Lincoln-driving, Perrier-drinking, Grey-Poupon-spreading millionaire Washington special-interest lobbyist." But it did not stick. Mr. Thompson won with 60 percent of the vote, and was re-elected last year with 61 percent.
"I still am who I was," he said when asked about doubts about his authenticity. "It's not incongruous for me to be comfortable with a tobacco farmer or a diplomat."
Mr. Thompson will also be well-served in the hearings by his experience in the movies, in which he has played all sorts of authority figures, including an F.B.I. agent, a White House chief of staff, a university president, a Navy admiral and, not surprisingly, a lawyer.
The only time he played the President was opposite Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, during his preparation for the debates with Mr. Clinton last year.
Mr. Thompson calls himself "a bit actor" who took a few weeks off from his law-and-lobbying practice to do something that was fun. "It's like hundreds of thousands of average people who once a month go out to their community theater and get up on stage and play a little part," he said. "I got to do it, you know, with Paul Newman."
 
The Successor To Ronald Reagan?
As for the future, Mr. Thompson, whose Senate victory celebration in Tennessee last November was filled with "Fred for Prez" signs, has not discouraged speculation about a bid for the Presidency. He is even mentioned as the logical successor to another former actor-turned politician: Ronald Reagan.
"It's interesting that someone just having gotten re-elected after a Presidential campaign is immediately called upon to forswear forever that he would never run for President or denounce his candidacy," he said. "I'm not thinking about it and I'm not talking about it."
A divorced father of three grown children and the grandfather of five, Mr. Thompson has been romantically linked to a number of women, but keeps his personal life to himself. When asked who sent a dozen long-stemmed roses to his office on Valentine's Day, he demurred.
"Why, it was Tom Daschle!" he joked, referring to the South Dakota Democrat and Senate minority leader who is fighting to limit the budget and duration of the investigation. "Now wasn't that a nice surprise?"

HEADLINE: World Bank Chief Asks Slimmer Staffs and Better Lending

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The World Bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn, has proposed a sweeping reorganization costing up to $400 million that is intended to shake up the institution's vast bureaucracy and improve its performance in promoting the economic development of poor nations, bank officials said today.
Mr. Wolfensohn has been goading the bank's staff to become more nimble and aggressive since he took over 20 months ago after a lucrative career on Wall Street, saying that the bank cannot tolerate its current failure rate of one-third of its lending programs. 
 After months of study and debate, Mr. Wolfensohn laid out a detailed program to the bank's board last week for accomplishing that change. Officials said he had told the board and top managers that the World Bank would need to show improved results or risk an irreversible loss of public support, not least in the United States, where foreign-aid programs have come increasingly under attack in Congress for both ideological and fiscal reasons.
World Bank officials said the plan was an attempt by Mr. Wolfensohn to put his stamp on an institution that had resisted change in the past. And they said that while it primarily involved changes involving the bank's 10,100-member bureaucracy, the intent was to signal a more fundamental shift in the approach to development.
"We are not satisfied that we are getting maximum development impact from our projects," a briefing paper circulated among the bank's managers said. "Demand for our lending is flat. There are complaints about our slowness and bureaucracy. There has been under-investment in our staff and technical expertise, and we have not been active enough in building partnerships."
The World Bank's board, made up of representatives from member nations, is to discuss the proposals at a meeting next month. Although officials anticipate eventual board approval, they said they expected some opposition to Mr. Wolfensohn's call for as much as $400 million in increased spending over the next two years.
The funds would come from the bank's operating profit, and while officials said it would not require any cutback in lending, they said it could restrict the bank's ability to take on additional unplanned programs like the current effort to rebuild Bosnia.
Clinton Administration officials said they had not yet decided whether to support the plan. Last year, Congress cut the Administration's request for World Bank funds, leading the United States to pay only $700 million of the $934.5 million it had pledged to the bank's division that makes loans to the poorest countries.
Mr. Wolfensohn's plan would shift some of the $1.1 billion annual operating budget away from legal, financial and other back-office and support divisions to the institution's front-line lending and development programs.
In addition to the internal shift, amounting to $170 million over the next two years, the plan calls for $125 million in new spending in each of the next two years to spur what Mr. Wolfensohn views as his primary goal: nudging the bank away from a traditional emphasis on the construction of power plants, bridges, roads and the like, a role being increasingly played by private companies and investors.
Instead, Mr. Wolfensohn wants to focus more on jobs that private industry does not take on, or that will help attract investment, including establishing banking systems and social welfare, health and education programs. At the same time, he wants the bank to encourage more private investment and to engage in more partnerships with investors.
Much of the additional $250 million in spending the next two years would go to hiring people with skill in those areas, officials said. The bank would also invest in improving its technology to make it easier for experts working in various countries to share information and advice.
The plan calls for spending a further $100 million to $150 million over the next two years to pay the costs of laying off as many as 700 people from those sections of the bank that will face budget cuts.
After the two-year period of increased spending, the bank's budget would drop again, to slightly above its current $1.1 billion level, adjusted for inflation.
The World Bank -- by far the largest of the international development agencies -- has a long history of reorganizations and new strategies, four in the last decade. These, however, have done little to address the risk of its becoming inconsequential in a world where private investment in developing nations dwarfs the $13 billion it lends each year.
Mr. Wolfensohn has attacked the bureaucracy and the institution's approach more directly than his predecessors, generating unease within the bank along with support for his efforts.
Internal studies in recent years have found that about two-thirds of its lending programs to developing nations meet the bank's standards for success. Those include not just repayment of the loan, but a continued economic benefit to the nation from the project without adverse environmental or social consequences.
Environmental and other development groups have complained that the bank puts too much money into building hydroelectric dams and other big projects that poor nations cannot afford to maintain or operate for long.
But economists say that a two-thirds success rate is not terribly low -- and is probably higher than that of any other international development institution, given the risks of operating in developing countries with little money or technical expertise and often substantial corruption.
Mr. Wolfensohn has often spoken of raising the bank's success rate to around 75 percent, suggesting that would be a level that balances the need to take some risks against the need to show results. He has broadly supported the findings of an internal study released three months ago that said the bank should direct more of its lending to those nations that have relatively stable economies and that have shown they are capable of using financial assistance effectively.

HEADLINE: CHINA AFTER DENG: THE OVERVIEW;
China Plans Deliberately Simple Funeral for Deng

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 20

 BODY:
China today announced a spare and modest memorial ceremony for Deng Xiaoping, apparently reflecting the leadership's desire to impart a message of calm and continuity and perhaps to avoid risking any spontaneous displays of discontent.
The funeral committee headed by President Jiang Zemin said 10,000 party loyalists, friends and family members would be invited to the Great Hall of the People on Tuesday to view a closed coffin bearing a simple portrait of the last man who is likely to be called paramount leader of China. As has been customary in past funerals of major Chinese figures, no foreigners are to be invited. 
 But Mr. Deng's body will not lie in state, as Mao's did for one week in September 1976. And no one will be allowed to bow three times before the coffin in the traditional Chinese manner of paying respect to a departed elder.
And in an unusual demonstration that business continues uninterrupted by the period of mourning, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is to visit Beijing as planned on Monday.
The simple sendoff for the revolutionary giant was attributed to the wishes of the man himself, but it was loaded with political meaning.
Mr. Jiang and other political heirs of Mr. Deng clearly wish to portray his death not as an unsettling occasion but as the passing of a retired leader who had already handed over the reins of power.
The leaders may also have feared that a more public event would give rise to recriminations over Mr. Deng's role in ordering the military assault against unarmed student protesters during the 1989 pro-democracy movement at Tiananmen Square. The demonstrations at the time began with wreath-layings in honor of Hu Yaobang, a former general secretary who died.
Moreover, for millions of Chinese, politics has simply been out of mind since democratic reform became a futile, if not dangerous, pursuit in the years since.
Even as the funeral plans went forward, so did plans for China's top leaders to receive their first visit from Ms. Albright on the day before Mr. Deng's memorial. Ms. Albright's schedule in Beijing is likely to include blunt exchanges on the failure by Chinese and American diplomats to find a formula to avoid confrontation next month in Geneva, where the United Nations Human Rights Commission takes up its annual debate on China's human rights record.
In Washington, President Clinton said he expected "continuity" in China. "We will continue to engage strongly with China," he told reporters, adding, "The policy we are following of engaging with China, to work where we agree and to honestly air our disagreements and work through them, is the right policy for the people of the United States and indeed for the world in the 21st century."
"If you imagine what the world will look like 30 years from now, 40 years from now, we can do nothing other than what we are doing," Mr. Clinton said. "It is the right thing to do."
As if to reinforce the point that the torch has already passed, Li Lanqing, China's Deputy Prime Minister and a contender to become Prime Minister next year, said on a visit to Israel that the continued expansion of China's economy since Mr. Deng's official retirement "fully demonstrates the competence and abilities of the current Chinese leadership with Mr. Jiang Zemin at the core."
With flags at half-staff across China during a five-day period of mourning declared after Mr. Deng's death on Wednesday night, the official funeral committee, comprising 459 Chinese luminaries and top party leaders, announced that the memorial services would be attended by "representatives of the central party, Government, military and people's organizations, and people from all walks of life in the capital, his friends, and representatives from his hometown" of Paifang in Sichuan province.
The committee made public a letter dated last Saturday from Mr. Deng's wife, Zhuo Lin, and their five children, calling for minimal funeral arrangements. "Comrade Xiaoping always has a philosophical view of life and death, and has talked many times with us about his own funeral affairs," it said.
"There should be no farewell ceremony for his remains," the family said, adding that "the memorial meeting should be held after cremation" and the "coffin should be covered by a party flag" with "a color photo that displays the superb mental outlook of Comrade Xiaoping above it."
Mr. Deng's remains will be cremated before the memorial service and his "ashes cast into the sea" in accordance with his and his family's wishes, said the announcement by the official funeral committee.
Mr. Deng's corneas will be donated to an eye bank, the announcement said, and his body will be "dissected for the purpose of medical research" before cremation. Mr. Deng died of complications associated with advanced Parkinson's disease. He was 92 by Western reckoning, since official records give his birth date as Aug. 22, 1904. Chinese state-run news organizations gave his age as 93. Traditionally, Chinese infants are declared 1 year old if they live beyond the first month. Other Chinese add a year to their age at the start of the Lunar New Year, which this year fell on Feb. 7.
The family letter said that since Mr. Deng had "devoted his entire life to the motherland and the people without any reservation, we hope that the last thing we do for him will reflect the essence of his mental outlook, and express our grief in an utterly plain and solemn way."
Mr. Jiang's decision to appoint himself the "chairman" of the funeral committee echoed his efforts to elevate his stature by being appointed Chairman of the Communist Party, of which he is already General Secretary. But the elevation would put him on the same leadership plane as Mao, with whom the title of chairman has been associated since it was retired in the early 1980's.
The huge roster of funeral committee members was also a sign of Mr. Jiang's desire to galvanize the party under his nominal leadership even as he shares power with Prime Minister Li Peng and the other five members of the standing committee of the Politburo.
The roster was conspicuous for its inclusion of both Yang Shangkun and Yang Baibing, who were poised to challenge Mr. Jiang's leadership in 1992. Also on the committee is Hua Guofeng, Mao's hand-picked successor who was pushed aside by Mr. Deng in 1978. Conspicuous for his absence from the committee roster was Zhao Ziyang, the former party secretary who lost his job over his refusal to send troops against the student protesters in 1989. Mr. Zhao remains a party member.
The utterly plain funeral for Mr. Deng contrasts with the great pageantry that attended the passing of Mao, or even of Prime Minister Zhou Enlai, whose death in January 1976 led to the first large-scale pro-democracy demonstrations of the Communist era. Mr. Deng was blamed for those demonstrations and was purged for the second time in his career as a national leader.
By making public the Deng family letter today, President Jiang and the collective leadership that succeeds Mr. Deng were able to sidestep the difficulty of mandating the kind of minimalism that suits their craving for maximum tranquillity in the capital.
And the timing of Mr. Deng's death, coming as it did during the long recess on China's university campuses for the Lunar New Year, spares the Politburo for now from the unseemly act of strengthening the police presence there to prevent any spontaneous student demonstrations in memory of -- or vilification of -- Mr. Deng's rule and his Tiananmen legacy.
Much like Zhou Enlai, Mr. Deng discouraged the kind of personality cult that surrounded Mao, whose huge portrait that stares out over Tiananmen Square is the emblem of the Chinese capital and whose cavernous mausoleum towers over the 100-acre parade ground in front of the Gate of Heavenly Peace where millions have lined up to view the well-preserved body of the Chairman.
China virtually stood still for days after the deaths of Mao and Zhou Enlai in 1976, but today the streets of the city bustled at their usual frenetic pace, with rush-hour crowds seemingly oblivious to the historic moment that had passed.
"I came to work at 9:30 this morning," said Wang Shuzhen, a 50-year-old soda salesman on Tiananmen Square. "I am not surprised -- everybody dies. It's a pity a leader is gone." Wang Rong, a high school student, added, "The impact of his death should be very small because these days the country is developing very fast."
But others expressed sadness and grief.
"I cried when I heard the news," said a 30-year-old businessman dressed in fashionable denim on the chilly winter morning. "When Mao and Zhou died, I was young and at that time our feelings were imposed on us. Now if someone mourns for Deng it is from their heart, not from politics."
But the young man had to admit that the capital did not seem as seized by Mr. Deng's passing. "I saw a lot of people on the street showing little response, going on with their business or talking about it in a light way," he said. "I just feel that they are numb."

HEADLINE: CHINA AFTER DENG: THE DISSIDENTS;
Chinese Exiles Wonder How Wind Will Blow

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Inside the world of China's exiled dissidents where they talk about the future, the shape of China after the death of Deng Xiaoping has been the main topic for years, with nearly as many opinions as dissidents.
But now that Mr. Deng has actually passed from the scene, there is something different in the atmosphere, a sense that at least the things that could not change as long as Mr. Deng was alive have some chance of changing now. 
 "The general feeling is that Deng's death opens up some chances," said Xiao Qiang, a former physics student who is director of Human Rights in China, a monitoring organization in New York.
"Deng allowed an economic opening but no political liberalization, and nobody could challenge that as long as he was alive," he said. "In the post-Deng era at least you will be able to question the policy, the timetable of liberalization, and whether liberalization should be on the timetable."
In all, according to Mr. Xiao, some 40,000 Chinese received residency permits in the United States after the violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in June 1989. Another 2,000 to 4,000 came to this country after the crackdown and were granted political asylum. Of these, a few hundred have remained active in organizations that study events in China or provide information on human rights abuses there or campaign for greater freedoms.
Virtually all of the exiles are officially unpersons in China, and it appears that they have little if any influence there.
Among dissidents themselves, the exiles may not enjoy the prestige of some democracy activists, like Wei Jingsheng or Wang Dan, who remained in the country and are serving long prison terms. But they are untainted by any involvement in the suppression of the Tiananmen demonstrations and conceivably could return to positions of influence should a more liberal faction come to power in Beijing, or even if the current Government of President Jiang Zemin decides to make a gesture of reconciliation to the many officials who lost their posts after 1989.
The large and varied community of exiles includes many aides or advisers to the two leading purged reformers, Hu Yaobang, who died in 1988, and Zhao Ziyang, the former General Secretary of China's Communist party, who was pushed from his post by Mr. Deng when he showed a too sympathetic attitude toward the student demonstrators.
In addition there are many students, now in their 20's and early 30's, who were active in the Tiananmen demonstrations, including some who served prison terms and have now been released.
Some of the exiles, interviewed the day after Mr. Deng's death, seemed pessimistic about the immediate future, saying China's leaders will feel insecure now that Mr. Deng has passed from the scene and will therefore govern more repressively than ever before.
Others take a very different view, saying Mr. Deng's death will open the way for an official reassessment of the military crackdown at Tiananmen, possibly a re-emergence for Mr. Zhao, and even a future role in a democratic China for the exiles now in the United States.
"The day of going back is closer," said Liu Binyan, the editor of China Focus, a magazine published in Princeton, N.J. In the relatively open China of the 1980's, Mr. Liu enjoyed national fame as his country's chief investigative journalist.
"The death of Deng marks the end of the old era, the era when everything was decided by a few politicians," he said. "Even though Deng didn't interfere in politics in the last few years, he was like a stone weighing on the country, and the removal of the stone will make people more courageous in raising demands and expressing dissatisfaction with the status quo."
Mr. Liu, who was visiting the United States when the Tiananmen crackdown took place and remained in this country afterwards, said President Jiang is likely to respond to popular pressure by formally reassessing the Tiananmen demonstrations so that they will no longer be designated counterrevolutionary but a legal and even patriotic movement.
As long as Mr. Deng was alive, any such re-evaluation would have been considered an indirect criticism of him and therefore impossible. Now, however, a re-examination of the events of 1989 could bring Mr. Zhao back into favor, Mr. Liu said, not as a senior official but as a consultant to a government favoring political reforms as well as economic ones.
Having been away from China for several years now, often struggling with a new language, receiving news from back home via the press and telephone conversations, the exiled dissidents are often eager to return home and may be prone to excessive optimism about the pace of change in China in the future.
Appearing on the Charlie Rose program on public television Wednesday night, Chai Ling, a Tiananmen student leader who fled the country after the crackdown, spoke emotionally about her expectation that great changes will soon sweep over China in the direction of the rule of law, a free press and other elements of democratic government.
"Jiang Zemin could be China's George Washington," Ms. Chai said. "Or he could be another Deng Xiaoping."
Liu Gang, a former physics student from Beijing University who spent six years in prison after the Tiananmen crackdown, said, "Things will get better because there's an opportunity for China to change."
Mr. Liu, who is now studying computers at Columbia University, says, like many other exiles, that there may be a power struggle in China during which challenges to the old order will be made. "After Deng, nobody will be able to be a powerful dictator again," Mr. Liu said.
Some exiles, by contrast, say change for the better, if it comes at all, will be slow. They argue that Mr. Jiang will be cautious about moving away from the Deng legacy, in part because he himself owes his power as General Secretary of the Communist Party to Mr. Deng. Mr. Jiang also has to contend with conservative factions in China that would like to see greater political controls and even a curtailment of some economic freedoms.
"In the short term, the Government is going to be more repressive," said Mr. Xiao, of Human Rights in China. "The leaders now have fewer credentials than Deng did and no legitimacy of their own. So they will feel insecure."
One of the highest party officials now among the exiles is Su Shaozhi, who was the director of the Institute for Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought at the Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing.
Mr. Su, who left China four days after the Tiananmen crackdown, lost his post when his patron, Hu Yaobang, was purged. He is now president of the Princeton-China Initiative, an institute that monitors developments in China.
"With Deng's death, different factions or different forces might challenge the Jiang Zemin regime," Mr. Su said. "The first group is the people who remember the June 4 massacre, though they didn't dare mention it while Deng was alive. This is the force that can unite the reformists both inside and outside the party and press for a reassessment of Tiananmen.
"The second force," he said, "are the Marxist-Leninist fundamentalists, who have already challenged Deng's reforms and might apply pressure to Jiang Zemin to turn left."
Mr. Su said that Mr. Jiang is by nature a Marxist-Leninist himself, though when Mr. Deng repudiated that wing of the party in 1992, Mr. Jiang supported his patron. Now that Mr. Deng is dead, Mr. Su said, Mr. Jiang might be tempted to move toward tighter political controls even as he continues to promote a more open economy.

HEADLINE: U.S. WON'T OFFER TRADE TESTIMONY ON CUBA EMBARGO

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Just hours after the World Trade Organization appointed a panel of judges to hear a European challenge to Washington's embargo of Cuba, the United States said today that it would refuse to take part in the legal proceedings. It declared that the new body, which was intended to be the arbiter of world trade rules, "has no competence to proceed" in an issue of American national security.
"We will not show up," a senior Administration official said today when asked what Washington would do when the panel convened. 
 The American action, which falls short of a formal legal step, followed six months of negotiations with Europe over the Helms-Burton Act that failed to produce a compromise. The Helms-Burton Act is intended to punish companies that trade with Cuba.
In the hope that the announcement today would force the European Union to back down and reach an out-of-court settlement, the Administration said that it would not formally invoke its "national security exemption" for several weeks.
American officials insist that if they formally declare the issue a matter of national security, that move would abort the hearings. But European officials may ask for a judgment against the United States in absentia, even though an Administration official briefing reporters today said, "We do not believe anything the W.T.O. says or does can force the U.S. to change its laws."
The central issue in the increasingly bitter dispute is Europe's claim that the United States has violated international law by imposing penalties on foreign companies that conduct business in Cuba using properties or assets that once belonged to American companies. Those properties, which include Cuba's telephone system, were expropriated by Havana four decades ago.
The penalties, which include barring executives of those companies from entering the United States, are intended to force foreign governments to support the American effort to isolate Fidel Castro.
But the European action and the American response raise a deeper issue: how this highly charged case could damage the authority of the W.T.O., which was created by a global trade accord that went into effect two years ago. The case is the first to test the scope of the organization's authority, in an age when trade issues and broader political and security questions often merge.
Today officials on both sides of the Atlantic accused each other of undermining the organization.
European officials described as arrogant the American effort to declare the law outside of the World Trade Organization's jurisdiction. They argued that if the United States did not want the issue dealt with as a trade matter, it should not have employed trade sanctions.
"It is not credible to suggest that protection of U.S. national security requires interference in the legitimate trade of European companies with Cuba," Sir Leon Brittan, the European Union's top official for foreign trade, said this week.
The United States insisted that the embargo has nothing to do with trade because it is not intended to protect American products or American industry. "By bringing noncommercial matters into the W.T.O., the E.U. may well jeopardize what we and others have worked so hard to achieve," Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of Commerce and the President's special envoy on the Cuba issue, said today.
For many in the Administration, however, the confrontation poses particularly difficult problems. Several of Mr. Clinton's advisers counseled him against signing Helms-Burton, though the fact that Cuba shot down two American planes flown by members of a Cuban exile group led Mr. Clinton to conclude that he had no choice. Other advisers urged him to sign the bill, arguing that it was important to Cuban-Americans in Florida and New Jersey, which at the time were considered potential swing states in the Presidential election.
The signing of the bill led to outrage in Canada, Mexico and Europe, all of which do extensive business with Cuba. They all passed laws countering with sanctions on behalf of their own companies if Washington sought to invoke its sanctions.
Since then, however, President Clinton has twice suspended a crucial element of the law, which would allow Americans to sue foreign companies -- in American courts -- for the use of expropriated American property in Cuba. Europe was not satisfied. "We cannot have the sword of Damocles hanging over our heads," Jacques Santer, president of the European Commission, said during a visit here two months ago.
Under the provision barring executives of foreign companies that run afoul of Helms-Burton, only executives from Canada and Mexico have been barred so far, though it is likely that officials of Italy's telecommunications company will soon be prohibited as well, American officials say.
The most disputed aspect of today's action was the American insistence that it could stop the case by simply declaring that Helms-Burton was not a question of trade, but one of national security and foreign policy -- and that the W.T.O. did not have the power to come to its own judgment on that question.
"I think the U.S. is way off base," said Prof. John H. Jackson, a leading expert on the treaty that created the World Trade Organization. Professor Jackson, who teaches at the University of Michigan, added in a telephone interview: "The U.S. might be right that this is an issue of national security. But I don't think there is any basis for saying that it can take a walk, without allowing the panel to consider the issue."
Within the Administration, that decision was the subject of considerable debate. The United States files far more complaints about foreign trade practices than are filed against it, and some Administration officials have argued inside the White House that the precedent in this case could soon be turned against American interests. Japan, for example, claims that its prohibition on rice imports is a matter of "food security," not trade; South Korea has made a similar argument about protecting its car industry.
American officials disputed this argument. Mr. Eizenstat argued that Europe is challenging "three decades of American Cuba policy that goes back to the Kennedy Administration," and is aimed entirely at forcing a change of government in Havana.
European officials said they hoped that a settlement could be reached, and both sides are looking for a way out. But late today one senior American official said: "What the Europeans want us to do is agree not to enforce the law. We can't do that. If there was an easy way out we would have found it by now."

HEADLINE: Attack Is Waged on Plan to Pay for Fewer Doctors

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Hospital executives around the nation and powerful members of Congress are reacting with rage to the Federal Government's highly unusual plan to award special payments to hospitals in New York State that agree to train fewer doctors.
They say that at a time when hospitals everywhere are struggling to hold down costs in an era of managed care, the program amounts to a multimillion-dollar sweetheart deal for hospitals with powerful political ties. 
 "The chairmen of this committee are asking why did New York get this special goody before Congress got to their orderly process of developing a national policy on medical education?" said Ari Fleischer, the spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee, which provides money for Medicare.
Under an experiment announced earlier this week, the Health Care Financing Administration will pay New York hospitals $400 million in exchange for the hospitals' agreement to reduce the number of doctors they train by 20 to 25 percent over the next six years.
Proposed by the Greater New York Hospital Association as a demonstration project last fall, the plan received an unusually quick approval from the Health Care Financing Administration and does not need Congressional approval.
But Republican Congressmen on the Ways and Means Committee were furious that they were barely consulted about so large a deal. And though the committee cannot alter the New York program, Mr. Fleischer predicted that the coming health care debates could take on a newly acrimonious tone and cause problems for the Clinton Administration's attempts to change Medicare.
"The deal may have merit," he said. "But in offering a special deal to New York, the administration may have created for themselves some non-New York headaches."
The project's goal is to create a financial incentive for hospitals to produce fewer doctors and to save the Medicare program money. Some health care experts contend that the nation has too many doctors, who drive up costs by ordering unnecessary tests and expensive procedures.
Medicare now pays hospitals up to about $100,000 each year in "training subsidies" for each resident they employ; critics say those payments have led to a swelling number of residents. The new program gives hospitals that have relied on residents as a source of cheap labor money to find alternate ways to dispense care.
Hospital executives across the nation have praised the idea behind the program, but say they too should receive the compensation that New York hospitals will be getting. They say that the pressures of managed care have forced them to cut training programs, too, and that no Federal program has cushioned their financial losses.
Dr. H. Richard Neeson, president of the Partners Health Care System in Boston, said that he is already well into a five-year plan to reduce the number of residents by 20 percent. "We're doing this anyway, and as of now we're not getting paid for it," he said. "I see no reason why we shouldn't be helped."
But New York hospital executives, Health Care Financing Administration officials and New York politicians defended the plan and dismissed the complaints as sour grapes. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who last month wrote a letter supporting the plan to some members of the Ways and Means Committee, said that people in other parts of the nation should view the program as an interesting experiment that they will someday join in if it proves to save the Government money.
"If this is just a case of 'I want everything you have at the same time,' it won't work," Mr. D'Amato said. "We don't have as many defense bases as people in other states, because you look at national security needs. We don't get money from farm bills because we're not a state that participates in many of those programs. We don't have big water project like dams. But hospitals and teaching hospitals we have provided."
Bruce C. Vladeck, the administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, has a simple answer for why the demonstration project was awarded to New York: "The reason we went to New York is because New York came to us with the idea and asked."
Last summer, officials from the Greater New York Hospital Association sent an unsolicited and radical proposal to Federal regulators: why not see what would happen if the Government paid hospitals in New York not to train so many doctors?
Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the New York hospitals group, said many member hospitals had complained to him that while they wanted to cut the size of their resident staffs, they could not afford to lose the generous Federal training funds that came with each resident.
In just six months, the association's proposal moved through the normal bureaucratic hurdles of theGovernment with surprising ease.
Mr. Raske said the quick approval was partly due to the Hospital Association's clever plan and hard work -- as well as to the fact that 15 percent of the nation's doctors train in New York. But some health experts give equal credit to a host of powerful New Yorkers, in Congress and in health care, who used their connections to smooth the way.
"New York is clearly a leader in medical education in the United States," Mr. Raske said. "And anyway, we designed it and we had the technical expertise to carry it out."
He added that the member hospitals were forced to make major concessions to the Health Care Financing Administration to be allowed to join the program, like accepting restrictions on how to deploy their residents.
He said that the terms that the association negotiated with H.C.F.A. last December were so restrictive that he anticipated that at most 12 hospitals would participate in the voluntary plan. Three weeks later, he was shocked when 41 signed up, including all of New York City's major medical centers.
The many ties between New York's hospitals, politicians and the top officials at the Health Care Financing Administration probably helped pave the way for this highly unusual plan, health experts say.
For example, Mr. Vladeck, who approved the project, is a former health care executive from New York City who has said he expects to return there. Because of his connections, he has previously recused himself from deliberations involving projects in New York, but chose not to in this case.
Mr. Vladeck said that he "worried about being involved in this decision a little bit," but decided that there was no direct conflict of interest and that "there were enough external checks and balances."
The Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Office of Management and Budget both had to approve the proposal.
Although the project did not need Congressional approval, Senator D'Amato -- who last year won the annual award of the Greater New York Hospital Association -- ran interference on the House floor, firing off calming letters to Representatives Bill Archer of Texas and Bill Thomas of California, powerful Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee.
But since the plan's release this week, it has become clear those misgivings remained. Mr. Fleischer, the spokesman for the committee, said that Mr. Archer and Mr. Thomas were upset that the administration had announced the program before even consulting the House committee. And they disagreed that New York was a natural testing place for the plan.
"When you pick for a demonstration project the nation's biggest market," Mr. Fleischer said, "you cross the line from demonstration to special deal for big player on block."
Some health care experts worried that the poltical fireworks would obscure what they saw as the overwhelming merits of the plan.
"Hospitals are a major part of the New York economy, like Grumman fighters, so of course the New York delegation would not let graduate medical education shrink without exacting something," said Dr. Ed O'Neil, director of the Center for the Health Professions at the University of California of San Francisco. "But this is really a great first step for teaching hospitals. And if it took $400 million in grease to make it happen -- it's better than doing nothing, which is what the New York delegation was willing to give in the past."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Loses 92.75 Points, Falling Below 7,000
Stocks tumbled in what some analysts saw as a natural retreat for an increasingly expensive market. The Dow industrials fell 92.75 points, to 6,927.38, after being down by 114 points at one point late in the session. 
 Since crossing the 7,000-point level last week, the Dow has swung sharply, and many analysts have said it will be difficult for stocks to maintain their rapid growth, though few say they expect the market to give up its gains. [Page D6.]
 
Treasury securities prices were lower for the third consecutive session, hurt by a decline in the dollar and a selloff in Treasury futures. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.65 percent from 6.57. [D13.]
 
The drop in the dollar came amid signs of economic strength in Europe and more attempts by German central bankers to stem the American currency's recent rise. [D5.]
 
China's Economy After Deng
Deng Xiaoping seemed to have a magic touch in China's rocky transition to a mixed economy. Though the death of Mr. Deng, China's paramount leader, is not expected to stop the free-market forces he helped release, the big question now seems to be at what pace the nation's economic shift will proceed. [A15.]
 
Compuserve Reports a Loss
Compuserve, whose chief executive resigned this week, reported a quarterly loss that was slightly smaller than expected. The company also reported a decline in subscriptions for its flagship computer on-line business but said membership rose in other areas. [D2.]
 
Borland to Cut 300 Jobs
Borland International, the struggling software company, said that it would lay off about 30 percent of its work force. [D2.]
 
Mixed Signs in Economic Data
Reports showed a possible cooling off in housing and continued strength in the labor market. Construction starts on homes and apartments rose 2 percent last month, less than expected, while initial claims for unemployment benefits rose less than expected last week. [D2.]
 
Tandy: On the Road Back?
Tandy reported stronger-than-expected operating earnings for the fourth quarter, though the gains were wiped out by charges from a revamping of its retail chains. Still, the results hint that Tandy may be starting to turn itself around. Market Place. [D6.]
 
U.S. to Boycott Review of Embargo
Hours after the World Trade Organization appointed a panel of judges to hear a European challenge to Washington's embargo of Cuba, the United States said it would refuse to take part in the proceedings. It declared that the body "has no competence to proceed" in an issue of American national security. [A1.]
 
Boeing 737 Is Called Less Safe
The Boeing 737, the most widely used passenger jet, is less safe than other airliners because the failure of a single valve, the one that controls the rudder, can cause it to crash, the National Transportation Safety Board said. But the board did not ground the planes or even declare them unsafe, and Boeing and the F.A.A. disagreed that the plane was less airworthy than others. [A1.]
 
Earnings Decline at Penney
J. C. Penney said that operating earnings declined in the fourth quarter despite a 23 percent increase in sales. The period was disappointing for many retailers. [D6.]
 
Protection for Medicaid Patients
President Clinton prohibited health maintenance organizations from limiting what doctors may tell Medicaid patients about treatment options. And he urged Congress to guarantee similar protections for more than 100 million Americans with private insurance, declaring that changes revolutionizing the health insurance and health care industries must not be allowed to erode the quality of medical care. [A22.]
