HEADLINE: A Figure of Infamy Is Held in a 2d Outrage

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
Some of his neighbors here say they believed Lawrence Singleton when he claimed to have been framed for the rape and mutilation of a California teen-ager nearly two decades ago, a crime that had made him a figure of nationwide infamy. Others, who have known him from childhood, believed that whether he had been framed or not, a man could always change.
So when Mr. Singleton made his way back here to his hometown in 1988 after his release from a California prison, and then settled last year in his old neighborhood, he was eventually accepted, although some mothers watched their children more closely and some husbands kept closer track of their wives. 
 "We were scared of him at first," said his next-door neighbor, Tom Bennett. "But every day he'd talk to you; he'd cook steaks and bring them to you. He fixed up his property really good. He was the neighbor you dream of. I started to believe him: 'maybe he was framed.' "
But on Wednesday night, Mr. Singleton, now 69, was arrested and charged with first-degree murder in the fatal stabbing of a prostitute inside his renovated single-story wooden home, the house that had made his neighborhood proud.
And now Mr. Bennett, like others on Mr. Singleton's street in that working-class neighborhood, are saying that the California authorities should never have released him to live in their midst.
Mr. Singleton was convicted in 1979 of raping a 15-year-old hitchhiker near Modesto, using an ax to chop off her forearms and leaving her to die at the side of a road. The girl, Mary Vincent, survived, and testified at his trial.
Sentenced to 14 years 4 months in prison, then the maximum punishment, Mr. Singleton was freed on parole after 8 years because of good behavior and his participation in a work-study program. That was in 1987, and the national notoriety he had acquired a decade earlier resurfaced as one California community after another protested parole officials' efforts to relocate him there. Mr. Singleton was finally forced to live in a mobile home on the grounds of San Quentin prison until the end of his parole, in 1988, when he returned to Tampa and, as required, registered with the State of Florida as a convicted felon.
The arrest on Wednesday night came barely three weeks after neighbors had pulled Mr. Singleton from his van as he attempted suicide in his driveway. On that afternoon, the neighbors said, he was found breathing the van's exhaust through a dryer hose that he had attached to the tailpipe. He spent about a week in psychiatric custody before returning home.
"He told me he was feeling sorry for himself," Mr. Bennett said, adding that Mr. Singleton had offered nothing more by way of explanation.
About 6 P.M. on Wednesday, Hillsborough County sheriff's officials said, a man who had done some renovation work for Mr. Singleton dropped by his house and heard a commotion inside. Peering in, the officials said, the man saw Mr. Singleton, naked, in the living room, choking and punching a woman, who was also nude, as she cried for help.
A deputy who responded to the man's 911 call says Mr. Singleton had blood on his shirt when he came to the door. The woman was dead.
The victim was identified as Roxanne Hayes, 31, a Tampa resident and mother of three children. She had a record of 99 arrests since 1986, more than a third of them for prostitution but some on charges of grand theft and cocaine possession.
The precise cause of death has not been determined, but Ms. Hayes suffered multiple knife wounds in the upper body, said Lieut. David Gee, a spokesman for the sheriff's office.
Exactly why Ms. Hayes was at Mr. Singleton's home -- whether he was a prostitution client of hers, or whether there was another reason for her being there -- remains unclear. The police said they did not know the answer, and Ms. Hayes's common-law husband, Clifford Tyson, a 40-year-old unemployed truck driver and cook, said in a tearful interview that he knew only that she had left their home to shop for groceries not long before Mr. Singleton's visitor found him attacking her.
That the dream neighbor has seemingly turned into a nightmare is no surprise to the California prosecutor who sent Mr. Singleton to prison for attempted murder, kidnapping, rape, sodomy, oral copulation, aggravated mayhem and the use of an ax to cause great bodily harm.
"I'm not going to say he's Hannibal Lecter, but once a guy like that has a certain bent he follows it the rest of his life," said the prosecutor, Donald N. Stahl, who retired last year as Stanislaus County District Attorney. "This guy has a personality that's bent in the direction of going after women."
The case that Mr. Stahl prosecuted helped galvanize the movement for tougher sentences in many states. In California, for instance, the Legislature has increased the mandatory terms for most violent crimes, and as a result Mr. Singleton would now face a life sentence for the kind of attack he inflicted on Miss Vincent, said Katie Corso, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Corrections.
Some sex-crime experts caution that Mr. Singleton is in ways an anomaly. They maintain that sex offenders as a whole are very much in need of treatment, not harsher punishment, and note that only a small minority go on to commit murder. The passions stirred by the crime of which Mr. Singleton was convicted and another with which he has now been charged should not be grounds for advocating the kind of penalties that would be unfair to most other sex offenders, these experts contend.
"This is a major public health issue in this country, and people need to look at it as such instead of trying to enact all these bizarre laws like public notification and chemical castration," said Robert Freeman-Longo, founder of the Association for the Treatment of Sexual Abusers, a treatment and prevention group.
But the Tampa murder sent shudders through the string of Northern California towns that, one by one, fought to keep Mr. Singleton out after his release on parole 10 years ago.
The killing of Ms. Hayes "could have happened here," said Dale Vassey, 27, a lifelong resident of one of those towns, Rodeo, about 20 miles northeast of San Francisco. "It just goes to show it's a good thing they did run him out of town."
Mr. Singleton, who was one of eight children reared in Tampa, also met with scorn when he first returned to the city, where most of his siblings still live. At first he moved into a brother's home, which soon became the target of a firebomb tossed into the front yard. A car dealer offered him $5,000 to leave the state.
In addition, protesters showed up at court hearings where he appeared as a result of his subsequent minor brushes with the law. Sheriff's officials say that in 1990 and 1991, he was arrested three times on shoplifting charges. At one hearing, he described himself as "a confused, muddle-headed old man."
But in Orient Park, the Tampa community where he had spent part of his childhood, and where he returned last year, his neighbors let him be. In fact, some say they did not learn of his record until his recent suicide attempt rekindled gossip about his criminal past.
"We never knew all that," David Sales, a neighbor who rescued him from the van, told The Associated Press today. "But when I found out, the first thing I thought was, 'Should I have left that man in there?' If I had known, I probably would have at least given it a second thought."
But many other neighbors did know, and say any concerns they had were assuaged by Mr. Singleton's conduct. He lived alone and on Social Security, they say, and spent most of his time remodeling and landscaping his property -- owned not by him, the neighbors say, but by his family. Several of his brothers and their wives visited often. And he loved his dog, a Rottweiler named Kala. He was also solicitous, offering to repair a neighbor's broken mailbox one day, going the next to the bar where another neighbor played in a band.
"We didn't like the idea that something had happened," said Georgia Polston, 78, who remembers Mr. Singleton as a 9-year-old and whose son went to school with one of his brothers. "But you can't make a big thing about it if you want to give people a chance."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
TENTATIVE AGREEMENT REACHED IN AUTO WORKERS' STRIKE

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Johnson Controls Inc. reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday with the United Auto Workers union, bringing an end to a 24-day strike that disrupted production at the Ford Motor Company. The contract covers about 500 workers at seat assembly plants in Plymouth and Oberlin, Ohio. Workers at the plants will be asked to ratify the contracts within two days. The Plymouth plant employs about 300 hourly workers and produces seats for the Ford Expedition sport utility vehicle. The Oberlin plant employs about 200 hourly workers and produces seats for the Econoline and Club Wagon vans. Ford refused to accept seats made by nonunion replacements and shut the lines down for a time.

HEADLINE: Pataki to Seek Waiver on Requiring Work for Food Stamps

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki plans to seek a waiver from new Federal welfare rules requiring adults to work in exchange for food stamps, sparing tens of thousands of the neediest New Yorkers from the prospect of losing their benefits.
The decision by Mr. Pataki, whose administration had been reluctant to pursue the waiver, came as he faced growing criticism from Democratic legislators and advocates for the poor who argued that recipients living in areas where jobs are scarce would otherwise lose their food stamp benefits. 
 In seeking the waiver, the Governor, who has trumpeted his record on economic growth, is acknowledging that there are not enough jobs in the state to absorb food stamp recipients.
The tightened food stamp rules are scheduled to go into effect on Saturday and will provide no more than three months of food stamps a year for able-bodied, childless adults under age 50 who are not working at least 20 hours a week.
The waiver the Governor will apply for is only temporary, lasting at least through the end of this year, said an aide who spoke on condition of anonymity. The aide said the decision to apply for it was made to give counties the time they need to do two things: place recipients in jobs, or establish systems for tracking the number of hours recipients work each week.
"No one should be penalized because they're able-bodied and willing to work," the Governor said last night during a radio interview on WCBS-AM.
The Governor's decision came after a rising chorus of criticism by religious groups who argued that tens of thousands of people would be harmed by the new rules. So far, 11 other states, including Illinois, Pennsylvania and Ohio, have applied for similar waivers by declaring that there are certain pockets in those states where the labor market is too weak to absorb welfare recipients.
But until now the Pataki administration has refused to apply for such a waiver, arguing that with the right mix of sanctions and incentives, it can coax beneficiaries into the job market.
Instead, it has sought a narrower waiver that would apply only to areas where unemployment rates are above 10 percent. In New York, only two such areas exist: the Bronx and Hamilton County, in the southern Adirondacks.
Another reason for the administration's reluctance to seek the broader waiver has been that in doing so, it would have to acknowledge there are regions in the state where job opportunities are scarce. That admission would be at odds with Mr. Pataki's contention that the state's economy has improved enough to provide jobs to most people who want them. Indeed, the basic premise of the Governor's plan to overhaul the state's welfare system is that most of its 500,000 recipients will be able to find work with the right combination of incentives and punishments.
But advocates for the poor and religious leaders have urged Mr. Pataki to apply for the broader waiver for the entire state, arguing that there are not enough low-skilled jobs for welfare recipients. They estimate that 100,000 able-bodied adults receive food stamps now and that many of them will lose their benefits in the next three months unless Mr. Pataki applies for the waiver.
They further argue that poor communities will be hurt economically if the Governor does not seek the waiver, because thousands of small grocery stores depend heavily on food stamp business. The advocates noted that seeking the waiver would not cost the state any additional money because food stamps are paid for entirely by the Federal Government.
This afternoon, a group of Democratic legislators and ministers held a press conference in the Capitol imploring the Governor to apply for the waiver before the deadline.
"There are not enough jobs," said Arleon L. Kelly, the executive steward of the New York State Community of Churches. "The waiver would benefit hungry people, neighborhood businesses, and the state economy. All would be winners."
Tonight, aides to the Governor continued to contend that their critics have exaggerated the effects of not getting a waiver. They say most of the people affected by the new Federal law are already required by state rules to work or to enroll in workfare programs and, as a result, will remain eligible for food stamps.
The aides also estimate that at most, 17,000 people might lose their benefits, and that they would eventually be placed into volunteer or other jobs created by local governments.
The aide said that counties do not have to take advantage of the waiver Mr. Pataki has applied for if they believe they are in the position to place their food stamp recipients into jobs. By contrast, the aide added, counties that do not have programs to place people in jobs or track the number of hours they have worked can use the waiver.
"This is not a jobs issue," said the aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "This is about giving counties additional time."

HEADLINE: CHINA AFTER DENG: THE ECONOMY;
Deng's Legacy: Finishing Long March to Capitalism

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Deng Xiaoping, the architect of China's policy of economic openness, seemed to possess a magic touch with China's economy in its rocky transition from Communism to capitalism.
But Mr. Deng has left his successors facing even tougher challenges, ones that he may not have been brave enough to take on. 
 Jiang Zemin, Mr. Deng's designated successor, and his circle of colleagues and adversaries have far less political legitimacy and influence than Mr. Deng. That may be crucial in pushing ahead with the next era of restructuring -- tackling the cumbersome state-run sector and adopting unpopular but necessary economic policies, like raising taxes, hiking prices or allowing large-scale layoffs.
This leaves one pressing question: will Mr. Deng's death threaten to derail the pace of China's progress on economic restructuring? Or is it possible his death might pave the way for even swifter change?
Today, business leaders in the United States expressed an almost stubborn optimism that China would remain on its current course of economic modernization. And markets around Asia seemed to take his death in stride, with stock indexes in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Taipei and Shenzhen edging higher.
Trading in the Hong Kong stock market opened smartly Thursday, as the Hang Seng Index jumped more than 200 points. The market finished the day up more than 300 points to close at 13,411.3, for a 2.3 percent gain. That would have been inconceivable a few years ago, when people were talking about a drop of 30 percent after Mr. Deng's death, and it is a sign that more and more people accept that a leadership transition has taken place.
Mr. Deng's death was not only anticipated, but Mr. Deng had already set in motion an economic revolution in China that stretched far beyond what any one man could control.
"It is still a market of taxicabs and chauffeur-driven vehicles," said John F. Smith Jr., chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, which has a sizable business in China. "The roads are currently missing, so that has to come first."
Mr. Deng's death does not change the fundamental strength of the economy, which grew nearly 10 percent last year. Savings rates are still high, labor remains cheap. China's public works and legal systems both remain weak but they are improving.
"Nobody in China has really lost from economic reform, and in the beginning that was very important," said Nicholas R. Lardy, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "But somehow along the line, you've got to start making some tough choices."
Those tough choices loomed while Mr. Deng was still alive, and they remain China's greatest challenge for the future. And yet, Mr. Deng's presence was so pivotal to China's economic restructuring that his own gradualist approach suggests how difficult it must have been at times to bring China this far.
It will certainly be hard to match the magic of China's former patriarch. When Mr. Deng made what has become known as his imperial journey to the south in 1992, a time when economic restructuring was stalling, he was nominally just a retired old man.
But in fact, his trip paved the way for remarkable changes in national economic policy. A "socialist market economy was in favor;" central planning was out. And suddenly, a new economic vitality spread rapidly throughout the country.
Mr. Deng was a decisive leader, and when problems arose or critics swooped down on him, he forged ahead steadily and determinedly. That is exactly the opposite of the approach taken by Jiang Zemin, China's cautious Communist leader.
Mr. Deng had the influence to override conservatives who thought economic modernization should proceed much more slowly. China still has a clutch of elderly leaders, some of whom are ardent, revolutionary purists, and they may now press for a slower pace of economic restructuring. It is unlikely they will win, but there may at least be a tortuous, protracted battle that itself could delay economic change.
Finally, Mr. Deng had the political capital to make dramatic and painful changes in China. He did not always exercise it, but he did begin to allow companies to lay off workers and he gingerly began to accept the concept that companies could go bankrupt.
Still, in a sense, one of Mr. Deng's critical economic contributions survives him: economic restructuring is no longer an ideological question. It is more of a technical one.
When the Chinese leadership debates how to introduce capital markets or dissolve inefficiencies in the state sector, the debate is not over whether these steps are allowable. Instead, they are about the concrete process of how to go about orchestrating the change.
For example, how can welfare benefits be taken away from people? How can workers be laid off, and how can new jobs be found for them, to keep them from protesting in the streets? They are issues that are as much a headache for any capitalist leader.
In some ways, China's younger, more technocratic and worldly crop of leaders are better equipped than their elderly predecessors to handle the next stage of economic challenges. Mr. Jiang and Mr. Li probably understand the technical issues about the economy better than did Mr. Deng, and they are acutely aware that a vibrant, flourishing and progressing economy is the core of their legitimacy.
But they may not have a strong enough political will, the discipline or the mandate to carry out unpopular measures. Moreover, if the Chinese leadership is divided, neither Mr. Jiang nor Mr. Li may have the ability to break the impasse.
There are a cast of characters surrounding Mr. Jiang and Mr. Li in the collective leadership, and one or another of them may be potentially daring and shrewd enough to emerge as a kingmaker.
One leader who sometimes has demonstrated a flair for the bold is Zhu Rongji, a Deputy Prime Minister who is often considered China's new economic czar. He helped steer China's overheated economy to a soft landing in recent years, curbing inflation without choking growth.
Some even see him as China's Gorbachev, or a future emperor, though, those who do are mostly foreigners. Indeed, with Mr. Deng gone, some economists like Mr. Lardy say there may be possibilities for faster or more substantial progress to be made if well-informed, better-trained technocrats are allowed to proceed with restructuring.
China's economic successes have been phenomenal. But along with this wealth has come signs of the evils of 19th century industrial capitalism in the West. Fly-by-night companies in China often produce dangerous products, families send their children to sweatshops instead of schools, inequalities are expanding, and the get-rich-quick mentality creates its own excesses.
Mr. Deng was perhaps not courageous enough to confront the most troublesome remnant of Communism: the inefficient state sector and the circle of financial and systemic problems surrounding it.
"I think there were some things that it was harder to raise and debate openly while he was still alive," said Robert A. Knapp, president of the U.S.-China Business Council.
China's state sector used to be the core of its economy, but now it is draining the economy dry, Mr. Knapp added. Loans to inefficient state-owned enterprises have doubled as a percentage of gross national product, according to Mr. Lardy.
"When we look back in 5 to 10 years, I think his legacy will not look so strong," said Mr. Lardy. "Because it will be more readily apparent that part of the success of Deng's strategy has been one of deferring reform. So he has left it to the next generation of leaders to make some of the tough choices."

An article on Friday about China's economic prospects after Deng Xiaoping's death misspelled the surname of the president of the U.S.-China Business Council. He is Robert A. Kapp, not Knapp.

HEADLINE: Columbus Circle Arts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I applaud Michael Kimmelman's recommendation (Critic's Notebook, Feb. 15) that New York City should guarantee a place for the visual arts at the redeveloped Columbus Circle site.
Rather than support the visual arts and its resident artists who add to the city's cultural hegemony and economic vigor, New York City closed its own gallery at 2 Columbus Circle in the early 1990's. 
 Mr. Kimmelman reports that the Dahesh Museum is interested in relocating to Columbus Circle. That might increase the visibility of 19th-century art, but it would do nothing to increase the visibility of the city's underrepresented and talented living artists.
 
LIBBY W. SEABERG

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers to End Day Up Against Mark and Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered somewhat yesterday, ending higher against the Japanese yen and the German mark after a broad decline on Thursday.
The dollar continues to be bolstered by expectations that robust growth and attractive interest rates will keep drawing foreign investors to United States markets. 
 "It's a no-brainer," said Paul Spirgel, senior currency dealer at Royal Bank of Scotland in New York. "The U.S. economy is doing all the right things. Interest rates are high and the stock market is going nutty."
For the week, however, the dollar's rally sputtered, as Germany's economy showed signs of life, and as monetary officials there and in Japan spoke out against further gains. The dollar ended the week lower versus the yen for the first time in six weeks, and was little changed against the mark.
Currency traders were also reluctant to buy too many dollars before Congressional testimony next week by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, which could provide clues to the outlook for interest rates.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 123.28 yen, up from 122.55 Thursday. The dollar rose to 1.6887 marks from 1.6840. But the dollar lost ground against the British pound, which fetched $1.6172, compared with $1.6107.
Most of the dollar's gains came in late morning trading in New York, when it shot up about 1 yen and almost 1 pfennig in a brief rush to sell yen for marks, traders said. Many mark-yen transactions go through the dollar, so traders were buying dollars for yen and then selling the dollars for marks. Traders also sold yen for Swiss francs.
The dollar retreated from its highs when Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said that it had "fully corrected" against the mark, the Reuters news service reported, echoing the statement made by leaders of the world's leading industrial countries at the close of their meeting in Berlin at the beginning of the month.
Earlier, Eisuke Sakakibara, a senior Japanese Finance Ministry official, said the yen had stabilized against the dollar. Those kinds of statements are leading traders to speculate that too rapid a rise in the dollar may prompt central bankers in Japan and Germany to buy their own currencies to strengthen them.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bond Prices Stage a Cautious Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bonds staged a mild rally yesterday, as buyers emerged to take advantage of the lower prices and higher yields after three days of selling in the bond market. But even though there appeared to be interest at these higher yield levels, traders said investors remained cautious.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 7/32 , to 99 28/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.64 percent from 6.65 percent. 
 Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the price rise was hurt by comments by the Federal Reserve's vice chairwoman, Alice M. Rivlin, who said tight labor markets could force higher interest rates.
"It's important to note that this warning raised a significant number of eyebrows within the credit markets, primarily because many market bears had been whipsawed into believing that their fears of inflation due to the tight labor markets have been mostly unjustified," Mr. Chan said.
The dollar rebounded from its previous day's decline to give added support to the bond market, and so did futures trading, where the expiration of options yesterday kept the March bond contract near a key price level of 113.
"Although Rivlin indicated that the stronger dollar helps mitigate some of the economy's inflationary pressures," Mr. Chan said, "she indicated that one of the side effects of a stronger dollar was to hurt exports, which in turn could worsen our inflationary environment."
Analysts said that next week bond market investors would have to absorb fresh supply, several pieces of economic news and testimony by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan. before the Senate and the House.
Mr. Chan does not think Mr. Greenspan's testimony in the Senate on Wednesday and in the House on Thursday will cause too much nervousness among investors "because everyone knows that he is going into those sessions with a favorable set of Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index numbers in his pocket," Mr. Chan said. "As a result, even if we get a strong nonfarm payroll report in early March, most investors expect the Fed will be able to keep policy unchanged a bit longer."
Still, enough uncertainty exists to keep investors from taking any large positions over the near future. Mr. Chan figures investors are more likely to focus on the forward-looking information like unemployment claims and durable goods data, both to be released on Thursday.
Michael Krauss, chief technical strategist at Chase Securities Inc., said Treasuries were stuck in a trading range, with the yield on the long bond trapped between 6.50 percent and 6.75 percent.
Yesterday's session was quiet as the market basically moved sideways, Mr. Krauss said. "In fact, this year could see a lot of sideways action and not a big trending year," he said. "This will be a good year for singles hitters as opposed to the home run hitters, where market participants will be looking for smaller trades, trying to profit from 10-to-20-basis-point movements. Speculators will have to lower their sights and take profits quicker."
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's Treasury note auctions, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.85 percent and the five-year issue at a price to yield 6.16 percent.
David Ader, managing analyst at Technical Data of Boston, said that based on recent volume data of when-issued trading "we would look at those auctions with a defensive posture."
He noted that through yesterday afternoon, the market had traded 60 percent of the typical when-issued volume for the two-year notes, while for the five-year notes, the market had traded 58 percent of when-issued volume.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Delayed, but Good Deeds Get Done

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
With only six days days left in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's 85th annual appeal, donations have slowed and the fund remains about $140,000 behind the total collected last year. The appeal, which began after Thanksgiving, runs until Friday.
Last year's appeal, the second-best in the fund's history, raised $4,815,609.76. The record of $5,083,520.81 was set in 1992. 
 February is typically the fund's slowest month and, as donations have waned in recent days, the mail accompanying readers' contributions has become a stream of confessions from procrastinators across the New York metropolitan region. For one reason or another, they delayed. But they did not forget.
"After reading almost every daily installment of your touching stories, I am moved to tears, to contemplation, and to donation -- but I procrastinate," wrote Marina L. Myhre of Tenafly, N.J. "I'll send the check tomorrow. Oh, I was going to send that last week. Well, finally today I made the move." She sent $100, adding, "Go break $5 million."
Frann L. Goldstein of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, also rallied against the forces of delay. "Finally," she proclaimed in a note with her contribution of $118. "I don't even remember how many years of thinking and intending to . . . I am a long-time reader of The New York Times, and so, a long-time admirer of the fund. I have been moved, humbled and sometimes scared by the stories you print, by the life circumstances some have to meet. I have had moments of true thankfulness -- on the subway, on my way to work -- because of all that I have. Thank you for the example and the reminder of the fund."
Founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, the former publisher of the newspaper, the Neediest Cases Fund extends a helping hand to New Yorkers who need one by supporting seven of the city's oldest and largest private charities. Mr. Ochs believed that stories of the city's poor would move readers to give.
The newspaper pays all administrative expenses so donations go directly to cash assistance and services for poor people in the five boroughs, including the hungry and the homeless, the sick and the disabled, many of them children and the elderly.
William Perez, a second grader at Public School 21 in Queens whose class raised $17.18 for the fund, wrote: "My class has collected money for the neediest cases. I would like the money to be used to help the people that are poor and the people that don't have clothes and people that don't have money and people that don't have a place to live and people that don't have food to eat, people that don't have a car and a TV."
The readers who contribute represent a rainbow of generosity. Donations arrive from around the world, from the famous and the modest. They are young and old, some are rich, some are just getting by. But all feel fortunate to be able to give, to help those who have less, even if they wait until the last minute.
"I regret that I have procrastinated all these years," wrote Nancy Crawford Sutcliffe of Northport, L.I., who sent $20. "I am currently unemployed and thus cannot give much. Hopefully that will soon change. Please add this money to your fund."
Many people associate the fund's appeal with the holiday season but donations are accepted all year, just as the aid to the poor is given all year. Contributions postmarked after Feb. 28 will be applied to next year's campaign.
"I have been procrastinating sending this donation to you since Christmas-time," wrote Tricia Cotthaus Brown of the Upper West Side, who sent $50. "Everyday I read about others in New York who endure difficult circumstances and I realize how lucky I am."
There are six days left. To delay may mean to forget.

HEADLINE: World Forestry Talks End in Division on Whether to Curb Logging

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 21

 BODY:
With the world's forests continuing to shrink, more than 70 governments ended two years of talks today deeply divided over whether to propose binding steps to curb overlogging.
Senior environmental ministers meeting in April might yet breathe life into the proposal when discussions continue at a commission monitoring pledges made at the the Rio de Janeiro environmental summit meeting of 1992. 
But if opponents of a forestry convention -- including the Clinton Administration and Brazil -- stand their ground, firm action is unlikely to be taken on forestry when world leaders gather in June for the fifth anniversary of the Rio meeting.
After holding 10 meetings on five continents since 1995, the Intergovernmental Panel on Forests today drew up a wish-list for preserving dwindling forest reserves. It set no specific targets and left compliance voluntary and unmonitored.
The 15 European Union countries and Canada pressed hard for the forestry panel to recommend an immediate start to talks on a binding convention. They had the support of several developing countries, including Malaysia, Indonesia, Uganda and Papua New Guinea. Such a proposal would then have become the centerpiece of the June meeting.
But they failed to overcome the opposition of an unusual coalition of the United States, Australia, Brazil and some other developing nations, united with several environmental groups, including the Worldwide Fund for Nature, Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth.
The Clinton Administration appears as reluctant to accept a forestry convention as the Bush Administration was at Rio five years ago. But many environmental groups, after lobbying unsuccessfully for an agreement then, are having second thoughts today.
At Rio, world leaders adopted three conventions: to protect the climate, to protect plants and wildlife (which the United States refused to sign), and to stop the encroachment of desert onto fertile land.
But a planned fourth convention -- now often called "the missing Rio convention" -- was blocked by the United States, fearful of restrictions on its lumber industry. It acted in alliance with much of the developing world, which feared that an agreement might limit economic growth. Instead, the summit meeting settled for a nonbinding declaration of principles that countries should follow.
Today, many environmental groups have concluded that the record has been so dismal that in the six to 10 years it would take to negotiate and ratify a convention, governments would only relax their protection of forests.
And given the depth of disagreement over the shape of a convention, they also despair that the actual text would be geared to anything but the lowest common denominator, amounting to little more than "a loggers' charter."
A better approach, they now argue, is to build on the many voluntary initiatives that have begun, including a plan to declare 10 percent of the world's forests protected areas by 2000.
At their closing news conference today, the two co-chairmen of the governmental panel, Sir Martin Holdgate, who is scientific adviser to the British Environmental Ministry, and Prof. Manuel Rodriguez-Becerra of Colombia, put the best face on their group's inability to agree on a forestry convention.
They argued that their deliberations had led to a better understanding of the dangers facing forests and to a shared determination. "At Rio the two sides were shouting past each other," Sir Martin said. "Now we have a real dialogue."
But he acknowledged that the world had not lived up to the lip service paid to forest conservation at the Earth Summit. "Some trends in the misuse of forests have not been reversed, and in some parts of the world they are accelerating," he said.

HEADLINE: Too Many Lawyers? Wait Until 2005

BYLINE: By Richard Dooling; Richard Dooling, a lawyer and novelist, is author of "Blue Streak: Swearing, Free Speech and Sexual Harassment."

DATELINE: OMAHA

 BODY:
The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently predicted that we will have 28 percent more lawyers by the year 2005. That means 839,000 working lawyers, compared with the 656,000 practicing law in 1994. From another perspective: Job growth in the legal profession will be twice the average projected for all occupations. Pretty promising stats for the most hated profession in the America.
Everybody detests lawyers, but we can't seem to make them fast enough. The same people who nod approvingly when it is reported that the number of sexual harassment cases has increased by 300 percent, or that environmental litigation has doubled, draw another breath and vent their spleen on the profession charged with drafting, enforcing, interpreting and litigating their beloved regulations. 
 We despise lawyers, but we seem to like laws, especially when they provide us with federally mandated extra maternity days in the hospital, federally guaranteed unpaid leaves from our jobs and, perhaps in the near future, federally guaranteed rights to coffee brewed at federally regulated temperatures.
Passing more comprehensive and more intrusive laws every year and then blaming the growing number of lawyers for the ensuing litigation is a little like starting a war and then blaming the casualties on the growing number of morticians.
In the first 70 years of this century, 25 laws regulating employment were adopted. Between 1970 and 1993, Congress passed 72 more, including such Gordian knots of legal obfuscation as the Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Occupational Safety and Health Act. Small wonder that one growth area is employment law, with the hottest segment being sexual harassment litigation.
We've also passed new and better laws governing the environment and health care. No surprise that a bumper crop of environmental litigators and joint-degree lawyer-hospital administrators are projected to arrive on schedule.
The angels of our better natures were no doubt in charge when we passed most of these important, popular laws. But even an angel can use a smart lawyer. New laws or expanded interpretations of old ones are often widely supported because they confer rights or attack perceived vices. But laws spawn litigation, and litigation brings its own costs, including huge bills from teams of lawyers who are simply doing their jobs and resolving disputes authorized by the laws we have passed.
They are no more reprehensible than any other free agent in a free market economy. They can be for or against rights or vices, depending on whose ox is being gored and whether the fee is being paid by the cattlemen or the slaughterhouse. But without laws to fight over, they are out of work. Even the most carefully drafted Family Leave Act, for example, will throng the docket with lawyers paid by the hour to argue over the statutory definitions of "family" and "leave."
Then, of course, committees of lawyers must write and read the inevitable accompanying voluminous regulations detailing record-keeping, administrative procedures, filing requirements and other stuporifics so unspeakably dense, tedious and prolix that no lawyers in their right minds would invest the time and effort required to read and understand them, unless they were getting paid $200 an hour for their trouble -- present company included.
Is all of this worth the mandatory leave heretofore denied by a small percentage of hard-hearted employers? "Yes! Definitely," scream the lawyers. Now go ask your barber if you need a haircut.
 The old Latin proverb put it best: We labored first with vices, now with laws. How much of our hostility toward lawyers is displaced frustration with the limits of laws and lawsuits? And if those dreaded lawyers keep popping up everywhere, maybe it's because we have an irrational faith in litigation.
Maybe we legislate to express our compassion for our fellow citizens and then blame lawyers when our statutory works of art go into the meat grinder of litigation. We have not yet absorbed the lesson learned by Voltaire, who said: "I was never ruined but twice: Once when I lost a lawsuit, and once when I won one."

GRAPHIC: Drawing (E. Subitzky)

HEADLINE: Condolence Calls Put Rare Light on Deng's Family

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Just north of the Forbidden City, where China's emperors once lived, a maze of dusty lanes and grubby back alleys are punctuated by simple red doorways befitting ramshackle homes. Behind some of these doorways, however, lie the elegant and spacious courtyard dwellings of the families of China's Communist Party leaders, a new kind of Forbidden City.
In one dirt-and-cobblestone lane, one black limousine after another came to call this week to see the elderly widow and five middle-aged children of Deng Xiaoping. 
 The visitors were classmates and colleagues, relatives and friends, fellow members of a select club: the sons and daughters to China's senior leaders, also known as princelings, or taizi, as they are called in Chinese.
The five Deng children have enjoyed being at the pinnacle of this club for years, but one question that looms over Beijing since Mr. Deng's death is exactly how it will affect them.
Mr. Deng's death has not led to any repudiation of his rule, at least not yet, so there is no sudden movement to purge his relatives. Their wealth, though it causes resentment among more ordinary folk, is partly protected by the deep sense of fraternity among the politically privileged.
"None of the Deng children have any money problems, but the problem lies right there," said the daughter of a senior official, suggesting that they had taken advantage of their positions to make large sums of money. "They are all vulnerable, but I don't think anything will happen to them unless they look as if they're getting excessive." She spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Translating superior connections into lucrative business, the class of princelings has profited enormously from the economic freedom the previous generation introduced.
The myth of Communist China was that everyone would be equal, if poor; today's version is that a socialist-market economy gives everyone a chance to grow rich. But the rules are stacked, it turns out, in favor of the families of the leaders who make the rules.
While the Deng family's position at the top of this club has receded slightly with Mr. Deng's health in the last year or two, the brothers and sisters are so entrenched in the network that purging one or more would require serious political effort by Jiang Zemin, China's President.
Last year he had a chance. The younger of Mr. Deng's sons, Deng Zhifang, was at the top of a state-run corporation whose leaders were prosecuted for corruption.
Deng Zhifang returned to China in 1990 after studying physics at the University of Rochester for seven years. A socially awkward man, he was fascinated by the challenge of adapting computer software to Chinese characters, but, apparently unable to resist the lure, he turned to business.
He accepted some of the deals offered by the many Hong Kong businessmen looking for "iron connections" within China, including a partnership with Li Ka-shing, a billionaire real estate developer. But the young Mr. Deng became most closely allied with Zhou Beifang, who headed the Hong Kong subsidiary of China's leading steel producer, Shougang Corporation, and whose father, Zhou Guanwu, the head of the corporation, was close to Deng Xiaoping.
Last November, when the younger Mr. Zhou was sentenced to life in prison for taking bribes of more than $1 million, it was unclear whether Deng Zhifang would also be investigated, a decision so sensitive that it could be made only with the approval of President Jiang. Since then, Mr. Deng has resigned his position as a managing director at the Hong Kong company, but remains a consultant.
"Deng Zhifang has probably set it up so he can go overseas if he needs to," a member of a prominent political family said. "It's hard to imagine Jiang Zemin moving against him."
Deng Xiaoping's youngest daughter, Xiao Rong, angered senior leaders when she gave The New York Times an interview in January 1995 without their prior permission, and discussed her father's failing health.
Deng Pufang, her older brother, made a speech last summer that ostensibly defended his father's aggressive economic reform policies, but which apparently was interpreted by some senior officials as a defense of the Deng family's influence, and their right to wield it.
Family members are said to have frequently quarreled with the Communist Party staff over how to care for Mr. Deng as his health deteriorated. These instances may be a normal part of the push-and-pull tension that always exists between a political family and the government with which it is intertwined.
Yet such clashes often required the intervention of Wang Ruilin, a top aide to Mr. Deng for decades, and head of Mr. Deng's personal office until it was formally disbanded a few months ago.
"The importance of his role in assisting Jiang Zemin has been in getting the Deng family out of politics," said Michael D. Swaine, director of the Center for Asia-Pacific Policy at the Rand Corporation.
Zhuo Lin, Mr. Deng's wife of 58 years, is 80 and has suffered from a nerve disease that became so painful, acquaintances said, that one day last year she took so many painkillers that she almost died. The panic that ensued among doctors set off a round of rumors that Mr. Deng was close to death, before word gradually spread that it was his wife.
The leader's widow is said to eschew the kind of ostentatious luxury her children enjoy, keeping with the tradition of the elder generation of China's leaders, who extolled Communism and simple living.
But the sons and daughters of senior leaders are highly secretive and almost tribal in the way they keep to insulated circles of friends, It is often difficult to uncover even the most basic information about them, including where they work or live or invest their money, except in unusual cases like Deng Zhifang's.
Yet some information is available:
*Deng Lin, the eldest daughter, 55, was once a painter of traditional Chinese watercolors who more recently started dabbling in abstract expressionism. Critics have not been as enthusiastic about her work as have Japanese businessmen, particularly ones with operations in China.
*Deng Pufang, the eldest son, 52, is chairman of China's Federation for the Disabled. He has used a wheelchair since he fell from a fourth-story window after being harassed by Red Guards during the Cultural Revolution.
*Deng Nan, a second daughter, 51, is a deputy minister in the State Commission for Science and Technology.
*Xiao Rong, 46, who for years accompanied her father and yelled in his ear to compensate for his poor hearing, has two positions listed on her business card: deputy chairwoman of the China Association for International Friendly Contact, and deputy to the National People's Congress, the rough equivalent of a Congresswoman.
Also a consultant to many Hong Kong companies, Xiao Rong has said she still draws a $125-a-month salary from the army, where she once worked full time.
Her husband, He Ping, is president of the Poly Group, one of China's leading arms sellers.
Deng Xiaoping had four grandchildren, and at least one is enrolled in a secondary school in the United States.
Since the end of the Cultural Revolution, when a breakdown in social and political order meant that the families of leaders were divided, persecuted and often sent to internal exile, the system has deemed that party families maintain discipline; consequently, few are actually prosecuted except in extreme and unusual cases, like Zhou Beifang's.
Nor do they like to talk to, or at times even be seen by, outsiders.
This week, a few policemen stood at the entrance to the lane, firmly stopping any outsiders who tried to enter, saying the residential street was "a restricted military area." It is such a small and modest-looking lane, an outsider might be forgiven for thinking it an unlikely place for a home for a man who once ruled a fifth of humanity.

She angered senior Chinese officials when she discussed her father's ailing health. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Files Hint of Illegal Venezuelan Link to Democrats

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
The Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday that he had given Federal prosecutors evidence that a Venezuelan banking family might have illegally funneled campaign contributions to the Democratic Party during the 1992 election.
The contributions, of roughly $92,000, are listed in Federal Election Commission records as coming in 1992 from a Miami lawyer for the bankers, Charles Intriago, and a member of the banking family, Jorge Castro Barredo, who is an American citizen. 
 But in a hearing in Manhattan Supreme Court last year, prosecutors said they had evidence that the Americans had been reimbursed by companies controlled by the Castro family in Venezeula. It is illegal for foreign citizens or companies to make campaign contributions to American political campaigns or for contributions to be made through surrogates.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau made his remarks in an interview yesterday, three days after three members of the Castro family were convicted in a bank fraud case brought by his office.
In recent months, in a widening controversy surrounding campaign fund raising, the Democratic National Committee has acknowledged that it received $1.6 million in illegal contributions from foreign companies or individuals, most of them in 1994 and 1995. The contributions described by Mr. Morgenthau would be the earliest known donations to have come under question.
Amy Weiss Tobe, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said the organization knew nothing of the contributions but would look into them.
Mr. Morgenthau said that during his inquiry into the Castro banking empire, one of the largest in Venezuela, "we came across contributions to the Democratic National Committee which may have been made illegally by offshore entities."
He provided no additional details.
Mr. Morgenthau said he had turned over the material, including evidence obtained through a Manhattan grand jury, to Federal prosecutors in Manhattan and Miami. The prosecutors in Miami received the information in October, and those in Manhattan in January, he said.
A spokesman for the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, in Miami, declined to comment. "The Department of Justice's policy is to neither confirm nor deny an investigation," said the spokesman, Wilfredo Fernandez. "If there ever comes a time when there is something appropriate to say, we will say it."
Before the 1994 collapse of Venezuela's banking system, the Castro family, led by Orlando Castro Llanes, controlled banks, real estate companies and a network of radio stations. Most of the family's financial holdings were lost in the collapse, and Mr. Castro Llanes has been living in Florida.
Mr. Morgenthau said yesterday that he did not know why the contributions had been made. "That would be rank speculation on my part," he said. "We could all guess, but I don't have any information on that."
In 1991, Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn tried to seize $1 million from one of the Castros' banks, maintaining that the money had been transferred as part of a money-laundering scheme. But the matter was dismissed at the request of Federal lawyers before any of the contributions had been made.
The lawyer who represented the Castros at the time, Kenneth Kaplan, said the allegations concerned one of the bank's clients and not the Castros. "The government was not able to prove anything," Mr. Kaplan said. "It was dismissed, and that is how it ended."
In the Manhattan Supreme Court case, a jury on Wednesday convicted Mr. Castro Llanes, his son Orlando Castro Castro and Jorge Castro Barredo, a grandson of Mr. Castro Llanes, on various charges stemming from the bank collapse in Venezuela. They face sentences ranging from four years for Mr. Castro Llanes to up to 25 years for the other two.
The questions about the campaign contributions were first made public in a bail hearing for the Castros in last May. The assistant district attorney handling the case, Joseph Dawson, told a State Supreme Court judge that the men should not be allowed to go free on bail because of what he called efforts they had made to avoid prosecution.
According to a transcript of the bail hearing, Mr. Dawson said prosecutors had obtained evidence showing that Mr. Castro Barredo and Mr. Intriago had "made substantial political contributions in apparent violation of Federal law through payments made by Jorge Castro Barredo, Intriago himself, and at least one other Castro family member, which funds were later reimbursed through Castro-controlled companies."
Yesterday, Mr. Intriago vehemently denied the prosecutor's assertions.
"It is a bunch of baloney," he said in an interview. "These were my contributions. I did not get anything from anyone offshore."
Mr. Intriago said he had represented Mr. Castro Llanes as a lawyer since 1980 but had not consulted with him or dealt with him in any way regarding campaign contributions.
Andrew Lawler, a lawyer representing Mr. Intriago, said no law enforcement officials had ever approached him about the campaign contributions. Mr. Lawler said he had contacted the district attorney's office to object to the allegation made at the bail hearing.
"It damages his reputation under circumstances where he has no opportunity to respond," Mr. Lawler said. "No one has been in contact with us to indicate that there was an ongoing investigation or that there were questions to be answered."
"If there is, we will be happy to respond and provide whatever information they want."
Richard Sharpstein, the lawyer who defended Mr. Castro Llanes during his trial in Manhattan, said there was no basis for Mr. Morgenthau's accusations. Mr. Sharpstein said that not only was there no evidence that the contributions were improper but also there was nothing to suggest that the Castros had received any favors from the United States Government. In fact, Mr. Sharpstein said, Mr. Castro is the only Venezuelan banker, among many involved in the 1994 collapse of the Venezuelan banking system, who has been prosecuted in the United States and is now facing jail time.
"The suggested issue is some type of corruption and that is ridiculous and asinine," he said.
Asked about a photograph of Mr. Castro Llanes shaking hands with President Clinton that appeared in Latin American newspapers, Mr. Sharpstein said it had been taken during a large conference of Latin American business leaders at the White House. Mr. Castro Llanes at the time was one of the leading business figures in Venezuela and was attending the conference, he said.
"The President happened to be standing near Mr. Castro and he took the same picture that a million other people have," Mr. Sharpstein said.
Thousands of people in that country lost several billion dollars after the Venezuelan banking system collapsed in 1994, and the Castros were charged with fraud in Venezuela following the collapse.
In an unusual prosecution for a local district attorney's office, the Castros were charged in Manhattan with defrauding depositors at their bank in Venezuela.
Mr. Morgenthau has said he agreed to prosecute the Castros for bank fraud at the request of the Venezuelan Government and following an investigation by auditors at the New York Federal Reserve bank. As the basis for his prosecution, Mr. Morgenthau argued that New York banks had been used to transfer money between the Castros' banks in Venezuela and banks in Puerto Rico.
Mr. Sharpstein has argued that the Castros were targets of a political vendetta in Venezuela and that the case against them was fabricated by people trying to destroy their businesses there. He has said that the Manhattan prosecutors were used as tools by the Venezuelan Government, which he said had manipulated the evidence and witnesses.
Mr. Sharpstein has also repeatedly questioned the decision to prosecute the case in New York when no New Yorkers were involved in the fraud and there were no victims in United States.
But Mr. Morgenthau said the contributions "show the major U.S. interest in this case."

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Next 42d Street

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH; Russell Baker is on vacation.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Above the entrance of a grim old office building in the Loop is a plastic sign ubiquitous in American downtowns: CHECKS CASHED MONEY ORDERS. Then you walk through the door and, as if propelled by a cinematic jump-cut, stumble instead into a dusty Xanadu -- an abandoned 1926 movie palace with a balcony that stretches to Heaven and a gilt-and-camp decor that a historian described as "a cross-cultural concoction of Cambodian chimeras, Indian elephants and Thai-inspired temples."
The theater, named the Oriental, is littered with cigarette butts and scarred by graffiti. In its last theatrical incarnation, as an action-movie outlet in the late 1970's, it was home to rats, gangs and drug-dealers. Then came oblivion. "A number of Chicagoans, including some of the city's professional planners, had no idea there was a theater in that place," says Greg Longhini of Chicago's Planning Department -- even though the Oriental is but a minute's stroll from City Hall. 
 Today the Oriental is the centerpiece of the most ambitious downtown renewal effort in an American city since -- well, since New York's refurbishing of 42d Street. And the two cities' tales are in some ways uncannily similar. A tour of the Oriental and other adjacent, abandoned theaters slated for restoration here eerily recalled my visit to the slumbering playhouses of Times Square only three years ago, when Disney's arrival was still a rumor.
Some of the corporate players are also the same. Garth Drabinsky, the Canadian producer who is building a 42d Street showcase for his musical version of "Ragtime," is the savior of the Oriental. Disney has taken a long-term lease on the nearby Chicago Theater, a similar old movie palace now used for theatrical attractions. Two other 1920's North Loop theaters set for revamping -- the side-by-side Harris and Selwyn -- share the names and builders of two houses on 42d Street.
But Chicago, second to no city, is not copying New York. The dream of a revitalized Theater Row here had its own origins some 20 years ago and is far more focused on adding legitimate theaters than is the 42d Street plan. Its godfather is Lew Manilow, a prominent attorney and fund-raiser (for Democrats and cultural institutions) who has long wanted to build an expansive new complex for Chicago's premiere nonprofit theater company, the Goodman, on a lot encompassing the Harris and Selwyn. Mr. Manilow is a theater nut -- he produced an Off Broadway hit, Sean O'Casey's "Purple Dust," in 1956 -- and has pleaded his cause to five Chicago Mayors. In Richard M. Daley he says he has found a kindred spirit. Mayor Daley not only goes to the theater "but stays for the whole play," adds Roche Schulfer, the Goodman's executive director.
What the Mayor stresses, though, is the importance of culture and entertainment as an economic engine for the city; his administration regards the $160 million it has earmarked for the North Loop as an investment in future tax and tourist revenues. Chicago business leaders, exemplified by John Bryan of Sara Lee, know that culture also pays off as a magnet for attracting top executives to town. Corporate largess accounts for most of a staggering $230 million raised in recent drives for the Chicago Symphony, Lyric Opera, Art Institute and Museum of Contemporary Art, according to Mr. Manilow.
Whether the drawing power of those great high-culture institutions will rub off on the North Loop is unknown. Chicago could end up with more big theaters than shows to fill them. But like the Times Square revival, the Loop's at least raises the hope, wild though it may be, of reversing three decades of downtown entertainment-district decay prompted by white flight to the suburbs and their malls.
Outside the Harris and Selwyn -- both abandoned in the 1950's -- is a much earlier vintage of urban hope. In a 1922 "Dedicatory" poster, the theaters' impresarios declare their "unlimited faith" in Chicago's future and their "desire to give the people of this Wonder City, to their children and their children's children, two perfect temples of the seven arts of the stage." The innocence of this statement juxtaposed with the theaters' subsequent fates was only yesterday another cruel urban irony. What dramatist could have imagined that after a 40-year intermission the curtain would rise on so stunning a second act?

HEADLINE: Pataki Says Waiving of Food Stamp Rules Doesn't Signal Economic Problems

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Defying claims to the contrary, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that his decision to give 38 counties and cities with high unemployment rates the option of waiving stricter new welfare rules did not signal that the state was having economic problems.
The move is intended to prevent tens of thousands of needy New Yorkers who are willing to work from losing their food stamp benefits because they are unable to find jobs. Under the new Federal rules, adults would have to work in exchange for their food stamps. But the Government has allowed states to request a waiver of those rules. 
 The request by Mr. Pataki, whose administration had been reluctant to ask for such a waiver, came as he faced increasing attacks from the clergy, Democratic lawmakers and from advocates for the poor who warned that people would go hungry if he did not act.
In seeking the waiver, the Governor, who has hailed New York's economic revival during his administration, tacitly acknowledged that there were still regions in the state that were struggling.
But Mr. Pataki maintained today that the main reason for seeking the waiver had nothing to do with the state of the economy in those localities. Rather, he said, the waiver was intended to give counties the time they need to create workfare jobs or volunteer programs for unemployed food stamp recipients. He also noted that he never expected that all recipients would immediately find jobs with private businesses.
"It has nothing to do with private jobs or the economy," Mr. Pataki said, adding later, "It's a question of having workfare programs available."
The tightened Federal food stamp rules, which are to go into effect March 1, will provide no more than three months of food stamps a year for able-bodied, childless adults under 50 who are not working at least 20 hours a week.
Mr. Pataki is seeking a waiver that will extend only until Nov. 21. He said he intended to give localities with relatively high levels of unemployment, including New York City, the option of either waiving or enforcing the stricter food stamp rules.
Anthony P. Coles, deputy counsel to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said today that New York City had been ready to place food stamp recipients in workfare jobs if Mr. Pataki had not decided to seek a waiver from the Federal Government. "But if the state did seek a waiver," he said, "then we would make sure that food stamp recipients in the city are treated the same way as recipients elsewhere in the state."
Thirteen other states -- including Illinois, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Rhode Island and Texas -- have applied for similar waivers by declaring that there are pockets in those states where the labor market is too weak to absorb welfare recipients. Such areas have generally been defined as those in which the unemployment rate is at least 20 percent above the national average of 5.4 percent.
Until today, the Pataki administration had refused to apply for such a waiver. Instead, it sought a narrower waiver that would apply only to areas where unemployment rates were above 10 percent. In New York State, only two such areas exist: the Bronx and Hamilton County, in the southern Adirondacks.
The United States Department of Agriculture, the Federal agency that administers the food stamp program, has been granting states one-year waivers from the rule, which can be renewed. But New York is the only state so far to request a waiver that would run for less than a year, said Yvette Jackson, the deputy administrator for the agency's food and consumer division.
The Pataki administration said it decided to request a waiver of nine months because it believed that was about as much time counties would need to place recipients in volunteer or workfare jobs. The administration has long argued that at most, 17,000 people might lose their benefits, and that they would eventually be placed in volunteer or other jobs created by local governments.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Governor, said a number of counties indicated that they will probably not seek the waiver. "They're saying: 'Thanks for the waiver, but we don't need it,' " he said.
Mr. Pataki's decision drew cautious praise from advocates for the poor, who had argued that many of the 100,000 able-bodied adults receiving food stamps would have lost their benefits in the next three months if the Governor had not acted.
But they expressed concern that there were not enough private jobs to absorb the recipients, and said they doubted that counties would be able to create enough workfare jobs. They said the Governor, before he allows any counties to turn down the waiver, should seek assurances that they will not deny benefits to food stamp recipients who are unable to find jobs.

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 2-7
 
Albright Tries to Assure Russians About NATO
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, visiting Moscow, tried to assure President Boris N. Yeltsin and the Russian people that NATO was "no longer a situation of you versus us." But she seemed to make little headway in easing Russian anxiety about expansion of the Western alliance. Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov said that Russia remained "negatively disposed to the expansion of NATO." 1
 
Mexico Approval Is Expected
The Clinton Administration expects to certify Mexico as an ally in the war against illegal drugs despite the arrest of Mexico's chief antidrug official for links to drug traffickers, officials in Washington said. Some American law enforcement officials said the revelation of corruption at such a high level should have prompted a serious review of what has become an almost automatic certification of Mexico. 1 

Praise for Deng's Policies
President Jiang Zemin of China, speaking publicly for the first time since the death of his mentor Deng Xiaoping, vowed to pursue the economic changes that have turned China into a rising superpower. Security forces tightened their control of the capital before Mr. Deng's memorial service next week. 3
 
Reversal by North Korea
North Korea announced that it would attend a briefing given by the United States and South Korea to explain proposed peace talks for the Korean peninsula. North Korea also named a new Acting Prime Minister, Hong Song Nam, a sign that Prime Minister Kang Song San has been replaced. 3
 
Serbian Protesters Take Over
Serbia's opposition coalition took control of the Belgrade City Council, the biggest prize so far in its fight to topple President Slobodan Milosevic and a main goal of its nearly three months of street protests. Zoran Djindjic, above, a philosopher-turned-politician and one of three leaders of the demonstrations, was elected Mayor. He is the third non-Communist to hold the post since 1945. 7
 
Forest Talks End in Division
More than 70 governments ended two years of United Nations talks deeply divided over whether to propose binding steps to curb overlogging. If foes stand their ground, no firm action on forestry is likely when world leaders gather in June for the fifth anniversary of the Rio de Janeiro environmental summit meeting. 7
 
British Prisoners Freed
A British judge freed three men who had served 18 years in prison for murder. Prosecutors conceded that their 1979 trial had been "fundamentally flawed." The judge released the three on bail, pending a hearing in April. They are expected to be exonerated and compensated, though meagerly, for their years in prison. 7
 
NATIONAL 8-10
 
Starr Reverses Course On Quitting Whitewater
Kenneth W. Starr reversed himself and said he would, after all, stay on as the Whitewater independent counsel until the investigation was complete. He said he had come to realize that his departure to become a dean at a California university would harm the investigation. 1
 
Democrats to Return More
The Democratic Party said it would return additional contributions from sources that were either "unverifiable or improper." The contributions were identified by an internal audit commissioned after questions were posed about the party's fund-raising. One report said more than $1 million was involved. 1
 
Illegal Gifts in 1992 Are Alleged
The Manhattan District Attorney said he had given Federal prosecutors evidence that a Venezuelan banking family might have illegally funneled campaign contributions to the Democratic Party during the 1992 election. That is earlier than the illegal foreign contributions that the Democrats have admitted receiving, which came mainly in 1994 and 1995. The Democratic National Committee said it would investigate. 10
 
Little Use for Ratings System
Interviews and a poll found that most parents say they are not using the new rating system for television programs to guide their children's viewing. Nearly all said that in principle they endorse rating television programs. But some said they found the new system confusing, while others said they didn't trust it. 8
 
Concern Over Beef Processing
The Agriculture Department said a new machine for deboning beef contaminated ground beef with bits of bone and spinal cord. That could be a health issue because spinal cord tissue has been implicated in bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. No case of the disease has been found so far in the United States. 8
 
Jurors Debate Doctor's Case
Jurors began deliberating in the case of a doctor who is charged in Federal court with illegally putting unapproved drugs into interstate commerce. The doctor, Stanislaw Burzynski, has said he offers the drugs to cancer victims to save lives. 9
 
Ex-Informer Faces Deportation
The Clinton Administration is seeking to deport a former Salvadoran guerrilla commander who was secretly resettled in the United States by Federal officials. The man, Pedro Antonio Andrade, is seeking political asylum; the Government says he was a terrorist who was involved in a 1985 attack in San Salvador in which six Americans were killed. 9
 
Shuttle Back at Cape Canaveral
The astronauts who repaired the Hubble Space Telescope returned to Earth with a landing in darkness at Cape Canaveral. At astronauts' request, the runway's centerline was marked by a new row of halogen lights. 9
 
NEW YORK/REGION 23-27
 
Nature Is Not Cleaning
PCB's From the Hudson
Natural processes are not cleaning up the blanket of PCB's on the shores and bottom of the Hudson River, researchers found, contradicting the assertions of some industrial polluters. The studies said substantial amounts of PCB's were evaporating from mud flats into the air. 1
 
Officer in Death Dismissed
The Police Commissioner dismissed an officer who used a deadly choke hold on a man during a 1994 struggle on a Bronx street corner. A jury had acquitted the officer, Francis X. Livoti, of manslaughter. 23
 
Child Agency Workers Complain
Completing paperwork has been emphasized over quality investigations of vulnerable children, supervisors at a Queens office of the city's child welfare agency have charged. In two memoranda to the agency's chief, Nicholas Scoppetta, the supervisors said they were being pressured to improperly close out a vast backlog of cases. Mr. Scoppetta said several of the more serious allegations were patently false. 25
 
Health Payments Are Delayed
Some insurers and managed health care companies in New York State are delaying payments on tens of millions of dollars for medical bills, hospital officials and doctors complained. They want the state to pressure the health plans to pay up. 26
 
Pataki Explains Welfare Move
Governor Pataki said his decision to give counties and cities with high unemployment rates the option of waiving stricter new welfare rules did not signal that the state was having economic problems. He said he wanted to give counties the time they need to create work programs for unemployed food stamp recipients. 26
 
SPORTS 29-34
 
Bowe Quits Marine Corps
Riddick Bowe, the former heavyweight boxing champion, dropped out of the Marine Corps after 10 days in basic training. His manager, Rock Newman, said Bowe was used to "living a life of luxury" and did not like the Parris Island regimen. 29

HEADLINE: North Korea Inches Toward Talks to Finally End '50-'53 War

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 21

 BODY:
North Korea confirmed today that it would attend a briefing by the United States and South Korea to explain proposed peace talks.
North Korea also named a new Acting Prime Minister, Hong Song Nam, a sign that Prime Minister Kang Song San has been replaced. The move set off speculation about a power struggle, but some analysts say the change was made because Mr. Kang, 66, has been ill. 
 North Korea's decision to attend the briefing, to be held on March 5 in New York, is a further sign that efforts to improve relations have not been derailed by the defection of a high-ranking North Korean ideologue or the shooting of another defector near Seoul. But attendance does not necessarily mean that the North will join full peace talks.
In the drive to improve relations, the United States and South Korea have announced food aid to North Korea, which is experiencing widespread famine. They also plan to send a team to survey a site in the North where they plan to build two nuclear power plants to replace plants that the North was suspected of using to produce bomb fuel.
North Korea appears to have accepted the defection of a senior ideologue, Hwang Jang Yop, who is in the South Korean Consulate in Beijing seeking asylum. He is expected to come to Seoul as early as next week. But news reports from China indicate that South Korea will have to agree not to use Mr. Hwang in propaganda against the North.
Last April Washington and Seoul proposed that the two Koreas, the United States and China draft a peace treaty to replace the fragile armistice that ended the Korean War. Pyongyang agreed to attend a briefing on the proposal but has twice put it off in an effort to get Washington to push Cargill, the American agribusiness giant, to provide North Korea with 500,000 tons of grain on favorable terms. The United States said it would not intervene in private negotiations.
South Korean officials say Pyongyang is agreeing to the briefing because the United States has promised to hold high-level bilateral talks with North Korea immediately afterward. Pyongyang has made little secret of its desire to improve relations with Washington, while cutting Seoul out of the picture.
Madeleine K. Albright, the Secretary of State, who is to hold talks here this weekend, is expected to send a signal to North Korea that it cannot drive a wedge between Washington and Seoul. [Mrs. Albright arrived in Seoul early Saturday.]
News of the change in prime ministers came in a broadcast from Pyongyang radio announcing that Mr. Hong, in the role of Acting Prime Minister, had sent condolences to China on the death of Deng Xiaoping.
(Another radio report, quoted by Reuters, announced the death of North Korea's Defense Minister, Choe Kwang. Mr. Choe, 78, who died of a heart attack, had been Defense Minister since October 1995.)
Some reports speculated that Mr. Kang, the current Prime Minister, was being made to accept responsibility for Mr. Hwang's defection, or that both the defection and the change suggested a power struggle.
But Suh Jae Jean, director of the unification policy division at the Korea Institute for National Unification, which is affiliated with the South Korean Government, said the move was probably related to Mr. Kang's failing health.
Mr. Hong, 73, an engineer who has been a deputy prime minister, is considered an expert on China hand who can maintain good relations with China, North Korea's main ally, Dr. Suh said.
Mr. Kang was not as powerful as his No. 2 ranking in the hierarchy would indicate, Dr. Suh said. The prime minister normally deals with economics; politics and military affairs are handled by the Communist Party.

HEADLINE: Clinton Trampled Labor in Airline Dispute;
Regulation Redux?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
By invoking the 1926 Railway Labor Act, President Clinton has prevented a strike by the pilots of American Airlines in a startling way that has yet to be mentioned (news article, Feb. 15). Railroad laws were based upon the operation of regulated industries. As public utilities, the continuous operations of such industries are deemed essential to "public convenience and necessity." 
 The airlines were deregulated in 1978, yet the President is dealing with this strike as if the industry were still subject to the economic regulation of the Civil Aeronautics Board. The President's decision appears to have unusually broad ramifications.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Pittsburgh, Feb. 16, 1997
