HEADLINE: Despite Scandal, U.S. Plans To Certify Mexico Drug Fight

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Despite the shock over the recent arrest of the Mexican Government's top anti-drug official on charges that he had links to drug traffickers, the Clinton Administration plans to certify Mexico next week as an ally in the war against illegal drugs, Government officials said today.
Mexican authorities arrested the official, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, on Feb. 6, accusing him of having collaborated with a notorious Mexican drug trafficker, but did not make the news public until this week. 
 The incident, which occurred two months after General Gutierrez started the job, caused embarrassment within the Clinton Administration, which had welcomed the general on a visit here only a few weeks ago.
Administration officials are also concerned about how much information on American efforts the general might have passed on to the man reported to be his associate, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, whose criminal syndicate has smuggled tons of cocaine, heroin and marijuana across the border.
Some American law enforcement officials said the revelation of corruption at such a high level should have prompted a serious review of what has become an almost automatic certification of Mexico, which is the United States' third-largest trading partner.
But several officials here said the internal discussion that followed the disclosure of the accusations against General Gutierrez amounted to damage control.
They said it did not lead to a new discussion about whether the role of Mexico as a neighbor, free-trade partner and magnet for American business investment should outweigh the fact that it is also a transit route for as much as two-thirds of the drugs that come into the United States.
Supporters of certification said Mexico's arrest of such a high-ranking official, in fact, demonstrated President Ernesto Zedillo's commitment to the fight against drug trafficking. By contrast, Colombia seems sure to be decertified for a second successive year, despite its modest progress in destroying some coca and poppy fields and in enacting a law that permits the seizure of drug assets.
An Administration official described the situation bluntly: "Mexico is in the vital national interest, and Colombia isn't."
The State Department is expected to announce a decision on Mexico's certification at an antidrug rally next Thursday or Friday. Department officials declined requests for interviews, as did others at the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Treasury Department, saying the matter was still being discussed.
At the White House, President Clinton's senior adviser, Rahm Emanuel, said President Clinton had not yet received formal recommendations on the certification from the State Department and an inter-agency working group considering the matter. Mr. Emanuel said he could not comment on what the President would decide.
But another official, calling Mexico's certification a done deal, said, "They have no choice but to move forward."
The discussions this year have been described as a pallid echo of the spirited arguments waged up until the deadline last year, with some law enforcement officials arguing that Mexico did not deserve certification, and financial and trade officials contending that the United States' relationship with Mexico should not be jeopardized by criticism of its drug problem.
Mexico's Foreign Minister, Jose Angel Gurria, who was in Washington today, emphasized in meetings that the dismissal and arrest of General Gutierrez showed that the Mexican Government was serious about policing drug traffickers.
"This is one area in which cooperation has to be very full, and sometimes it means we have to take some risks," the Foreign Minister said at a news conference in the Mexican Embassy.
Mr. Gurria also met with Attorney General Janet Reno, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, who is the White House's director of national drug policy, and members of the National Security Council.
In other briefings this week on the Administration's new national drug strategy, officials said Mexico should be viewed in the larger context of its overall relationship with the United States.
One official said Mexico was the key to the antidrug strategy and the top-priority plan to reduce the flow of drugs across the 2,000-mile-long border. The plan is to be released on Tuesday.
Meetings on Thursday between Mexico's Foreign Minister and Thomas F. McClarty, the former White House chief of staff, who is now responsible for Presidential affairs regarding Latin America, were further evidence that the scandal over General Gutierrez has not led the Administration to reconsider its treatment of Mexico.
Mr. Gurria said his discussions with Mr. McClarty included the length and itinerary of a visit to Mexico by President Clinton planned for April 11 and 12. The visit was announced earlier this month.
President Clinton would find it diplomatically awkward, if not impossible, to visit Mexico if he added it to his Administration's short list of pariah drug-trafficking countries. Last year that list included Afghanistan, Colombia, Iran, Myanmar, Nigeria and Syria, all of which are expected to be on the list again this year.
The prospect of certifying Mexico but not Colombia highlights the inconsistency that political considerations have interjected into the certification process since it became law in 1986.
The law requires the President to inform Congress annually about any lack of cooperation among countries that produce drugs or serve as transit points for drugs. The law also set up a mechanism for imposing trade and other economic sanctions on countries that fail to meet Washington's standards for cooperation.
But while Colombia looks all but certain to be "decertified," there is talk that sanctions could be waived for three to six months to give the Colombians a deadline to come up with a more convincing plan to combat drug production and trafficking.
Some American drug agents contend that Mexican traffickers, who had the support of the national police, now pose a worse threat to the United States than Colombian traffickers.
Doug Wankel, who recently retired as chief of operations for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said of the scandal over General Gutierrez: "This really points at the magnitude of the problem down there. If people didn't know it before, they really are aware of it now."
Mr. Gurria said at a news conference today that the Mexican Government had "absolutely no comment" on the certification issue because it was "an internal process of the United States." He went on to say that the process inhibited cooperation between countries.
"The reason why Mexico is fighting against drugs is not to obtain any country's certification," Mr. Gurria said. "We are fighting against drugs to preserve our institutions, to protect our youth."
 Because of another editing error, the article misstated Mexico's place in United States anti-drug policy. The State Department says that while Mexico holds a high priority in Washington's efforts to reduce the flow of drugs into the United States, there is no designation of top priority.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 25, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an impending decision by the United States on whether to certify Mexico as cooperating in anti-drug efforts misidentified the event at which the decision is expected to be announced. It is a State Department news conference on Thursday, not an anti-drug rally.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BECAUSE THEY WANTED TO: Stories, by Mary Gaitskill. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) The enviable wealth of emotion and perception in these stories' characters makes them large enough for the author's inspection of women's sexual relations.
 
 THE BOY WHO WENT AWAY, by Eli Gottlieb. (St. Martin's, $21.95.) A touching coming-of-age novel whose adolescent narrator, a crackerjack at domestic intelligence work, compiles the facts about a family and its secret suffering.
 
 BRIAR ROSE, by Robert Coover. (Grove, $18.) A very complex novelist's intricate variations on "The Sleeping Beauty," treated with a kind of irreverent logic as sex and storytelling are seen as metaphors for each other.
 
 GLASS, PAPER, BEANS: Revelations on the Nature and Value of Ordinary Things, by Leah Hager Cohen. (Currency/Doubleday, $22.95.) Informed, meticulous historical and economic reflections on a tumbler, a newspaper and a cup of coffee, and the evocative power of each.
 
 HUNGRY GHOSTS: Mao's Secret Famine, by Jasper Becker. (Free Press, $25.) A journalist's re-creation of the famine of 1959-61, in which perhaps 30 million Chinese perished because of the ignorance and obstinacy of their ideologically ensorcelled leaders. Gruesome details.
 
 IMAGINING ROBERT. My Brother, Madness, and Survival: A Memoir, by Jay Neugeboren. (Morrow, $24.) A novelist's liberating development of two real-life themes: his brother's illness and his own struggle to manage it.
 
 THE LANGUAGE OF NAMES, by Justin Kaplan and Anne Bernays. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) An exploration of why names matter and how they are used to alter or preserve personal identities.
 
 LOVE WARPS THE MIND A LITTLE, by John Dufresne. (Norton, $23.) A deeply affecting novel that begins with an offhand love affair and focuses on painful truths: for instance, that everybody's going to die, unpleasantly in most cases, but someone still has to walk the dog.
 
 NIAGARA: A History of the Falls, by Pierre Berton. (Kodansha, $27.) A Canadian historian tells how this sublime natural wonder has been used and misused, admired and corrupted.
 
 THE REICHMANNS: Family, Faith, Fortune, and the Empire of Olympia & York, by Anthony Bianco. (Times Books/Random House, $30.) A nicely balanced study, by a Business Week writer, of an ultra-Orthodox and ultra-rich Jewish family.
 
 WILLIAM FAULKNER AND THE TANGIBLE PAST: The Architecture of Yoknapatawpha, by Thomas S. Hines. (University of California, $35.) Splendidly illustrated, this deft survey by an architect and historian enhances Faulkner's own use of the resonance of particular time and place.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2397 words

HEADLINE: The Worst Was Yet to Come

BYLINE: By Fritz Stern; Fritz Stern is the author of "Dreams and Delusions: The Drama of German History."

 BODY:

NAZI GERMANY
 AND THE JEWS
 Volume 1: The Years of Persecution, 1933-1939.
 By Saul Friedlander.
 436 pp. New York:
 HarperCollins Publishers. $30. 
 History and memory are distant yet often confused cousins. But as the example of the Holocaust shows, they differ greatly. Individual memories made possible the recollection of the Holocaust that is now part of collective memory: images of brave and terrified victims, of helpless children, of cattle cars and crematories, of corpses. But that memory becomes unhistorical, a scene from hell, as it is stripped of context. Historians, on the other hand, search for and sift evidence, insist on sequence and chronology, seek to make as precise a reconstruction of the past as is possible. Nowadays they tend to do so in narrow monographs, but occasionally a work of synthesis appears, as is the case here.
Since the gap between collective memory and history is especially great regarding the murder of six million Jews, general knowledge of how that horror happened is appallingly primitive. We have not thought enough about how it might not have happened, how it was not inevitable.
Saul Friedlander has long been haunted by the links between memory and history. Born just before Hitler came to power, to Jewish parents in Prague, he survived in enforced disguise in Roman Catholic hands in wartime France, while his parents perished in the East. He now teaches history in Israel and the United States. Mr. Friedlander draws strength from memory, yet adheres scrupulously to the discipline of a historian's detachment. He writes history with a novelist's sense of the telling detail; he is both analytic and evocative.
In "Nazi Germany and the Jews," his purpose is to assess the causes and contexts of Nazi policies and the responses to them among victims and among Germans. He switches with deliberate abruptness from the general -- state decisions and decrees -- to the particular, to the experiences of individual men and women, of Jews entrapped, of a German caught in bureaucratic wrangling about his claim to Aryan status. Such an impressively unconventional technique enhances the great value of his carefully constructed study.
The division of this projected two-volume work has meaning: "the years of persecution," as the subtitle of this first volume calls them, 1933-1939, differ fundamentally from the years of extermination. In these early years, Hitler -- and Mr. Friedlander is right to emphasize his direct and ultimate control in planning the anti-Jewish campaign -- sought the segregation and extrusion, not the extermination, of German Jewry. Aware of competing pressures upon him, Hitler had to curb his obsessional hatreds with tactical pragmatism. Among his followers he instilled or strengthened what Mr. Friedlander calls "redemptive anti-Semitism," according to which the Jew, defined by race, is all-powerful and all-malignant; if the Aryan, or Germanic, race is to survive, it must battle the Jewish menace, free Germany of the Jewish presence. This was the "idealistic" element in the poisonous fantasy: the threat of one's perdition, the promise of one's salvation.
The radicals in Hitler's party -- including Hitler himself, if he had followed his own vicious impulses -- would have chosen extrusion by immediate violence, the kind that the Nazis instantly visited upon political enemies like the Socialists and Communists. But Hitler gauged the limits of his "conservative" ministers, whom he needed for respectability; they, in turn, though imbued with various forms of traditional anti-Semitism, understood that the Jews' presence in Germany could not be extirpated all at once without calamitous effects on the country's well-being. Hitler also had to watch foreign responses to his persecution of Jews; Germany was economically vulnerable, and he had, if anything, an exaggerated view of Jewish power abroad.
Still, as Mr. Friedlander shows, ideological obsession was swiftly translated into enacted policy. By April 1933, only months after coming to power, the Nazis organized a boycott of Jewish enterprises and offices, which, though not a success, served to satisfy the party, to harm the Jews and to show the outside world that they were hostages. In the same month, the "Law for the Restoration of the Professional Civil Service" (Nazis were masters of euphemism) stripped practically all Jews and Christians of Jewish descent, as well as "politically unreliable" people, of their positions in the Civil Service, a category that in Germany included university professors, judges, and doctors in public hospitals. The removal of Jews from cultural life, in which they had attained great prominence and visibility, proceeded apace.
In 1935 the Nuremberg Laws decreed that citizenship was limited to "Aryans." Jews became mere subjects of the state, and in order to enforce total segregation between Germans and Jews, intermarriage and sexual relations between them were forbidden. Thereafter, the most frequent denunciations to the Gestapo concerned "race defilement" (Rassenschande). Sexual insecurities and fantasies had their place in Nazi and German consciousness, as did pornography in their propaganda.
Strangely enough, as Mr. Friedlander notes, Nuremberg created the illusion among some Germans and Jews that segregation might be not a stage in but the end of Nazi discrimination against Jews. Actually, it was a decisive step in the policy of extrusion, clamored for in vicious propaganda. There were still 450,000 people of the Jewish faith in Germany, 50,000 more who were Christian by religion but Jewish by descent and decree (defined as having four grandparents who were Jewish) and approximately 200,000 Mischlinge, offspring of the union of German and Jew. The high degree of German-Jewish assimilation is implicit in this number. By making race the determining element, the Nazis declared converted Jews were full Jews, a policy that raised countless questions for the Christian churches and for Germans who now had to prove that they were racially pure. Germans anxiously had to hide their Jewish grandmothers or great-grandmothers (only to resurrect them with some pride after 1945). Germans, for a century obsessed by the question, "What is German?," now had to ask, "Who is Aryan?"
Mr. Friedlander, in assessing the German response to the anti-Jewish measures, notes -- as others have before him -- the "moral collapse" of the German elites, including the Christian churches. With few exceptions, German academics accepted the dismissal of their Jewish colleagues. Most, indeed, pledged enthusiastic support to the new regime.
Summarizing the German response to the Nuremberg laws, Mr. Friedlander persuasively concludes that "the bulk of the population disliked acts of violence but did not object to the disenfranchisement and segregation of the Jews." Most Germans seemed relieved that the state now controlled the Jewish presence in Germany, although there were exceptions, and as late as 1942 Goebbels was enraged that German intellectuals with philo-Semitic leanings were still to be found.
The reasons for enthusiastic support of the new regime, or at least grudging submission to it, were many, and their relative importance has been endlessly debated. Mr. Friedlander certainly does not claim that anti-Semitism was the sole cause; it probably was not even the principal one. There was, of course, a tradition of antagonism, or at least reserve, toward Jews, expressed in the old Imperial Germany in various forms of discrimination despite the guarantee of civic equality. Fanatical and paranoid anti-Semitism became ever more widespread, beginning with World War I and Germany's defeat and continuing during the unloved Weimar Republic. Hitler carried out his persecution of the Jews in the shadow of his great victories: the re-establishment of "order," an end to unemployment, the resurgence of German power. Charles Lindbergh was not the only American -- or the only foreigner -- who admired the Fuhrer's achievements.
Mr. Friedlander's second subject is the victims' reactions to persecution, their varied responses to the consequent alienation and dispossession. "The Jews themselves," he observes, "were only partly aware of the increasingly shaky ground on which they stood because, like so many others, they did not perceive the depth of liberal democracy's crisis." Hope and despair mingled, with some Zionists taking satisfaction from the prospect that Jewish cohesion could now be restored, and others encouraging a vibrant, if segregated, Jewish cultural life. Anguished debates about emigration took place, though the will to leave did not suffice; it became increasingly hard to find places to emigrate to.
By early 1938 Hitler's entourage had become radicalized, the conservatives in the Government had been dismissed and the international balance of power had changed: in defiance of treaties and promises, Hitler had rearmed, reoccupied the Rhineland and stood poised for limited war. In March, Austria was annexed, and 190,000 more Jews found themselves instantly threatened. "The persecution in Austria," Mr. Friedlander writes, "outpaced that in the Reich. Public humiliation was more blatant and sadistic; expropriation better organized; forced emigration more rapid."
The year 1938 spelled disaster for all Jews under German domination. The Nazis began to think of the "Austrian model," and in a stream of decrees they ordered the Jews' total elimination from German life. Businesses were ruinously "Aryanized," lawyers and doctors deprived of their licenses, all Jews systematically impoverished and degraded. The goal remained forced emigration, with the cynical hope that penniless, humiliated Jews arriving in other countries would promote anti-Semitism and thus sympathy for the Nazis.
Perhaps Mr. Friedlander's most distinctive contribution lies in his emphasis on the full context of this unfolding horror. The countries of Eastern Europe, for example, adopted ever greater anti-Semitic measures of their own, while the Western democracies practiced appeasement and watched anti-Semitic movements grow within their borders. The Munich Agreement, epitomizing Western weakness, emboldened the Nazis in November 1938 to pounce on the assassination of a German diplomat by a Polish Jew as a pretext for the pogrom known as Kristallnacht, in which party squads destroyed 267 synagogues, vandalized 7,500 businesses and herded some 30,000 Jewish men into concentration camps, to be released only on the promise of immediate emigration.
AND what was the German response to this public, nationwide violation of every civilized norm? Protestant and Catholic clergy -- despite their presumed respect for the sanctity of places of worship -- kept silence, as did virtually all other Germans in the face of a terrorist regime. Many individual Germans disapproved, but passivity had become habitual. Mr. Friedlander concludes: "Outside party ranks, there was no massive popular agitation" to expel the Jews from Germany or "to unleash violence against them. The majority of the Germans accepted the steps taken by the regime and . . . looked the other way." This is a terrifying indictment, and one to heed: silent submission to state criminality can and does occur at any time and anywhere.
"Redemptive anti-Semitism" -- Mr. Friedlander's highly persuasive interpretation of Nazi thought -- was "an ideological trend shared at the outset by a small minority only, and, in the Third Reich, by a segment of the party and its leaders, not by the majority of the population." Assessments of popular attitudes in a totalitarian society are at best approximations, but his nuanced view seems plausible.
Even as Jews were hounded to unimaginable misery, even as Nazi anti-Semitic rhetoric soared to new heights, the German Government continued to force Jewish emigration. But a frightened, callous world had slammed most doors shut, and the escape from hell became almost impossible. We today know the worst was yet to come, but Mr. Friedlander cautions that before the war, "no program of extermination had been worked out, no clear intentions could be identified."
"Nazi Germany and the Jews" is a synthesis of recent scholarship, supplemented by adroit explorations in archives. It provides a readable, reliable, commendably unconventional overview; it is necessarily a book of idiosyncratic compression. Only rarely does Mr. Friedlander slip -- as when he states that Carl Goerdeler, the archconservative Mayor of Leipzig (and later a prominent member of the conspiracy to overthrow Hitler), ordered the removal of Felix Mendelssohn's statue in front of the concert hall. On the contrary, the local party boss ordered its removal while Goerdeler was away, and upon his return and in response, he resigned his post. Conservatives like him held various anti-Jewish prejudices, but most of them believed in the "good Jew," in the Jew of taste and accomplishment, especially in the classic Jewish masters of the past like Mendelssohn.
A great merit of this book is its implicit moral judgment on so much culpability, complicity and cowardice among not only Germans but also those not yet under the German heel. Some of France's most prominent Jews pressured their Government to limit the influx of refugees. Two weeks after Germany's absorption of Austria, Switzerland's Federal Council sought to bar Jewish immigration: "If we do not want to create a basis for an anti-Semitic movement that would be unworthy of our country, we must defend ourselves with all our strength and, if need be, with ruthlessness against the immigration of foreign Jews." Closing the book, I was reminded of a diary entry by Britain's Permanent Under Secretary of the Foreign Office, Sir Alexander Cadogan, written a week before Munich: "We must go on being cowards up to our limit, but not beyond." In that short era of Hitler triumphant, how many people exceeded that limit!
Yet there were exceptions, some of them noted in this book: righteous people, who at a time of the fiercest terror and at grave risk, instinctively reached out to the victims with a piece of bread, an offered haven, a human gesture. They need to be remembered and honored. Their example should serve as a judgment on the past and an admonition to the future.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Keeping Your Powder Dry

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
THE RETURN OF the regular, monthly Presidential news conference is a fine thing, not the least because it gives us a chance to instruct the Chief Executive -- and one another -- on the use of famous phrases.
Pleased at the prospect of bipartisan cooperation, President Clinton said, "Now both sides are keeping their powder dry enough to create the possibility we can reach a balanced budget agreement." Later, he returned to the phrase: "I would ask our friends on the Republican side and the Democrats who care as passionately as I do, just keep our powder dry." 
 His meaning in both contexts is clear: "remain calm, keep cool." But that is only half the meaning of the phrase and misses the most telling part.
Oliver Cromwell, at the Battle of Edgehill in 1642, is supposed to have told his Roundhead troops in that opening fight of the English civil war, "Put your trust in God, my boys, but mind to keep your powder dry." (Nobody wrote it down at the time, and its first report came in 1834, but I say let's give it to him.)
The Pretender wasn't talking talcum; gunpowder was his subject, and when the powder is wet, the gun does not go off and the ammunition just sits there. The attraction of the phrase was its combination of what Bergen Evans called "piety and practicality." That combination was repeated in World War II in the saying and song, "Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition."
The purpose of keeping powder dry is to be able to blaze away at the proper time. Thus, the phrase keep your powder dry is not limited to "stay calm" but carries an implicit, most ominous threat: "and be prepared to blow the enemy's head off at the propitious moment."
That cannot be the message that Clinton, in his bipartisan mood, intended to convey. On the other hand, in this column I'm a lexicographer and usagist, not a mind reader.
 
Salami in a Spoon
At the annual conclave of executive heavies, political powers, scientific Nobelniks and media biggies known as the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, words have historic resonance and metaphors fly. This was the year of the "network society," plugging a plugged-in world, and the netties found it easy to get hooked.
Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's Prime Minister, held a breakfast for diplomatic reporters and foreign-policy sages. He used a word that he knew would reverberate among the hypercognoscenti.
"This will come as a shock," he told the assembled power pack, "but in the case of Europe, Israel hopes for an evenhanded policy."
Netties nodded knowledgeably. Evenhanded has long been a code word in America's Middle East diplomacy. From the 50's through the 70's, State Department "Arabists" (some of us apply that term as a derogation, to mean "striped-pants pro-Arab cookie pushers," but it is borne by many diplomats with pride, to mean "those experienced in Middle Eastern affairs") felt with suave fervor that United States policy in that region was unduly influenced by political leaders eager to curry favor with American supporters of Israel.
The Arabists called for an evenhanded policy, imputing fairness and impartiality. Pro-Israel advocates, citing America's moral commitment to an island of democracy that was also a reliable strategic partner, retorted that "what Israel needs is not a broker but an ally"; to this group, evenhandedness was a code word made famous by the U.S. fact finder William Scranton in the late 60's for helping the rest of the world press Israel for concessions.
The adjective was coined by Shakespeare in "Macbeth" and carried an ironic overtone: "This even-handed justice/Commends the ingredients of our poison'd chal ice/To our own lips." In Netanyahu's use, it meant "Israel is prepared to settle for a fair shake from nations usually on the side of the Arabs." (Fair shake, an 1830 Americanism, may be a metaphoric extension of the even hand.)
Emboldened by the ready reception of this allusion, the Prime Minister -- educated in the United States and familiar with the nuances of the American political vernacular -- went overboard. Speaking of the way the previous Government had made concessions little by little, he charged that the Israeli public had been "spoon-fed withsalami slices." The press gasped at the audacity of the mangled metaphor, and Netanyahu responded, "Do something with that, Safire."
Right on. The compound verb spoon-feed began in 1615 to describe a means of feeding the infantile or feeble. By metaphoric extension, to spoon-feed means "to explain or persuade in small, understandable portions; to make easy to swallow and digest information."
Salami -- from the Italian salame, "salted pork" -- led to a more overtly political phrase, salami tactics. Coinage is attributed to Matyas Rakosi of Hungary's Communist Party in 1945; he described the way he overcame his opposition by getting it to slice off its right wing, then repudiate its centrists, until only those left in power were Communist collaborators. The specific Rakosi citation has not been found, but the phrase's popularizers were surely the columnists Joseph and Stewart Alsop, who much preferred the striking image to the bloodless "gradualism." In 1971, Stewart wrote prophetically in his Newsweek column about Czech politics: "Alexander Dubcek will certainly not be the last of the liberals to fall victim to the salami knife."
Both the feeding by spoon and the slicing with a salami knife are delicious figures of speech, but both in the same sentence, as the Prime Minister belatedly realized, are a lot to swallow.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Riding the Strong Dollar For All It's Worth

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SUDDENLY, Japan is a bargain. And Germany doesn't look so pricey either. Make no mistake, it's not like the glory days, when the yen was fixed at 360 to the dollar -- where it stayed for decades after World War II -- or even like the early 80's. Anyone who dined cheaply in Tokyo or stayed at a decent hotel for $30 in Berlin during the mid-70's will be disappointed.
But in travel and in exchange rates, everything is relative. With the dollar now worth about 123 yen, Japan is nearly 50 percent less expensive, in dollar terms, than it was two years ago; with the dollar now worth about 1.68 marks, Germany is about 20 percent less, and lower than it's been in three years. So while the dollar is generally strong around the world these days -- even in France and England -- you'll notice it most when you go to spend yen and marks. 
 Travelers may have Washington to thank for this sudden change in fortunes. The most common -- but hardly the only -- explanation for the rise in the dollar in recent months is that the world has suddenly come to the conclusion that the United States is serious about balancing the Federal budget. With Japan still mired in a recession and much of Europe unable to break out of high unemployment, the dollar seems like the safe haven for the world's money. Such a safe haven, in fact, that a few weeks ago Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin started hinting that the dollar had risen too much for its own good, or the country's.
The mystery for the next few months will be whether the world's foreign exchange markets believe that Mr. Rubin and his fellow finance ministers in Europe and Japan are serious. The early evidence is that they are unimpressed. Soon after Mr. Rubin made his first stab at lowering the dollar's value, it rose anew against the Deutsche mark. But for globe-trotters, here's the bottom line: Although the dollar might get a bit stronger in coming months, it's not likely to surge the way it has in recent times. So if you are planning a trip abroad, it's probably not worth delaying much longer.
Of course, translating a strong dollar into a strong buy is not always so easy. Many package-tour operators snatch up exchange-rate gains to increase their profits rather than pass them on to customers. If you are buying a tour, it's worth asking what the same package cost a year ago. If the numbers (except for the air fare portion, which is denominated in dollars if you are leaving from the United States) sound the same, you are probably being denied the benefit of the strong dollar.
But there are bargains for independent travelers. Probably the best is the Japan Rail Pass, available from Japan National Tourist Organization offices around the United States. The rail pass allows you to tour Japan on its famous bullet trains; you can buy a one-week or two-week pass that allows for unlimited travel.
There is no purer test of the dollar's buying power than the rail pass. The Japanese Government sets its price in yen, at 27,800 for a seven-day pass.
Two years ago, when the yen was hovering around 80 to the dollar, the economy pass ran $347. Recently it was priced around $230.
Lodgings in Japan are rarely a bargain, but the dollar's rise has removed some of the sting. The Okura Hotel, across from the American embassy in Tokyo, charges 41,000 yen for one double-occupancy room. At the yen's height, that came to an astounding $512 a night; today the same room is more like $333. For those with more modest tastes, Tokyo is filled with antiseptically clean if cramped hotel rooms, near downtown rail and subway stations, for 27,000 yen a night; at present rates that's close to $219. And the real bargains are available to those who are comfortable going off the beaten track. The wonderful 1,000-yen sushi plate I used to get at a hole in the wall behind the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo has just declined to $8.13 from $12.50 two years ago.
What works in Japan probably won't work elsewhere in Asia. The Korean won is down compared with the dollar, but the Hong Kong dollar is pegged pretty close to the American currency, meaning that the prices charged by Hong Kong hotels in advance of the city-state's transfer to China this summer are still outrageous.
But prices in Germany are on the decline, at least as measured in dollar terms. The discounts, though, are not as deep. At the Hotel Grand Esplanade, one of the leading hotels in Berlin, the weekend rate of 370 marks would have been $268 in the spring of 1995 but today is around $220.
One caution: Before leaving home, it's worth calling your credit card companies to find out what kind of exchange rate they use. There's often a bigger variance among companies than you might expect. On any trip with thousands of dollars in expenses, knowing which card to use out can make a difference when the trip is a hazy memory and the credit card bill is on your desk.

HEADLINE: A Chalet of One's Own

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH WISSNER-GROSS; ELIZABETH WISSNER-GROSS teaches journalism at Hofstra University.

 BODY:
WHILE hiking in the Swiss Alps one autumn, I passed a log chalet, smoke puffing neatly from the chimney, and children playing contentedly on the balcony in view of waterfalls, pastures, densely wooded forest and shockingly high mountains crowned with snow. Surrounded by the strong aroma of pine and the sounds of tinkling cowbells and rushing river water, I realized that my elegant room at the hotel in town was not quite what an Alpine vacation was meant to be.
What I did not know at the time was that spacious, private chalets with magnificent views were often cheaper than one-room units in a high-rise -- something I learned only last August, when I returned to the Swiss Alps with my husband, mother and two sons, determined to sample chalet living. 
 Since most Alpine hotels accommodate a maximum of two people to a room, a family of four would have to pay about $300 to $400 a night for two rooms in a modest hotel. Even youth hostels in choice locations charge about $35 a person for dormitory accommodations. Chalet prices, on the other hand, range from $420 a week for a two-bedroom chalet apartment for five people in Wengen off season to $1,600 a week and up for apartments in St. Moritz during peak season.
I began my search for a chalet by calling Switzerland Tourism's automated fax information line in New York, which within seconds sent me a one-page list of chalet rental agencies. After telephoning several I was unimpressed: each claimed to have only one chalet to meet my needs, and the rates they quoted were higher than the cost of luxury hotel rooms. So I decided to try reserving directly with chalet owners in Zermatt, in the Valais region, and Wengen, in the Jungfrau region, both car-free resort villages. Within hours of contacting the Zermatt tourism office I received a list of available chalets that would comfortably house five people.
Among the most appealing were Residence Patricia, a newly built chalet that was a rather long walk from the village, and the centrally situated Haus Monazit and Haus Memory. Unfortunately, like many chalet rentals, each required a full week's stay. Since we were only visiting Zermatt for four days, we chose an apartmentlike loft atop the Hotel Dufour. (When I explored Zermatt for future family rentals of a week or more, I learned that it's better to rent a chalet slightly beyond the main streets of this bustling resort, where the views of the Matterhorn from chalets will not be blocked by neighboring high-rises.)
Perhaps because Wengen, where we spent five days, is smaller, sleepier, and less publicized, chalet owners were more flexible. Among the listings that met my requirements -- a balcony with a view, a quiet location within 15 minutes' walk of town and children specifically welcomed -- I chose the Chalet Isabelle. It was also one of the least expensive in the five-bed category: 26 Swiss francs (about $20) a person per night in winter (about $12 a person off season).
I contacted the owner, Silvia Kaiser-Gross (no relation) by fax, and a few days later she faxed me a contract, in German. Although I speak passable German, I spent hours with a German dictionary trying to understand the rules, which included the stipulation that the stay had to be paid in full in Swiss francs at least two weeks in advance. Since we were about 10 days away from departure, we faxed back the signed contract with a photocopy of the check we would be bringing with us.
 LIKE many chalet owners, Ms. Kaiser-Gross does not live in the town where she rents out her rooms and rarely sees her guests. So as we rode the train up the mountain from Interlaken to Lauterbrunnen and then on to Wengen, I wondered where we would find the chalet key.
The information officer at the Wengen train station who gave us directions to the chalet quickly set me straight: "In the door, of course," he said, laughing at such a ridiculous question.
We walked down the mountain to the chalet, lined up like a family of ducks on the narrow, paved road, dragging our wheeled "carry on" luggage behind us. As I had requested, the chalet was only a 15-minute walk -- but those 15 minutes were entirely downhill at a steady 45-degree angle. The more we descended, the more we worried about the ascent back to town.
"Exactly how rustic is this going to be?" Alex, my 15-year-old son, asked. "Is this still Wengen?" 11-year-old Zach chimed in. Eventually, after a series of steep zigs and zags in the road, we reached Chalet Isabelle, a dark wooden house that turned out to be a multi-unit chalet, meaning three other apartments shared the same building (an unexpected, or perhaps untranslated, arrangement, but no real intrusion on our privacy).
No concierge was in sight but, yes, the key was in the door. As we walked through the center hallway of our upstairs apartment, we saw two large, bright rooms, and our initial disappointment began to fade. The rooms were done in light wood, with lots of storage space. One contained three comfortable beds with thick mattresses; the other, with a trundle bed and big wooden table, served as both living room and dining room. Still skeptical of what $60 a night could buy in Switzerland, the five of us inspected the facility thoroughly, opening every closet and cabinet door.
We found clean, crisp, cotton linens, fluffy down comforters and pillows, a fully equipped eat-in kitchen, a stack of board games, and French doors in the living room and bedroom that opened onto a balcony with an overwhelming view. Our panorama included the village of Lauterbrunnen below, distant valleys, gleaming snow-covered mountaintops, pastoral fields, stark cliffs, tall, ribbonlike waterfalls, and occasional tidy wooden chalets. We also had a clear view of the gravity-defying cog train to Murren across the Lauterbrunnen valley, as well as an above-the-clouds perspective on storms approaching Lauterbrunnen below.
"This isn't real. This is a Hollywood set," Alex commented as a cow ambled onto one of the carpetlike pastures below us. As if on cue, we all felt like sipping hot chocolate. But it was getting late and we did not have hot chocolate, or bread, or even a bar of soap. The only amenity in our spotless bathroom was a roll of toilet paper; we'd had no idea that chalet guests are usually expected to bring or buy their own bath linens. So we quickly made up our beds and set out on a dinner hike into town.
As expected, the straight-uphill climb required about 30 minutes for five healthy New Yorkers more accustomed to flat turf. By the time we arrived in the village, most stores had closed for the evening. Only restaurants and gift shops, where edelweiss-embroidered hand towels were selling for $40 apiece, were open. We washed up and had dinner at an eclectic Swiss-Mexican restaurant at the Bernerhof Hotel, which featured a salad bar, vegetarian chili, pasta and fondue.
The next morning my husband and I volunteered to trudge back up to town to shop for supplies at the Migros supermarket, a large national chain, where our purchases included an assortment of local cheeses and muesli cereal to be eaten Swiss style (mixed with flax seed and yogurt with exotic flavors like hazelnut, walnut, and coconut chocolate chip). We picked up warm grainy bread and croissants at a bakery across the street.
In the early morning, the village was already humming. Wengen is especially popular among British vacationers (American and Japanese tourists gravitate to Grindelwald, just over the mountain; Murren draws many Germans). It is small and flat for an Alpine resort, but its blocklong main street bustles seven days a week with wall-to-wall restaurants, gift shops and hotels -- and people occasionally congregate around an outdoor life-size chess board equipped with light, plastic pieces.
After a breakfast of croissants and hot chocolate on the balcony, the family voted unanimously not to head back uphill, but to hike down to Lauterbrunnen instead. From there we took the cog rail train up to Murren for yet another magnificent view of the Jungfrau region. From the train, we could see our chalet across the valley and quickly figured out that we could return home that evening by taking the train to Wengen, and walking down from the station once again.
We continued this pattern of downhill hiking for the next few days. One of our favorite trips entailed a 20-minute train ride down to Interlaken and then a boat ride on Lake Thun to the Caves of St. Beatus, where we dined at an outdoor cafe before embarking on a one-hour walking tour of stalagmites and stalactites. Lauterbrunnen itself offered many scenic walks along the green rushing waters of the clean, glacial Lutschine River. On one hike to Lauterbrunnen my mother discovered wild raspberries and blackberries growing in the woods along the trail.
While paths were clearly marked, we learned to ignore distances marked on direction signs, which are generally indicated in "minutes" rather than kilometers. These are Swiss minutes, not American, and do not differentiate between an uphill distance and a downhill distance. On one hike, we found a "20-minute walk" in Swiss time translated into a "40-minute hike" by American standards.
Often we stopped along the way for afternoon snacks of strudel and hot chocolate at outdoor cafes conveniently situated along our routes. In Murren, one of Switzerland's highest villages, we ate lunch at a cafe directly facing glaciers and mountain peaks. But most of our lunches were eaten picnic style: baguette, cheese, fruit, boxed juices or water, and Swiss chocolate bars. In Wengen, a favorite dinner spot was the Victoria-Lauberhorn Hotel, where the specialties included crepes and pizza. We fixed our other meals at the chalet, once attempting rosti, a potato and cheese dish we had tried and loved in Bern. The modern kitchen had everything we needed, though our first chalet dinner turned up a minor surprise. After trying to boil water for more than half an hour, we noticed that the stove had shut down. At first we thought it was broken. But after we fed a coin into the unidentified meter hidden in a kitchen cabinet, the water began to boil again. For our next meal, we collected coins in advance to keep operations running smoothly.
Gradually we became comfortable in our chalet. Simple pleasures seemed more enjoyable in full view of the Alps. At night we could see thousands of stars and even the twinkling lights from villages in distant valleys and on nearby mountains. During the day we practically had to force ourselves to set out in search of other views that might equal but never surpass our own.
At the end of our stay the concierge telephoned and arranged to come by for the check and key. He also inspected the chalet and collected the cleaning fee, which is stipulated in most chalet contracts and ranges from $50 to $100. Chalets rarely offer daily maid service, but all are cleaned between visits. Owners usually request payment of the cleaning charge up front, along with advance payment for the entire stay. Given the last-minute nature of our arrangements, we were permitted to pay after we arrived.
When the concierge heard us groaning about dragging our luggage back up the mountain to the Wengen station, he suggested that we hire a "taxi," a resort-style electric cart that would pick us up and take us to the station for about $15. Apparently this luxury is available at all mountain resorts, although sometimes it is horse-drawn rather than motorized. Buggies and sleighs have their charm, but we were relieved when a speedy electric cart arrived to take us to the Wengen station 15 minutes before our train was to leave.
As we savored the luxury of riding up the mountain, Alex informed us that next time he would prefer a luxury hotel smack in the center of town with an indoor pool, a fancy restaurant and 24-hour room service. This was not the majority opinion.
I have every intention of arranging another chalet vacation -- for a full week, perhaps in that newly built Residence Patricia in Zermatt, where a duplex chalet with three bedrooms, three baths and a view of the Matterhorn is $295 a night in peak season. We may need crampons to get to town -- but more likely it's just a very good deal.
 
How to go about arranging a rental
 
The Basics
 Chalets are very popular among Europeans, and many of the most economical and most luxurious accommodations are booked months in advance. They are usually rented by the week, Saturday to Saturday. During the slower seasons (spring and autumn) some can be rented by the day. The Switzerland Tourism office in New York, (212) 757-5944, will provide telephone and fax numbers for village tourism offices.
In many villages, accommodations are rated by the Swiss tourism industry to provide comparisons, with five stars representing the most luxurious. Once a vacationer selects a suitable chalet, reservations can be made with the owner (most have fax access). Contracts are usually in German or French or both.
For those who prefer to let someone else do their chalet hunting, the Switzerland Tourism office offers a list of agencies in the United States. The advantage of going through an agency is the comfort of being able to discuss things in English, along with a sense of quality control. Most agencies say they inspect their properties. The disadvantage is price; agency rentals are more expensive.
Although most resort towns have chalets for rent, locations within a town vary significantly. The most convenient ones are not always the most expensive. Chalet "apartments" in high-rise (sometimes five- or six-story) buildings tend to be near the center of a town, which can also make them noisier. Single-unit chalets are usually on the outskirts and may require more strenuous hikes.
At most chalets, rates include bed linens and bedding (down puffs and feather pillows are standard), a kitchen supplied with dishes and utensils (many with dishwashers), heat, electricity and firewood. Many also include amenities that luxury hotels do not offer: washing machines and dryers, living rooms with fireplaces, mud rooms and board games. Many chalets provide television or radio. Guests are usually expected to bring towels, soap, napkins, paper towels and trash bags.
 
A Sampling
Rates depend on the season and are much lower in spring and fall. Skiers should note that the winter peak season can vary from village to village. Considering the complexity of high-high, high, middle, low and lower-than-low seasons in Switzerland, the only way to know prices for sure is to let the chalet know the precise dates that interest you. Owners say every situation is different, and they are ready to adapt prices not only to the seasons but also to such things as how full they are or whether schools are in session. Here is a sampling of current prices:
In Wengen, the Chalet Isabelle, telephone and fax (41-32) 351-4061, has a ground-floor room with three single beds, a small kitchen and a long terrace for $58 a day, or $19 a person, from December to April; $27.50, or $9 a person in May, October and November; $43.50, or $11 a person, from June to September. Tourism office: (41-33) 855-1414.
In Zermatt in peak season, $295 a night (through April 4) pays for six people in the four-star Residence Patricia, (41-27) 966-3097, fax (41-27) 966-3055, a newly built house facing the Matterhorn. The apartment is a duplex, with three double bedrooms, two bathrooms and a shower room, living room and kitchen. The three-star Haus Monazit, (41-27) 967-5222, accommodates up to six in a third-floor chalet apartment with a view of the Matterhorn for about $440 a night high season, $220 low. Tourism office: (41-27) 967-0181.
In upscale St. Moritz, where a double room at the five-star Badrutt's Palace Hotel, (41-81) 837-1000, is $465 a night in March, a studio apartment for two, with balcony and view in the Derby Chalet goes for $406 a week, or $58 a night. Tourism office: (41-81) 837-3333.
The resort town of Gstaad, known to Americans as a playground for Hollywood celebrities, has a 25-page list of weekly rental apartments. Prospective vacationers need to specify dates, number in the party and length of stay to receive faxed information about vacancies from the local tourism office, (41-33) 748-8181.
Saas-Fee, a resort near Zermatt that is popular among Germans, also has an extensive list of chalet apartments. From now through April 11, weekly prices range from about $252 for a studio for two people at the Azalea chalet to $2,899 for a six-and-a-half-room chalet that accommodates up to 12 people at the Alpengluck, with a wide range of choices in the $500 to $700 range. Tourism office: (41-27) 957-1457.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 15; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: FILM;
Some Keep Shining, but Most Just Fade to Gray

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
ACTORS OVER 60 SEEM TO BE enjoying something of a rejuvenation on screen. At 66, Armin Mueller-Stahl has an Oscar nomination for his performance in "Shine." So does Lauren Bacall, 72, for hers in "The Mirror Has Two Faces." In "Absolute Power," Clint Eastwood, 66, is running them ragged as an older master thief. Last summer, Sean Connery, also 66, led a commando team into Alcatraz in "The Rock." Earlier this winter, Jack Lemmon, 72, and James Garner, 68, galloped cross-country in "My Fellow Americans."
And there are more: Shirley MacLaine, 62, in "The Evening Star," Debbie Reynolds, 64, in "Mother" and of course Walter Matthau, at 76 perhaps the liveliest older actor going. 
 One might even get the impression that the old have at last risen to smite their traditional oppressor: the archtypical 32-year-old studio executive whose notion of the world extends all the way to 25.
But rank-and-file older actors tell a depressingly different story. While occasional roles materialize for the Matthaus and MacLaines, most working older actors find themselves as persona non grata as ever. Some have never seen it so bad.
"Our senior performers have all but disappeared from television, and they're practically invisible in feature films," says Richard Masur, 48, president of the Screen Actors Guild and a younger older actor with dozens of credits in films and television. "And I'm not talking about people over 65," he says, "I'm talking about 50." If you're a woman, make that 40.
That state of affairs may seem surprising in an aging population whose dominant segment, the baby boom generation, is already turning 50. Nevertheless, Mr. Masur says, Hollywood feels as free as ever to pursue a young audience that tends to be satisfied with formulaic movies and characters.
It is generally left to independent films to create complex older roles like Mr. Mueller-Stahl's in "Shine." Although older actors are understandably loath to discuss the situation on the record, Mr. Masur and his counterparts in the directors' and writers' guilds say that Hollywood is creating virtually no interesting older characters for the average actor to portray. Down in the acting ranks, the aging huddle and hope. "A few men between 50 and 60 are still considered somewhat viable because they're playing heads of corporations, governments, physicians, mentors and the like," Mr. Masur says. After that they, too, find themselves obliged to shuffle off to a no-person zone, as if people of 62 or so cease to exist in any guise anybody might have any interest in.
Women between 50 and 60 are for the most part long gone. "They totally disappear in that age range," Mr. Masur says. "Then they pop up again at about 65 when they've made the transition from being women to being old ladies."
Most galling to women at that age is the fact that their male screen contemporaries can still be found in the company of young women. Witness Gene Hackman, 67, who as President of the United States in "Absolute Power" wrestles with the willowy wife of an elderly tycoon (E. G. Marshall, 86).
On screen, older women are ordinarily deprived of sex, which in the world of Hollywood hinges entirely on looks. "You occasionally see a woman showing up well who is above 50," Mr. Masur says. Goldie Hawn, for example, who is 51, plays sexually appealing women in "Everyone Says I Love You" and "The First Wives Club." So did Ann-Margret, 55, in "Grumpy Old Men" and its sequel. "But the point is that Ann-Margret didn't look 50," Mr. Masur says.
If none of this is new in Hollywood, neither has age bias been quite so pronounced in the view of many older actors. "The business has changed more radically in the last five years," says Hal Holbrook, 72. "It's all gone to youth." A four-time Emmy winner who is perhaps best known for his portrayal of Mark Twain, Mr. Holbrook found his career tailing off in the early 1980's. "My hair was turning gray," he says. "I decided not to color it any more. My former wife told me, 'Holbrook, you're making a big mistake.' "
CURRENTLY HE IS PORTRAYING an old man suffering from cancer in a television film being shot in British Columbia. It's not a bad part, he says, and it's more satisfying than the usual run of movie roles coming along. These days, he adds, he usually finds better work in theater than he does on screen.
In the seemingly endless stream of Hollywood action fodder or, for a change of pace, comedies and dramas involving younger people, he and other older actors find little that is relevant or worthwhile to do on screen. If senior performers could create fulfilling roles for themselves, the characters might resemble those played by Mr. Mueller-Stahl as the emotionally brutalizing father of the pianist David Helfgott in "Shine," or the troubled widow portrayed by Gena Rowlands, 66, in "Unhook the Stars." Such characters have abounded in foreign films with stars like Jeanne Moreau (nearing 70) or Marcello Mastroianni (who died in December at age 72).
In Hollywood movies, according to many actors, when an older person does happen to wander onto the scene amid the stunts and car crashes, or for a pat on the silvery pate from patronizing young people, it is usually as the victim of abuse, the bumbling laughingstock, the rancorous so-and-so or other cuddly-prickly stereotypes.
"The deadliest thing you fight as an actor in movies and television is that they type you in their mind and they can't see anything else," Mr. Holbrook says. "And to a point they're right; you are what you are. But there are people who are actors -- Jason Robards, you know -- who have the capacity to alter themselves and play various characterizations. But we don't get much chance. The material isn't there these days."
Rarely in Hollywood movies, or so it is alleged by many senior actors, writers and directors, are older people portrayed with understanding or appreciation. With an aging population in this country, why is that tolerated? It is commonly assumed that older audiences are uncomfortable with the sight of aging people on screen to begin with, especially in films that portray them so narrowly and stupidly, and for this and other reasons avoid going to movies altogether.
Many older film people say that wouldn't be the case if people their age were depicted on screen the same way they function in life. Occasionally fine films come along -- "Cocoon" or "The Trip to Bountiful" or "Atlantic City" -- that treat the elderly as people with their faculties intact. Otherwise audiences usually seem to be fed buffoons, basket cases and crazy old coots.
It doesn't help that the older population doesn't complain. "Seniors are vocal about things like health care and social security, but almost totally silent about having themselves reflected accurately in the media," Mr. Masur says.
So that leaves the field pretty much to the young. Older actors mention a kind of vicious circle of economics and studio mindset. First, from Madison Avenue to Hollywood it is perceived that "younger" people, from the teens through about 45, are the ones spending money for specific products in this country. And what is a movie if not a product? Not that older people don't have a lot of money and leisure time to spend, but they aren't regarded as being as targetable.
With movies being made for the young, naturally it's the young who go to the movies. Teen-agers, in fact, often go several times to the same movie, for example Wes Craven's current high school horror film "Scream."
Studios obviously gear up accordingly. "In their view everything has to be written by young writers," says Brad Radnitz, president of the Writers Guild. "For parts you need young actors, and to understand the whole scene you need young directors."
Mr. Radnitz notes that in the old days of the studio system, directors and producers were company men churning out a balanced slate of films with room for all ages. Hollywood films, he says, are now individual projects of the producers, with studios serving merely as packagers and distributors. As for the film makers, he adds: "Each entity says: 'I'm not going to get too many shots here. I have one picture so I'd better make damn sure I make money on it.' "
That doesn't lead to broad-based film making. "Essentially it's an amusement park ride," Mr. Radnitz says. "No one is willing to take a risk. We've catered to the lowest common denominator in demographics, so pictures are for the 12-year-old mentality. That's the market, the kids coming back five and six times and making money for the studios."
Not surprising, many people in Hollywood regard this as a vast oversimplification. "I just don't think it's true at all," says Tom Rothman, president of production of 20th Century Fox. The studio, he points out, plans to release "Out to Sea," with Mr. Matthau and Mr. Lemmon, on May 30 and has several other films coming with solid roles for older actors. "Yes, there is a certain homogeneity in movies," he says, "but the problem is lessening because what you're seeing now is that the more original a picture is, the better it is doing."
Possibly that could be said of several recent independently made films -- "The English Patient," "Big Night," "Secrets and Lies," "Breaking the Waves," "Shine" and others -- all of which have attracted good critical attention and drawn mature audiences, not to mention most of the top Oscar nominations. But Mr. Rothman says it's also true of mature studio films like "The Crucible," "The People vs. Larry Flynt" and, speaking of the old folks, "Mother" and "The Evening Star."
Ms. MacLaine, for one, sees a slightly improving situation, if not a breakout, for older movie characters. "There seems to be more interest in wisdom, in what someone with more experience might have to offer," she says. "They're funnier, they've lived longer, they have more appreciation for contradiction."
As for Mr. Mueller-Stahl, recognition has come only recently in this country, and he says he will be glad for whatever comes along. "So you can play characters. They're still with us," he says. "I've been heroes and sons in East Europe and fathers of bad guys in West Europe. Now I'm going to make myself a career as a grandfather in America, which is a great benefit."
As for the tyranny of youth, he may have found another way. Recently he directed his first film. "I got an invitation as a young director for a film festival in Madrid," he says.

LENGTH: 1372 words

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Melvyn Bloom;
Furthering the Cause of 'New Zionism'

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AS executive vice president of the American Society for Technion the last 12 years, Melvyn Bloom has the job of overseeing efforts to raise money on behalf of Technion, formally known as the Israel Institute of Technology.
Through his work, Mr. Bloom, a resident of Pelham Manor, furthers what he calls "New Zionism" -- a partnership with a successful Israel rather than a handout to a needy country. It is a job he does well, raising from nonalumni more money in the United States for a university thousands of miles away than some Ivy League schools can do for themselves. 
 Founded in 1924, the institute, based in Haifa, is often called the M.I.T. of the Middle East. Mr. Bloom, who began his career in journalism and public relations, formerly worked for the United Jewish Appeal. He recently obtained a $30 million donation for Technion, from an American businessman, the largest in the school's history and one of the largest to education anywhere.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. What ingredients make for a good fund-raiser? Is it tenacity or is it connections?
A. I think traditionally both of those things have been part of it. But having said that, while those things are hardly irrelevant, that is not it any more. I think, yes, having an affection for people, wanting to make very good friends, enjoying those interactions are certainly a part of it.
But similarly, the notion of connections on an individual basis is too personalized, if you will, to be effective for someone who has to run a large and complex organization. The issue from my point of view is more of conducting the orchestra than playing the violin. The question is how do you put together the right combination of people -- the volunteers and professional organization -- who have the right set of networks among them. Who collectively can help reach out to a large variety of people?
Q. Must you have a good cause as well?
A. That's exactly it. That's the other thing that has to be stressed. I almost would have said that was the beginning. The same thing in terms of my experience in public relations, if your mission -- if your case -- is not valid and not something about which you as a fund-raiser can feel passionate about and able to communicate to others, then nothing that you say or do can be that effective.
Q. People must ask you why are you doing all this for another country? Much is often said about the special relationship of American Jews to Israel, but there are still so many needy causes at home.
A. First of all, there is the whole notion of the Zionist connection. The inextricable link between the Jewish people and the homeland certainly has a basis, depending on where you come from, that is almost biological. It's spiritual. It's historic. It's part of our continuity as a people.
While you're absolutely correct that there are serious needs and challenges and problems at home, it would be a false choice to say it's an either-or issue. First of all, no one knows precisely how to solve the problems that we face here; secondly, it's at the core of our identity, of our future and identity as a people to maintain that connection with Israel.
The next question becomes what is the most apt, most appropriate way to help Israel in a contemporary sense. That's where the mission or our organization comes along and why I believe we have the right mission for this particular stage of Israel's growth.
Q. What is that mission?
A. Our mission statement says it's to convince the leadership of the American Jewish community that the future of Israel is in high technology, and in Israel high technology is at the Technion.
Which is a way of saying this institution, often called the M.I.T. of the Middle East, is the only comprehensive technological and scientific institution not only in Israel but in that whole part of the world. It's the only institution like it in the whole history of the Jewish people. It's part of the enlightenment of the 20th century, and the question is now as we move toward the 21st century what direction it should move.
Q. What is this "new" Zionism that you believe in?
A. If one buys into the validity of the connection between American Jews and Israel, the next question is, How can you be most helpful? Many of us who are not yet senior citizens can remember the creation of the state of Israel in our lifetime, yet it's barely 50 years old. In that period of time, obviously, the evolution of Israel has been remarkable. It has moved from a country that only a generation ago was having its survival questioned by many.
The kind of New Zionism that I refer to is one that emphasizes pride over tragedy and future over past. If we can achieve intellectual power, Israel can, in my view, truly be a light unto the nations in a biblical sense. Painfully for many of us, I don't think Israel is in a place where for the Jewish people it can be the beacon right now in terms of ethical and religious teaching. But I think through science and high technology, Israel can do things for people all around the world and in that part of the world in particular, as hostilities become less important. People are going to eat better, have cleaner water; people will begin sharing pioneering technologies.
People, I think, are going to work together, and that will provide a path to the future, which is a very exciting vision. There's no limit in terms of what can be done by those of us who have this traditional commitment to try always to be repairing this universe into which we were born.
Q. How does the Technion come into this?
A. Israel is in a different era. Just recently the International Monetary Fund decided to add Israel to its list of industrial nations, which means that, clearly, Israel has either reached first-world status or is on the threshold of that. But there are some problems. There is a national consensus about the importance of economic independence for Israel. Israel hasn't achieved that. Israel needs the skills and people to ride the horse harder and in a more skillful way in the direction it is already going to achieve economic independence.
Technion is speaking to national goals. It speaks to excellence, and it speaks to pride in the sense we are talking about an institution of excellence.
It can attract support because of the historical and emotional connection with American Jewry and also in the same way that a Japanese industrialist might make a gift to Stanford or Harvard, or Oxford University might conduct a campaign in the United States. And that's really a source of pride for our friends in Israel, as opposed to the notion that the help is a form of social welfare.
Q. Does this idea of excellence at the top trickle down to the lower levels of schools in Israel? And if so, how does that compare with what is going on in the United States?
A. I was just in Israel last week, and one of the figures I heard that was instructive -- maybe good material for a comedian -- is that Israel is now second only to the Untied States in the number of attorneys per capita. If they continue to produce law school graduates at the current rate, they will actually be No. 1 in the world before long.
I think it's an issue of whether young people who have the aptitude to move in the areas of science and high technology need to be educated about those opportunities -- both in the United States and Israel. If I remember the numbers, Israel has something like 130 scientists for every 10,000 workers, which is not enough for where Israel has to go. As I recall, the United States had 80 and Japan about 75 scientists per 10,000 workers.
So the United States also, I think, can see an opportunity or a gap in terms of the distance between the opportunities out there and the number of individuals who are trained.
Q. Is Technion expensive to attend or does the Government subsidize its students?
A. It's really the latter. Yes, it's expensive, but not for the student. The tradition in Israel is, If you grow up as an Israeli and you serve in the army and you have the smarts to get into one of the top universities, you are entitled to go, heavily subsidized by public funds.

HEADLINE: ART;
Mt. Vernon Reorganizes Schools

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
MAJOR restructuring of the school system here was approved by the Board of Education at a crowded and fiery meeting earlier this month. The nine-member Board of Trustees voted 6 to 3 to start a three-year pilot program altering the makeup of the district's schools.
Under the program, the trustees will reconfigure some elementary schools as kindergarten-through-eighth-grade schools and phase out at least one middle school in the 10,000-student district. This would create what some refer to as "elemiddle schools." The change has been criticized by some community leaders and by the board's only two black members. 
 School officials first responded to a call for change by embarking on curriculum reform, but after a turbulent school board election, the idea evolved into a dispute that has divided the community along decades-old racial and economic lines.
For decades, the Metro-North tracks were an unofficial color line, with most whites on the north and blacks and Jews on the south. But the city is now more diverse, with blacks constituting a slight majority. Whites are still concentrated on the city's north side. Poorer residents live mainly in northwestern and south-central areas, and middle- and upper-middle classes are in the northeast and the southeast. Eighty-five percent of the student population represents minorities.
Some officials say the real issue is more about class and economic status than race. In the last 30 years the demographics of Mount Vernon have changed to an older population and a shrinking middle class, and 55 percent of the tax assessment on residential property is allocated to the school system, City Controller Maureen Walker said.
Last summer Mount Vernon teachers took part in the Summer Institute on Curriculum Restructuring organized by the National Urban Alliance for Effective Schools of Teachers College at Columbia University, receiving $100,000 from the school board, supposedly to help establish a districtwide curriculum. Then the board started debating the restructuring of the district's 11 elementary and 2 middle schools.
In school board elections last spring, four white candidates defeated four blacks, two of whom were incumbents. The board at the time was the most diverse ever in Mount Vernon, and blacks stood to gain a first-time majority. The four new trustees were endorsed by the Italian Civic Association, a 70-year-old organization, which until 1994 held considerable influence in school board elections. That year the Coalition for the Empowerment of People of African Ancestry helped elect three black trustees, the largest number of blacks ever to serve.
Gloria T. Coleman, civil rights and political action chairwoman of the Empowerment Coalition, said of the most recent election that voter rights violations had occurred and that the results were being challenged in a complaint to the United States Department of Justice and the State Department of Education.
Mrs. Coleman said she is also seeking a change in how school board elections are administered, suggesting that the county's Board of Elections handle them. She expressed opposition to the kindergarten-through-eighth-grade concept, saying that students would be forced to attend only schools in their neighborhoods. Currently, parents have the option of sending their children to any school in the district, provided there is enough space.
Anthony M. Mosca, a newly elected trustee and member of the Italian Civic Association who favors the reorganization of kindergarten through eighth grade, said, "During the campaign, we had many cottage meetings with parents, administrators and other school districts, and one of the items on our platform was the K-through-8 concept." He also said he believed students would fare better in small neighborhood schools, as they do in parochial schools.
In addition, Mr. Mosca cited complaints from some merchants about the large number of students dismissed from the two magnet middle schools near them -- Franko Performing Arts and Science Magnet Middle School and A. B. Davis -- as another reason for phasing out middle schools.
"The business and commercial districts have been concerned with the hordes of children being released from the middle schools at 3 o'clock," he said. "A lot of people sell their homes and leave Mount Vernon when it comes time for their children to go the middle schools."
In the face of tougher academic requirements imposed by the state, however, some residents have expressed concern about the district's ability to meet the higher standards.
Mayor Ernest E. Davis said, "People are doing this because, perhaps, they have more faith in the elementary schools than in the high schools and middle schools."
Board members favoring the kindergarten-through-eighth-grade plan say that some parents would rather send their children to parochial or private school because they believe they will receive a better education there and that public middle schools are "too large and overbearing."
Under the pilot plan, sixth graders attending two elementary schools on the north side and one on the south side would remain in their present schools until eighth grade, starting in the 1997-98 school year. If parents wish to send their children to the district's middle schools, they will have that option, under the plan, but Franko Middle School will be closed within a year.
Alfonzo Grimes, principal of the Franko Magnet Middle School, questioned before the board made its recent decision, said he was opposed to the kindergarten-through-eighth-grade proposal because he believes adolescents are better educated in environments with children of the same age and that the magnet programs offer a more challenging curriculum. The Franko Middle School has been featured in the National Middle Schools Association's magazine, High Strides, Urban Schools, as a model secondary school. According to school officials, Mr. Grimes will serve as co-principal of the two combined middle schools, which will be at A. B. Davis next year when Franko becomes a school for lower grades.
In Phase 2 of the district's plan, at least one elementary school will be reconfigured into a kindergarten-through-fifth-grade school. This was an idea suggested by two of the board members opposed to the kindergarten-through-eighth-grade concept. Frances W. Wynn, a two-term board member, voted against combining elementary and middle school students along with two other school board members, Kenneth B. Sylvester, a black trustee, and Donald P. Augustine of the Italian Civic Association.
Ms. Wynn, Mr. Sylvester and a former board member, Lynn McBride, presented an alternative for reshaping schools as kindergarten through fourth grade and fifth through eighth grade. Mrs. Wynn also said in a recent interview that she believed the board was rushing into a change without sufficient research.
Mount Vernon will be the only public school district in the county structured with kindergarten-through-eighth-grade schools.
State law requires school districts to include ideas from community leaders, parents, school staff members and students in their decisions. This cooperative school management concept is conducted through what is known as the Compact for Learning/School-Based Management Teams. The Mount Vernon district's Compact for Learning Congress, made up of all of the district's management teams, has opposed school restructuring. The stated objective of trustees who voted for restructuring is to remove about 800 students from the Franko and A. B. Davis Middle Schools and enroll them in neighborhood "elemiddle" schools. The Superintendent's office estimated that the cost of the pilot program in the first year will be $135,000. Construction of modular classrooms may also be required. A Head Start program in a south-side elementary school is expected to be displaced.
Mrs. Wynn said at a previous board meeting: "You need at least a year to implement this type of major restructuring. It scares me that we don't know that. As trustees, we have to think seriously about our mission. This is not the kind of thing we can do quickly, as we are trying to do it."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Children play in the yard outside the Longfellow School in Mount Vernon before classes begin; Philip Beckerich, science teacher, teaching photosynthesis to eighth graders at Franko Middle School in Mount Vernon. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
