HEADLINE: Plan to Reduce Nitrogen in Sound Is Criticized by Sewer Officials

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
PROPELLING efforts to reinvigorate Long Island Sound, a Federal and state panel has proposed reducing nitrogen discharges to the Sound by 58.5 percent over 15 years.
The proposal evolved from broad agreements that reducing nitrogen held the greatest potential to help reverse the decline of the estuary. In 1994 New York and Connecticut formally endorsed a plan that identified nitrogen abatement as an important objective, and the two states have pledged major spending. 
 But as news of the new plan, to be the subject of meetings in the summer, spread along the shore since it was announced last month, it has met opposition over its proposed methods. Operators of eight of the nine sewage-treatment plants on the North Shore that discharge into the Sound have opposed the across-the-board approach. They said the approach overlooked more economical and equitable methods.
The plan, the operators added, would penalize Long Island, the section of the shoreline least responsible for the problem, while letting off New York City, the largest nitrogen contributor, with too much leniency.
The operators said they worried about costs, which the proposal underestimated, and about financing from a $1.75 billion bond act that voters approved in November. About $200 million in bond money is supposed to be earmarked to clean up the Sound.
Last week the regional director of the Environmental Conservation Department, Ray E. Cowen, said adequate financing would be available from the bond act, a separate environmental protection fund and a low-interest revolving-loan fund.
"They don't have to worry about funding," Mr. Cowen said. "We are going to process those applications and give them the maximum amount that is available under those three programs. They should just get something in to us."
The operators may continue to worry that state financing will not cover the costs. Excess costs could add to tax burdens for sewer districts. The operators also question whether the expense at small plants would be worth the limited reduction of nitrogen.
The reduced levels were proposed by the Long Island Sound Policy Committee, headed by environmental officials from New York, Connecticut and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
The proposal starts a new phase in a federally sponsored effort that began 12 years ago. The 58.5 percent cuts would apply equally to discharges from Long Island, New York City, Westchester County and Connecticut, a quantity that totals 222,838 pounds a day.
The proposal requires that each of 11 designated shoreline areas, including one in Nassau and one in Suffolk, find ways to meet the goal through actions that would include improving sewage plants and limiting industrial discharges.
On Long Island, where direct industrial discharges are not a factor, reductions would be achieved through a combination of sewer projects and plans to reduce discharges from so-called nonpoint sources. Those include the runoff from storm water, which includes lawn fertilizers and animal wastes. Faulty septic tanks are also sources.
Meeting the 58.5 percent goal would cost $650 million, the committee said, including $299 million for New York. The Long Island share would include $22.6 million to upgrade the sewage plants, according to state estimates.
Operators of Long Island sewage plants said nitrogen from their discharges accounted for 2 percent of the New York total. The proposal, they added, should emphasize reducing nitrogen from sewage plants along the East River in New York City that account for 95 percent of the state sewage total.
"Equity suggests that the dischargers which cause the problem should bear the burden of solving it," the operators wrote to the committee. They argued that equal investments would yield far more benefit in reducing nitrogen from New York City than from Long Island.
An engineering consultant for the operators, Gary E. Loesch of Holzmacher, McLendon & Murrell, said the across-the-board approach also ignored computer models that showed that the largest nitrogen discharges were from New York City.
But officials involved in drawing up the proposal said the modeling showed other factors. An official of the E.P.A., Mark A. Tedesco, said the operators were overlooking evidence that the Long Island discharges, while small compared to those of New York City, had "a greater impact on a per-pound basis," because of points of entry, geography, currents and other factors.
Nitrogen from sewage plants, storm runoff and other sources like fertilizers is linked to hypoxia, or low dissolved oxygen in water. A study that the two states and the E.P.A. began in 1985 found that hypoxia was the greatest single threat to the Sound.
Hypoxia usually occurs in late summer, when algae and marine plants that nitrogen has fertilized sink to the bottom and consume oxygen as they decompose. Nitrogen is associated with urine and other organic material in sewage.
Some 70 sewage plants discharge more than one billion gallons a day of treated effluent into the Sound. Nitrogen in the effluent spurs abnormal growth of marine plants when it is excessive, worsening the hypoxia.
From 1987 to 1993, researchers found, hypoxia in the summer occurred in one-half to two-thirds of the bottom waters. On Long Island, the area of hypoxia was as far east as Riverhead, but was most severe in western reaches. The researchers have linked hypoxia to the loss of types and abundance of fin fish, stunted growth of lobsters and a general decline in the marine habitat. Hypoxia can also kill slow-moving species. If oxygen levels fall low enough, fish kills may ensue.
Environmental officials said efforts to limit nitrogen discharges and in some cases reduce them had had beneficial effects. The state's Director of Watershed Management. Phil DeGaetano, said Nassau and Suffolk had complied with earlier requirements.
The operators of sewer plants in the two counties were not alone, he said, adding that operators in New York City and Westchester County were also complaining.
Boards of commissioners operate some districts. The City of Glen Cove, the Village of Great Neck are also operators in Nassau. In Suffolk, the County Public Works Department operates plants in Port Jefferson and Kings Park.
The Town of Huntington was the sole operator on the Island that did not join in writing to the committee. Mr. Tedesco, whose office is in Connecticut, said he knew of no complaints there.
Mr. Tedesco and Carolyn J. Hughes, executive director of the Long Island Sound Study, said the plan was flexible and could be changed. "We have spent a lot of time looking at this problem," Ms. Hughes said. "We have essentially talked a lot to a very small number of people about it. Now we will explain at the public meetings how we developed this plan and allow people to ask questions."
Each area would be free to devise its way to meet the goals under a trading system. The system would award credits to an operator that invested in upgrading another plant. Credits would be based on the quantity of nitrogen removed and then be used by the investing operator to avoid performing similar work at a possibly higher cost.
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove said last week that he was proposing that other operators in Nassau take advantage of the credit program by joining in upgrading the Glen Cove plant.
"Our plant is well suited for significant reduction of nitrogen for the least investment," Mr. Suozzi said. "In return they could be given credits that would allow them not to meet the standards at their own plants."

GRAPHIC: Graph/Map: "Saving the Sound"
In the third phase of a program that began in 1990, environmental agencies have announced a plan calling for a 58.5 percent reduction in nitrogen discharges to Long Island Sound over the next 15 years. Nitrogen is the nutrient most directly responsible for low dissolved oxygen -- a condition that scientists call hypoxia -- which renders large areas of the Sound unhealthy for marine life. Discharges from the 70 sewage treatment plants that ring the Sound contribute greatly to this problem.
Graph shows current and proposed nitrogen discharged in Nassau and Suffolk. It also lists Government estimates for sewage treatment plant upgrades in nine communitites. (Source: The Long Island Sound Office of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency)

HEADLINE: ART;
Emerging Photographers Capture Images Radiating Power

BYLINE: By PHYLLIS BRAFF 

 BODY:

Dark Images, Bright Prospects: The Survival of the Figure After World War II
The Parrish Art Museum, 25 Job's Lane, Southampton. To Mar. 29. 283-2118. 
 An assembly of painting, sculpture, video, photography, decorative and industrial objects, slide projection and music, this show feels dynamic, and it feels big. Certainly its ambitions are large, for the aim is to look at the American psyche during the 1945-55 decade and use the information as a context for that era's art.
The project is the most recent in a series of collaborations between the Parrish Art Museum and Southampton High School. Student participants were guided by educators, museum professionals and outside consultants specializing in art history, literature, economics, history, political science, film, journalism and design.
Examining artists' approaches to the figure in the new society is the central theme. Insecurity produced by the atom bomb and the cold war is used as part of the social definition. A consciousness of the general vulnerability of the human body is reflected in art in which the figure is not dominant, not in control, not celebrated. Fracturing, fragmentation and dissolving are frequent approaches. In the Hans Hofmann example here, pigment takes over and dominates the figure.
Much of the art is aligned with expanding researches into abstraction and in many instances the human motif is barely recognizeable. The body is never preserved as a coherent whole. It dissolves into vigorous brush gestures that integrate figure and landscape in examples by Willem de Kooning and Jack Tworkov. Another fine example, and one of the show's best pieces, is Ethel Schwabacher's "Woman III," which features a central mass of vibrant strokes, with one mark suggesting a green arm bent at the elbow and a middle, flesh-toned section that immediately suggests a breast.
In a particularly energetic work by Alfonso Ossorio, "Full Mother," the body is a flat mass of loose, throbbing lines. The Surrealists in New York in the 40's had a significant impact. Their explorations of biomorphic forms were an important influence on a painting of amoebalike figures by Dorothy Dehner and on a major canvas featuring cell-like shapes by Gerome Kamrowski. The Surrealists' use of the inner world, and especially the subconscious, made intuitive gestural abstraction an extension of human subject matter.
Some pieces, like Byron Browne's "Lion Hunt" and Herbert Ferber's "Apocalyptic Rider" suggest that the interest in mythology, reinforced by the Surrealists, provided one valid way to present a figurative motif.
A chronological installation accompanied by a current events time-line text brings some expected and unexpected insights. In 1946, for instance, we see a grid-format Adolph Gottlieb painting near a history panel pointing out widespread developments of housing tracts and the introduction of the first computer. Jacob Lawrence's faceted figures hang nearby and Seymour Lipton's spiky, aggressive and weighty sculpture is not far from the text noting the first use of the term "iron curtain."

Emerging Photography
 Sag Harbor Picture Gallery, 66 Main Street, Sag Harbor. To Mar. 15. 725-3100.
There is a considerable amount of power in this grouping of 13 talented photographers in early phases of their careers. Much of the force comes from insights into human situations, but there are also a number of bold esthetic successes. In spite of the crowded format, the selections project the thematic, stylistic and technical goals of each artist.
In many ways the show gives evidence of a growing wave of artists concerned with identifying social problems. Strong works by John Lucas and Axel Koester also convey emotional uncertainty and present the artists' own conflicts rather than the observations of a documentarian.
Addressing issues of race and isolation, Mr. Lucas allows fractured images of heads, hands and industrial landscapes to be broken again by 35 panes from an old, weathered window in a fine example of message blending with method. Auschwitz, German family members and their possible complicity in the Holocaust are woven into Mr. Koester's sequence of eight diaristic pieces, "What Will I Tell My Son?" The group includes images of a visit to the death camp by the photographer and his young child.
Other artists clearly taking positions of responsibility in their revealing works include Kristen Ashburn, Andrew Lightenstein and Alex Tehrani. Ms. Ashburn has studied institutional cases in Romania, while Mr. Lichtenstein has tried to penetrate the thoughts of individuals in Texas detentions centers. A special kind of compassion comes across in Mr. Tehrani's images of luckless, troubled students at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn. He manages to contrast toughness with a yearning for educational accomplishments.
As he pursues his interest in slice-of-life photography, with the subjects unaware of the camera, Richard Sandler tries to show people deeply absorbed in their own isolation in spite of the surrounding crush of city life. Their reverie has dignity. Mr. Sandler's talent with light achieves a delicate magic in his handling of the gauzy headcover worn by a woman waiting for a subway train.
Waiting is also the theme of Evan Kafka's memorable photograph of a solitary horse profiled against St. Petersburg's massive, stark palaces. A fine metaphor and symbol of a fragile nation, the huge empty square has the appearance of a stage on which anything might next occur.
Further insights into world conditions occur in James Nubile's black and white images from Eastern Europe that successfully combine history with extraordinary tonal and pictorial effects. One example uses the irregular night lightbeams spraying the sky to silhouette guards patrolling the Berlin Wall. Another surrounds movie makers in Sarajevo with a mysterious and dramatic foggy mist.
Imposing color photographs by David Leeson and Stephen Ferry mix their social observations with a strong sense of pattern and design, often using black shadows as a dominant compositional element. Mr. Ferry's images of women in a Spanish Sahara refugee camp, and of a mining family in Bolivia, are among the examples that deserve high marks for both compelling human insights and forceful visual components.

HEADLINE: A Stamford Landmark's Facade at the Center of a Battle

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
IN downtown Stamford, virtually denuded of landmarks after seemingly unending urban renewal, a nondescript 70-year-old building on upper Atlantic Street has become a line in the sand in the battle between preservationists and developers.
In truth, it's not the entire building, which houses the Palace Theater, that is in question, only its facade of brick, terra cotta and glazed tile, which, covered with grime, bespeaks its years of exposure to the elements and neglect. And yet it still exudes an architectural distinctiveness. 
 The four-story building opened as a vaudeville and movie house in 1927 with apartments on the upper floors and, since its revival in the 1980's, has been a center for the performing arts.
Now, though, a controversy -- perhaps the most intensive yet over a city landmark -- has developed as to whether the familiar facade on Atlantic Street should be preserved or should torn down during a proposed renovation project.
Not even those bent on saving the facade will say it is an architectural gem comparable to the now-vacant Old Town Hall, the Post Office or the old Stamford Advocate building, all of which are on the lower end of Atlantic Street. Rather, it is because the facade -- and the building itself -- is one of the few remaining tangible memories of old Stamford in the downtown district, and a very special one at that.
The Palace was for many years the grand dame of Stamford's movie theaters because of its magnificent foyer, its wide but relatively shallow 1,584-seat theater with side loges evocative of its days as a vaudeville house and its close, sharply-steeped balcony. Old-timers can recall when, during vaudeville's heyday in the 1920's and 1930's, stars like Will Rogers, Hattie McDaniel, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, Jackie Cooper, Red Skelton, Lucille Ball, The Three Stooges and Harry Blackstone the magician (and later his son, Harry Jr.) performed at the Palace.
"There's been an extraordinarily cavalier attitude in Stamford about the razing of landmarks, and the Palace is one of the last vestiges of older downtown that are left," said Neil Sherman, the president of the Stamford Chamber of Commerce. "In order to have any sense of community, we have to retain some of our community memories. And old buildings, like the Palace, are one source of memories. Other cities are now stressing the special heritage of their old buildings, but we haven't done that in Stamford."
Because of inadequate lobby space, the Stamford Center for the Arts, which owns the building in which the Palace is situated, plans to widen the front of the theater from 50 to 126 feet. To do so, the nonprofit organization bought a nearby carpet store and the site of a burned-out restaurant adjacent to the Palace. Funds for those purchases came from private donations, says John Hiddlestone, the director of development and community affairs for the Stamford Center for the Arts. Part of the renovation of the old theater, including the doubling of the stage and the construction of rehearsal rooms, is already under way, paid for in part by a $1.3 million state grant.
Though the Center's 49-member board has not yet made a final decision on the fate of the facade, most members are believed to favor razing it and building a front similar to the one on the Rich Forum on lower Atlantic Street, another venue for theatrical productions and concerts that the Center for the Arts also owns. Indeed, during a meeting of the board last month, the 20 members present unanimously agreed that the facade should be torn down and replaced with a new exterior. That nonbinding action was taken after the center had commissioned three architectural firms -- one from Bridgeport and two from New York -- to come up with separate renderings for the exterior renovation, one with the existing facade and the other without.
Comments by some board members antagonized preservationists and others determined to retain the facade, including the city's governing body, the Stamford Board of Representatives, which has unanimously voted in favor of preserving the facade.
One member of the center's board, Robert Harris, was quoted as describing the facade as being "ugly" and unworthy of preservation. Another, Robert Neu, a former Stamford superintendent of parks and recreation, went even further, speaking out against "hard core building huggers who have been diverting the process."
Frank D. Rich Jr., the president of the center's board, about half of whose members live outside of the city, was more diplomatic. "We're glad to have input from the community before we make a decision," Mr. Rich said in an interview. "I think there's a legitimate case for preservation, although we think that a minority of people in town want to preserve the front of the building. We also have to decide whether it's prudent to spend between $625,000 and $700,000 to preserve the facade."
That was a reference to the estimate, which Mr. Rich and other board members say such a project (shoring up the facade while razing the lobby), would cost. Opponents have contended that the cost would be substantially less if the entire front of the building, about 50 feet in depth, were saved, rather than merely the eight-inch-thick skin.
"The community is not going to let them" -- the Stamford Center for the Arts -- "tear the facade down," said David Anderson, president of the Stamford Partnership, a coalition of business, government and community leaders and a member of a citizens' committee set up to try to resolve the controversy. "The Palace is one of the few meritorious public places we have left and it would be folly to tear down the facade."
Roger Lang, a New York architect associated with the New York Landmarks Conservancy, agreed. "It's distinctive in its own right, and it's all the more worth saving because so little of the past is left in downtown Stamford," said Mr. Lang, who was the architect for the theater's interior restoration in the early 1980's. "It all comes down to a question of will and attitudes towards the past."
That may not bode well for the Palace's facade, given Stamford's record over the last quarter-century during which much of the downtown has been gutted and replaced by an array of contemporary construction.
"We've already suffered so many terrible losses of buildings," said Renee Kahn, the director of the Historic Neighborhoods Preservation Program in Stamford and arguably the city's most passionate and indefatigable preservationist. "Now they want to tear down a beautiful facade that is part of a historic street and replace it with something glitzy and out of place. Frank Rich doesn't like the building and his board has to go by what he tells them. After all, the Rich taste has been imposed on Stamford for the last 30 years."
That was a reference to the fact that much of Stamford's urban renewal has been done by a construction company owned by Mr. Rich's family. Indeed, the Rich Forum, which is owned and operated by the Stamford Center for the Arts, is named for the Rich family, which has deep roots in the city.
"It's no wonder that a lot of Stamford people say they never go downtown any more because they don't recognize the town," Ms. Kahn added. "There's no sense of belonging anymore. But I must say that I've never seen such across-the-board support for an issue like this."
In the end, the city of Stamford may have something to say about whether the facade will be saved. Through the city, the Stamford Center for the Arts has obtained a $ l.5 million grant from the State Department of Economic Development to help pay for the overall renovation project, estimated at between $3 and $4 million. As the conduit of that grant, the administration of Mayor Dannel P. Malloy has the authority to approve or disapprove of any design for the Palace, including the facade. And Mr. Malloy is on record as being in favor of preserving what few city landmarks remain.
The Mayor has criticized parties on both sides of the controversy. "There's been a bad job of managing this discussion," Mr. Malloy said. "There are certain buildings, like the Old Town Hall, that you preserve regardless of any particular future use. Then there are others, like the building that includes the Palace, that you want to preserve if they can be rehabilitated for specific purposes. In the case of the Palace building, I'd like to see some of the building used for office space and maybe a restaurant."
Carmen Domonkos, the president of the city's Board of Representatives, has been sharply critical of the Center for the Arts' board in the controversy.
"We've been giving tax incentives to owners of downtown property like the Stamford Center for the Arts," said Ms. Domonkos. "But if we give them such incentives and then they tear down their buildings they lose all credibility. And the city has also given about $2 million to the Stamford Center for the Arts."
Ms. Kahn sees the Palace controversy as a watershed episode in the struggle to save Stamford's few remaining landmarks. "It's time to draw a line in the sand," she said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
How a State Initiative Helps Create New Jobs

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A PROGRAM initiated by the state last May has proven helpful to companies expanding within New Jersey and has induced others to relocate to the state.
In the process new jobs are being created and empty office space is filling up, making a tight market even tighter. 
 Called the Business Employment Incentive Program, the initiative returns to companies -- in the form of grants for up to 10 years -- as much as 80 percent of the personal income tax revenue generated by each new employee. In some cases, companies also get an exemption from the state's sales tax on the purchase of machinery and equipment.
"What this does is give businesses a share in the tax revenue generated from unanticipated jobs," said Alan J. Steinberg, assistant commissioner of the state Department of Commerce, which oversees the program.
So far 24 companies have been approved for grants resulting from a total of 5,785 new jobs either created or promised, according to state data. That reflects the pattern of job growth in New Jersey, which has recaptured 217,000 of the 263,000 jobs lost during the recession, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
Among the first companies approved for the program is MSNBC, the 24-hour cable news network begun last July by Microsoft Corporation and NBC. The network is turning a 110,000-square-foot warehouse on Hartz Way in the Secaucus Meadowlands into its expanded headquarters and studio.
The site, which was chosen over 200 others in the three-state metropolitan New York region, is expected to open by April and generate 400 jobs, said Lauren Leff, a company spokeswoman. (Separate from the program, the state is about to issue $150 million in bonds for the purchase of equipment for the building, which is being leased for 15 years from Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus.
Other concerns approved for the grants include Coopers & Lybrand, the Manhattan-based accounting firm; Lucent Technologies, an AT&T spin-off that develops and produces telecommunications products, and Teleport Communications Group of Staten Island.
Many of the companies are moving into existing office space, helping to reduce the vacancy rate in the 11-county northern New Jersey market. By the end of 1996 the rate was 16.4 percent, down from 19.4 percent the year before, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage.
Other companies are constructing buildings. One is Albert's Organics, a distributor of organic produce, which is relocating from Chadds Ford, Pa., to a 36,000-square-foot office and warehouse at the Pureland Industrial Complex off Route 95 in Bridgeport. The company is also receiving state financing to build the $2 million project, where it will employ 106 workers over the next two years.
To be eligible for the incentive program, concerns must create and maintain at least 25 jobs in targeted urban areas (municipalities with low-income neighborhoods in need of rehabilitation, such as Camden, Trenton and Newark) or at least 75 jobs elsewhere in New Jersey. Companies also have to retain a presence in the state for one and a half times the term of the grant, and it must be a prime reason they are moving to or growing in New Jersey. No money will be disbursed until the State Treasurer certifies that the taxes withheld from new employees' paychecks at least equal the amount of the grant. There are penalities and payback provisions: If a company does not maintain the jobs agreed upon the grant is terminated and if it does not stay in New Jersey the required time the state may recapture all or part of the grant.
The percentage of income tax returned to companies and for how long is based on several factors. Among them are the number and location of the jobs, the average salary for those jobs and whether the company is in an industry targeted as a growth area for New Jersey. The latter include financial services, telecommunications and international trade.
To accommodate its growing business Teleport Communications Group, a provider of telecommunications services, is expanding into a 121,000-square-foot building at the Princeton Technology Center in Dayton. Teleport, which retained its Staten Island offices, will use the Dayton building for its national training and operations center, where it expects to employ 375 to 400 workers over the next 18 months. The grant to the company, which operates in 57 metropolitan markets, will be $2.4 million over 10 years.
"While important to our original plan to expand to Dayton, the incentives became crucial as we saw opportunities to bring in additional functions such as our executive offices and sales and human resources folks," said John A. Scarpati, Teleport's chief financial officer.
THE grant to Coopers & Lybrand, which is expanding its presence in New Jersey, will be $3 million over 10 years. The accounting firm recently leased 67,000 square feet of space at 101 Hudson Street, an office tower along the Jersey City waterfront.
That brings the total amount of space the firm occupies in several locations in the state to 346,000 square feet, said Stephen A. Karness, managing partner for the firm's New Jersey operations. He said that 450 people work at the Jersey City office, and that an additional 200 jobs would be added at its New Jersey sites in the next two years.
"We could have relocated anywhere in the tristate region," said Mr. Karness. "But absent the incentive we probably would not have made the move."
Caren S. Franzini, executive director of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, which is administering the incentive program, said: "The idea is to bring highly skilled jobs to the state." And in terms of competition, she added, "it helps even the playing field" with other parts of the country where the costs of living and doing business are lower.
Mr. Steinberg also pointed out that the program "honors the state's nonraiding agreement" with New York.
Developers, landlords and brokers also see the program as a plus in marketing existing or proposed office buildings.
"I don't want to hype it but the program has keened the interest of major tenants," said Edwin H. Cohen, an executive director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield. And it can have an impact on the cost of doing business, creating "an additional economic advantage" to draw tenants, he added.
Mr. Cohen is the exclusive leasing agent for the 758,525-square-foot office tower the Lefrak Organization, of Rego Park, Queens, plans to build at the Newport mixed-used project on the Jersey City waterfront once a major tenant leases space. Three other developer groups are also planning offices on the riverfront in Jersey City and Hoboken.
State incentives, which are not new, are largely borne from a "keep up with the Joneses attitude and their use goes up and down" depending on market forces, said Gene DePrez, a partner at Fluora Daniels Consulting, an international firm based in Morristown that specializes in corporate location issues. The trend is away from the pure cash awards given to companies during the mid-80's building boom, he said.
New Jersey's program "is an extraordinarily conservative incentive," said Dean Hughes. "The state is getting some revenue while not reducing existing tax revenue. And it is creating jobs that might not be there otherwise."
Mr. Steinberg of the Commerce Department added: "The key is that the program is revenue neutral." It does not cut into other state programs or cause taxes to rise, he added.
For companies, such incentives, while not the driving force behind their decision to relocate, could be "the tie- breaker," said Mr. DePrez. He said the availability and cost of labor and operating costs remain priorities.
"No one incentive is a panacea," added Mr. Steinberg. It is, he said, "another tool in the state's economic development arsenal" to help it capture its share of future businesses and jobs.

HEADLINE: UConn, Capitalizing on Salt Water Connections

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE studies and projects underway at the University of Connecticut's campus at Avery Point in Groton are as varied as the marine life in Long Island Sound: aquaculture, marine sciences and research partnerships with marine businesses. And Avery Point's maritime heritage is getting richer as construction of a new marine sciences center begins.
"Part of my vision is seeing these entities come together in a more coherent way, and that's happening," said David Madacsi, the interim director at Avery Point. "The campus is clearly developing a niche strongly associated with its marine location." 
 UConn is spending $51.8 million on construction at Avery Point to enable the university to compete with other research institutions for financial support and to attract scientists, students and partners in industry. Construction is expected to begin in June on a new Marine Sciences Research Laboratory; a building to house Project Oceanology, a marine science program primarily for high school and middle school students, and a central utility plant. Construction of a library is scheduled to start in the year 2000, Mr. Madacsi said. These plans are included in UConn 2000, the 10-year program to improve the university's infrastructure and buildings.
The Avery Point campus, situated on a 73-acre finger of land jutting into Long Island Sound, has been associated with the study of coastal waters since its founding in 1967. As southeastern Connecticut's economy shifted away from dependence on military construction contracts, the university and the state agreed to develop a research and technology center that could promote maritime industries, create jobs and train students -- undergraduate majors in coastal studies are being set up -- for the job market. The Marine Sciences and Technology Center was established in 1994.
One of the aquaculture projects at the center, conducted in collaboration with the National Marine Fisheries Service Laboratory in Milford, involves bay scallops, currently in limited production in the United States. Research has focused on identifying obstacles to commercial production in Connecticut, improving cultivation methods and restoring scallop populations in Long Island Sound.
More than 130,000 seed scallops have been provided to Stonington, Waterford and East Lyme to help bolster wild stocks. And 15,000 seed scallops were grown in Clinton Harbor, according to the university. If a commercial scallop industry were developed, jobs would be available in cultivation and supporting businesses like net and gear manufacturing.
In the Coastal Environmental Laboratory at the center, Richard Jadamec and Carol Anderson, co-directors of the laboratory, are working under contract with Marine Research Associates in North Stonington to identify the properties of oils that cause them to float or sink. The information is useful in finding and cleaning up oil spills.
Beakers of water were lined up in a recent visit to the lab. In some containers, a blanket of black goo lay on top of the water. In others, it floated beneath the surface or sank in a ball to the bottom.
Mr. Jadamec, a research assistant, and Ms. Anderson, a chemistry teacher, watch the movements of these residual oils in order to gain a better understanding of oil spills.
Shifting relationships between the properties of oil and water -- for instance, changes in surface tension or density -- affect oils in different ways, Mr. Jadamec said. "Turbulence is a factor, as well as the changes oil undergoes when exposed to the environment," he explained.
Mr. Jadamec measures the buoyancy of a ball of oil by timing its rise between two points in a glass cylinder. He also analyzes the effects of weather, evaporation and bacteria on the components of a given type of oil. Knowledge of its makeup is necessary in identifying the origin of a spill, a process called fingerprinting.
"If we can understand the behavior of oil, we may find a better way of doing cleanups," Mr. Jadamec said.
UConn belongs to a consortium of contractors in the United States, led by Ship Analytics International Inc. of North Stonington, that established a training center in Egypt for oil spill management and prevention.
Ship Analytics, a developer of maritime simulation and training, received a $21 million contract for the project from the Arab Academy for Science and Technology in Alexandria, Egypt. Merchant marine and environmental engineers from Egypt, Africa and the Middle East train on simulators at the academy.
Mr. Jadamec, who went to Egypt to help the academy develop oil fingerprinting techniques, said collaborating in research and sharing resources benefits the university and its corporate partners alike.
"These strong ties offer students exposure to problem situations in industry so they learn what the industrial environment is about," he said.
Building on Avery Point's relationship with the sea, two new undergraduate degrees in coastal studies, were recently approved by UConn's board of trustees. If approved by the State Department of Higher Education, the bachelor's degree programs would be the first offered at the Avery Point campus. Students would earn a B.A. or B.S. degree in the department of marine sciences. Currently, students transfer to the main UConn campus at Storrs to complete requirements for graduation.
Providing impetus for a coastal studies major, in addition to economic changes in southeastern Connecticut, is the fact that half the population of the United States lives within a hundred miles of its coasts. The concentration of people in coastal areas is expected to increase to 60 percent within the next 15 years, Mr. Madacsi said.
The coastal studies curriculum was developed after surveying businesses and obtaining the admissions criteria for a dozen graduate schools. Marine businesses were asked what skills and training they look for in employees, said the program's coordinator, James Kremer. Courses include liberal arts and marine and social sciences. Students would work with actual case studies of coastal issues and policy problems, participate in field research and gain experience through internships.
Graduates with a degree in coastal studies would be prepared for careers or graduate study in coastal environmental policy and management, regulation, education, science, law or business. "No matter what direction students go in, there are going to be implications of living in a coastal zone," Mr. Kremer said. A professor of marine sciences, Mr. Kremer arrived at UConn a year and a half ago from the University of Southern California, where he was a biology professor and coordinator of an undergraduate science curriculum on Santa Catalina Island.
Classes in the coastal studies major are scheduled to begin in the fall, said Mr. Kremer, who expects the program to accommodate 20 to 40 majors a year over the next five years. Although expansion would require addition of new teachers and equipment, Mr. Kremer said, he is optimistic that the university would support if the program were attractive to students. Noting that a large number of high school graduates in Connecticut attend college out of state, Mr. Kremer said, "We need to entice them to stay here."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Andrew Farkas and ESG;
A New Lead Player Who Is Changing the Game

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AGGRESSIVELY raising money and buying financially shaky housing properties across the country during the early 1990's, Andrew L. Farkas quickly built Insignia Financial Group into the nation's largest manager of residential real estate.
With the purchase of the Edward S. Gordon Company last year, Mr. Farkas, who is chairman, president and chief executive of Insignia, signaled that he wanted to increase the company's presence on the commercial side as well, with the goal of becoming a national company in that segment of the business. 
 But competitors say buying commercial real estate companies in a strong market will be a lot more difficult than taking over distressed housing developments that lenders were happy to part with. And, they say, Mr. Farkas may not appreciate how difficult it may be to knit disparate corporate cultures into a seamless organization.
Nevertheless, the 36-year-old Mr. Farkas is currently a hot young man in a field that has seen more dreams dashed than fulfilled in recent years. Revenues at Insignia swelled from a little over $18 million in 1991 to $125 million in 1995, the most recent year for which figures are available. He is the owner of about 27 percent percent of Insignia's stock, a share worth $175 million, after being $5 million in debt at the beginning of the decade.
Despite the company's rapid growth and the recovery of real estate values across the country, he said, there are still opportunities out there. "I loved buying distressed properties because the values were terrific, but the last distressed deal we did was in early 1993," he said in a temporary office on the 34th floor of 375 Park Avenue. He is occuping the space until all of Insignia's New York holdings can be consolidated in one location.
The company's current strategy, he said, is to create additional value by operating real estate better than previous managers. "If we buy a property for X and it has a revenue stream of 0.2 X, we think we can get it to .4 X or .5 X," Mr. Farkas said.
One reason the bulk of Insignia's operations are in Greenville, S.C., is to keep a low cost base for a business that has traditionally had thin margins. "Historically speaking, management was a loss leader in commercial real estate," he said. "You did management to get the leasing deals. But we have figured out a way to make money in management."
The company manages over 300,000 residential units, which include condominiums and cooperatives as well as rental apartments.
Although he affects a folksy, country manner, responding "Yes, sir," and "Yes, ma'am" to questions, he is a New Yorker born and bred, a son of Robin L. Farkas, the former chairman of Alexander's, the department store chain that filed for bankruptcy in May 1992.
He acknowledges that having his name helped his early career as a real estate tax shelter syndicator, because many of the investors he was wooing were his father's friends who would return calls. The family relationship also provided an early connection with the Gordon company.
"Robin Farkas was one of a number of senior people who were very kind to me when I was young," Mr. Gordon recalled. "So, one day he called me and said his son was at Harvard and wanted to do his thesis on commercial real estate. He asked if I would allow him access to the dossier of market information we had collected and the people who put it together. We met and I found that he was a super kid with a tremendous energy level and a thirst to discover what the world was all about."
The paper, entitled "An Econometric Model for Prime Commercial Office Space in Manhattan," was duly delivered to the Harvard College Economics Department, where it was given a rating of magna honors, the second highest possible grade.
After graduation, Mr. Farkas, who said his initial application was rejected by Harvard Business School, went to work on Wall Street, starting at Salomon Brothers.
Both men stayed in touch, with Mr. Farkas avoiding Mr. Gordon's attempts to hire him and Mr. Gordon declining to invest in the various real estate deals Mr. Farkas was organizing.
MR. GORDON said he was content to keep his company private, but acknowledged that a public company's access to capital gave it a powerful engine for growth. When he and Stephen B. Siegel, ESG's president, decided it was time to expand the company out of the New York metropolitan area, they looked for ways to accomplish the task.
"I ended up calling Andrew," said Mr. Gordon. "He was in South Carolina when I called him and said I had an idea for ESG that I'd like to talk to him about. His response was to ask me what I was doing for lunch tomorrow."
The $74 million deal was done quickly and the Gordon empire, the fourth largest commercial real estate operation in the country, was folded into Insignia's commercial group, which now manages 110 million square feet of property nationally.
Mr. Siegel, who was named to manage all of Insignia's commercial properties, said the first months after the takeover were spent consolidating operations spread out across the country. But now, he said, he's on the hunt.
"We will never be a company with offices in 70 or 80 cities," he said. "It will probably never be more than a dozen major markets." He said acquisitions in the Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington areas were high on the list, followed by Florida and Boston.
Mr. Siegel said Insignia officials had decided that acquiring existing full service firms was preferable to trying to send people out from New York to start up cold in new markets. He said that since the established national firms, such as Cushman & Wakefield and CB Commercial, were not for sale, Insignia would have to seek out individual companies prominent in local markets.
But veterans of national expansions say they are neither easy or cheap. "We did it, but it took 15 years and we had our successes and failures," said Arthur J. Mirante, president and chief executive of Cushman & Wakefield.
"Part of the management challenge is to take different types of companies and blend them into a common platform," Mr. Mirante said. "The client does not want one type of research report in Chicago and another one in New York."
Because the real estate market has recovered from its lows, Insignia will have to pay "top dollar" for acquisitions, Mr. Mirante said, which could put pressure on earnings.
"I clapped when Insignia acquired Gordon," said Steven A. Swerdlow, executive vice president of New York area operations for CB Commercial. "The reason is that Steve Siegel is going to be taking his eye off the ball in the best market in the country -- New York."
He said CB Commercial had expanded from its original base of the West Coast by opening what he termed "home grown" offices in nearly 80 cities.
Mr. Swerdlow said one problem with acquiring local companies is that they are often dominated by a small number of people who may lose their drive after receiving a large payment for their business.
"In many cases it's an exit strategy," he said. He said Gordon was widely reported to be negotiating with Rostenberg-Doern, a commercial brokerage active in Westchester County and in Fairfield County, Conn. "You have two individuals in their late 50's or early 60's," he said. "What happens if they are acquired?"
John Rostenberg. one of the principals of the company, declined to comment on talks, if any, with Gordon. But he said "we would certainly not go into a venture and then walk out the door -- that's not why you do it."
Mr. Siegel said: "We don't do deals with people we don't have pre-existing relationships with. In addition, there are ways to structure things so that payment is linked to performance for three to five years, so there is time to integrate cultures."
Richard Podos, co-manager of the New York office of Equis Corporation, which specializes in tenant representation, said "the problem with acquiring service businesses is that the assets go home at night.".
The top Gordon officials say they have fit easily into the Insignia organization, despite Mr. Farkas's youth and hard-driving ways. "Andrew has dealt with me in an elegant way," said Mr. Gordon. "He gives me respect, but I recognize that he has the ultimate decision-making power."
Mr. Farkas, who lives in New York with his wife, Pamela, and two young daughters, admits to being computer oriented, and his ways are rubbing off on executives who tried to avoid the onrush of technology.
"I'm a convert to E-mail," said Mr. Siegel, who admitted that he seldom confronted a computer in the past without a technical assistant at his side. "Andrew uses it a lot -- he literally speaks to you through the computer," he said. "I took a laptop with me on my last trip and used to to communicate with people on the East Coast who were hard to reach because of the time zones."
"We have a complete internal E-mail system for all 9,200 people in the company," Mr. Farkas said. "E-mail is going to be as important to business as the telephone."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Always at the Crossroads

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
RICARDO KHAN remembers it well, after a fashion and after perhaps 18 years.
It was a time of incubation for the Crossroads Theater Company, then on the second floor of a former sewing factory. He was working the box office. He was answering the telephones. He was directing. He was acting. Between productions, he was appearing on the unemployment line. 
 One day a woman called. "You know, I'm white," she said. "Is it O.K. for me to buy a ticket?" The rest is fuzzy. "It's O.K., it's O.K.: we have a special section roped off in the back, just for whites," Mr. Khan may have said, or wished he had.
"Her question floored me," Mr. Khan said, now with total recall. "The reason we came into existence was to bring folks together. And here was a white person doing the same self-editing things that black people do, revealing the compromises we make within ourselves before we bring our whole being to someone else."
Delivering the message that Crossroads isn't "just a black theater," but a theater for everybody, has been an all-consuming mission for Mr. Khan, 45, founding member, artistic director and resident visionary, through almost two decades of standoffs on the race card.
"In the early 80's, liberal was not a bad word," he said. "The thought of people coming together in the name of peace was not considered corny. Today, the sound bites say, 'Blacks for blacks, whites for whites,' so we must ask, 'Is there a common ground?' and 'Is it a safe ground?' The world is more polarized than it was on the day the woman asked me that question."
And variations of a simplistic black-versus-white dichotomy go on. "Just as you don't have to be Jewish to enjoy Levy's rye bread, you don't have to be black to appreciate and be moved by 'Fear Itself,' " one reviewer wrote about Eugene Lee's play, produced at Crossroads last year.
If Mr. Khan's ideal of a cosmic rainbow -- a sublime contradiction of celebrating diversity while envisioning oneness -- is still reduced to black-and-white by some theatergoers and reviewers, he responds with resignation, forgiveness, patience and enlightenment. "These are honest reactions, real and welcome," he says. "We have much more to learn about how we're thinking than we think."
Mr. Khan would rather have the questions asked -- "it's just distressing that they are asked," he admits -- and the assumptions expressed "than for people to think this place is only for us."
IN 1978, two recent graduates of the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University here had a dream, and a plan of action. Armed with master's degrees in acting and directing, Mr. Khan and L. Kenneth Richardson assailed the theater establishment that had made patronizing offerings to black actors: roles as drug dealers and deadbeats, pimps and wife-beaters, with an occasional nod to "some of my best friends are . . ." tokenism.
In his earliest years, Ricardo Mohamed Khan, the oldest of five children born to Dr. Mustapha Mohamed Khan, a native of Trinidad, and Jacqueline Driver, lived in Washington. The family moved to a farm in Norristown, Pa., during Dr. Khan's medical internships, then to Philadelphia (his mother's birthplace) and Camden before settling in Cherry Hill.
Mr. Khan, then known as Rick, enrolled in Rutgers University in 1969. "I stayed for graduate school," he said. "I stayed for graduation. And I stayed for Crossroads."
Mr. Khan and Mr. Richardson founded Crossroads with a $50,000 grant under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, a Federal job-creation program of the 1970's. Necessary sponsorship came from the George Street Playhouse, then under the artistic direction of Eric Krebs.
"To a certain degree, forming Crossroads was about changing the world," Mr. Khan said. "But it was really, really about wanting to be a part of a world -- not with us on the side, but a world that turns to glorify the human spirit. That's what we were about then, and that's what we're about now."
Within a decade of its formation, Crossroads won an assured place on the regional-theater map. Joseph Papp, founder of the New York Shakespeare Festival singled it out as one of his two favored theaters. (The other was the Royal Court in London.) In quick succession, two plays by George C. Wolfe, a Crossroads discovery who in 1993 became Mr. Papp's successor, moved from New Brunswick to Off Broadway: "The Colored Museum," a trail-blazing satire of black stereotypes, and "Spunk," an adaptation of three stories by Zora Neale Hurston.
And by 1992, Crossroads itself had moved from its rickety birthplace on Memorial Parkway to a $4 million showplace, the tony centerpiece of New Brunswick's cultural complex on Livingston Avenue that includes George Street and the State Theater. So significant has Crossroads become as a living symbol of emerged black theater that Bill Cosby, who donated a week of one-man shows to the new space when it opened, refused to answer the queries of a New York reporter who had never heard of it.
NOW that Crossroads is at the center of a publicity blitz touched off by the recent war of words between the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright August Wilson and Robert Brustein, founding director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and critic for The New Republic, it is no longer likely that the theater is unheard of by representatives of New York's news media or cultural elite. (Related article, Arts & Leisure, page 5.)
And Mr. Khan is, yet again, in the midst of the sort of reductive black-versus-white debate that it is his eternal struggle to avoid. He compares the self-conscious, "sanitized" dispute between Mr. Brustein (an advocate of all-inclusive art transcending race) and Mr. Wilson (a champion of separatist black theater), to the credos (nonviolent versus militant) that separated heroes (the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X) who are cut short of conciliation in the 1960's. That was a bitterly ironic message of "The Meeting," the Crossroads production at the time of the Wilson-Brustein debate last month at Town Hall in Manhattan.
The meeting between Mr. Brustein and Mr. Wilson was sponsored by American Theater magazine, published by the Theater Communications Group, an association of countrywide nonprofit theaters -- of which Mr. Khan is the president.
Mr. Khan can't help wondering why the event was so uneventful. "It's the American way that everybody has to compete, take a side, win -- as if both couldn't be right," he said. "With Martin and Malcolm, we had to pick our hero. Thirty years later at Town Hall, we had to take a side."
He is objective about heroes and passionate about taking no sides, about "celebrating all of who we are." Mr. Khan was speaking out for multiculturalism before a belief turned into a handy buzzword. He was championing diversity before it became politically expedient on grant applications.
"Theaters should produce what they want to produce," he said. "But I get offended if they go out and say, 'Let's put on a black play.' You should do it because your heart is in it, not because you should do it, but because you must."
When Mr. Wilson, pronouncing himself "a race man," railed against the lack of financial support for the black theaters last June in the keynote address of the National Conference of the Theater Communications Group at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, he mentioned that out of 66 member theaters of the League of Resident Theaters, only one was black.
"Crossroads is one of many non-mainstream organizations around the country," Mr. Khan said. "We cannot define ourselves in such a limiting way, like, 'I'm the only black in this room.'
"And I don't know what 'race man' means. I am very aware of my race when I want to be and when I don't want to be. It boosts me at times. It nags me at other times."
In discussing his position as the head of Theater Communications Group, Mr. Khan saidpaused to remember the group's conference at Rutgers in the early 1980's. "Crossroads was just two or three years old," he said, "and Lee and I wanted to go and belong to something beyond race. But we couldn't afford it."
When he took over, he added: "I needed to be the president, not the black president. But there was a need to treat me as the black president. The real issue that divides people is class, not race.
"I wanted to get into something I could take home with me and use. We need to talk about collaboration, what we can do to make theater central to American society, and about being respected for who we are. We're not in a melting pot of dissolving ingredients. I prefer the metaphor of a tossed salad, and I'm concerned about the role imagination and creativity play in the making of society.
"We have to redefine the African-American experience in more global terms, who we are. Yes, we're black. Yes, we're American. Yes, we're in the world -- on a meeting ground. Race relations have changed drastically. But we're still at a crossroads, and we still pivot on the same axis."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ricardo Khan working on a script with Naima Imani Welcher, an intern actress, at the Crossroads Theater Company. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1249 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUND;
A Scorecard Doesn't Help In the Money-Fund Game

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
WHEN Strong Capital Management bailed out three of its money market funds early this month, investors had every right to be surprised.
The most recent report on holdings by two of the funds was dated last Aug. 31, five months before the bailout. The shareholder report for the third fund was dated Oct. 31. 
 And that highlights a weakness in fund disclosure. By the time investors in any fund receive its twice-a-year reports on portfolio holdings, the information may be hopelessly out of date. It is especially true with money market funds, whose holdings have average maturities of no more than 90 days.
"I don't think disclosure on any fund is good enough," said Louis P. Stanasolovich, president of Legend Financial Advisors Inc. in Pittsburgh. But, he added, "twice yearly is ridiculous." Furthermore, fund companies now have 60 days to get those reports to regulators and shareholders; Mr. Stanasolovich advocates a 15-day requirement.
Although the reports of all three Strong funds listed some holdings in Mercury Finance -- the auto lender that defaulted on its debt and led to the bailout -- those reports noted that all such securities were set to mature before the end of January, when Mercury's debt became virtually worthless. Mercury Finance defaulted on $17 million in short-term loans on Jan. 31 after the disclosure of serious accounting irregularities.
But the Strong funds acquired more debt from Mercury Finance after the reports' dates, and Strong confirmed early this month that it bought back commercial paper from the three funds to avoid investor losses. The affected funds were the top-yielding Strong Heritage Money fund, the Strong Institutional Money Market fund and the Strong Money Market fund.
Shareholders in many other money market funds still don't know whether their funds held similar securities. At the time of the Mercury default, half of the 10 top-yielding money market funds tracked by IBC Money Fund Report on Feb. 11 had not provided shareholders with a new report since June 1996. Updated reports for these funds, with information through December, are due by the end of this month. By telephone, all the top 10 funds besides Strong denied holding Mercury Finance paper.
In recent years, attempts to provide more timely disclosure have gone nowhere. "So far, the industry has won every battle with the S.E.C. on this issue," said Sanford Bragg, head of the managed-funds ratings group at the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In July 1995, the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed that money market funds provide portfolio information electronically each quarter. The commission was concerned after a number of money market funds got into trouble in 1994 because of the bankruptcy of Orange County, California, and the rapid increases in interest rates that undermined some complex financial instruments known as derivatives.
The S.E.C. proposal met with a withering attack from the Investment Company Institute, a fund trade group in Washington. The I.C.I. argued that compliance would be costly and burdensome. The systems and procedures for preparing the data "are far more significant than the commission seems to have anticipated and outweigh any useful purpose," the group wrote. As an alternative, it proposed that more general information be provided monthly to regulators and to the public, and that in a crisis, the S.E.C. could request more information.
Since then, the S.E.C.'s proposal has gathered dust. "We got substantial negative comment," said Barry Barbash, director of the agency's division of investment management. "We haven't found a disclosure format yet that meets our needs and that of investors." He noted that the commission has a legal obligation to take costs into account in its rulemaking.
Quarterly updates would not have prevented the Strong problem, industry officials and regulators say. "If information had been provided to us on a quarterly basis," Mr. Barbash said, "would we have been in a better position to see the problem with Mercury Finance? I don't think so."
Two ratings agencies -- Thomson Bankwatch and the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company -- had given Mercury Finance's paper a top-tier rating. But the two leading agencies, S.& P. and Moody's, had awarded the paper lower ratings -- marks not good enough for money market fund investments. "If someone who's in the business of rating funds can't figure out there's a problem, how are you and I going to figure it out based on information that's months old?" asked Paul S. Stevens, senior vice president and general counsel of the I.C.I.
A spokeswoman for Strong, Jody R. Lowe, agreed. "Disclosure would not have prevented what happened with Mercury," she said.
Given the rapid turnover in money market portfolios, nothing short of daily disclosure would provide a truly accurate picture. But that would be costly and would force funds to reveal proprietary trading strategies to competitors, Ms. Lowe said.
Concerns about strategy seem overblown to some. "Money market instruments are relatively generic," said Mr. Bragg of S.& P. "There is only a certain range of things you can do running a money market fund."
Even with quarterly or daily portfolio information, investors might not be able to act on market news before their funds suffered, the regulators argue. "It is unclear to me whether access to immediate information would be of assistance," said Robert E. Plaze, associate director of the division of investment management at the S.E.C. "It wouldn't allow you to avoid the problem."
Mr. Barbash said his agency's mission is not to eliminate risk in money market funds. "We're not bank regulators," he said. "Our mandate is investor protection, and therefore our efforts would be geared toward whether investors were misled."
Perhaps the most compelling argument for better disclosure is that it would help investors do a better job of picking funds. According to Mr. Stanasolovich, monthly reports would give him a better idea of which funds were stretching for yield and, therefore, taking more risk. "It's not that big a burden," he said, "and certainly these organizations can afford that."
In fact, more than 200 money funds already provide weekly data to S.& P. so they can be rated. "We require weekly portfolio holdings to be provided because money market portfolios turn over quite frequently," Mr. Bragg noted. "The information is all there."
Funds now report electronically to the S.E.C., too. The information could even be made available to investors on the World Wide Web site for Edgar, the S.E.C.'s electronic data gathering, analysis and retrieval system (http://www.sec.gov). Peter Crane, managing editor of IBC Money Fund Report in Ashland, Mass., said that with Edgar, "The time may be ripe for quarterly or monthly reporting."
More frequent disclosure might also discourage some funds from investing in risky securities altogether. "I think it would cause some problems to be addressed before the report was ever published," Mr. Stanasolovich said.
For now, investors should realize that even if portfolio information seems dated, money market fund managers tend to roll over their money with an issuer once they have done the research to buy one of its securities. That was true of Strong and the Mercury Finance paper, Ms. Lowe said.
On better disclosure, the fund industry will probably "drag its feet," Mr. Stanasolovich predicted, but "we will see quarterly reporting."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "High Yield, but at What Price?"
Money market funds often waive at least some of their expenses to bolster their yields. Chart list the the 10 highest-yielding funds for the week ended Feb. 11, when the average yield for general-purpose funds was 4.86 percent. All 10 leaders waived some expenses.
Funds can also achieve higher yields by buying riskier securities. If you are curious about the holdings of these top-yielding funds, don't run to their twice-a-year reports for answers. Money funds hold securities with very short maturities, so the reports may be hopelessly out of date. (Source: IBC's Money Fund Report)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Raw Sewage, Great Timing: An Election Year Tale

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
It was a campaign strategist's dream.
Standing on a bluff, overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, as a dozen television cameras recorded every word, Governor Whitman issued a stern warning to New York: Don't even think about dumping 560 million gallons of raw sewage into New York Harbor, an act, she argued, that would threaten New Jersey's shellfish beds and beaches. 
 By the end of the day, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, both Republicans, had backed down. They promised there would be no sewage dumping this year, and no dumping next year without a thorough environmental review.
For Governor Whitman, the prospect of raw sewage flowing south handed her a great opportunity during a re-election year. She was able to appear on the television news Tuesday night not only as a strong, commanding leader on behalf of her state, but also as a fearless environmental crusader at a time when she badly needs to bolster her record on the environment.
The environment ranks particularly high among issues that New Jersey voters care about. The state's economy has been long dominated by petroleum refining and chemical manufacturing companies that operate close to densely populated residential areas and waterways. There are more Superfund toxic-waste sites in New Jersey than in any other state.
Until recently, Mrs. Whitman has not been getting high marks from environmental groups.
In fact, this time last year environmental groups barraged her with criticism. Among other things, they strongly objected to deep budget cuts at the State Department of Environmental Protection and 1,500 pages of proposed changes in water regulations that would have allowed more toxic substances to be dumped into the state's waterways.
They held regular rallies, news conferences, and even paid for a radio advertising campaign that accused her of rolling back the state's environmental-protection measures.
At the time, Democrats viewed Mrs. Whitman's stance on the environment as one of the few areas, where the popular tax-cutting Governor could be vulnerable in this year's election. And while publicly defending her approach to the environment, Mrs. Whitman's top aides were privately expressing concern that the criticism would resonate with voters.
Beginning late last year, the administration set out to create a much different perception among voters about the Whitman administration's environmental record. Bob Friant, a top aide to the Governor's chief of staff, Harriet Derman, was dispatched to the environmental protection department to help improve its image.
Quickly, things began to change.
Governor Whitman announced that the state would scrap its 1,500 pages of proposed new water rules and start over. This time, Mrs. Whitman promised, both environmentalists and business groups would be at the table, and they would reach agreement on the major issues before new regulations would be published.
Then, after steadily slashing the environmental agency's budget over the last three years, Governor Whitman last month proposed a slight increase.
She also took every opportunity possible in her State of the State address to the Legislature last month to point out her record on the environment, which even her opponents acknowledge is quite good when it comes to preserving open space.
And then, came the raw-sewage plan, giving her a picture-perfect opportunity to dramatize her commitment to keep New Jersey's beaches, and shellfish beds clean after cutting funds only a year ago to help clean up the shore. Lawmakers eventually restored the program.
The environmental lobbyists embrace Mrs. Whitman as a new-found ally, but they say that her new stance does not make amends for her past policies, and record.
"She certainly has taken more pro-environmental positions in the last three months than she has in the last three years," said David Pringle, campaign director for the New Jersey Environmental Federation, an umbrella group for dozens of state environmental groups. "But that in no way makes up for all of the anti-environment positions of the last three years."
Mr. Pringle praised Governor Whitman for strongly opposing New York City's plan to dump the raw sewage, but he noted that New Jersey continues to dump a significant amount of raw sewage into the state's waterways.
New York City's plan would have dumped 140 million gallons of raw sewage into the harbor a day, over four days, totaling 560 million gallons. Mr. Pringle said the aging sewer systems in the northern part of the state, following a heavy downpour, can dump up to 140 million gallons of raw sewage a day that eventually finds its way into the ocean.
"It is a easy to tell New York what to do or what not to do, " Mr. Pringle said. "It is a lot tougher to get New Jersey's house in order. When all the headlines go away, we are still going to have 85 percent of our waters un swimmable, and unfishable, in violation of the Federal Clean Water Act."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
New Round In Fight Over Mortgage Fee

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

 BODY:
A VIRGINIA case that had mortgage borrowers and consumer advocates celebrating only a few weeks ago was appealed last week, with the two banks accused of illegal practices asking that the suit be dismissed.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, is expected to decide within weeks whether to accept the case. If it does, it will take on a controversial question: Are banks breaking the law by paying certain fees to the independent mortgage brokers that refer loans to them? 
 At issue are the fees commonly paid by banks when a broker sends them a mortgage loan for a higher-than-normal interest rate. A bank might pay a broker the special fee, called a yield spread premium, if the broker writes a home loan at 9 percent that could have been written at a lower rate. Banks say this is an accepted way to compensate brokers that generate loans for them. And they say it can reduce a home buyer's closing costs by shifting part of the broker's fee to the bank.
Borrowers who have sued call such payments kickbacks that result in higher interest payments. The plaintiffs argue that the payments are outlawed by the Federal Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act.
Last month, Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr., of the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, sent shock waves through the mortgage industry by saying -- in a ruling that denied the banks' motion to dismiss the suit -- that the payments were prohibited by law. Although it was only an early ruling in the case, the statement was surprisingly definitive.
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America filed a brief on the side of the two banks, Saxon Mortgage Inc. and the Crestar Mortgage Corporation. Those banks, both based in Richmond, won a stay of all further action in the suit while they sought an appeal of Judge Bryan's refusal to dismiss.
In granting the stay, Judge Bryan said he had not made a final decision in the case and that his earlier ruling meant only that the "plaintiff has stated a sufficient claim" that the payments were illegal.
Crestar's lawyer, Leonard Bernstein, said Judge Bryan was backtracking. But Daniel A. Ragland, who represents the two couples suing the banks, said: "He's not changing his mind here. He is still saying that under the facts as alleged it is illegal."
Homeowners began suing in recent years as mortgage brokers became more prevalent. The early suits were settled without the lenders admitting wrongdoing. The Ford Consumer Finance Company, a subsidiary of the auto maker, agreed to pay $20 million in a settlement last August.
In cases that proceeded, different judges produced different outcomes. Three weeks after Judge Bryan criticized fees in the Virginia case, a Federal district judge in Alabama ruled that a yield spread premium was "permissible as a matter of law."
More than a dozen lawsuits dealing with the issue have been filed in Federal courts across the country, Crestar argues in seeking an appeal. "No court of appeals has yet spoken on the legal questions raised in these cases," the bank said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Latin Markets Again Run With the Bulls

BYLINE: By DAN COLARUSSO 

 BODY:
ANYONE who bought Latin American stock and bond funds a year ago can claim bragging rights at cocktail parties. The gains in both categories have been handsome, exceeding 40 percent in some cases.
But a not-so-subtle shift has taken place early this year. After a two-year rally, bonds have been replaced by stocks as the winning investment in the region. 
 After all, stocks are supposed to be the riskier, more rewarding investment in good times. And though the bonds have behaved much like stocks in recent years, money managers and financial analysts expect Latin American equities to now have their day in the sun.
Continued political changes and resurgent local economies created the two-year bull market for bonds and set the stage for this stock rally. Enthusiasm for the stock markets has returned, though not to the frothy levels of 1993 before the Mexican peso crisis, says Juan Carlos Garcia, the head of equity research at Santander Investments in New York.
To be sure, political risk remains apparent in Ecuador, Peru, Colombia and even Mexico. A political meltdown could occur elsewhere as well. Still, the stability of the governments and their economic policies after the devaluation of the peso in late 1994 has reassured investors.
Money managers and equity analysts see relatively little risk in the region, barring volatility in the United States -- namely, a sharp increase in interest rates or a plunge by the stock market.
"The current recovery in equity prices is driven by the improvement in risk perception," said Walter Molano, an SBC Warburg economist.
The performance of the regional stock markets was solid last year, and mutual funds, stocked with blue-chip shares like Telebras, Telefonos de Mexico and Electrobras, performed well. Morgan Stanley's Latin American retail and institutional portfolios were the pace-setters, with gains of more than 46 percent for the 12 months ended on Feb. 14.
The pace has picked up this year. Every Latin American stock fund tracked by Morningstar had a gain of more than 10 percent for the first six weeks of the year. The leader, Merrill Lynch Latin America, exceeded 17 percent.
Still, the markets have room to run. While the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in this country is trading at about 22 times earnings, Brazilian stocks have a p/e ratio of 12.4, Mexican stocks 19.5 and Argentine stocks 24.5, according to State Street Global Advisors, money managers.
Mr. Garcia of Santander cites overall regional strength as a main reason for optimism. "For the first time in Latin America, growth is at the same levels in all of the big countries," he said. The gross domestic products of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Mexico are growing at 3.5 percent to 5 percent, he said.
More capital in the area and low valuations in most stock sectors will fuel equity growth, he said. Consumer products and construction sectors, dependent on domestic spending, look more attractive to him than defensive stocks like utilities.
Other fund managers agree. "In all of the Latin economies, we've seen strength in the core emerging-markets plays, such as telecom and infrastructure, and the next stage in that progression is for consumers to start spending," said Robert Furdak, manager of the State Street Global Advisors Emerging Markets fund.
THE last couple of years, though, belonged to the region's bond markets. Fidelity New Markets Income returned 42 percent for the 12 months ended Feb. 14, and Bear Stearns Emerging Markets Debt gained 37 percent.
The bargains found in Latin American debt in early 1995 no longer exist, but investors seeking a high yield will still find better value in the region than in the United States junk-bond market, said David Reiss, an emerging-markets fixed-income portfolio manager at Bankers Trust Global Investment Management.
Latin debt captured the imagination of investors in 1995, when, despite a hangover from the peso crisis, it rose along with the United States Treasury market.
Last year, Argentina's commitment to its currency, Brazil's move to keep President Fernando Cardoso in office and the successful international bailout of Mexico made the bonds perform like "equities in drag," said Ali Naqvi, the head of emerging-markets fixed-income research at Citibank Global Asset Management.
The ride shows no sign of ending. Ed Vaimberg, manager of the Bear Stearns Emerging Markets Debt Portfolio, predicts 20 percent gains this year.
