HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH;
Filling Gap Left by Caldor

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Hailed in July 1995 as a sign of the resurgence of Flatbush Avenue, the Caldor department store at the corner of Tilden Avenue may again be a bellwether.
Following the Feb. 11 announcement by the Caldor Corporation that it would close the store in May because of poor performance, owners, managers and workers at a half-dozen nearby businesses were already reporting mediocre sales last week. And they were already expressing fears that unless a new tenant is found quickly to fill the cavernous space, the closing of the Caldor could bring stagnation to an area that was taking its first steps toward economic revitalization. 
 "In '94, '95 and '96, it's been stable, but not growing very quickly," said Joseph Gindi, who has owned the Flatbush Houseland store across the street from the Caldor site for the last 25 years, back when a Macy's branch was there. "We make a living. Replacing it would be better. We need a big department store to bring people to the area."
The loss of the Caldor also points out the importance of finding a developer for the nearby Loew's Kings movie palace, which was once the economic driving force of the avenue but defaulted on taxes and was taken over by the city in 1978 and closed.
Steven R. Schubert, the executive director of the Flatbush Development Corporation, and some local merchants argued that Caldor struggled because it failed to tailor itself to the needs and tastes of the area's Caribbean immigrants.
The troubled nationwide department store chain, based in Norwalk, Conn., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September 1995 and is closing three other poorly performing stores, including one on Fordham Road in the Bronx. More than 300 employees at the Flatbush branch will lose their jobs.
The merchants and Mr. Schubert predicted that fitting several smaller stores or an upscale Caribbean restaurant into the Caldor site may be more successful.
"The closing appears like a setback on the surface, but we'd like to see it as an opportunity," Mr. Schubert said. "We'd like to see it combined with the Loew's Kings development."
Joyce Baumgarten, a spokeswoman for Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of the site, said the store would be marketed to other large retailers. DAVID ROHDE

HEADLINE: COPING;
Public Schools? But of Course.

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THERE is a public school in Brooklyn where first-graders enter a science classroom that resembles a rain forest, and there is a public school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan where fifth-graders isolate DNA. A third public school, supposedly the best in the city, is in East Harlem and most of its students are poor.
Are these schools "flowers growing out of the cracks in the pavement," as one administrator pessimistically suggested, or are they, as Clara Hemphill declares, proof of progress and signs of hope for the future of the city? 
 "People think that the rich go to good private schools and the poor go to bad public schools, and that's simply not true," said Ms. Hemphill, a 43-year-old former journalist with two children approaching school age. "The best public schools in the city are the best schools, period. The rewards of public education are not only social -- you learn to live with all kinds of people -- they are also academic. Better teachers, better programs, and you sit next to a kid who makes geography and history real."
This is not exactly conventional wisdom, so Ms. Hemphill is constructing her case neighborhood by neighborhood. Operating out of a tiny office at the century-old Public Education Association on West 32d Street, she is compiling a book of profiles of the 100 top public elementary schools (out of 676) in the city. It is part consumer guide, part urban plan. Without public schools, she maintains, the dream of a multi-ethnic democracy will live on only through jury duty and subway travel.
"I don't think kids should be guinea pigs for your political beliefs," she said, "but public schools are much better than most people imagine. There have been dramatic improvements in the past 10 years. Visionary educators such as Anthony Alvarado and Deborah Meier have created models.
"A generation of middle-class parents, many of them immigrants who aggressively shop for schools, have pushed for better programs, volunteered, raised funds.
"By the way, when it comes to special education, public schools are far and away the best. Corporations that want to create a work force and to make the city a more attractive place to do business have funded New Visions for Public Education and sometimes even adopted schools."
Ms. Hemphill's 20-year career included war reporting, which she wryly concedes may have been a preparation for her project. She sees New York on the brink of becoming a Third World city of isolated rich and desperate poor with public education as the only possibility for social harmony.
Her guidebook, to be published in the fall by SoHo Press, is aimed at middle-class and working-class parents, although the wealthy may find alternatives to what one private-school teacher has described as their tendency to "treat their kids like BMW's and park them in the best educational garages."
From a practical point of view, Ms. Hemphill points out, the $35,000 saved by not sending two children to an exclusive private school will pay for a lot of flute lessons. It will also relieve some parents of needing to earn about $60,000 pre-tax. Will that free Dad or Mom to spend more time with the kids and at school, assuming they want to?
Volunteerism at public schools helps bring down the adult-to-child ratios, but Ms. Hemphill says it is only a stopgap; government money is crucial. One reason poor schools can do so well, she says, is Federal aid.
Ms. Hemphill has returned from her treks through the city with some certainties: A good principal is the key to a good school. There is no Right Way; there are good schools where students wear uniforms and good schools where they sit on rugs. Good schools will adapt to ethnic or economic changes in a neighborhood.
She also discovered that whites underestimate the size and energy of the black middle class, whose values are shared by many conservative whites. Many parents educated in parochial schools are sending their children to public schools. Typical, she said, is a mother in Bay Ridge thrilled that her son's world view was enlarged by the classmate who fasts for Ramadan.
Ms. Hemphill's definition of a good school is complex, statistical, physical and emotional, but here are some quick eyeball checks. Are all the desks in neat rows? Are there only textbooks, no real books? Do all the bulletin boards look the same? Three yesses mean the children are probably being pelted by info-bits, rather than encouraged to think, which is a goal of a good school.
She hopes her guide will be an inspiration for more people to take charge of their neighborhood schools. In a time of centralization, budget cuts and lack of public support, that is critical. Her basic message is this: There is a good public school near you, and if there isn't, you can build one. (They will come.)

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Mark Matcho)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
For a Passionate Few, Nothing's as Good as Gold

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
THE Dow may be flirting with 7,000, but don't expect all investors to be impressed. Some of them are much more enchanted by that traditional bedrock of investments: gold. And not just gold stocks or shares in gold mutual funds, but the real, solid, heavy, yellow stuff.
Take Robert F. Hague, 71, a retired investment banker who lives in Upper Montclair, N.J. He keeps 90 percent of his portfolio in gold -- bullion, coins, mutual funds and individual equities. He started buying gold 30 years ago, and his reason for doing so -- fiscal conservatism -- is a common one among gold bugs. 
 "I've felt for many, many years that we're going to have to use gold to straighten out our financial system," Mr. Hague said. "The reason the economy and the market look so good is because of excessive credit and debt. It's all false appearances. I think there will come a time when gold is recognized as the ultimate money."
Others apparently agree. While recent gold sales are dwarfed by, say, the 26.2 million ounces of net purchases in the inflationary days of 1974, buying has been on a modest rise. The 2.2 million ounces in net sales last year, for instance, were up from 1.5 million in 1995, according to CPM Group, a New York commodities consultancy.
Fears of an overvalued stock market and the large Federal debt are two reasons for the recent buying, said Richard Scott-Ram, an economist at the World Gold Council, the industry's trade association. Another may be low prices. Gold has been relatively cheap in recent years, and on Feb. 11 an ounce sold for $341.90, its lowest price since the first quarter of 1993.
But whatever the immediate conditions, investors have been drawn to gold for centuries, and their goal has always been safety: diversifying their portfolios, securing a haven for tough times and gaining a hedge against inflation.
Gold loyalists say the precious metal does these jobs superbly. "Gold is the only investment that holds its own," said Pat Gorman, a gold bug and the host of a radio show about the metal in Tucson, Ariz. "In the 1930's, you could have taken a $20 gold piece or a one-ounce gold coin and bought a fine men's suit. Today you can take that same coin and purchase that same suit of clothes."
Most investment experts are as skeptical of gold as the bugs are enthusiastic. The experts acknowledge that gold has sometimes served its historical purposes, but they generally warn investors to put only a small portion of their assets in it. Rather than enhancing safety, they say, too much gold can increase risk.
"Having a hefty portion of gold stocks would basically mean you have a concentrated sector play," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago.
Others question gold's traditional strength as a haven during crisis or times of high inflation. While gold often zoomed in value during war, for instance, it did not do so during the Persian Gulf war. And while inflation has been low recently, "gold prices haven't even kept up with it," said John Davis, a financial planner in Elmhurst, Ill.
Experts raise other warnings about gold, -- like average annual returns of just 46-hundredths of 1 percent from 1991 to 1996.
In turn, the gold industry and others offer counterarguments. While gold may not excel when inflation is modest, its inflation-fighting powers come to the fore when price increases step up, said Jeffrey Christian, managing director of CPM Group. "When inflation is over 7 percent in the U.S., gold does well," he said.
For many gold bugs, though, the debate is beside the point. Big fans of gold say that when the clouds gather -- as they believe they ultimately will -- those who hold gold will be glad.
Consider Raymond A. Igou Jr., 63, an orthopedic surgeon who has a practice in Stoneham, Mass. "Everyone is sitting around watching the stock market go crazy," he said. "Inflation is down, and we haven't had an oil crunch lately. But when everyone else thinks it's a bull, I call it a bear." As a result, Dr. Igou keeps 25 percent of his portfolio in gold coins, with the remainder in stocks, bonds and some partnerships.
The doctor chooses to hold gold in coins because "you get a double whammy: the rarity plus the gold," he said.
"Also, when the price of gold moves," he said, "collectible coins move faster and farther."
In this regard, Dr. Igou is typical. Eighty percent of individual investors who physically own gold -- as opposed to gold futures contracts or stocks and mutual funds that invest in mining companies -- hold only coins, according to the World Gold Council. (The most popular coins are South African Krugerrands and American Eagles.) Eighteen percent of these investors own coins and bars, while 2 percent own only bars.
Dr. Igou is typical in another way: behind his gold gathering looms a keen fear of disaster, and not just of a drop in the market. In a practice that some investors may find hard to fathom, he keeps some gold in a hiding place nearby. "I live on the ocean, so I made a list of all the things I would need in case of a big flood that washes away everything," he said. "One of them is gold, so I keep $40,000 or $50,000 worth."
SOME gold bugs are prompted by visions of mayhem on a huge scale. An economic bust is the worry of one 44-year-old manufacturer's representative in Northern Arizona, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Fearing a run on banks and great difficulty in finding and paying for food and other necessities, he keeps 50 percent of his $250,000 portfolio in gold bars, some hidden close to his home.
"In an economic dislocation," he said, "at least gold will give me a fighting chance."
For some people, gold is not just a shield from calamity. It verges on a life style.
Consider Rose Morgan, 49, a former commodities trader who lives in Vancouver, Wash. True, she is a mainstream gold bug in many ways. About 40 percent of her portfolio is in gold, both physical gold and gold stocks. She frets about inflation and, like Mr. Hague, she is a staunch fiscal conservative.
But Ms. Morgan is also a prospector. Three months out of the year, she searches for the metal high in the Sierra Nevada in California. She estimates that prospecting has earned her $100,000 the last six years.
She is also a self-described gold recycler, combing auctions and flea markets for bottles, china -- anything with gold plating. "It all started with a cologne bottle that I saw at a gold exhibit," she said. "I wondered, what's that bottle of cologne doing on display? Turns out it had 24-karat gold on the lid and bottle. And I had been throwing my husband's cologne out the window!" (She shares secrets of foraging for this ancient metal on a very modern tool, the Internet, at http://www.worldaccess.com/goldbug/.)
Ms. Morgan even tries to use gold as money. "My car repairman takes gold instead of a check, and so does my dentist," she said. "I always offer to pay in gold."
Indeed, with her all-encompassing approach, Ms. Morgan symbolizes a pattern among gold bugs: the belief that gold is much more than an investment. For them, it is variously a political statement, a source of wisdom and even a tenet of faith.
"There's something incredible about being the first or second person ever to have held a gold nugget in your hand," said Ms. Morgan, speaking about placer gold, which is gold in its original state. "You get a tingle."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Some gold enthusiasts don't stop at a few coins or nuggets. Robert F. Hague, right, keeps 90 percent of his financial assets in gold, while Rose Morgan, above, even offers gold as payment to the auto mechanic and the dentist. (Robbie McClaran for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Watching for Banks in the Parade of Financial Mergers

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
AFTER Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover announced a $10.2 billion merger earlier this month, the new game on Wall Street became "Who's next?" Is Chase Manhattan about to buy Paine Webber, or will it snap up Prudential Securities?
As a result, the stock prices of many Wall Street firms that look like takeover candidates have been bid up sharply. Charles Schwab's stock price had risen by Friday to $37.375, from less than half that last summer, for example. And shares of Alex. Brown rose to $61.50 by Friday from less than $50 a few weeks ago, on rumors of a possible takeover by Nationsbank or another ambitious company. 
 Given such price jumps, investors may want to broaden their search for merger targets to a part of the financial industry that is out of this spotlight. A promising area, one that is much bigger than the securities business, is commercial banking.
While the names of Chase Manhattan, Nationsbank and other commercial banks have been uttered in Wall Street's new guessing game, the fact is that mergers within the banking industry itself are very common. There are now about 9,500 banks in the United States, down from 14,000 in 1985, and industry analysts say that the trend will continue until there are fewer than 2,000. Banking and finance accounted for $75 billion of takeovers in 1995, more than any other industry, according to Houlihan Lokey, a Los Angeles investment banking firm. Last year the industry ranked third, after communications and utilities.
Coming months may bring more of the same. "We think 1997 is shaping up to be a spectacular year for bank merger and acquisition activity," said Thomas H. Hanley, managing director and senior bank analyst at UBS Securities in New York. Mr. Hanley said recently that he expected his basket of bank acquisition candidates "to deliver at least a 20 percent to 25 percent return over the next 12 months."
He is currently recommending First Commerce of New Orleans, Summit, Hibernia, Union Planters, RCSB Financial and First American as regional banks that are likely to attract merger partners.
The truth, however, is that it is well-nigh impossible for an investor to predict mergers. "It is extremely difficult to pick acquisition candidates," said Rick Escherich, a managing director in the mergers and acquisitions department of J. P. Morgan. "The probabilities are so low for the investor."
"That's an old game," said Eric A. Longmire, director of research at Wyser-Pratte & Company, a New York money management and investment concern. "It's called 'rumitrage.' "
James K. Schmidt, who manages the John Hancock Regional Bank fund, which has $4 billion in assets, sees takeovers as just the icing on the cake.
"I very rarely buy a stock because I think it's a takeover candidate," said Mr. Schmidt, an executive vice president of the Hancock company. "I'd rather buy stocks like Union Planters of Tennessee. It's good value and if it gets taken over it's an extra."
Union Planters "is still at a discount to its peers in Tennessee," he said. One reason is that the bank missed analysts' earnings estimates for the last quarter of 1996, but that was largely because of a number of acquisitions the bank has made. Moreover, he said, "Tennessee is a real interesting state that is doing well economically."
The bank's lackluster recent results make it a more likely takeover candidate, some analysts add. The poor numbers, they reason, could put more pressure on management to increase shareholder value by selling the company.
Another solid bank and possible takeover target is First Commerce, according to Mr. Hanley and other analysts. It dominates the New Orleans market, and ranks second in market share in Louisiana. The company also has a high degree of insider ownership, which suggests a well-motivated management team.
First Commerce's fee income, which includes revenue from consulting and money management, has risen steadily, climbing 18 percent in the fourth quarter from the comparable period a year earlier. Its credit quality has stayed constant, and the bank's capital remains robust compared with many of its local rivals.
Another good regional bank, and a favored acquisition candidate for Mr. Hanley, is First American. With $10.4 billion in assets, First American ranks second in the growing Tennessee deposit market. It is well positioned, UBS says, in consumer and small-business loans, and has recovered well from its real estate losses of a few years ago.
What about investors who still think that guessing takeover targets will alone make them rich? Mr. Hanley cautioned that they needed to be closely in touch with firms that research the field thoroughly. Also, "You need tremendous patience and conviction in your own view," he said. "You can either get hurt, or you can make a fortune."
But in the end, he said, "There's no substitute for buying good companies."

PUB-DATE: February 23, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3403 words

HEADLINE: Patching the Cracks in the Rock

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
ADA AND BILL WELLS had been loyal customers of the Prudential Insurance Company of America for most of their lives. But at a time when they were settling into retirement and thinking of cutting back on their life insurance, a Prudential agent saddled them with a new policy that he promised would virtually pay for itself.
After a few years, they said, they discovered that they had been deceived by the agent, who had arranged a loan to pay for the new policy. Facing rising debt on the loan and annual premiums of $1,800 -- several times what they had been paying -- the Wellses, of New York City, joined legions of aggrieved Prudential customers taking legal action against the insurer that once possessed one of the most trusted names in corporate America. 
 This costly dispute, involving nearly 11 million policies, is merely the latest woe for a company that has been bombarded by calamities in recent years and was finally forced to put an outsider in charge for the first time since it was founded more than 120 years ago.
For two years, Arthur F. Ryan, an outsider recruited from Chase Manhattan Bank, has been struggling to turn the Newark-based company around after a loss in 1994 of more than $900 million. Not only is he trying to restore Prudential's reputation, but he faces an even greater challenge in bringing cohesion to a jumbled empire that once seemed to resemble nothing so much as the warring fiefs of medieval Europe.
Though revenues have been flat for two years at about $30 billion, Mr. Ryan has put Prudential back in the black through cost-cutting and profitable sales of securities and other assets. Earnings for 1996 are estimated at roughly $1 billion, up from $478 million in 1995.
But whether Mr. Ryan, 54, can improve operating performance and restore prosperity to the nation's largest insurer, with almost 50 million customers and nearly $180 billion in assets, remains in doubt.
More than half of Prudential's businesses -- from life insurance to corporate health care, from homeowners' insurance to guaranteed investment contracts, a field that Prudential thoroughly dominated only a few years ago -- are still losing ground to competitors. Last fall, for example, the health care unit failed to win renewal of a nearly $4 billion contract with the American Association of Retired Persons.
Prudential's standing with the insurance rating agencies has been slipping, too. Only last week, Moody's Investors Service dropped the company another notch and other agencies are contemplating additional downgrades.
While Prudential's ratings are still at the high end of the scale, they provide an unflattering comparison with competitors like John Hancock, Northwestern Mutual and New York Life, which remain at the absolute top, and sales of insurance and pension plans have suffered. Moreover, each tick downward has meant a tick upward in the cost of borrowing.
But Mr. Ryan knew what he was in for at Prudential, and he is pressing ahead. To begin with, he has set up a new way of selling life insurance, largely to guard against the abusive sales tactics that have landed the company in so much trouble. Now, once an agent has talked a customer into a policy, an administrative worker from headquarters must review the policy directly with the client, making sure that he or she understands precisely what is being bought.
Just as important, the life insurance business, upon which Prudential's image as the Rock of Gibraltar was built, is finally being streamlined. The five regional headquarters that were once proud outposts for the company's centurions have been shut down. Two of those offices are being converted into service centers to handle administrative tasks once done in local offices.
Prudential's central problem stems from the fact that life insurance -- while still the largest single part of the company's business -- has been steadily losing appeal to Americans far more interested in investing in the booming stock market for a more comfortable retirement than in planning for death.
But that's not all. Its homeowners' division had concentrated too heavily in hurricane zones and was staggered by enormous claims. Its big corporate health care business was being outmaneuvered by more nimble competitors in important markets across the country. And shortly before the insurance complaints began coming to the surface like long-buried land mines, Prudential's securities subsidiary paid $1.5 billion in fines, compensation and legal costs for misleading clients -- many of them elderly, with modest nest eggs -- who lost money on high-risk limited partnerships that they could ill afford.
That is why, at the end of 1994, Prudential's board turned to Mr. Ryan almost in desperation. Tall and slightly stooped, with an easy smile and a warm handshake, Mr. Ryan had cut fat and introduced new technology at Chase, where he rose to the No. 2 job. He was renowned for rolling up his sleeves at his own computer. He liked working one-on-one, but was perfectly at ease at center stage in the company auditorium. And he had never had anything to do with insurance. As Prudential's board saw it, he was exactly what the company needed.
"Here was someone with a new approach who could make the reforms," said William H. Gray 3d, the former Representative from Pennsylvania who is a Prudential board member in addition to heading the United Negro College Fund.
Burton Malkiel, a professor at Princeton University and former member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, was on the board's search committee. He found Mr. Ryan to be "extremely bright, extremely decisive."
So Mr. Ryan set to work. No longer, he decreed, was Prudential to be first and foremost a life insurance company, with anything else regarded as a distant afterthought. He had been watching the revolution that had catapulted the Fidelity mutual funds to the top of the heap of the country's money managers and had transformed banks into financial powerhouses again, while seemingly leaving life insurance as something your father recalled with nostalgia.
"I don't want to communicate that insurance is less important," Mr. Ryan said in a conversation the other day at Prudential's white marble headquarters here, "but that money management is equally important."
One of his first big changes was to consolidate a handful of sometimes competing investment units under a single umbrella with more than $193 billion under management. Money management for individuals and institutions -- in contrast to investing premiums, as insurance companies have always done -- was a crucial part of his vision, and he told his executives to start coming up with new mutual funds and other investment vehicles that would compete with industry leaders.
AT a gray marble work table in his 24th-floor office, an elegantly simple Japanese screen stretching behind him, Mr. Ryan strikes a measured tone, neither glowing nor gloomy. The company is "going through a tough period," he acknowledged. But he figures he's gaining on the demons. "We're well on our way," he said.
The company that Mr. Ryan inherited was encrusted in gentlemanly tradition. It was a place where managers received their bonuses whether or not they made their annual goals, and where regular hours and uninterrupted weekends were regarded as an entitlement. "It was a very comfortable place," one longtime Prudential executive said. It was also a formal, somewhat stuffy place where the chain of command was rigidly observed and where a saccharine form of corporate circumlocution known as "Pru polite" often left managers wondering what top executives were trying to say.
Mr. Ryan, of course, wasn't the first at Prudential to identify life insurance as a waning business. The company had already expanded beyond it into about a dozen separate businesses. But instead of operating under a comprehensive strategy, those businesses, as well as the five regional headquarters of the life insurance division, addressed the world on their own terms. It was not only a matter of little central control. Each of the units had its own computer system, its own purchasing system and its own advertising program. They did not share information about their customers, so the company could make the most of each relationship, and all too often one Prudential unit would be elbowing another for the same piece of business.
To Mr. Ryan, the organization looked like "a series of independent silos," free-wheeling subsidiaries working at cross purposes with fragmented game plans.
To bring about change, he figured, a lot of the old guard had to go. Twelve of the 14 executives who report directly to him are new to their jobs. Of the top 150 executives, two-thirds are new. About half were recruited from the outside. The others were longtime Prudential employees who passed the test of the new mission.
In two years, Mr. Ryan has shrunk the work force to 83,000, from about 100,000. In doing so, he has cut deeply into the ranks of the company's notoriously unproductive insurance agents. But with the sales force now at about 12,000, down from roughly 16,000, "the company has also lost some agents it didn't want to lose," said Larry Mayewski, a senior vice president and analyst at the A. M. Best Company, a rating agency. And with regulators still breathing down its neck, Prudential is not a particularly attractive place for newcomers, either.
Not everyone at Prudential is thrilled with the Ryan way of doing things. But one of the hundreds of specialists working under contract to help transform Prudential said that some of the initial resistance seemed to be fading.
"People are saying," he explained, " 'We've had some bad press on the life insurance side. Some of our other units are bleeding. Things are getting tougher out there. Maybe we do need some realignment.' At least on the conceptual level, people are becoming receptive to the idea."
Bob Koehler, a former vice president and head of the company's retiree association, still keeps in touch with colleagues. "A lot of people say Art Ryan is like a breath of fresh air," Mr. Koehler said, "and they're glad to see him in there."
Many people who had been trained by Mr. Koehler moved into more prominent positions under Mr. Ryan. "These people were not in senior management, but close to it," Mr. Koehler said. "They give him the continuity of the old Prudential without being committed to the old ways."
Still, one recurring conflict, the independent specialist said, is between short- and long-term goals. "They want to get things done quickly to stop the bleeding," he said. "But sometimes that delays fundamental change that, by its nature, takes longer."
As an example, he said, the plan for new regional service centers calls for them to be staffed with teams of employees trained to handle several kinds of work. But to get the centers up and running, he said, the company is assigning employees to their old, single-mission roles while planning only later to retrain them to fit the team concept.
Mr. Ryan has not been reluctant to prune dead wood. He sold off several of the company's businesses: its reinsurance unit, whose earnings had fluctuated widely; its mortgage division, which had been suffering through a downturn in housing sales, and its weak Canadian life insurance branch.
PERHAPS the most troubled of Prudential's businesses these days is its corporate health care unit, a behemoth with a network of 90,000 physicians, 1,000 hospitals and 4.5 million clients, which accounts for about 30 percent of the company's revenues but has been unable to make a profit for two years. In September, shortly after its two senior executives had been pushed into retirement, the unit lost its bid to renew the contract with the A.A.R.P. While searching for a new head of the unit, Mr. Ryan has put himself and a group of four executives in charge.
Mr. Ryan's solution for most of what ails the health care unit is consolidation. Here was an operation, Mr. Ryan said, with way too many silos. "We had 40 markets in which we operated," he said, "and all acted relatively independently."
While imposing uniform operations, Mr. Ryan recognizes that health care is an essentially local business and that to succeed companies need to dominate or at least play leading roles in each market. In markets that Prudential does not have a prayer of dominating, units are being sold, as happened in Boston in mid-January. In others, where the fundamentals look good, Mr. Ryan is shopping for acquisitions. Throughout, Prudential has been shifting from traditional health insurance to managed care and is trying to expand its dental and disability insurance programs.
Because of a heavy concentration of homeowner policies in South Florida, Prudential's property and casualty company was nearly wiped out by Hurricane Andrew in 1992. Claims rose to $1.3 billion and the operation had to borrow from sister units. Prudential wanted to simply stop selling homeowner insurance in South Florida. But regulators ruled that if the company wanted out of that business it would have to get out of Florida entirely, abandoning its lucrative life insurance business there as well. So to reduce its risk, Prudential began paying a full year of premiums for homeowners willing to sign with another company. These days, Prudential estimates, a hurricane disaster in Florida would cost the company, at most, $440 million.
The next milestone in the company's saga of scandal comes tomorrow in Federal District Court in Newark, where teams of lawyers will debate whether a proposed class-action settlement fairly compensates up to 10.7 million policyholders who regulators across the country say may have been misled. Last summer, Prudential paid a fine of $35 million, imposed by the regulators, and acknowledged that for more than a decade, until 1995, some of its agents had improperly persuaded customers to cash in or borrow against existing policies to buy new, often more expensive ones in a practice often referred to as "churning." The main beneficiaries were not the customers but the agents, who received additional commissions, and the company, which gained market share and made more money.
WHATEVER the outcome at the hearing in Newark, the company's worries are far from over. Nearly 20,000 policyholders have refused to go along with the class action and hundreds of individual suits -- including one by the Wellses -- are being prepared by lawyers or are working their way through the courts. Other suits have been filed by agents who say they were dismissed because they tried to blow the whistle on dishonest insurance sales.
Officials in five states had been campaigning against the class-action settlement. But over the last two weeks, with the payment of $35.2 million, hours of personal negotiations by Mr. Ryan and an improvement in the provisions for compensation of policyholders, the officials in California, Florida, Massachussetts, Texas and Virginia dropped their objections.
No one knows how long it will take to restore Prudential's reputation. For many people like the Wellses, redemption may never come. "I believed in them," said Mrs. Wells, who taught elementary school in College Point, Queens, for nearly 20 years. "I had confidence in the company. I thought they were honest. Now I don't. We were misled all the way."
While former agents contend that they were trained by Prudential in the kind of tactics that were used in the Wells case, Robert DeFillippo, a corporate spokesman, said that such practices were "unacceptable and against company policy."
"What's painful about this story is that the woman has lost faith in the company," Mr. DeFillippo said. "The company knows there are a lot of people like that. And we know we have one last chance to provide remedies and to demonstrate that we will keep our promises."
For some insurance experts watching Prudential, the situation seems grave. "The problems at Prudential are very deep," said Kevin Ceurvorst, a group vice president and senior analyst for the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company in Chicago. "They've made some progress, but while they've been dealing with their problems, their competitors have been moving ahead. It's hard to say whether Prudential can overcome its deterioration."
In lowering Prudential's ratings last Wednesday, Moody's said that besides the burden of overcoming the insurance scandal, the company faced "significant operating and competitive challenges that will likely continue to hurt its financial performance over the near term."
Still, not all the outsiders tracking Prudential have turned sour. Mark Puccia, the senior insurance analyst for Standard & Poor's, another major rating agency, sees Prudential as continuing to regain its health, mainly on the strength of Mr. Ryan's leadership. It is its confidence in Mr. Ryan, Mr. Puccia said, that has kept Standard & Poor's from further lowering Prudential's ratings.
Mr. Mayewski of A. M. Best is also betting that Mr. Ryan will make it. "He's putting the fundamentals and the discipline in place that are required for success," Mr. Mayewski said.
In the coming year, Mr. Ryan is aiming for another substantial increase in earnings, to about $1.5 billion, as he continues a three-year plan to chop expenses by $800 million. But for future growth, Mr. Ryan says, Prudential will eventually need to go on the acquisition trail, particularly in the money management field.
"Right now, we see lots of opportunity to grow by investing internally," he said. "And very frankly, in terms of acquiring other companies, prices are too high. But I'm sure that at some point that will be part of our game plan."
One possible advantage for Mr. Ryan is that as the chief of a mutual company, he has no shareholders nudging him to get the company's earnings hopping. As a mutual company, Prudential functions somewhat like a cooperative. Ownership is formally in the hands of policyholders whose main interest is in their own insurance rather than in how the company is being run. When it comes time to pick board members, few policy owners exercise their right to vote.
The original idea of mutual companies was that they would not try to make a profit, but would return dividends to policyholders on any earnings above operating expenses. But without a profit motive, many mutual companies, including Prudential, became more comfortable than competitive.
Mr. Ryan argues that the formal structure of a company is not a principal influence on a company's performance. "It's the management first and the management second," he said, followed at some distance by "the oversight of the board."
One big drawback of a mutual company is that because it has no shares to sell, it cannot easily raise money for expansion. Mr. Ryan may well want to convert Prudential into a stock company for precisely that reason. That is not out of the question, he says. But it is not on his agenda for this year. He has also been watching the development of a hybrid corporate form in which the mutual company takes on the designation of a holding company and is permitted to create a publicly owned subsidiary through which investment money can be raised. The legislatures of five states have approved that form, but not the one in New Jersey, Prudential's home state.
A priority for Mr. Ryan has been trying to fix the company's image. But just last month a Federal judge fined Prudential $1 million for "gross negligence" after discovering that executives in several field offices had destroyed stacks of documents related to the life insurance case. And, in another indication that all is not yet right with Prudential's dealings with its customers, ABC's "Prime Time Live" broadcast footage in December from a hidden camera showing an agent assuring a customer in Syracuse that she would receive higher interest on a life insurance policy than could actually be delivered. Prudential responded by dismissing the agent.
"Prudential has got to put this issue behind them," said Mr. Puccia of Standard & Poor's. "And in order to become a vibrant, ongoing enterprise, they've got to start growing their book of business and improving profits. Up to now, they've been in a divestiture mode. They've got to turn the wheel 180 degrees now and start aggressively increasing revenues."

LIFE INSURANCE
 
PROBLEM: Interest in traditional life insurance has waned. And Prudential has a more fundamental difficulty; As many as 10.7 million policies sold from 1982 to 1995 are affected by accusations that agents "churned" customers, essentially talking them into using cash values in old policies to buy new ones just to create commissions.
 
ACCOMPLISHMENT: Moving toward settlement of class-action suit at an estimated cost of up to $2 billion. Centralized control by closing five regional headquarters, and underwriters from headquarters now review all new policies to make sure customers understand exactly what they are buying.
 
GOAL: To complete all litigation, restore reputation and recover position as industry sales leader.
 
HEALTH CARE
 
Problem: Organization is fragmented and is being out-maneuvered by more nimble companies.
 
Accomplishments: Starting to sell-off units in markets where results have been poor and looking for acquisitions in markets where attaining leading roles seems possible. Improved customer service and efficiency by consolidating more than 40 centers at four locations that will operate round the clock, seven days a week.
 
Goal: To become a leader in many of the company's 40 market areas and to get out of those areas where the chance of success seems remote. New head of unit expected to be named soon.
 
INVESTMENTS
 
Problem: Operations lacked focus as Prudential concentrated on life insurance. Several units offering competiting services. One subsidiary, Prudential Securities, paid $1.5 billion in fines, compensation and legal fees for misleading clients, many of them elderly, who lost money on risky limited partnerships.
 
Accomplishments: Investments given equal priority with life insurance. Several previously independent units combined under the umbrella of Prudential Investments. Developed several new mutual funds and annunities. Sale of limited partnerships ended.
 
Goals: Continue to develop new investments products and to emphasize retirement services, variable annunities, mutual funds and institutional asset management.
 
PROPERTY and CASUALTY
 
Problem: Company suffered heavy losses in Florida and other hurricane zones. Policies were often sold as inducements to securing or keeping life insurance clients, with an inclination to bend underwriting rules and not focus on the bottom line.
 
Accomplishments: Replaced head of unit with outsider in January, 1996. Reduced number of policy holiders in high risk areas to reduce overall risk. Began tightening underwriting guidelines in an attempt to more closely correlate premiums with risk and dememphasizing linkage with life insurance.
 
Goal: Profitability by 1998. (pg. 12)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 13; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Keepers of the Dismal Faith

BYLINE: By Alan Ehrenhalt; Alan Ehrenhalt, executive editor of Governing magazine, is the author of "The Lost City: The Forgotten Virtues of Community in America."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Not long ago, in a widely read introductory work on economics, I came upon an extended discussion of why popcorn is expensive at the movies. It turns out that economists have been debating this subject in scholarly journals for more than a quarter century.
Many of them have concluded that the common-sense explanation of the problem is wrong. Movie popcorn doesn't cost $3 a box because the theater owner has a monopoly. It costs that much because people go to the movies in groups, and if a theater started offering cheap popcorn as a come-on, popcorn lovers would try to pull the whole group to that theater, causing dissension. Expensive popcorn is the price of leisure-time social harmony. 
 It's an ingenious theory, but it ignores some common-sense truths. The cost of popcorn is utterly irrelevant to anyone's decision about where to go to the movies. All that really matters is the movie being shown and the location of the theater. To factor in concession prices is to assume an all-purpose calculating mind that moviegoers simply don't possess.
What is it about economists, anyway? For the past generation or more, most of us have suspected they are a little eccentric, and much of the time they seem to agree. They have always liked to make jokes about themselves: "Your idea may be fine in practice," the senior professor sneers at his junior colleague. "But it will never work in theory." Economist jokes revolve around a couple of defining characteristics: their love of theoretical assumption and their haughty rejection of common sense.
There is nothing economists enjoy more, they will readily admit, than telling the uninitiated that the plain evidence of the senses is wrong. These days they are doing it with a particular vengeance. Ordinary Americans look at their country and note the disappearance of 40 million jobs in the past two decades and conclude that something terribly disruptive has been going on. They see that many of the nation's biggest corporations now do most of their manufacturing in third world countries, and infer that precious livelihoods are fleeing to Thailand and Sri Lanka.
The response of many economists is to insist that no such thing is happening, that for every job lost a new one is born and thus the country does not suffer materially in the transition. (The individuals who are affected materially by this transition are rarely considered relevant.) In the past couple of months, the economic professoriate has been a familiar presence on the country's most influential Op-Ed pages, smacking down the journalists and occasional renegade economists who insist that the evidence of the senses holds some truth.
It is not my purpose to intrude on the arcana of the foreign trade debate. What interests me is the argument that the professoriate ultimately seizes upon in its effort to discredit the heretics: They aren't "real" economists. They lack credentials. Worst of all, they don't know the math.
"There are . . . important ideas that are crystal clear if you can stand algebra," a distinguished economist wrote in a typical diatribe a few weeks ago, "and very difficult to grasp if you don't."
Of all the ammunition an economist can throw at you in an argument, the math insult is perhaps the most dispiriting. It is essentially a charge of illiteracy. And anybody who has not mastered the algebra of trade theory by middle age is probably never going to pick it up.
But even people who know very little math know something about math: It is a reasoning process based on a set of postulates, a set of assumptions. It is only as good as the assumptions it starts with. Medieval astronomers developed highly sophisticated mathematical models for tracking the path of the planets, and they got their numbers to work. The only problem was that they thought the sun revolved around the earth.
Present-day economists may know more than medieval astronomers, but they too are captives of a single overarching idea: that most people in everyday life are rational calculators of their own self-interest -- that they are, in economic jargon, maximizers of utility. Given a sufficient amount of information, they will come to the logically correct decision every time.
Modern conventional economics is not just a series of calculations about trade or jobs or money. It is a theory about human behavior. And it is a theory that, to say the least, deserves more scrutiny than it normally gets.
The sociologist Alan Wolfe gave it that scrutiny in his ground-breaking book, "Whose Keeper?" Treating human beings as pure calculators of self-interest, Mr. Wolfe pointed out, ignores virtually all differences across time, space, temperament and culture. Such an approach assumes that given the right amount of information, we would make the same "rational" decision whether we were young or old, sick or well, outgoing or reclusive, alone or in a group. Most mainstream economists would shrink from defending this idea in its bluntest formulation. And yet it is the fragile assumption upon which an entire edifice of formulas, calculations and predictions is ultimately based.
What attracts economists to questionable ideas and makes them so belligerent? The best way to answer that question is to think of economics more as a faith than as a science.
If you look at some of the personal recollections of the current cohort of free-market economists, you usually find a common thread. At some point in their early lives, beset by the usual self-doubts of youth, they discovered the market and fell in love. Some of them actually use those words. The market offered them a certainty that no other available creed could provide. It gave them a cascade of answers. In fact, given the initial assumptions of individual rationality, the market can answer all questions -- not just questions about trade or jobs or inflation but all the important questions of life. Even questions about the price of popcorn at the movies.
In that respect, free-market economics resembles such earlier claimants to truth as Marxism and psychoanalysis -- sweeping theoretical systems that provide their acolytes a reassuring certainty in exchange for a few gigantic assumptions as starting points. Like Marxists and Freudians, free-market economists take refuge from their critics by retreating under the cloak of unimpeachable science.
Market economics is not only a faith; it is an entirely appropriate faith for the generation of thinkers who were born shortly after World War II, went to college in the 1960's and now dominate the public policy discussion in academia and much of government. Market economics enshrines choice and lionizes the individual. Carried to its furthest extreme, it all but suggests that anything the individual really feels like doing can't be wrong. It is a branch of 1960's ideology in formal dress.
As the mantra for millions of Americans, perhaps most of a generation, this set of ideas is entitled to some respect. But it need not be taken at face value, and mastery of algebra should not be a prerequisite for discussing it.

LENGTH: 1173 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

CAMPAIGN FINANCE
Did Someone Say Reform?
Campaign finance reform? I'm absolutely, 100 percent for it, politicians always say -- how about tomorrow? Next week at the latest. First, though, I've got to get a few million in my pocket so I'll be around next week. And, oh yes, start with that other party -- it's the real culprit. Last week, alas, it was hard to sense any bracing breeze of reform on either side of the aisle. First it turned out that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had taken money clearly intended for Republican Senate campaigns and shifted it to New York races -- all legal, he said, but an army of eyebrows shot up. And President Clinton didn't exactly stand out as a warrior for frugal politics, traveling to New York to grab a quick million for his party's Senate candidates. Senator Trent Lott's take on unlimited donations: It's "the American way."
 
CLASS ACTION
Heads, You Lose; Tails, the Lawyer Wins
The class-action suit certainly sounds like a wonderful invention. Thousands, maybe tens of thousands, of powerless civilians employ a single team of lawyers. Each person pays a tiny legal fee and thus, naturally, gets a decent chunk of any damages awarded. What efficiency! But this naive notion, alas, ignores the astounding ability of lawyers to run through cash -- a phenomenon documented with jaw-dropping vividness in the best seller "A Civil Action." A case in point: One Dexter J. Kamilewicz, of Yarmouth, Me., was a class-action "winner" recently in a suit involving mortgage escrow accounts. His winnings: $2.19; his legal bill: $91.33. No, that's not a joke. Mr. Kamilewicz didn't think so either, and, yes, he is now suing the lawyers. Can he afford to win this one, too?
 
TRANSPORTATION
The Grail of Airline Safety
Nothing is totally safe. Stay inside? The house could burn. Go outside? Lightning could strike. Go for a drive? That's one of the riskiest things you could do. How about flying? It's remarkably safe, but the slight margin of risk is a matter of endless scrutiny. Take last week's semantic skirmish: The National Transportation Safety Board said the Boeing 737 fell short on safety because a small rudder failure could cause a crash, but both Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration disagreed, with Boeing calling the plane "absolutely safe" and the agency citing a "very good" safety record. The debate revolved around whether the risk of a crash fell into the highly nontechnical category "extremely improbable." And as Vice President Al Gore announced recently, new rudder valves should be on the way soon.
 
DOOMSDAY DREAMING
Fixing Social Security, Again
Clearly, the parlor game of the moment is fixing Social Security. Hardly a week goes by without some new formula, some new twist, some new set of projections incomprehensible to the laity. Last week's entry: "Fixing Social Security," a report by a business group called the Committee for Economic Development. The plan? Radical it's not -- it tinkers here, fine-tunes there, leaving the structure of the thing pretty much intact as it rumbles into the 21st century. Some highlights: After the first $425 in monthly wages, new retirees will gradually get back a lower percentage in their retirement checks. The retirement age will move toward 70, not 67. And you'll need to work 40 years, not 35, for full benefits. But here's the political bone tossed to the elderly: current benefits would be untouched.
 
TALENT SEARCH
Older Siblings? Of Course
Job applicants, take note. Education, job history and such trivial matters still count for something, but today's hot resume item is the old family snapshot. Are you the oldest, the youngest or in the middle? Surprisingly, this suddenly carries weight with employers, thanks to a recent book called "Born to Rebel," which argues that first-borns are authoritarian conformists, and that younger siblings are more adventurous types. Gerald Levin, the Time Warner chairman and the youngest of three, fits the theory, says the author, Frank Sulloway of M.I.T. Mr. Levin, he said, citing the purchase of Turner Broadcasting, has "a marked penchant for risk-taking." Can you dismiss this as oversimplified nonsense, as a theory too cute by half? Not easily: the book's in its fourth printing, Mr. Sulloway's panel at that snazzy World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, was packed, and executive recruiters are perking up. Tomorrow's growth company: Rent-a-Big-Brother.
 
THE NEW LITTER
Pennies From Hell
In 1964, if memory serves, this mighty nation did just fine without a coin worth a fifth of a cent. Gum was purchased, change was made, commerce hummed merrily along. Yet that's what today's penny is worth -- a fifth of a 1964 cent. That year's penny bought what a nickel does today. Yet the penny survives, an indestructible relic gradually taking over every drawer and jar in the land. They sit on the floor unclaimed, and some customers won't even take them as change, a New York merchant said last week. "They don't want anything to do with it," he said. Round off to the nearest nickel? No, we are a precise breed, ruled by merciless computers. You can almost hear the alarms go off. Ban this copper-plated litter? Insult Lincoln's memory? Never. They'll just keep piling up, till they outnumber the cigarette butts in office-building doorways. They'll be put on barges and no one will take them.
 
 
GLOBAL TRADE
One Deng Legacy
A lot has been written about the legacy of Deng Xiaoping. But from a purely economic standpoint, here's a vivid snapshot of one revolutionary change that took place during his tenure.
 
THE MEDIA
$100,000? Oh, That
On Dec. 13, on "20/20," Barbara Walters interviewed Andrew Lloyd Webber -- then dutifully disclosed that ABC's owner, Disney, had invested in several Lloyd Webber musicals. She did not mention that she herself had invested $100,000 in the Broadway production of his "Sunset Boulevard." "She just didn't think of it," a spokeswoman for ABC News said last week. Whoops.
 
RADIOACTIVE WASTE
Both Deadly and 'Safe'?
Deadly radioactive waste started leaking from the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island at least three years ago, the Energy Department said last week. Various politicians assured nearby residents that their drinking water was safe. What a relief.
 
ADVERTISING (THE LACK THEREOF)
A Ford Gift: 'Schindler'
It's a fair guess that Henry Ford, who once wrote a tract called "The International Jew: The World's Foremost Problem," would have wanted nothing to do with "Schindler's List." His successors at Ford Motor, though, are not only sponsoring the film on NBC tonight but are doing it without commercial interruption -- a rare and wondrous event in the commercial-saturated world of network television. Is this a return to TV's "golden age," the time of single-sponsor shows like "Ford Theater" and "Ford Star Revue"? Or is it simply that a pitch for any product would seem jarringly tasteless in the midst of this shattering Holocaust movie?

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE -- 1996 REPORT;
The State of Brooklyn

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE

 BODY:
Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, delivered his annual State of the Borough speech Wednesday. While emphasizing the positive -- such as the strongest economic growth in downtown Brooklyn in 50 years -- Mr. Golden's review also noted several stalled initiatives and a handful of massive, unresolved projects that have the potential to significantly brighten or significantly mar the borough's future. 

WHAT WENT RIGHT
 
Renaissance Plaza -- After a 13-year effort, construction of Brooklyn's first major new hotel in 50 years began.
 
Atlantic Center -- The long-awaited retail center opened in downtown Brooklyn to massive crowds.
 
Atlantic Terminal -- After years of delay, the Transit Authority committed to a $140 million refurbishment of the terminal, which includes 10 subway lines and a terminus for the Long Island Rail Road.
 
WHAT WENT WRONG
 
Traffic -- A decade-old effort to reduce traffic congestion in downtown Brooklyn followed the same pattern: inaction.
 
Housing -- Completion of the new, 2,400-unit Gateway Estates project near Starrett City, the biggest housing initiative in the borough in 20 years, was delayed by technical issues. A proposed development on Bergen Street between Underhill and Vanderbilt Avenues remained frozen after years of court battles.
 
Education -- Long-running complaints by the Borough President about the School Construction Authority's failure to quickly build and repair schools and open itself up to more public scrutiny remain unresolved.
 
WHAT LIES AHEAD
 
Gowanus Reconstruction -- The state agreed to prepare an environmental-impact statement that will examine alternatives to rebuilding the dilapidated elevated expressway. But a proposal from residents that the roadway be replaced by a tunnel has a slim chance of succeeding.
 
Hub Port -- Mayor Giuliani backed a long-running proposal to build a freight tunnel under New York harbor that would make Sunset Park and Red Hook part of a deep-water "hub port" serving a new generation of ships and bring thousands of jobs to Brooklyn's long-stagnant waterfront. Where the $900 million in funding needed for a new tunnel will come from remains to be seen. DAVID ROHDE

HEADLINE: Second Thoughts About Being Better Off;
The Rehabilitation of Morning in America

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
NOTHING has so defined the American mood over the last 20 years as economic pessimism. From nearly every quarter came the message that prosperity was in decline and young people would have to adjust to a lower standard of living than their parents'. But now, all of a sudden, the last couple of decades don't look so bad. Recent economic history is being revised. And in the new version, Americans turn out to have been more prosperous than they realized. The children can relax.
The revisionists are multiplying. They appear in the Clinton Administration, in the pronouncements of Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's just-departed chief economist. They are evident in Congress, in the optimism of Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a liberal Democrat, and Connie Mack, a conservative Republican. They show up on Wall Street, in the bullishness of Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker, and in corporate America, in the boosterism of Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. And they appear among academics who study and pronounce on the American condition. From all of them, the new message, though never uniform, is roughly this: 
 The world's juggernaut economy has turned out to be America's, not Japan's or Germany's. Those nations went down the wrong road, while Americans -- bemoaning their situation every step of the way -- nevertheless remade their corporations into streamlined global competitors. What's more, living standards, instead of stagnating or deteriorating, rose in ways that are only now being noted. And Americans developed technology with an inventiveness and flexibility not recognized before.
"We never realized how much we did in the 1980's to restructure American business and capitalize on new technology," said Mr. Rohatyn, who is managing partner at Lazard Freres & Company.
Like Mr. Rohatyn, the revisionists are mainly the well-off and successful. Their views, reflecting their own good fortune, flourish because the present looks good. The nation is six years into an economic expansion, unemployment is low and median family incomes have begun to rise, just as they did at this point in the 1980's expansion. But in the seventh year of that expansion, 1990, a recession came that soon made most Americans even more pessimistic. That could happen again, deflating the revisionists' line.
For now, there is no talk of the next recession, although one is inevitable. Certainly there is no such talk from the Democrats, who had played a big role in rekindling the pessimism of the early 1990's. After four years in the White House, they have a stake now in the economy's achievements. Mr. Stiglitz, chief author of the 1997 Economic Report of the President, points, for example, to the "promising statistics" suggesting that income inequality, after 20 years, might finally be reversing.
 
Thanks, Japan
 The new economic thinking also gets a boost from Japan and Germany, whose economies seemed so invincible in the 1980's but are caught today in downturns and, in Germany, high unemployment. For the revisionists, these reversals are inevitable results of a mistaken preference in Japan and Germany for government intervention in economic activity. By comparison, they say, America's laissez-faire approach has finally given the United States the upper hand.
"People had written off the innovative character of American entrepreneurs and their workers, and they were wrong," Mr. Jasinowski said. "They had emphasized our troubles, the slower economic growth, the downsizing, the uneven distribution of income. These are real issues, but they had gotten out of proportion to the industrial renaissance that has been taking place."
Even the millions who suffer from these real issues appear to be helping re-establish what Mr. Jasinowski considers the right proportions. Expectations have diminished, said Richard T. Curtin, a director of the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center. What Americans accept today as a step up in living standards would have been scorned as piddling 25 years ago.
"It is a little like people are saying, 'I am not earning enough to get by, but it is not as bad as it could be,' while in the 60's they thought, 'How good can it get?' " Mr. Curtin said. "When you make that downward change in your standard of judgment, that makes a great deal of difference in the national outlook."
The shift in expectations began in the 1973 oil crisis, with its gas lines and new sense of vulnerability. Rising fuel prices, the severe mid-1970's recession, Japan's inroads into American markets and high inflation all contributed to what President Carter first characterized in the late 1970's as the "malaise" settling on the country.
Resisting such pessimism, Americans elected Ronald Reagan, with his morning-in-America message. But the onslaught continued. The 1981-82 recession was the worst downturn since the Depression. Heavy manufacturing was devastated, the layoffs massive. The air traffic controllers' strike marked an accelerating deterioration of union bargaining power. Mergers and downsizing made job insecurity commonplace. And wage inequality became, in the 1980's, a national characteristic as the less skilled, less educated lost ground to the college trained. Even the skilled often found themselves falling behind sometimes.
 
Redistribution
 "We have redistributed an incredible amount of income and wealth without managing to raise the living standards of most Americans," said Lawrence Mishel, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
Without challenging that statement, Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate in economics, said that the American economy has turned out to be the best in the industrial world and that has offered breathing space to solve the nation's problems. "There is plenty of trouble at the bottom," he said, "but you don't have to worry about the Titanic going down. There isn't an iceberg. You have plenty of time to fix the deck chairs."
If they are very broken. Neither Mr. Mack nor Mr. Moynihan, leaders in Congress on economic issues, thinks they are. For Mr. Mack, the 1980's were years of robust economic growth, unrecognized by the Democrats until now. And for Mr. Moynihan, the groundwork laid in the 1980's and 1990's is paying off. "There is a reward for good behavior," he said, "but perceptions lag. It takes time for a culture that was deeply pessimistic about the future and deeply anxious about the present during the cold war to come out of that."
The main misperceptions, in the eyes of the revisionists, involve productivity and wages. Steady improvements in productivity, or output per worker, are essential for robust economic growth. The Government's productivity statistics, however, say the improvement has been anemic -- a finding most economists endorse and most revisionists reject. How can the data be accurate, says Mr. Jasinowski, when corporate America is performing so well? "It is hard to find an industry," he said, "where we are not equal to or better than our competitors."
The other misperception involves wages and salaries. By most measures -- family income and hourly earnings, for example -- they stopped rising in the early 1970's, except for brief spurts upward in the late 1980's and again very recently. But measuring incomes involves measuring inflation. Stagnant wages in the national statistics mean wages have failed to rise faster than inflation. A 3 percent raise today comes out zero, once statisticians subtract the current annual inflation rate of 3 percent, according to the Consumer Price Index. But inflation is over-stated, many revisionists insist, and as Exhibit A they cite the recent report of a commission of economists appointed by the Senate Finance Committee, mostly at Mr. Moynihan's instigation.
The commission concluded that the C.P.I. has been overstating inflation by 1.1 percentage points -- that the real annual inflation rate today, for example, is not 3 percent but 1.9 percent, which means the 3 percent raise represents not stagnation but a 1.1 percent increase, and since 1973 such gains have gone unrecorded. Accepting that conclusio means accepting a more subjective standard of measuring the cost of living.
 
Better Every Day
 What the statistics fail to reflect sufficiently are quality improvements, the commission concluded. An automaker adds $50 to a car's price to cover the cost of a better anti-rust paint. That extra cost should not have counted as a rise in the inflation rate, or at least not as much of a rise as the Bureau of Labor Statistics calculates when it totes up the Consumer Price Index. Indeed, Americans for 20 years have been enjoying better cars, better medical care, fancier houses and more powerful computers, never realizing, the revisionists argue, that their living standards were rising.
But that raises the income inequality problem again, says Joel Popkin, a former chief of the bureau's C.P.I. division. "We have to consider," he said, "that, while the quality of goods and services may be rising, this new living standard is beyond the reach of an increasing proportion of Americans."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Maybe a Strike Wouldn't Have Cost That Much

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
PERHAPS it was a political no-brainer for President Clinton to intervene last week and halt the pilots' strike at American Airlines.
As George Stephanopoulos, a former senior White House adviser, explained on "Nightline" just before the pilots' strike deadline, "Despite all the highfalutin theory about getting involved in labor and management disputes, when all of the people in the country who are inconvenienced by this can say, 'The President could have prevented it and he didn't,' I don't think that's a price he wants to pay." 
 But some of those highfalutin theories deserve a second look.
Mr. Clinton said he based his decision on economics, arguing that the potential damage of the strike met the test of the 1926 Railway Labor Act: that a labor dispute "threatens substantially to interrupt interstate commerce to a degree such as to deprive any section of the country of essential transportation service."
This was no small decision. Lyndon Johnson was the last President to use the powers of the act, when machinists struck several airlines in 1966.
Invoking the act will inevitably alter the rhythms of labor negotiations at other major airlines in coming years.
But those concerns were apparently outweighed by the potential impact of a strike: according to a widely quoted study by the United States Department of Transportation, a walkout by the pilots at American would have cost the economy up to $200 million a day, and possibly stranded 43,000 travelers.
Where did these numbers come from? Before the strike deadline, the department gave the total figures to the public but not the math that produced the totals. The agency said that its economic assumptions were intended only for Federal mediators and the President.
But the report, which was obtained by The New York Times, shows that some of the Government's totals are as shaky as a fold-down tray on a commuter plane.
 
Funny Numbers
 For example, the estimate of 43,000 stranded passengers "does not reflect at least three significant factors that could mitigate the impact," the report says. Other airlines might add service in places like Miami and Dallas where American is dominant; many passengers might postpone or cancel their travel plans; and many travelers might switch their tickets to other airlines in anticipation of a strike.
So given the certainty that all these things would occur or had already happened, why was the publicized total so high?
For all the potential ripple effect of a strike -- particularly in the Caribbean, where American is the dominant carrier -- the $200 million figure also seems high.
Consider that American Airlines' own doomsday study, intended to persuade the White House to intervene, estimated that the economic impact -- touching everyone from proprietors of a dry cleaner in suburban Dallas to Chilean salmon producers to waitresses in Jamaica -- would be $83 million a day.
And for context, consider that $200 million represents the daily total of passenger revenues of the entire United States airline industry (American's market share is about 20 percent).
The Government's calculations even included the potential loss to shareholders of AMR Corporation, American's parent, who might not get a dividend this quarter in the event of a strike. Not that anyone was expecting a payout in the first place -- shareholders have not seen a dividend from the company since 1980.
"The true economic loss to society is much too small to provide an explanation for Clinton's intervention," said Clifford Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution who has written extensively about the airline industry. "It's ridiculous."
Perhaps the Transportation Department heard so few challenges to its estimates of dollars lost and passengers stranded because its figures felt right, considering the outsized attention and interest the airline industry generates.
The airline business has become a kind of national spectator sport: roughly nine major teams with distinctive uniforms and personalities that often reflect the forceful characters of their head coaches, like Robert L. Crandall, the chief executive at American.
Few businesses can offer the kind of entertaining highlight film like that of the pilots' strike chairman, Matthew Field, on CNN announcing Operation Fire at Will: "What I do now, I do without reservation or hesitation. What I do now is for the pilots of American Airlines and their families. What I do now is for all professional aviators."
And the crowd cheers when fares go on sale. Then, like true New York sports fans, travelers immediately start grumbling -- there's no real deal here, it's impossible to get through to book a flight.
This is an industry that all Americans think they understand, so they can play armchair quarterback on what's wrong with it and how to fix it.
"Once you've been a passenger, you've been knighted as a pundit," said David A. Swierenga, chief economist at the Air Transport Association, the major airlines' trade group.
Mr. Clinton has not flown on a commercial flight for some time, but he too knows something about voters' interest in the airline industry. He scored several political points in 1993, for example, by nudging American and its flight attendants to settle their dispute and get thousands of travelers home for Thanksgiving.
 
Clinton's Calculation
 He also learned an important lesson earlier that year, after he parked Air Force One on the tarmac at Los Angeles International Airport to get his hair trimmed. Although airport records later showed that not a single flight was delayed, it was widely reported at the time that several airplanes were held up as his stylist combed and clipped, turning Mr. Clinton's haircut into a public relations buzzcut.
Since then, the President has made a big effort to improve his image and his poll numbers. So even if the Transportation Department's math isn't solid, Mr. Clinton's calculations are: 9,300 American Airlines pilots versus thousands of stranded passengers and millions of armchair quarterbacks. No contest.

HEADLINE: Delay Seen In Restoring NATO Role For France

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 22

 BODY:
France said more than a year ago that it would rejoin the NATO commands it left in 1966 if the United States would concede more of them to European officers. But now the French Government is under increasing domestic pressure to stay out and will probably decide to do so this spring, many French and American officials say.
NATO diplomats and French officials said that in talks held this week with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in Paris and other European capitals, neither the United States nor France had changed its position on the main stumbling block. 
 That is President Jacques Chirac's demand that the United States give up the right to name the officer in command of Allied Forces Southern Europe in Naples, whose main asset in wartime would be the United States Sixth Fleet.
The Clinton Administration, with Congress behind it, insists that an American admiral stay in charge. It has already agreed to a NATO reorganization that would put real power into the hands of the alliance's European deputy commander, allowing Europeans to use NATO equipment and communications for military operations of their own, officials say.
On Monday, according to diplomats who were present, Mr. Chirac told Mrs. Albright that France would seek to reach a compromise with the United States by April or May, but that if no agreement could be found by then he would keep France out of the military structure, with no hard feelings. He said another effort to resolve the issue would be made again in two or three years.
"If the French don't come back in," one American official said, "the European separate defense identity they wanted will just develop within NATO without them."
Mr. Chirac's conservative Government is grappling with seemingly intractable problems. At the top of the list are unwanted immigration from former French colonies and 12.8 percent unemployment. Frustrations, combined with fear that the far-right National Front party will make strong election gains next year and anxiety about France's losing pre-eminence in Europe to Germany, have produced a new chauvinistic tone in political debate.
Many of Mr. Chirac's friends and foes alike have taken to using the kind of anti-American oratory that de Gaulle used when he took French soldiers out from under American military command 30 years ago.
The change was strikingly apparent in a parliamentary debate on a French-German defense agreement at the end of last month. Jean-Pierre Chevenement, a deputy who served as Defense Minister during the Socialist presidency of Francois Mitterrand, said dismissively of NATO:
"Whether you like it or not, it's American. Its command is American, since the Americans haven't given it up, not even in the southern European sector in Naples, despite a demand by President Chirac."
An adviser to Mr. Chirac said Friday, "Our margin of maneuver was reduced by the parliamentary debate, no question about it."
The United States holds the top post of Supreme Allied Commander for Europe in Brussels and that of Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic, in Norfolk, Va.
So, the French argue, when President Clinton and other leaders approve a reorganization at a meeting of the 16 NATO allies in Madrid in July, they should provide balance between American and European posts by giving European officers the alliance's two main land commands in Europe. These will be the one in Naples, covering the Mediterranean and the troubled Balkan region, and one for northern Europe in Brunssum, the Netherlands, covering everything else.
"The President has said that France is ready to go back into NATO," a French official close to him said, "but he can only do it if the two sides are balanced."
Some diplomats say a compromise is still possible if both leaders want one. But with more pressing issues on the agenda -- like which countries to include in NATO and how to reconcile Russia -- one NATO official said the betting was against France's rejoining this year.
