HEADLINE: The Mexican Drug Scandal

 BODY:
The arrest on drug trafficking charges of the general who led Mexico's antinarcotics program is shocking evidence of how difficult it will be to stem the flow of drugs from abroad. Just two months ago America's top drug fighter, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, praised his newly appointed Mexican counterpart, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, as a man of "unquestioned integrity." Now General Gutierrez stands accused of accepting bribes from and collaborating with leading Mexican drug traffickers. The general's reputation for integrity stemmed from his crackdowns on the drug trade while a regional commander. Now he is suspected of ignoring his favored traffickers and moving only against their competitors.
The scandal raises questions about a key premise of antidrug policy in Mexico -- namely, that its military would be more immune to corruption than the already corrupted civilian narcotics agencies. It also raises the frightening possibility that General Gutierrez, who received high-level briefings in Washington, has already disclosed strategies and secret informants to his alleged drug lord patrons. 
 President Clinton must decide, by March 1, whether to certify that Mexico and other nations are cooperating with American antidrug efforts. He can either grant full certification, deny certification or allow certification based on "vital national interests" even if antidrug cooperation is less than full. Nations that are not certified lose most forms of economic assistance (except for counternarcotics aid) and Washington must vote against loans to these nations from international institutions. Last year six countries were decertified: Myanmar, Afghanistan, Nigeria, Iran, Syria and Colombia.
Mexican authorities moved with admirable swiftness to arrest General Gutierrez. But his arrest is yet more evidence that corruption is affecting even top-level Mexican drug officials and thus preventing Mexico from cooperating fully with the fight against cocaine. An honest assessment would lead President Clinton to withhold full certification from Mexico but grant instead a waiver on "vital national interest" grounds. That would acknowledge Mexico's less-than-full cooperation in the fight against drugs while continuing to recognize Mexico as an important ally whose economic health matters deeply to the United States.

HEADLINE: Rewards and Penalties Vary in States' Welfare Programs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Exercising the vast discretion given to them under the new welfare law, many states are adopting stricter work requirements and shorter time limits than Congress envisioned for public assistance.
But some states temper their stringent policies, allowing exemptions for parents who cannot find jobs or who are caring for disabled relatives. 
 Six months after President Clinton signed the welfare law, 40 governors have submitted state welfare plans to the Federal Government, and the Department of Health and Human Services has certified 37. Those states are allowed to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money that are, in many cases, greater than what the states would have received under the old welfare law.
States are, as Congress expected, going off in different directions, with different combinations of penalties and rewards. Some are using welfare money to subsidize wages or to pay housing and other expenses to help people get through crises so they can avoid welfare.
Some states encourage work by penalizing those who refuse to cooperate. Indiana has sharply increased the use of such penalties, which typically cut welfare checks by $90 a month.
Other states treat earned income in a new, more generous way, to make sure people are better off working than on welfare. In Pennsylvania, for example, a family of a mother and two children is now forced off welfare when the woman earns more than $10,300 a year. But under a policy effective next month, the ceiling will be raised to $14,100.
The 10 states that have not submitted their welfare plans are still working out details, often in negotiation between governors and state legislators. July 1 is the deadline for them to submit their plans to the Federal Government.
At first, state welfare programs look like a crazy quilt. But separate reviews of state plans by the Federal Government, the National Governors' Association and The New York Times disclose some patterns.
TIME LIMITS Eighteen states -- 45 percent of those that have filed plans -- set time limits on welfare stricter than the five-year lifetime limit authorized by the Federal law. Twenty-two states plan to enforce the five-year limit.
Indiana and North Carolina have two-year limits. In North Carolina, people reaching the limit may reapply for benefits after three years off welfare. Montana has a two-year limit for single parents. Louisiana will pay welfare for no more than two years in any five-year period. Utah has a three-year limit. Connecticut has a 21-month limit, but makes exceptions and grants extensions in some cases -- if, for example, a person is caring for an incapacitated child or spouse.
WORK REQUIREMENTS The Federal law requires adults to work within two years of receiving cash assistance, but 16 states, or 40 percent of those filing plans, have adopted more stringent work requirements. Twenty-four states intend to use the two-year work requirement.
Some states, including Florida, Tennessee and Texas, say that adult welfare recipients are expected to go to work immediately. Massachusetts requires work within two months. Virginia requires work in three months.
Michigan reduces welfare benefits by 25 percent if people do not meet work requirements within two months. In North Carolina, welfare recipients must obtain jobs or participate in job training within three months, or their benefits will be cut. Many states want to define "work" more broadly than Congress, so they can give credit for job-search activities or literacy classes.
INTERSTATE MIGRANTS At least nine states say they will treat new arrivals differently from longtime residents. Thus, families who have moved into one state from another may receive lower benefits or may be required to go through a waiting period.
If, for example, a family moves to New York from a state that pays lower welfare benefits, New York wants to pay that family the smaller amount it would have received in the other state for one year. Pennsylvania and Maryland have the same policy.
Florida allows people to receive welfare for two years in any five-year period, with a lifetime limit of five years' cash assistance. But if a family moves to Florida from a state with stricter time limits, Florida enforces the shorter limits.
The new welfare law permits such differential treatment, even though Supreme Court decisions dating back to 1969 suggest that it might be unconstitutional. The Court has expressed concern that such arrangements deny equal protection of the laws to some people or interfere with the "freedom to travel."
FAMILY CAP At least 19 of the 40 states that have filed welfare plans say they will not increase payments for women who have additional children while receiving public assistance. For decades, states have routinely provided more money to larger families. But in recent years, some states have ended such automatic increases, on the theory that they create an economic incentive for parents to have more children whom they cannot support.
DRUG TESTING Only two states, New York and Ohio, said they would test welfare recipients to see if they had been using illegal drugs. Thirty states said they would not require such testing. The other states have not made a decision or did not address the issue in their state plans. Several studies suggest that 20 percent to 25 percent of welfare recipients abuse drugs or alcohol in ways that may impair their ability to get and hold jobs. But experts say that drug testing is not necessarily the best way to identify those people.
Terrance M. McGrath, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Social Services, said state officials wanted to test all people applying for welfare.
"Our No. 1 priority is to get people off welfare and into jobs," Mr. McGrath said. "They won't be able to do that if they have a drug problem. Welfare money should not be used to finance the purchase of drugs. Under our plan, people who test positive would be required to go into a drug rehabilitation program."
Jacqueline A. Romer-Sensky, deputy chief of staff to Gov. George V. Voinovich of Ohio, said: "We screen pregnant women for drugs. It's not punitive. It's part of a larger effort to make sure that babies are born drug-free."
DRUG FELONS At least 20 states say they plan to deny welfare to people convicted of felonies involving the possession, use or distribution of narcotics. So far only Oregon has indicated that it wants to allow people convicted of such crimes to receive cash assistance. The other states have not made decisions or have not addressed the issue in their plans.
Under the new law, people convicted of drug crimes are generally ineligible for Federal welfare benefits, but states may override the ban by passing laws.
Jean I. Thorne, the Federal policy coordinator for Gov. John A. Kitzhaber of Oregon, a Democrat, said: "If you are a drug-related felon with a couple of kids, we want you to get drug and alcohol treatment so you can go back to work and be self-sufficient. It's a good use of money."
Brian C. McNeil, a policy adviser to Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona, a Republican, said: "The Governor is tough on drugs. But there is no reasonably efficient way to verify statements of people applying for welfare when they say they have not been convicted of drug crimes. If you're not going to verify the statements, then inquiring about a person's drug history is a questionable use of time."
IMMIGRANTS A surprisingly large number of states -- 36 of the 40 filing state plans -- said they would continue providing cash welfare benefits to impoverished legal immigrants who have not become citizens but were in the United States before Aug. 22, when President Clinton signed the welfare bill. Only Alabama, South Carolina and Wyoming said they would not provide benefits to immigrants already in the country. Those who arrive on or after Aug. 22 are generally ineligible for Federal welfare benefits for five years.
SUBSIDIZED EMPLOYMENT Twenty-seven states said they would subsidize jobs for welfare recipients. Typically, states take a portion of the money earmarked for welfare benefits or food stamps and give it to employers, who in turn pay wages to the welfare recipients.
Nineteen states, including New York and North Carolina, will make occasional payments to low-income families so they can cope with temporary setbacks and stay off welfare. People who are unexpectedly laid off or suffer brief illnesses may be eligible for such emergency grants.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Boone Would Rather See Any Team but His Royals Finish in Last Place

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: HAINES CITY, Fla.

 BODY:
Bob Boone will obviously win no humanitarian award this year. Gene Lamont will certainly not vote for him.
Boone, the Kansas City manager, suffered through the first last-place finish in the Royals' 28-year history last season, and it seemed that he might feel for Lamont, a fellow former catcher, who has the task of steering the Pittsburgh Pirates through what is destined to be an arduous season. 
 But no.
"Not one ounce," Boone said. "I've been through it. I understand it. I don't feel for him. I don't feel for him at all. For one thing, there's no pressure on him. No, I do not. I wish I could play him every day and beat his brains out. That's the way I feel about it."
It's nothing personal, you understand.
"Maybe if I wasn't in this position, I could have some compassion," Boone went on. "It's just that you're trained. That's what you do. I want to win, 10 to nothing, every day. I want to laugh at you every day. I'm not going to feel sorry for you that you can't beat my team. I want to dominate you every day and not feel sorry for you one bit.
"I can't take Gene Lamont out of that at all. If I had any of those feelings, it might have been toward Buddy Bell. At the start of last year he had no chance every day because of the pitching. So if there's any compassion I ever had, it was for Buddy Bell. But I didn't spend much time dwelling on it or thinking about it."
Well, so much for shared feeling.
The Royals, having added Chili Davis as their designated hitter and Jeff King and Jay Bell as half of their infield, have a better feeling about themselves this season. Boone even looks forward to using fewer lineups than the major league-leading 152 he wrote on lineup cards last season. It was a shuffling act that gained him much criticism.
"It was a real fun topic in Kansas City," the third-year manager said. "To say there was criticism is being kind."
In his defense, Boone pointed to the Yankees' frequently changing lineup. Joe Torre used 131 different lineups, second most in the league and, Boone said, "was pretty successful." Boone also rejected the idea that he enjoyed having different lineups, as if he woke up every morning gleefully asking himself what new alignment he could concoct today.
"Not true," he said. "Your team dictates what you do. I want a set lineup. I want to be able to write it down. I'd love to have Earl Weaver's teams. I don't have to do anything. We're going to play for three-run homers. I love that thought. But if you can't hit a three-run homer, you're going to do a lot of waiting around."
Last season, the Royals scored the fewest runs, hit the fewest home runs and amassed the fewest total bases in the American League. It was the absence of a couple of big hitters that forced Boone to put different names on different lines of the lineup card every day.
"I had no middle of the lineup that said, 'You play me in the middle of the lineup every day because I'm one of your best hitters and we're going to win,' " Boone said. "So my everyday challenge was to hook up who I thought were the best hitters against their pitcher for that day."
The second basic reason for the constant changes, he explained, was that when a team is in a development mode, as the Royals were, playing time is not necessarily dictated by what players deserve.
"I had players playing because it was their turn," Boone said. "When you develop, that's what you have to do. You close your eyes to what they're doing because you know they need X number of at-bats no matter what they did. It's kind of foreign to what I know as major league baseball, but we had sold this development package to our fans and we were on that course."
Boone had to learn what his young players were capable of doing and often placed them not only in different spots in the lineup, but also at different positions on the field. Craig Paquette, for example, started at first, short, third and left and batted third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh and ninth. Jose Offerman started at first, second and short and batted first, third, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth.
"A lot of it was experimentation," Boone said. "The other point was I was trying to make 12 or 13 guys think they were playing every day. I needed them to say, 'Boy, I had a full year; I played every day.' When you're trying to make 13 guys regulars on your team and you have only 9 spots, you're going to have a lot of different lineups."
Boone looks forward to having a more stable setup this season.
"King and Davis will be in the middle," he said. "Bell will be in there every day somewhere, Offerman everyday at second. Paquette's going to get a chance at third. Bip Roberts will be in left."
And maybe one day Earl Weaver will spiritually sit in the dugout.
 
A Boost for Baerga
 On the same day Carlos Baerga was at the Mets' camp in Port St. Lucie talking about his decision to quit drinking and change his life style, Mike Hargrove was across the state in Winter Haven responding to a question about Baerga's decline with Cleveland last season.
"Carlos is a good guy, a good person; I like him," the Indians manager said. "He's a good player. He's a leader. He cares about his teammates. I just felt Carlos got caught up in the extras around the game. He lost sight of his priorities. That comes out sounding like he's out doing drugs or chasing women or partying. I don't mean that.
"He liked to entertain people and have a lot of people around him all the time after the games. He'd go out and stay out late. His priorities got screwy and he couldn't get it back. He lost his focus. He quit working. We tried to get him to take ground balls, 50 ground balls a day, and he'd take 30. That sort of thing."
Told of Hargrove's assessment, the Mets' second baseman didn't duck any of it.
"I got a lot of friends," he said. "They come with me, and I also have my family and I like to go out and have a good time. But I always respect my teammates. I know that I have to work hard the next day to do my job and I give thanks to him."
Hargrove said that he expected Baerga to have a "huge year" this season and that he would be disappointed if Baerga didn't.
Baerga said he appreciated Hargrove for publicly saying he didn't have a drug problem. The whispers had already begun.
 
Arbitration Inflation
 In 1974, Richard Moss, then the Players Association's general counsel, argued the first salary arbitration case ever and won a $30,000 salary for Dick Woodson, a pitcher for the Minnesota Twins, who wanted to pay him $22,000. Last week, Moss presented the only winning case on the players' side in this year's arbitration hearings, gaining a $2.5 million salary for Tim Wakefield over Boston's bid for $1.55 million.
 
In Salary Race, Bonds by a Nose
 The negotiations that produced a record contract for Barry Bonds of San Francisco could have been completed earlier except for the goal of Bonds and his agent, Dennis Gilbert.
"They had one objective in this negotiation," said a person familiar with the negotiations. "Get Bonds's average annual value over Belle's. They wrangled for a week or two over it."
Playing "Can You Top This?" Albert Belle signed last November for $11 million a year. Bonds's two-year extension with an option for a third year in 2001 has been portrayed as a $22.9 million deal, or $11.45 million a year. It's not worth that much because $1.4 million is deferred in each of the two years without interest, but it still beats Belle. Bonds and Gilbert made sure of that.
With $1.4 million from 1999 to be paid June 30, 2002, and the $1.4 million from 2000 to be paid June 30, 2003, the current value of the package produces an annual average of $11,131,057.
Ken Griffey Jr. of Seattle is generally considered No. 3 on the list now, but deferred money without interest reduces the current value of his contract to an annual average of $8,228,307. The real No. 3 is Pat Hentgen of Toronto, the American League Cy Young Award winner, who two months ago signed an extension for 1999 that guarantees him an additional $8.5 million.

HEADLINE: Mayor's Campaign Selects Its New Face;
A Tough Deputy Switches Modes From Negotiation to Re-Election

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
By Thursday, less than 24 hours after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had transformed Fran Reiter from his blunt, driven Deputy Mayor into his blunt, driven campaign manager, the physical changes were already evident.
The severe, dark power suits were gone, as was the vague sense of siege that sometimes trailed her through City Hall. Instead, having been released into the informal, open-collar world of pure politics, she was wearing a sunny yellow sweater and black slacks, and was actually laughing and telling funny stories. 
 "I'm in campaign mode now," she explained.
In truth, Fran Reiter is almost always in campaign mode. As the Mayor's lead negotiator with business leaders and neighborhood groups over the last three years, she has embodied the administration's bulldozer style of conquest, criticizing and even withering opponents at times, compromising when necessary, tirelessly promoting her boss's agenda at every opportunity.
Now the woman whose negotiating skills have led many business people to call her the administration's brightest star, is poised to become "the face" of the Giuliani re-election campaign, in the words of her mentor, Raymond B. Harding.
"I now refer to her as the face of the campaign, the main political spokesperson for the duration of the campaign," said Mr. Harding, the Mayor's closest political adviser and the leader of the state's Liberal Party, to which Ms. Reiter has devoted much of her adult life. "That's the face we want to put on television."
And it doesn't hurt that the face happens to be that of a woman, particularly if Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, ends up as the Democratic nominee for Mayor after the September primary.
Ms. Reiter, however, will be only too pleased to blast away at whichever candidate emerges from the primary, male or female. Though the task will clearly be easier than it was in 1993, the job of managing the Mayor's campaign seems to fulfill a hunger within her to return to the world of full-blown politics, to which she is most accustomed. At 43, Ms. Reiter has come a long way from the day in 1982 when she joined the New York State Liberal Party because she considered the Democratic Party both too conservative and too indolent. (Family ties also played a role.) She remains no less committed, though, to the idea of a practical, muscular politics -- a method of getting things done far more important to her than ideology.
"There's a certain pragmatic streak in the Liberal Party that I love, and it goes side by side with its ideals," she said in an interview, explaining her devotion to the tiny party that has helped Mr. Giuliani appear more than a Republican and her something less than a dogmatic liberal. "I think we're a force for getting stuff done, for supporting candidates who want to make things happen."
Just minutes after her appointment on Wednesday, in fact, she had already assumed her post on the steps of City Hall on behalf of one such candidate. Arms folded, head tilted back, she unleashed for the cameras a stream of sarcasm directed at the four Democratic challengers to Mr. Giuliani who had appeared at a forum that morning. Each of them, she noted with distaste, had agreed to support the Rev. Al Sharpton if he won the September primary.
That moment on the steps was but the first of innumerable appearances Ms. Reiter will be making in place of the Mayor as his re-election drive begins to accelerate in the months to come. Though Mr. Giuliani's political advisers have been trying, not always with success, to rein in his own personal attacks on his opponents and make him appear more mayoral, Ms. Reiter will be under no such constraints.
Ms. Reiter is in no danger of being described as more diplomatic than her boss, but attacks on Ms. Messinger or the other candidates might sound less vicious coming from a woman, particularly among the key bloc of female swing voters.
"I don't see myself as a woman Deputy Mayor or a woman campaign manager," Ms. Reiter said. "But how will the rest of the world see it? You know, I'd be lying if I said it wouldn't be helpful for someone like me to be supporting Rudy Giuliani. Of course it's going to be helpful."
In 1992, in fact, Ms. Reiter performed a similar role for Robert Abrams, the former State Attorney General who was in a tight race for the Democratic nomination against two prominent women, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Elizabeth Holtzman. The Liberal Party, of which she was then the chairwoman, had decided to back Mr. Abrams, and Ms. Reiter was enlisted to persuade Democratic women to consider a man.
"If you're a male candidate with a macho image, it can often be misinterpreted by the public that you're beating up on a woman opponent," said Ethan Geto, Mr. Abrams's campaign manager and now a top city lobbyist. "Fran was a very impassioned speaker and helped to diffuse that political perception. In fact, she was our No. 1 choice after Mrs. Abrams as a surrogate speaker for the candidate." Mr. Abrams won the primary, but lost the general election to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Before the Giuliani campaign, she had never before worked for a Republican. In 1990, she even ran (heatedly, but quite unsuccessfully) against a moderate Republican very much in the ideological mold of Rudolph Giuliani: Bill Green, the former Upper East Side Congressman whom Mr. Giuliani later appointed to the city's Campaign Finance Board. But she sees no contradiction in her current advocacy for a Republican Mayor who is proud of spreading himself across the ideological spectrum, advocating at once immigrant rights, abortion rights, the death penalty and a rigorous workfare program.
"I don't think I've changed," she said. "Ideologically I'm still a left-of-center person. But I define my liberalism in much more traditional American liberal terms. I'm much more a Roosevelt-Humphrey type liberal than what we tend to refer to as liberalism here in New York, which I think is a 1960's aberration."
Ms. Reiter was reared in a family of Democrats in a building her grandfather built in 1928 at Second Avenue and 11th Street. (The effects of growing up on what was once the Rialto of Yiddish theater are still evident from the embroidered "oy vey" pillow on her desk, a sentiment that will presumably still apply to the campaign.) She still lives by herself there in an apartment not far from her mother's, elsewhere in the building; her brother, Jonathan, first vice chairman of the Liberal Party, lives a few blocks away. After studying directing at Boston University, she worked in a variety of theater jobs, but eventually became successful at marketing syndicated television shows, including movie packages, sports specials and even women's wrestling.
She had been drawn to the "libs" after her mother got a job with the party as an office manager in 1980. Jimmy Carter, Fran Reiter believed, was too conservative; the local Democrats resembled a "1960's radicalism" that she considered ineffective and out of touch. When Mr. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, selected a brash Federal prosecutor as the party's mayoral candidate in 1989, she decided she, too, admired Rudolph Giuliani's intelligence and sense of independence, and became head of the Women's Coalition for Giuliani.
"The evolution of Fran's political career has very much tracked that of the Liberal Party," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat who has been friends with Ms. Reiter for about 15 years, but who is not a supporter of Mr. Giuliani. "I don't think anyone would really say that Giuliani represented the historical position of the party, but they made a calculated decision about supporting him. And Fran rode that wave, and has performed very well in doing so."
By 1993, she was deputy campaign manager, overseeing the 34 field offices and serving as an adviser on women's and gay and lesbian issues. Though Carl F. Grillo, another Liberal Party ally (who died last December), actually directed the crucial get-out-the-vote effort, the Mayor and his confidants were impressed by Ms. Reiter's forcefulness and her organizational ability. After the inauguration, she was named Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations, the chief land-use and community liaison post; last April, she gave up community relations and took over the economic development portfolio.
She still bristles at suggestions from critics that she was installed in the job by Mr. Harding as a reward for the crucial support of the Liberal Party. Two of Mr. Harding's sons were also hired by Mr. Giuliani in important posts; Mr. Harding himself has recently been under fire for prospering as a lobbyist of city agencies while advising the Mayor on political issues.
"It is demeaning and it is annoying, but it is the world I live in," she said. "The only way you counter that is you do a good job, and you try not to get too crazy about it."
Having learned the art of negotiation from haggling with television stations, Ms. Reiter brought to her job a willingness to deal that impressed many of the developers, business leaders and community organizations she dealt with. Comfortable with power, she would come to the table with a hard line and then be prepared to back off a bit from it.
One business official who has sat across from her at the table described her as occasionally "slippery," willing to recast oral agreements that had been made in earlier meetings for an advantage. She can be bellicose and even rude with adversaries -- as she was with Time Warner Cable in the fight to get the Fox News Network a channel -- but most negotiators who have worked with her used words like "smart," "cocky" and "aggressive" in admiring terms.
Even Ms. Messinger describes her as "occasionally the only person in the administration you could reach out to and reason with on a community issue."
She lost the most important economic development initiative of her tenure when the City Council refused to go along with a plan to allow more superstores in the city. But she also won praise for pushing through a plan to bring new businesses and residents to the Wall Street area, and seemed likely to continue in her role until Peter J. Powers, the Mayor's oldest friend, decided he didn't want to reprise his role as campaign manager. (He will stay on as campaign chairman, providing strategic advice. Randy Levine, former labor commissioner, is one of several candidates being considered to replace Ms. Reiter.)
Ms. Reiter's intense loyalty and political mind-set made her a logical choice to run the day-to-day operations of the campaign, a decision she and Mr. Harding say was made solely by the Mayor based on her record.
"I've done a pretty damn good job as Deputy Mayor, and I'm prepared to let the record speak for itself," she says in characteristic fashion. "Which is more than I can say about the Democrats running for mayor."

HEADLINE: Florio Decides He Won't Run For Governor

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Ending months of speculation that he wanted his old job back, former Gov. Jim Florio said today that he would not seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination but that he would do all that he could to defeat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in November.
Mr. Florio said in an interview that he had given serious consideration to a rematch with Mrs. Whitman because he had believed that his fellow New Jersey Democrats were not making a strong enough case against Whitman administration policies, which he said threaten the state's economic future. 
 But after watching the field of six potential Democratic challengers over the last couple of months, and meeting with them privately during the last two weeks, Mr. Florio said he is now convinced that the other candidates can successfully draw attention to the long-term problems that he believes Governor Whitman's policies have created. He said he can be more effective by stepping aside and lending his support to one candidate, Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from Camden County, who he said would be able to wage the most aggressive campaign.
"Without exception, all of them are good people," Mr. Florio said of the field of contenders. "They are smart people. They are attractive people. I am enthusiastic about the energy that some of the candidates have. But what you need is all of those things and a commitment to be extremely aggressive about highlighting the differences between the Whitman administration and what I hope would be the consensus policies of the Democratic nominee and the Democratic party. I am now convinced that candidate is Rob Andrews."
Although Mr. Florio had never publicly declared his intention to challenge Mrs. Whitman, he did not dismiss a possible campaign until today. The prospect of a Whitman-Florio rematch had been the subject of much talk and concern in New Jersey Democratic circles. Democrats, who lost control of the State Legislature and hundreds of municipal and county seats after Mr. Florio pushed through a $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990, feared that a rematch would revive voter anger over the tax hikes at a time when they were seeking to rebuild the party and field the next generation of Democrats.
There was not a trace of ambivalence in Mr. Florio's voice as he described his decision to withdraw from the race and throw his support behind Mr. Andrews, who took over the Congressional seat that Mr. Florio left in 1989 to become Governor. "I am very comfortable and assured to have somebody who can carry a good message," he said.
Mr. Andrews will benefit not only from Mr. Florio's continued popularity among rank-and-file Democratic voters but also because he no longer has to worry about sharing the same political base in south Jersey with Mr. Florio.
In an interview, Mr. Andrews said that he welcomed Mr. Florio's support. "I'm obviously delighted and honored," Mr. Andrews said.
Mr. Andrews said he also believed that Mr. Florio's decision increased the chances of unifying the state Democratic party. "I believe that we will have a unified party very soon, and get on to the business of pointing out the reasons why Governor Whitman should be denied a second term," he said.
A poll by Quinnipiac College, published last week, showed that Mr. Florio, with his statewide name recognition, could have easily won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in June, but that Mrs. Whitman would trounce him in November.
Now that Mr. Florio has withdrawn from the race, Mr. Andrews, who is 39, and State Senator James E. McGreevey, 37, a Democrat from Middlesex County who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, are considered the front-runners in race for the Democratic nomination.
Mr. McGreevey praised Mr. Florio, saying that he deserves enormous respect, but he dismissed the former Governor's assertion that Mr. Andrews would make a stronger case against Governor Whitman than he would. He also said his background as a mayor, rather than as a member of Congress, would make him a more effective governor.
"Mr. Andrews and Governor Florio are both from Camden County and shared the same Congressional district," he said. "As a mayor, your results are measured on a day-by-day basis. It is not casting a particular vote. It is by delivering a product, which is more relevant to the challenges in the Governor's office."
Other Democrats who have declared candidacies include Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive; Susan Bass Levin, the Mayor of Cherry Hill; Michael Murphy, a former Morris County Prosecutor and George Zoffinger, a former State Commerce Commissioner.
Since the Democratic candidates all lack experience in a statewide campaign and are little known outside of their home counties, they share the problem of building name recognition among voters.
"We are all essentially known in our own area and not beyond. This makes it a very hot, even contest," Mr. Janiszewski said.
Mrs. Whitman, who was unavailable for comment today because she was in California, finishing a four-day trip to raise more than $100,000 in campaign funds for the New Jersey Republican Committee, has said she would relish a rematch with Mr. Florio so she could compare her record of cutting taxes with his tax increases.
Mrs. Whitman narrowly defeated Mr. Florio after a bitter campaign in 1993. Close friends and associates of Mr. Florio said they believed he had wanted to challenge her this year to vindicate his policies. But Mr. Florio insists he was motivated by his concern that Mrs. Whitman's fiscal policies -- along with her approach to the environment, property taxes and the public schools -- were creating long-term problems for the state. In the next economic downturn, he said, New Jersey will be without the resources needed to get through difficult times because of the Governor's policies of the last three years.
"The policies of this administration are nothing less than irresponsible," Mr. Florio said. "But to this point, none of this stuff has pierced through the clutter of public discussion. It is going to take a Herculean effort to mix passion, force and knowledge of the substance of the issues to uncloak what has been done. I am confident that the message will get across."
But does this mean that Mr. Florio will be stepping out of the public eye and retiring from politics forever? "I am not going away," he said.

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS SHOW SOME FLEXIBILITY ON CAPITAL GAINS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
After years of deriding any cuts in the capital-gains tax as a handout to country club Republicans, Democrats in Congress have softened their opposition and, in some cases, have come to support a reduction in the tax, increasing the likelihood of a compromise this year on the often bitter partisan dispute.
Democrats said the change had been driven to some degree by the stunning rise in the stock market, which has left many small, middle-class investors sitting on big gains and interested in minimizing their tax bills if they sell shares. 
 But the political dynamic of the issue has been most changed by increasing complaints about the tax from farmers and the owners of small businesses, powerful constituencies. Those voters have received a far more sympathetic hearing from Democratic lawmakers than have the Wall Street securities firms and other traditional proponents of reducing the tax on profits from the sale of stocks, bonds, real estate and other property and investments.
"This issue has moved from the country clubs and the boardrooms to the barrooms of middle America," said Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a leading Democratic proponent of capital-gains cuts, whose view would be disputed by his more liberal colleagues.
Important differences still hinder a compromise. Most Republicans want to slash the top capital-gains rate of 28 percent on all profits, arguing that such a reduction would unleash new investment and create jobs and economic growth. Democrats tend to favor narrower and far less costly proposals aimed specifically at small-business owners, farmers and homeowners.
Still, because a compromise will be essential to efforts by the Clinton Administration and the Republican-controlled Congress to reach agreement on balancing the Federal budget, members of both parties said that enough common ground existed on the issue to reach a deal.
"There has been a significant evolution of Democratic thinking on capital gains," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California and a member of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee who has introduced a proposal aimed at helping small businesses. "Generally speaking, many Democrats would be flexible, and some would consider moving to a broader-based approach."
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, one of the few Democrats to support a Republican proposal for an across-the-board reduction in the maximum rate, to 19.8 percent, said that only a handful of his Democratic colleagues would be willing to vote with him today. "But you're now talking about positions along a spectrum, rather than saying, 'No way; this can never happen,' " Mr. Lieberman said.
Part of the reason that Democrats in Congress appear more flexible is that President Clinton, who has never taken a strong ideological position on the issue, has made clear that he is willing to use capital gains as a bargaining chip in the negotiations over a balanced budget. Without any firm sense of where the White House will draw a line, Democrats said more of their colleagues were interested in staking out a middle-of-the-road position.
Republicans say no budget deal is possible without broad capital-gains relief, although it is unclear what tradeoffs they are willing to make between capital gains and their other tax proposals, including a credit for families with children.
The White House has been vague about how far it might go. But the Administration has said that the $33 billion in capital-gains reductions the Republican leadership wanted over the next five years would require spending cuts unacceptable to Democrats and that if the Republicans wanted an agreement, they would have to scale back their demands.
As an opening offer, the White House has proposed exempting from capital-gains taxes as much as $500,000 in profits from the sale of a home, a step that it estimates would cost $1.4 billion over five years.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said, "Tax cuts that are much higher than the President's proposals would require us to make program reductions that would unduly harm our economy and society."
The arguments about the economic effects of cutting the tax have hardened over the years into articles of faith. Conservatives are adamant that a deep reduction would unshackle the nation's entrepreneurial strengths and maybe even pay for itself through increased growth. Liberals reel off statistics about how half of capital gains accrue to the wealthiest 1 percent of the population, making the issue one of basic fairness, and of cost.
Those ideological differences, as well as raw political calculation, kept the two parties at loggerheads from the mid-1980's through the end of President George Bush's term. The harder Mr. Bush pushed for a reduction, the more determined the Congress, then controlled by Democrats, was to deny him a victory.
Senate Democrats are showing signs of changing that unyielding position. During the late 80's and early 90's, the Democratic leader in the Senate, George Mitchell of Maine, was an implacable foe of reducing the tax. Among the plans offered by Democrats this year are two by leaders in the Senate.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, is pushing a plan that would help farmers, owners of small businesses and homeowners by expanding on a narrow capital-gains measure that Congress approved in 1993 as part of a bill that raised taxes over all.
Mr. Daschle, who represents a farm state, is pushing hard for a provision that would allow farmers to exempt $400,000 in profits from the sale of land if they rolled the money into a pension savings account. The provision, aides said, is intended to address farmers' complaints that the current policy discourages them from selling their land.
Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, the chief Democratic whip, has made an innovative proposal that would set the maximum rate based on how long the taxpayer had owned the asset. The profits from any asset held more than two years would be taxed at 26 percent, with the rate declining two percentage points for each additional year of ownership, down to 14 percent for assets owned eight years or longer.
The proposal would reward long-term investors, making it less susceptible to criticism that it would reward Wall Street investors, some Democrats said. Mr. Ford said it would be far less costly than the Republican proposals, probably costing $10 billion over five years.
Like many Democrats, Mr. Ford said his thinking had been heavily influenced by what he had heard from owners of small businesses and farmers; many have complained that although they need the cash, they have been reluctant to sell their assets as they grew older because of the big tax bills they would face.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "AT A GLANCE: 4 Proposals for Changing Capital Gains"
 
CURRENT LAW -- The maximum rate is 28 percent for individuals. Taxpayers over 55 can get a onetime exclusion of gains up to $125,000 on the sale of a home. Individuals can get a 50 percent exclusion on the sale of certain investments in small businesses with assets of less than $50 million if the investments are held for at least five years.
 
CLINTON ADMINISTRATION -- Would retain 28 percent top rate. Would allow married taxpayers to exclude up to $500,000 in profits on the sale of a home ($250,000 for single taxpayers) with no age restriction. Would change the way profits on the sale of securities are calculated, effectively increasing the tax on many transactions, and would close a loophole used by big investors to avoid capital gains taxes.
 
REPUBLICAN LEADERSHIP -- Would reduce maximum rate for individuals to 19.8 percent and would allow investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating the gain on assets owned for three years or more. Would reduce the maximum rate for gains on investment in many small businesses to 14 percent.
 
SENATOR TOM DASCHLE -- Democrat of South Dakota. Would keep 28 percent top rate. Would allow exclusion of up to $500,000 profit on sale of home for married taxpayers ($250,000 for single taxpayers). Would double, to $100 million, the asset size of a small business that would qualify for the current 50 percent exclusion.
 
SENATOR WENDELL H. FORD -- Democrat of Kentucky. Would reduce top rate on a sliding scale based on how long an asset was held. After two years, the top rate would drop to 26 percent, and it would drop two percentage points for each additional year of ownership. The scale would bottom out at 14 percent for assets held eight years or more. The plan would not distinguish between types of assets but would reward longer-term investment.

HEADLINE: China's Rulers Face Key Test: Power of Army

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 22

 BODY:
On the seventh day after he took up the title of Commander in Chief of China's armed forces in November 1989, President Jiang Zemin went to the far western province of Xinjiang to inspect a frigid frontier post. He demanded to know why the soldiers were sleeping with only one blanket. "Aren't they cold at night?" he asked.
There in the barracks, like George Washington looking after the men of Valley Forge, he admonished the officers, "Our cadres must care for each and every soldier and be concerned with their welfare." 
 Every few months over the last five years, China's state-run propaganda apparatus has added a new page to the legend of Mr. Jiang's "paternal care" for China's soldiers. Once, when 1,000 sailors lined up for review on the deck of a ship in the scorching sun, Mr. Jiang was reported to have seen the sweat running down their faces and "quickened his steps" so they could stand down. And in 1995, he climbed 77 stairs -- someone actually counted them -- to meet sentries on the Russian border, even though it was raining and his clothes were soaked through.
For more than 47 years after the Communists came to power in 1949, China had been governed by men who had been military and political commanders. But unlike Mao and Deng Xiaoping before him, Mr. Jiang has no military background, he did not fight in the Communist revolution and he has never worn the uniform of the People's Liberation Army, which remains the most powerful and enduring institution.
Of all the issues facing China's younger leaders after the death of Mr. Deng on Wednesday, none are more critical than political control over China's vast military, whose scientists gave China the atomic bomb and whose soldiers defeated Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists and fought the United States to a standstill on the Korean Peninsula. Today, the military has its own representative at the inner sanctum of the ruling Politburo and takes part in all important political and foreign-policy decisions.
Thus, Mr. Jiang's success in becoming the pre-eminent leader in the coming years hinges on his ability to dominate this all-important institution. It is not yet clear that he can.
Despite the extensive image-building that Mr. Jiang's publicists have salted through the Chinese press organizations in recent years, there remain fundamental concerns among Chinese and Western officials about whether Mr. Jiang will be able to withstand rising pressure to finance ever-larger military budgets even while the civilian economy is straining for budget resources. And there are concerns whether he can walk China back from the aggressive posture it took toward Taiwan in 1995-96 in advance of the island's first direct presidential election.
And most important, if Mr. Jiang proves unable to match Mr. Deng's success in charting a course of growth and prosperity for the Chinese people, he risks internal deadlock and civil strife that could prompt a military intervention into China's internal politics and threaten his political survival.

Military's Status As Final Arbiter
 It would not be the first time the military stepped in.
In 1971, Mao's most favored military leader, Lin Biao, drew the armed forces into a failed plot to overthrow Mao's rule. In 1976, after Mao's death, the military conspired with Mao's palace guards to arrest the so-called Gang of Four, including Mao's wife, to end an era of radical politics. Mr. Deng was rescued from house arrest by Marshal Ye Jianying in early 1977 and, in 1989, he summoned the military to crush the pro-democracy revolt centered at Tiananmen Square, thus saving civilian leaders from an incipient rebellion.
"In the end, you have to say that the Chinese military is the final arbiter of Chinese politics," said David M. Lampton, a China scholar who frequently accompanies American military and civilian leaders to China as director of the National Council of United States-China Relations.
When Mr. Deng died last week, he bequeathed to Mr. Jiang unrivaled control of the world's largest standing army, whose antiquated weapons and equipment are in the midst of a costly modernization and whose nuclear arsenal is the size of France's.
Former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger, who held discussions with Chinese military leaders last fall, said Mr. Jiang "can never satisfy the demand" in the military for "more rapid modernization" and will have to struggle to balance the pressure from his uniformed chiefs with countervailing pressures from provincial leaders to concentrate on developing the civilian economy, which was Mr. Deng's priority.
Some of the more nationalistic military leaders he must control would like to disrupt the structure of security alliances that the United States erected in the Pacific, particularly with Japan and South Korea, during the cold war. Among many of these officers, "There is a certain sense that he is not a national leader, or that he has no presence as a national leader," as one longtime military observer here put it.
But intervention is not a role that the Chinese military relishes, Mr. Lampton said.
Jonathan Pollack, a China specialist at the Rand Corporation in California, said, "If you look back at history, every time the military leaders let themselves get sucked in, they got burned, whether it was with Lin Biao or at Tiananmen."
"I think that most of their senior officers would rather be pliant servants of the state or exercising authority in their own domain," he said, "instead of being the fundamental broker" of power and policy.
Mr. Pollack's remarks reflect a broad assessment today of China's military leaders, and their relationship to the new generation of post-Deng leaders. "Jiang Zemin will not be subject to a major challenge provided there is no major screw up," said Mr. Pollack, "but if something goes awry, that's where he will be subject to political challenge and the situation will become more complex. The tradition of the P.L.A. is that they get involved when things go awry, and that means they play a role that others can't and so their intervention can only severely diminish Jiang's authority."

Plans to Ease Out Two Old Warriors
 For this reason, perhaps, Mr. Jiang has seemed anxious to make over the top of the military.
He has spent more time inspecting troops in the field and pinning medals on generals than any of his predecessors, and he has purged or retired all of the top officers who were appointed by his rivals, the former President Yang Shangkun and his half-brother Yang Baibing, who were forced out of their military leadership posts by Mr. Deng in 1992.
Mr. Jiang's officer corps is characterized by younger, more professional military technocrats. But to more fully consolidate his power, Mr. Jiang must secure the retirement of the two most senior military men Mr. Deng put in place five years ago, Adm. Liu Huaqing, 80, and Gen. Zhang Zhen, 82, who serve as the principal vice chairmen of the Central Military Commission that Mr. Jiang chairs.
In Chinese culture and that of the Communist Party, they are elders to Mr. Jiang and their seniority of service to the Communist cause puts them in a position to criticize him in ways that military leaders contemporary to Mr. Jiang might not.
"Jiang does not want strong military leaders who would be inclined to step in quickly if he is having trouble," said Michael D. Swaine, director of the Center for Asia-Pacific policy at the Rand Corporation.
By all accounts, Mr. Jiang, 70, would like to replace the older pair with Gen. Zhang Wannian, 68, and Defense Minister Chi Haotian, 68. One test of Mr. Jiang's influence over the military will be whether he can force the retirement of the older men this fall at the 15th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.
"He has made good progress with the military," a military analyst here said of Mr. Jiang. "But I would not say they are loyal to him to the point that they would stand in front of him and take a bullet."
Mr. Swaine of Rand said, "He does not have the kind of close personal relationship with a large number of military officers to the point where they have confidence that he will make the right decision in each instance as they had with Deng."
June Teufel Dreyer, an expert on Chinese military affairs at the University of Miami, was more blunt. "He's just not Deng," she said, "he does not command the same kind of respect and he is not a hero of the revolution."
For now, there seems no question that Mr. Jiang is firmly in command of the country and has the support of the Chinese military leadership. But any number of challenges could test his ability to hang on to the military's loyalty.
Hong Kong returns to Chinese sovereignty in July and pro-democracy forces there are determined to test the boundaries of their freedom and the meaning of "one country, two systems" -- a formula for some local autonomy -- promised by Mr. Deng. Any civil disturbance that grows beyond the capacity of the Hong Kong Police to manage could force Mr. Jiang to invoke martial-law powers and risk the kind of bloodshed that devastated China's image at Tiananmen Square.

A Bellicose Stance On Fate of Taiwan
 And after Hong Kong's return, another crisis over Taiwan looms. Beijing has warned that sometime after the Portuguese colony of Macao is returned to China in 1999, reunification with Taiwan is a "programmatic" priority, a word that many analysts have interpreted as a threat to set a deadline for reunification if President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan does not begin a serious political dialogue to reunite what Beijing views as a renegade province with the mainland under a "one country, two systems" formula.
Though Mr. Jiang and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen appear to have calmed the waters over Taiwan after supporting a campaign of military intimidation, some military leaders are still taking a bellicose line.
"We told our American friends that we are not Saddam Hussein," a senior Chinese military officer said in a recent interview. "But if Taiwan became independent, we simply would have no room to back off and would resort to military force regardless of whether the United States interfered. If the Americans did not come, we would do it. If the Americans came, we would do it."
Mr. Lampton said the actions of Taiwan's leader also represent a wild card. "If Lee Teng-hui begins to take steps that are very disturbing" to the Chinese military, "those actions will strengthen the military more rapidly" and add to the pressure on Mr. Jiang to take decisive action that could risk another military crisis -- and his rule.
In the meantime, Mr. Schlesinger said: "China's military leaders are going to be interested in anything that affects the strength and status of China and on that they are going to have considerable voice, and the Taiwan question in particular has got to be handled with great delicacy. The name of the game for policy-makers on both sides is to continue to defer that question."
Mr. Lampton said he was certain that Mr. Jiang would like to.
"I see him as more reactive," he said, in trying to explain how Mr. Jiang might handle a showdown with the military.
"Like Deng, he is basically committed to an open economic and reform policy. He prefers better relations with the United States rather than worse. He prefers Taiwan on the back burner rather than on the front burner. But in the end, he is going to pursue a course that will lead to his survival."

HEADLINE: Average Russian Still Fears a Wider NATO

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Strobe Talbott's arguments are unlikely to allay Russian fears of NATO expansion ("Russia Has Nothing to Fear," Op-Ed, Feb. 18). 
 If the Clinton Administration's real reason for pursuing NATO expansion were to shore up the Central European economies and encourage democratization, it would be pressuring Western Europe to admit the former East Bloc countries into the European Union. Through trade, lowering of tariffs and integration of economies, the goals Mr. Talbott claims to seek would be attained.
Why do the United States and its European allies not use the E.U. as a training ground in which the newly democratic countries might demonstrate their commitment to free-market institutions? This would help soothe Russian apprehensions. A swift expansion of a military alliance right up to Russian borders will not.
 
WILLIAM I. HITCHCOCK
New Haven, Feb. 18, 1997
 
The writer is an assistant professor of history at Yale University.

HEADLINE: Average Russian Still Fears a Wider NATO;
Russian Self-Reliance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In regard to Thomas L. Friedman's Feb. 16 column, "Europe's Wild Ride": 
 The argument that NATO expansion will offend Russians and therefore we shouldn't provoke them sounds like appeasement of a misguided kind. A strong but nonaggressive NATO might even help Russia to set its priorities straight, and remind it that it shouldn't even think about following its traditional pattern of expanding to incorporate wealth rather than facing the hard questions of how to build economically on its own. Supporting real democracies in the neighborhood would also send the right message and provide the best example.
There seems to be ample good will toward Russia in the United States, despite its totalitarian past, and thus a good basis on which to build a foreign relationship. But we should not forget and fall back into naive patterns of appeasing the bully.
Just as after World War II we supported both Germany and Israel and worked to overcome the gulf by helping provide each what was necessary, Israel its identity and security and Germany its economic well-being, we should help mend wounds after the cold war by assuring Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic their security, and help Russia toward economic self-reliance and democracy within a free and friendly world.
 
VIRGINIA KAUFMANN
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 16, 1997

HEADLINE: Don't Remember Deng as Capitalist Apologist

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Feb. 20 front-page headline announcing the death of Deng Xiaoping suggested that the Chinese leader "chose capitalism." First, there was no choice. Market reform was forced upon China's leadership as the only means to escape an increasingly stagnant economy. Second, Mr. Deng's insistence upon the development of "Socialism with Chinese characteristics" hardly makes him a harbinger of capitalism. 
 Whatever is said of him, he would not wish to be remembered as a capitalist apologist. Deng Xiaoping shared a deep distrust of private property with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
CHRISTOPHER LINGLE
Cleveland, Feb. 20, 1997
 
The writer is a visiting associate professor in the economics department at Case Western Reserve University.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2897 words

HEADLINE: Even in Winter, The Market for Summer Rentals Is Hot

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THE cellular phone rang in Sonnie Hall's silver blue Ford sedan -- again. "What now?" she said, as she picked it up. "So how many of them are there?" she asked. "They didn't have an appointment and I can't see them today. I'm totally booked." She paused. "So what weeks do they want?" She listened. "Aug. 2 to Aug. 16 is gone. If they'll do July 12 to 26 there's a few openings; if they leave a name and number I'll get a fax out Monday."
Ms. Hall, a tall woman with streaky blond hair tied with an elaborate ribbon, turned to her passenger. "I hate to say we have nothing," the rental agent whispered in her baby-soft voice. "If they're willing to be flexible, they might get something." 
 Such is the life of a rental agent on much of Cape Cod these days. Ms. Hall works in Chatham, Mass., at the point unglamorously known as the elbow of the Cape, before the Jeeps and beach wagons swing north and head for Provincetown. In Chatham, where residents prefer the appellation "the Nantucket of Cape Cod," Ms. Hall estimates about 80 percent of her August rentals are gone, with slightly more available for July. In Osterville, another desirable village even closer to New York and Boston, Robert Kinlin, of Kinlin Grover Real Estate, gives the same estimate -- 80 percent -- but said that estimate extends across all the summer season.
In the Hamptons, brokers say that the season started earlier than ever before and that, as Alex Kulch of Sotheby's said, "most of the great stuff is gone." Because of this year's mild weather, the strengthening economy, the hot sales market and other factors, rental agents on the Cape, in the Hamptons and in parts of the Jersey Shore say the rental business is the best it has been since the late 80's -- not only for volume, but for prices -- up at least 10 percent and in a few cases, nearing 25 percent higher than just a year ago.
In Ocean City, N.J., where a white stuccoed cube-shaped house with four bedrooms on the beach rents for $5,000 a week, John Andrews at Berger Realty, the town's largest rental agency, said things were humming: "We're already 30 percent ahead of last year." Prices are up, too, he said, maybe as much as 20 percent. Besides the generally benign economy, he attributed the rises to local circumstances: "Our beaches are a lot cleaner than they have been in the past and word is getting around." Companies once "dumped things in the water," he said, "and they washed up on the beaches."
Chip Collins, general manager of Berger and last year's president of the Ocean City Board of Realtors, said the publicity that attracts people to Atlantic City casinos -- only 10 miles away -- helps to bring people to the Jersey Shore. Places like Ocean City are family-oriented, he said, "but one member of the family might break away for a day at the casino."
To take advantage of the tourist renaissance, the towns have responded. In Ocean City during the summer, Mr. Andrews said, the town fathers and mothers hold baby parades, a "Night in Venice" when yachtsmen decorate their boats, kite flying contests, sand sculpture competitions and Pamper Scampers, an infants' race -- all of which have helped make the town a magnet for renters.
In Cape May, the Victorian-era resort that has kept a remarkable proportion of its gingerbread architecture, large five- to seven-bedroom houses like the mansion-sized "cottage" at 1 Jefferson Street rent for $3,000 a week. "I wish we had a couple dozen more," said Bill Bezaire, co-owner of Coldwell Banker Sol Needles Real Estate. The big houses are 90 percent booked, he said, whereas the smaller places are 50 to 60 percent booked. Prices are up only about 3 to 5 percent over last year, he said. "But last year was a banner year, so I guess that means we're headed for our best year ever."
Yet the picture is not exactly the same in other places. In the Berkshires, agents say there are lots of places left -- including a converted cobbler's shop in the historic village of Interlaken. According to the rental sheet issued by Wheeler and Taylor Real Estate in Great Barrington, Mass., the "shop" has three bedrooms, a bath and a compact kitchen; it is "charming" and "cheerful" and "close to Tanglewood." It rents for $5,000 from Memorial Day to Oct. 1. One of the priciest rentals, an estate with extensive grounds, a pool and an antique farmhouse "with wonderful faux finishes," rents for $30,000 for the season.
Along the New Hampshire coastline, "from Seabrook to Portsmouth," Jim Mills, president of the Seacoast Board of Realtors, said that while the season started earlier than ever this year, prices are about the same as they were last year. And in Old Saybrook, Conn., the shore town where Katharine Hepburn keeps a rambling shingled summer waterfront cottage, the manager at William Raveis Real Estate said he hadn't even received any rental listings yet. "They start coming in around the end of March, early April," said Todd Skeirik of Raveis. "We have a whole different pace here."
Along the Connecticut shore, rentals often come in two varieties: very cheap and very expensive.
"This isn't a big rental area," said Mr. Skeirik. "We get a bunch of $600 or $700 a week places, and then we've got one that rents for $20,000 the season," he said.
"We've got nothing in Fenwick," he added, naming the section of Saybrook where Ms. Hepburn lives. "A lot of people around here just aren't interested in renting." Pat Jones, who helps run the Madison, Conn., company that bears her name, said she handled only a few rentals -- and those people would rather keep the fact that they rent out their house unpublished.
ON the northernmost tip of Cape Cod, an agent at Jack Kelly's Pied Piper Real Estate in Provincetown said that things were moving faster than last year, but that no more than 20 percent of their listings were taken. And in Provincetown, $1,500 a week will still pay for a 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath condominium in a romantic shingled house on a quiet lane, a two-minute walk to the bay and a 15-minute walk to the ocean beach.
The house, on Point Street, is in the West End near the concentration of art galleries just off Commercial Street, the town's main strip. The house bears a distinctive blue plaque with the symbol for a wave. "It's one of the floaters," explained Dominick Rizzo, one of the town's many agents. "It was floated over from the spit of land where the Long Point Lighthouse still stands 100 or so years ago." The apartment is on the second floor of the old house, with peaked ceilings, skylights and views of the garden.
The biggest surprise may be on Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard, where prices of summer rentals seem to have stayed pretty much the same as last year -- with a few notable exceptions at the top end. Or, as Curtis Barnes of Nantucket Real Estate puts it, "Rental prices are very stable this year." On the Vineyard, at Flanders Real Estate, an old-line firm, Abigail Howland, a rental agent, said that "things are pretty much the same as last year: we're just plugging along."
The reports are surprising because the sales market, particularly on Nantucket, is soaring; a survey of properties that were for sale two years ago, versus similar properties sold within the last two months, shows that sales prices have actually doubled in many cases.
"People are buying and paying unheard-of figures," said Deborah Killen of Killen Real Estate, which has been renting houses on Nantucket for 35 years.. "But people are buying these huge houses to have, to use, maybe to rent out for some of the summer -- but not as a short-term investment."
One gray-shingled house for rent on Orange Street near the center of town was totally redesigned by the architect Hugh Newell Jacobson and was featured in a national home style magazine several years ago: The floors are pickled, the antique paneled doors are painted glossy white on one side and left with the original mottled paint on the other side. The decor is spare and elegant and pristine. There is a handsome brick patio in the back, with dark green lawn furniture.
The last part of August is taken, but July and the early part of August are still available, according to Ms. Killen. The rent is $2,800 a week in July and $3,000 a week in August -- about the same as last year. Houses of similar size, age and condition -- without Mr. Jacobson's touches, of course -- are priced from $950,000 to $1.2 million, according to a survey of a half dozen color brochures issued by realtors on the island.
Although rentals tend to be moving at a faster pace on the lower part of Cape Cod, buyers there are also paying more than they have in years, and they are not buying with an eye to making money on rent. "These are not investors," said Mr. Kinlin.
"Someone would have to pay $1.95 million for this kind of waterfront house," he said, walking around a massive gray 1920's summer house overlooking the Oyster Harbor in Osterville. "And he's using it himself in August. He'll rent it out in July for $25,000. But if someone comes in and offers $20,000 or $22,000, he won't bother leasing it. He won't dicker. The price is the price; it's the principle of the whole thing."
In the Hamptons, according to agents, rentals are red hot -- like the small carriage house a block off Main Street in Southampton. It's like a doll's house; a privet hedge, a rose arbor and an ivy-covered tree serve to frame the entrance; the roof has a saucy peak, a chimney and just below the peak, a small-paned arched window. It has a little bedroom and bath downstairs and a little loft upstairs. It rents for $15,000 for the season -- and it's already rented, to a "professional woman from the city; she likes it so much it's her third year," according to Mr. Kulch of Sotheby's, who handles both rentals and sales in the area.
Then there is the rather nondescript rambling gray ranch with sliding glass doors and one of the finest locations: at the end of a cul-de-sac in Water Mill, on a point of land abutted on one side by Mecox Bay, on the other by Burnett Creek, and looking south to the ocean. As if the site weren't enough, it is further distinguished by an expansive Japanese-style garden, with low-slung spreading junipers, wine red in winter, and crushed rock, and a small concrete pagoda surrounded by tufts of yellow Japanese grasses. The house is no longer available for July, but the month of August is still open, for $40,000.
"Especially over the last year, rental prices have really jumped," said Mr. Kulch. "Perhaps 10 to 20 percent, and some even higher.
"You'd think there'd be some resistance -- and there is," he continued. "The tenants are savvy, and they remember the prices -- to a remarkable degree. Some should be brokers! But it's the result of a sustained economy, and people are still willing to come out. They may not be happy, but the demand is as strong as ever, and the inventory is less."
Mr. Kulch compared the Hamptons to a number of other summer destinations. "If you take a place like Northeast Harbor, Me., well, there's different people there. The Hamptons is New York-oriented, overwhelmingly so; people in business, in the arts. They may try Maine, they may try Nantucket. If they're trying to get to a business meeting and they're fogged in a few times, they'll come back here.
"Here, in a sense, they spend time networking," he explained. "It's more of a continuation of their life style; they like to do business when they get together. They entertain a lot: parties, parties, parties. They've always had a lot of private parties out here, but now the benefit parties are multiplying geometrically. On any one weekend, one can't even count them and they're not inexpensive: $50 to $250; it's a recent phenomenon."
Mr. Kulch is right. The crowd is different in other places, according to the brokers.
OSTERVILLE, near the beginning of the Cape, is an old summer resort still inhabited by old money. "The Mellon family owns a lot of Oyster Harbor, and there's the Du Ponts; years ago, the Singer family," said Mr. Kinlin. "There were a number of stockbrokers who came here in the late 1800's and built massive homes on the water. There were a lot of people from Pittsburgh."
The people who summer in Osterville -- where houses rent for up to $25,000 a month -- are different from the people who rent in nearby Centreville, where there are still many expensive properties but there are less expensive ones as well. "Centreville is more casual," he said.
Pressed to describe the differences on a superficial plane, Mr. Kinlin laughed.
"The people who rent in Centreville are into cutoffs, boat shoes and T-shirts," he said gamely. "In Osterville, it's the country club-beach club-Wianno sailing crew look. Golf attire: navy blue blazer, Lacoste shirt, country club cocktail crowd."
In Osterville, there is currently another beach cottage, gray shingles with yellow trim, on Seaside Avenue, where the owners let prospective tenants in to view the property only a few times each year. "The couple that own this house are very, very particular," said Mr. Kinlin. "It worked out well for this year, because the people who've rented it for the season were able to see it last fall, and they took it." The rent, he said, "is between $50,000 and $60,000 for the season."
The market for both rentals and sales began to come back about three years ago, according to several brokers in the Osterville-Hyannisport area, who said that aside from a few extra-special properties, sale prices are still about 60 percent what they were in the height of the mid to late 80's.
To cope with the increasing demand for rentals, Mr. Kinlin created a rental division just over a year ago. In Osterville and Hyannisport, a midsized rental in the town averages $4,000 to $5,000 a month. For the campier, beachier small houses in Centreville, like the Craig-Tide cottages across from Craigville Beach, the price goes by the week: $800 to $1,200.
In Chatham and Orleans, further up the Cape, rental prices are generally cheaper, with houses in Chatham going for more money than in nearby Orleans.
"This is only $2,000 a week," said Ms. Hall, who works for John C. Ricotta and Associates in Chatham, driving in the driveway of a sprawling five-bedroom house -- complete with covered patio and copper-toned kitchen appliances -- overlooking Pleasant Bay in Orleans, with a magnificent lawn leading to a wooden stairway to the sandy beach. "If this was in Chatham, it'd be $3,500 a week."
The difference?
"In Orleans, they can't walk to town, and there isn't an ocean beach," she said. "Lighthouse Beach in Chatham is famous."
Ms. Hall and the other agents around the region all stressed that they interviewed all prospective tenants. One hapless family grilled by the agent said they had rented in Chatham before, but had rented privately, directly through the owners. "That's too bad," she said. "Then you don't have any references from any other realtors; that could hurt you." (But by the end of the day, she had managed to set up one appointment for them, anyway -- after they mentioned they knew several people Ms. Hall knew.) Even with the big houses, Ms. Hall said she liked to see "related people" for house shares.
In the Hamptons, too, rental agents and the house owners they represent like to see families rather than a bunch of unrelated men or women out for a good time.
But when the rents are as high as they are in the Hamptons -- a fragile-looking three bedroom postmodern effort on stilts goes for $71,500 for the season; a grand mansion in Wainscott for $500,000 -- it gets harder to screen everyone who shows up once the place is rented.
NOT that there is likely to be much of a problem when -- and if -- somebody lays out half a million for a summer rental. But for the cheaper rentals, which can still start at $12,000 or $15,000 a summer, the landlords are becoming increasingly wary, according to the Sotheby's broker.
"Last summer, there were suits brought for misrepresentation," he said. "In one cul-de-sac there were at least two houses that became full-fledged group houses: real Animal Houses; way stations for refugees. And we've had cases of laying out the mattresses for 15 to 20 people.
"Now, the owners are banding together," Mr. Kulch said, "putting money together to combat it, for legal actions. Imagine if you spent $40,000 or $50,000 a season for your family and you had to be subjected to that! This is something that will have to be addressed more as time goes on."
For Mr. Kinlin on Cape Cod, there are other problems with rentals.
"Rentals are a necessary evil," he said, detailing the amount of work attached to handling rental business -- the daily telephone calls from tenants angry about broken refrigerators, about broken air-conditioning -- then the angry calls when owners come home and think the renters did not maintain the house properly.
"We clearly make our money by selling houses, but rentals are a way to service future clients," the broker said. "obviously, we hope someone who rents will sometime turn into a buyer. But there's a fine line as these things need to be addressed, with the owner on one side and the tenant on the other. We've also got to please the owner, who's saying, 'Hey, I'm getting a little tired of these phone calls.' You walk a very fine line."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 2, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about summer rentals included an imprecise reference in a quotation. When Sonnie Hall, a broker comparing rentals in the Cape Cod towns of Chatham and Orleans, said, "In Orleans, they can't walk to town, and there isn't an ocean beach," she was referring to a specific house, not to the community itself.
