PUB-DATE: February 23, 1997
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1707 words

HEADLINE: Prime Time;
The Communist Dynasty Had Its Run. Now What?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

 BODY:
WHEN Deng Xiaoping visited the United States in 1979, the actress Shirley MacLaine told him how impressed she had been on a visit to China during the Cultural Revolution, when Mr. Deng and countless others had been forced to toil in remote areas and "learn from the peasants." The actress said she had been particularly moved by a scholar working in a field, who had described how much more fulfilling it was to grow tomatoes than to work in a university.
Mr. Deng looked at her and said: "He lied." 
 It was Mr. Deng's genius to cut through the propaganda and chimera of Maoism, and thereby save Communism in China. His 18-year reign as Chinese Emperor was one of the greatest since the legendary Yellow Emperor who supposedly helped found the nation thousands of years ago, and he rescued the Communist Dynasty when it was tottering after Mao's death. But his own departure again leaves the dynasty in fragile shape.
The Communist Dynasty, founded by Mao in 1949, has today largely lost the "mandate of heaven" -- the moral authority and popular support or acquiescence -- that gives it legitimacy and enables it to rule. So China may now be approaching a transition not only of emperors but also of dynasties.
 
Possibilities Open
 This does not mean that anything much will happen immediately or even in the next few years. Still, Mr. Deng's death has created a tremendous range of possibilities, from a military coup at one extreme to evolution toward quasi-democracy on the other. So long as his heart beat, China was vaguely predictable, but now all kinds of things become conceivable.
One measure of the frailty of the Communist Dynasty is that the name already is a bit of a misnomer, for China is not a Communist country in any meaningful sense. It is run by a Communist Party, but the principles governing China are not Marxist-Leninist but Market-Leninist. In other words, China is a marriage of a market economy and Leninist dictatorial principles.
China's Communists today care not about Communism but about power. The bottom line is: We'll stay in power, and everything else is negotiable. There may be more Marxists in New York than in Beijing.
"By the end of his life, he saw clearly that it wasn't working" the widow of one of China's top leaders once confided. "But what could he do? Of course he couldn't admit it to anyone but me."
Mr. Deng's own youngest son, Deng Zhifang, demonstrates the path that the best and brightest are taking. An American-trained engineer, he worked for a state-owned company in the 1980's, answering his own telephone and riding a bicycle to work each day. Now he is a property magnate and international businessman based in China worth tens of millions of dollars. He makes decisions in the same way as any Hong Kong tycoon.
Deng Xiaoping effectively transformed China from an ultra-leftist country to an ultra-rightist country, and today the Communist Dynasty governs not by socialism but by something close to a dictionary definition of fascism. China's underlying dynamic, with its combination of vibrant free enterprise, state-owned companies and authoritarian political system, has little in common with Maoism but has great parallels with Franco's Spain or Park Chung Hee's South Korea or Pinochet's Chile.
This arrangement has given China tremendous vitality, but it has not done much for the longevity of the political system, and Mr. Deng's China may some day be remembered the way the world now looks back on Franco's Spain. The problem is that Market-Leninism seems to be an inherently unstable concept, for the market eats away at the Leninism.
It may seem odd to speak of China's leaders today as emperors, but that historical lens is probably the most useful in explaining their behavior. China's Communists initially rebelled against history, but they soon fell into traditional patterns, and Mr. Deng's role could not possibly be explained by his formal positions. At their peak he was Deputy Prime Minister, and for the last seven years he held no title loftier than Honorary Chairman of the China Bridge Association. In fact, of course, he was Emperor, and it was a title he could not have given up had he wanted to.
Throughout history, Chinese have noted a "dynastic cycle." The first emperor is a strong-willed general or peasant rebel who seizes power and imposes far-reaching changes, but he is followed by rulers who are steadily weaker. The dynasty's moral authority sags under the burden of taxes, corruption and ineptitude, and a new leader emerges to found a new dynasty.
 
A 'Melon-Head'
 Mao was a classic dynastic founder, and Mr. Deng was a strong ruler too. But Jiang Zemin, the stocky, bespectacled and totally uncharismatic "weather vane" whom Mr. Deng picked in 1989 to be the next emperor, is almost immediately recognizable as the kind of emperor who belongs at the tail end of a dynastic cycle -- if he becomes any kind of emperor at all.
Prime Minister Li Peng is even less the type to inspire the Mandate of Heaven. Intensely unpopular and widely ridiculed for his authoritarian and awkward style, denounced even by his mother, he is a lightning-rod for jokes about the regime. In one, a worker is arrested for shouting "Li Peng is a melon-head" and is sentenced to 20 years in prison -- 5 for counter-revolutionary crimes and 15 for revealing state secrets.
Mao was an avid reader of history and was acutely aware of the problem of the dynastic cycle. In July 1946, when he was still a gaunt guerrilla leader, he was visited by Huang Yanpei, a prominent scholar, who noted: "Dynasties begin with a surge of vigor, and then decay and disintegrate. Has the Communist Party found a way to break this vicious cycle?" Mao beamed: "We've found a way. It's called democracy."
Perhaps that would have worked, but Mao and Mr. Deng both refused to try real democracy (and, of course, Mao meant proletarian democracy rather than any kind of Western approach). It is a great pity, because in China the Communist Party was unusually compatible with democracy, for the simple reason that the party was much more popular with ordinary people than in most Communist countries. In Poland, the party would have lost a plebiscite. But in China, the Communist Party could have counted on the peasantry and perhaps won a free multi-party election. Even today, it perhaps could.
Mr. Deng had broad legitimacy, especially in the early 1980's, because of his decades organizing the Communist revolution and his later years freeing the economy. But Mr. Jiang lacks that kind of legitimacy, and there is no legitimating institution or mechanism, such as elections, to grant him that authority.
Among the greatest burdens for the Communist Dynasty in sustaining its legitimacy is the still-reverberating memory of the Tiananmen killings of 1989. It is a bit odd that the Communists should have caused the deaths of some 30 million peasants in the late 1950's and early 1960's, in a great Mao-made famine, and yet the killing of several hundred students should be a greater blot on the party's legitimacy. Yet one of the lessons of Chinese history is that a ruler can kill peasants to his heart's content, but tangles with students at his peril.
Even Mr. Deng's family members had their regrets about the Tiananmen killings, for his children told their friends that their father had nothing to do with the massacre. Few people believe that, and almost everyone expects China at some point to face the killings anew.
When Mr. Deng became Emperor, his approach was to try to evade his responsibility for the Cultural Revolution by pinning the blame on the "Gang of Four" and sending them to prison. In one sense it was ludicrous to say that those four hard-liners did everything. But as a political gesture it helped distance him and the Communist Party from the Cultural Revolution. Remembering that example, some new aspiring emperor might try making Mr. Li the scapegoat for Tiananmen.
So what will the next dynasty be like? The bleakest possibility is national fragmentation, even civil war, for that has occurred periodically in Chinese history. But that also seems an extremely remote possibility. In Tibet and Xinjiang, local people may mount insurrections against Chinese rule, but that is difficult to imagine in the main parts of China. The Cantonese in the south, who prospered in the Deng era, may complain all the time about the incompetent and corrupt weasels in the north, but it is almost unimaginable that they would shed their blood to prove the point.
 
Most Likely
 Another possibility is a military coup, for with Mr. Deng's passing it is now the People's Liberation Army that holds ultimate power. Often in developing countries the passing of a powerful leader has been followed by a coup, and Mr. Jiang seems very aware of the risks.
Yet another possibility, perhaps the most likely, is the kind of gradual evolution that occurred in Spain, South Korea and Chile. It may be slower yet, and there may even be new massacres ahead, but the "second revolution" that Mr. Deng instigated is creating the middle class and rising income and education levels that in other countries have been associated eventually with growing pluralism, tolerance and even democracy. China already has economic and cultural pluralism, and political pluralism may gradually emerge as well.
The dynasty most like the Communist one in Chinese history was the Qin, founded in 221 B.C. by a ruthless emperor much like Mao. The first Qin emperor unified China, created the Great Wall, and modernized the country in hundreds of ways, yet he also burned books and buried scholars alive. His dynasty was very short, expiring soon after his death, but it laid the basis for its successor, the Han Dynasty, a golden era of Chinese history. In the same way, the Communist Dynasty may be short-lived, for it has been unable to respond to the yearnings for political participation that its economic revolution engendered. Yet the Communist Dynasty has laid a framework -- by unifying the country, distributing land to the peasants, emancipating women, and educating the labor force -- for what could be an extraordinary dynasty in the years ahead.

HEADLINE: Allah's Messenger

BYLINE: By Jill Nelson; Jill Nelson is a journalist and the author of "Volunteer Slavery: My Authentic Negro Experience."

 BODY:

An Original Man
 The Life and Times
 of Elijah Muhammad.
 By Claude Andrew Clegg 3d.
 Illustrated. 377 pp. New York:
 St. Martin's Press. $25.95. 
 I can think of no 20th-century leader with anything like the impact of Elijah Muhammad whose life has been so profoundly unexamined. Even as Malcolm X and Louis Farrakhan, his closest disciples, have become part of the national debate and popular culture, Muhammad, the head of the Nation of Islam for nearly 50 years, has remained a shadowy figure, defined, if at all, by hearsay and propaganda. Yet this diminutive, frail, informally educated man built the Nation of Islam from a tiny fringe group into a multifaceted organization that became an important player in black America's spiritual, economic and political life. By the time of his death in 1975, Muhammad had in one way or another touched the lives of most black Americans and, less directly, most white ones, too. In "An Original Man: The Life and Times of Elijah Muhammad," Claude Andrew Clegg 3d, a professor of history at North Carolina A&T State University, has brought Muhammad to light in a fluidly written biography rich with information, analysis and suspense.
Born Elijah Poole in Sandersville, Ga., in 1897, Muhammad was one of 13 children; his father was a sharecropper and Baptist preacher, his mother a domestic worker who "claimed to have had a vision that one day she would give birth to a male child of pre-eminent stature and importance." The first decade of Muhammad's life gave no indication of the prominence to come. But at 10, while working as a laborer, he saw the lynched body of a young man he knew. "The murder and the subdued reaction of the African-American community repulsed him," Mr. Clegg says. In 1923, married and with children, he moved himself and his family, including his parents and siblings, north to Detroit. Mr. Clegg draws a vivid picture of the personal and social pressures he encountered there -- from economic insecurity and pervasive racism to political disfranchisement. They eventually led the unemployed Muhammad to despair and liquor.
It was in Detroit in 1931 that he met W. D. Fard, a short, white-skinned man who identified himself as God and offered Elijah Poole a new name, a religion customized for black Americans and the seeds of what would become the Nation of Islam. Muhammad, Mr. Clegg writes, "was mesmerized by the ideas of the Muslim leader regarding the originality and superiority of blackness, moral living, proper dieting and the new world to come." In a seamless interweaving of history and biography, Mr. Clegg sets Muhammad's almost immediate conversion to Islam in the context of national politics, his own personal history and existing black political and religious organizations, including Marcus Garvey's Universal Negro Improvement Association.
The building of the Nation of Islam was a long process, one rife in the early years with internal dissension and persecution by local police, the F.B.I. and the Federal Government, which convicted Muhammad of draft evasion in 1942. Four years in prison "did more toward consolidating his authority over the Nation of Islam than a decade of bickering, purges and wandering could ever have done," Mr. Clegg writes. Settled in Chicago after his release in 1946, Muhammad demonstrated a brilliant ability to turn adversity into advantage. He won new converts by capitalizing on government repression, and made his study of prison farms and businesses the foundation for the Nation of Islam's economic empire in the 1950's. Mr. Clegg provides a critique of the Nation of Islam's theology, which celebrates blacks as the "original people" and condemns whites as "devils," but he also observes that what attracted thousands to the Nation of Islam was Muhammad's personality, his warmth, persuasiveness and paternalism.
By the 1960's, membership was estimated at anywhere from 5,000 to 250,000. Whatever the numbers, the Nation of Islam's influence was enormous. It operated dozens of temples, owned property worth millions of dollars, ran numerous businesses and published a national newspaper. Muhammad's call to black Americans to "Do Something for Self" and to disdain integration put the Nation of Islam in militant opposition to most civil rights organizations of the era and made its leader a powerful voice in local and national politics. It is a voice that, more than 20 years after Muhammad's death, is still heard, most notably at the 1995 Million Man March in Washington. "An Original Man" begins the work of telling us why.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 528 words

HEADLINE: MAKING WELFARE WORK;
New and Improved? Not Quite

BYLINE: By Paul Offner; Paul Offner is the District of Columbia's Commissioner of Health Care Finance.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When President Clinton announced recently that welfare caseloads are down by 2.1 million from four years ago, he called it "the biggest drop in welfare rolls in history." The President pointed to the waivers he has granted to 43 states, making it easier for them to place welfare recipients in jobs and training programs. Republican leaders gave the credit to Governors like John Engler of Michigan and Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin.
But the impressive caseload reduction occurred under the old, discredited welfare law that Mr. Clinton and the Republicans have repealed. Neither party seemed interested in explaining why, if it was working so well, we had to scrap that system for an approach that will put millions of children at risk of becoming destitute. 
 The President's waivers may well have helped states move welfare recipients off the rolls. But the business cycle, historically, has been the primary influence on the number of welfare recipients. From 1989 to 1993, a period of rising unemployment, the welfare caseload grew from 10.8 million to 14 million. After that, unemployment declined, and by October 1996, the number of welfare recipients was down to 11.8 million. The system worked.
So why the need for such a drastic fix? The public seems to think that welfare dependence has been on the rise. It has not. Actually, a smaller proportion of the population is on the dole today compared with 25 years ago. From 1972 to 1989, about 4.8 percent received Aid to Families with Dependent Children. By 1993, about 5.4 percent did. Today, it's down to 4.6 percent.
Timing is everything in politics, and in this area, the conservatives have had all the luck. In 1988, a Democratic Congress passed, and President Ronald Reagan signed, the Family Support Act, which encouraged modest state and Federal investments in job training, day care and other services welfare mothers need to become self-sufficient. Then the economy soured, caseloads started growing, and governors found their states short of money to invest in reform efforts. The Family Support Act did finance a number of experimental programs that increased employment, earnings and school attendance. But because of the economic downturn, welfare caseloads increased by 30 percent in the first four years. Obviously, the new law wasn't working, critics said.
Now the economy is strong, the number of welfare recipients is declining and already the new law looks like a success. But eventually the economy will weaken and more people will seek welfare. States will run out of money -- the law freezes Federal financing at earlier levels -- and will be unable to meet the law's ambitious work requirements.
The President, though, foresees only clear sailing. "Together, we can make the permanent underclass a thing of the past," he said. Yet there's little in the new law to help reverse the high levels of unemployment and out-of-wedlock births in poor urban neighborhoods. In 1964, President Lyndon Johnson articulated a similar vision, saying the nation must make "a commitment to eradicate poverty." Unfortunately, Mr. Clinton is not likely to do any better than his predecessor.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1905 words

HEADLINE: Woody and Buzz, The Untold Story;
Could Pixar Make It Without Disney?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
When Andrew Stanton graduated from the California Institute of the Arts in 1987, he expected to struggle to make ends meet as an animator. And his expectations proved accurate for years.
For Mr. Stanton, as for most young animators at the time, work was a succession of humdrum jobs, each lasting a month or two, doing sketches or cleanup chores on brief, animated sequences for commercials, cartoons and movie credits. He made about $20,000 a year, and lived in a rented house he shared with three other young men, just as he had as a student. 
 Today, the 31-year-old Mr. Stanton earns a six-figure salary and owns a spacious house in the wooded affluence of Marin County. He is regarded as a rising young talent in the suddenly hot field of animation -- a reversal of fortune that has made people like him millionaires in the last few years.
"Sure, it surprised me," he said. "I went from being nobody to being somebody awfully quickly."
So have many others amid the animation gold rush in Hollywood. As one of the main writers of "Toy Story," the hit animated film that his employer, Pixar Animation Studios, made with Disney, Mr. Stanton has done better than most. But his quick ascent into the higher-income brackets has been fairly typical among animators.
Salaries for experienced animators, writers, directors and producers have more than doubled in the last three years, estimates Nancy Newhouse, a Los Angeles attorney who represents animation professionals. Six-figure incomes are common, she says, and a handful of animation directors now make more than $1 million a year.
Skilled teams as well as individuals are much in demand. So Disney is moving to tighten its partnership with Pixar by giving the computer-animation studio a larger slice of the profits from future films. After the surprising success of "Toy Story," the first in a three-movie deal with Disney, Pixar's bargaining position has strengthened considerably.
Pixar has been negotiating to lift its share of profits from the movies it makes for Disney from the present 10 to 15 percent to roughly three times that level. Those negotiations are close to completion, say people familiar with the talks. An announcement of the sweetened terms for Pixar is expected early this week.
Disney has good reason to want to keep Pixar happy. The animation boom has been fueled by the rush of major Hollywood studios suddenly eager to make animated feature films. Twentieth Century Fox, a unit of the News Corporation; Warner Brothers, a unit of Time Warner; Dreamworks; Viacom; and Universal, a unit of Seagram, are making sizable investments to build up their animation efforts. Put simply, they are all chasing the Walt Disney Company and its revitalized animation studio.
Disney's blockbusters of the 1990's -- "Beauty and the Beast," "Aladdin," "Lion King" and "Toy Story" -- have firmly focused Hollywood's attention on both the popularity and the extraordinary economics of successful animated movies.
Animated movies can be enduring profit machines, generating earnings year after year. While a live-action movie that produces $200 million in profit is deemed an enormous success, "Toy Story," for example, is expected to generate total profits from the box office, videos, computer games and merchandising of nearly $400 million in the two years since its release in the 1995 holiday season. Some industry estimates have placed the total profits from "Lion King," released in 1994, as high as $1 billion.
The allure of animation is obvious, but the odds for the Disney imitators are long. "There is this rush into animation now, but it remains to be seen if anybody besides Disney can really succeed," said George Lucas, the director. "That talent machine hasn't been nurtured over the years, except at Disney."
If the others fail, it will not be for lack of ambition or funds. Or for lack of former Disney managers or artists, since the challenge to the Magic Kingdom is being led by its alumni -- most notably, Jeffrey Katzenberg, the former Disney executive who guided the revival of Disney's animation unit until 1994, when he departed to become a founder of Dreamworks.
Pixar occupies an anonymous low brick building in an industrial park near the waterfront in Point Richmond, north of Berkeley. It is tiny compared with the big Hollywood studios, and it is certainly not a household name. Yet except for Disney, Pixar is the one studio that can claim to have produced an animation blockbuster. "Toy Story," the buddy film starring Woody the cowboy and Buzz Lightyear the spaceman, was the nation's leading box-office money maker in 1995.
Pixar is also a pioneer in the use of digital technology. Films that are entirely computer animated, like "Toy Story," have a three-dimensionality and detailing that is very different from the signature look of the hand-drawn animated features made since "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" in 1937.
Even the making of modern, predominantly hand-drawn animated films has been transformed by computer technology. The "extras" in crowds in the "Hunchback of Notre Dame" or the stampede of wildebeests in the "Lion King" were generated by computer animation. Today, much of the laborious painting and tracing, once done by hand, is done by computer. "It's like finding a magic pencil," Frank Thomas, an 84-year-old former Disney animator, said of the new technology. "So many of the things we used to sweat over, you don't have to do anymore."
Despite its encouraging start, both artistically and as a technology leader, Pixar illustrates the challenges of building an animation studio and an animation business. Its history goes back more than a decade, and its future is still uncertain.
In 1986, Steven P. Jobs purchased the computer graphics unit from George Lucas for less than $10 million. The group, known as Pixar, was a small team of computer scientists and film makers who were smitten with the notion of making computer- animated feature films.
Pixar's advanced computer graphics impressed Mr. Jobs, the co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., who had been ousted from Apple in 1985. (In December, Mr. Jobs sold his software firm, Next Software Inc., to Apple and rejoined Apple as a part-time adviser; he insists, though, that he spends 80 percent of his time at Pixar.)
In the 1980's, Pixar's technology was far too primitive to make a full-length movie. So for years, Pixar tried to earn its way by selling computer work stations and software used for digitally enhancing images ranging from satellite photographs taken by intelligence agencies to hospital X-rays.
That business strategy was mostly a failure, and Pixar chewed up $50 million of Mr. Jobs's money. Yet all along, he financed a small, back-room group at Pixar that made a series of critically acclaimed computer-animated short films, like "Tin Toy," which won an Oscar in 1988. All of them were directed by John Lasseter, a former Disney animator, who also directed "Toy Story."
The short films, and Pixar's technology, attracted the attention of Disney, and the two companies began working together. In 1991, Disney seemed to throw the struggling start-up a lifeline, when Pixar signed its three-movie deal with Disney.
Still, for those familiar with the ways of Hollywood, a contract with Disney was one thing, but the sign that Pixar was really up and running as a studio came a year later when Disney gave its "green light," meaning investing real money to develop "Toy Story."
"As soon as we had the green light, people here bought houses and started families," said Mr. Stanton, a bearded young animator, who had joined Pixar in 1990. "Ben, my son, was born later that year."
These days, Pixar is hard at work on its second movie for Disney, code-named "Bugs," scheduled to be released for the 1998 holiday season. Story development on the third film, unnamed as yet, has begun. Mr. Stanton will be co-director of "Bugs," along with Mr. Lasseter. The images and story line of "Bugs" are guarded as closely as state secrets.
The hallways at Pixar are marked with blue plastic signs bearing names like Toy Boulevard and Scooter Run. In fact, the workers occasionally zip by on white scooters, equipped with bicycle bells. Animators and artists work in partitioned cubicles, each done up in a determinedly individualistic decor. Toys, old couches, lava lamps, Art Deco mirrors and Japanese screens are all in the mix, along with high-powered computer work stations. Someone's pet Dalmatian roams the place.
It is a setting self-consciously designed to nurture creativity. For while Woody the cowboy may be 52,865 lines of computer code, what makes the audience care about that digital image is the character and the story, painstakingly fashioned by screenwriters, animators and artists.
The fledgling studio is growing rapidly with a payroll of 300 people, twice the size of two years ago. Pixar recently reported impressive financial results for 1996, its first complete year as a public company. Revenues tripled to $38 million, as profits jumped sixteenfold to $25 million.
Still, investors are not yet impressed. Pixar shares soared when first offered to the public in November 1995, just after the release of "Toy Story," but its stock has dropped sharply since. The shares closed last week at $14.125, down from a close of $39 a share on its first day of trading, Nov. 29, 1995.
The early enthusiasm evaporated as investors focused on two things. First, Pixar's financial performance will be cyclical, rising with hit movies and falling until the next one. Second, under the current three-movie contract, Disney collects nearly all the profits from Pixar's movies.
According to the terms of the 1991 contract, Disney supplies financing, story advice, marketing and distribution for the films, while Pixar makes the films and CD-ROM's based on the movies. For its contribution, Pixar receives 10 to 15 percent of the total profits from the box office, video sales, computer games and merchandising revenues.
Looking at Pixar's share price, Mr. Jobs says investors are being short sighted. His company, he says, is building a long-term asset of considerable value. "It isn't going to happen with one film or two but we have a shot at building the second great animation studio after Disney," he said.
Besides, Mr. Jobs has tried to brighten Pixar's immediate prospects recently by trying to negotiate a better deal for Pixar. "Toy Story" has strengthened his hand. Initially, Disney thought of it as a niche film instead of the blockbuster it became. So Mr. Jobs has been pushing to get Pixar 30 to 40 percent of the profits from future films, and perhaps sweeten the current contract.
Pixar, in theory, could try to link up with another major studio to obtain the marketing and distribution muscle it could not muster on its own. But Mr. Jobs observed, "We love working with Disney."
For Disney, the Pixar connection has proved lucrative. And the entertainment conglomerate seems eager to tighten its links with the pioneering computer-animation studio when rivals, including Dreamworks, are working on computer-generated films.
A year before Pixar went public, Mr. Jobs did offer Disney a 10 percent stake, and Disney declined. "It's my one regret," said Peter Schneider, president of feature animation for Disney. "When we had an opportunity to buy a slice of Pixar, we should have."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew Stanton and a friend at Pixar. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The $400 Million Man"
Whether digitally assembled or hand drawn, all animation starts with an artist's sketches and story boards. The similarities end there. Here is a look at the differences between Disney's traditional hand animation, like that used in the forthcoming movie, "Hercules," and the digital animation that Pixar used in "Toy Story," which is expected to generate $400 million in profits.
 
Framework
 
DIGITALLY
 
Millions of lines
Characters, like Woody, are translated from clay models into digitized ones -- made of millions of lines linked to make polygons.
 
MANUALLY
 
Hundreds of lines
All characters start with a rough pencil sketch by the lead animator. These are copied and refined by another artist. The most complex characters, like Hercules, are made up of hundreds of lines.
 
Color
 
DIGITALLY
 
Millions of colors
The computer has millions of colors available to it. Once the model is created, the surface is colored. The computer will adjust color for the light source, the light color, shadows and reflections on the object.
 
MANUALLY
 
Hundreds of colors
This is the only digital stage in Disney's animation process. Clean drawings are scanned into a computer and colored by artists, but the colors are largely determined by an art director.
 
Motion
 
DIGITALLY
 
Computerized motion
Key frames in a scene are built by an animator. Then a computer fills in the actions in between that will make the motion look fluid in the film.
 
MANUALLY
 
Hand-drawn motion
The lead animator for a scene draws the key frames, but one or two "in-betweeners" draw the steps that complete the fluid motion. The faster the motion in the scene, the more drawings the lead animator completes to get the subtleties just right.

HEADLINE: HOUSING PROJECTS IN NEW YORK CITY FACE BIG CHANGES

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Facing stiff reductions in Federal aid, the sprawling New York City Housing Authority is exploring what was once unthinkable: turning over some of its high-rise buildings to private managers and earning more money from all its projects by sharply increasing the number of tenants with jobs, who can pay more rent.
The authority, long the nation's largest and most successful public housing agency, says it has essentially concluded that it must abandon many of its long-held ideals if it is to survive in this new era of austerity as a provider of housing for those who cannot afford to buy or rent their own homes. 
 The authority is being forced to consider these proposals because of the major changes emanating from Washington, where the Republican majority in Congress is cutting housing subsidies even as it tries to spur local housing officials to adopt more market-driven policies by loosening rules that had restricted how they could spend Federal money.
"The status quo absolutely cannot be maintained," said John G. Martinez, a deputy general manager at the authority who is in charge of finding ways to revamp its operations.
While urban officials across the country have denounced the cuts in housing aid, some Republicans in Congress have countered that it is foolish for the Federal Government to continue pouring money into a system that they say has largely been a failure. Unlike the authority in New York City, many housing authorities across the country have been beset by mismanagement and corruption, and Federal officials in recent years have seized control of some, including those in Philadelphia and Chicago.
The Republicans say they want to reduce the housing subsidies to push the authorities to operate more efficiently. And they say that by relaxing many of the rules that have governed how much rent can be charged and how subsidies can be spent, Congress will give the authorities the freedom to flourish.
The reductions imposed by the Republicans in the last two years have so squeezed the New York City authority that earlier this month, officials announced that they would trim the authority's work force of 15,000 by at least 1,000 employees. Trying to avoid layoffs, the officials said they had reached a tentative agreement with municipal unions to offer workers who voluntarily leave a severance package.
But officials at the authority acknowledge that they need to do more than just cut staffing to compensate for the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal subsidies for its 331 housing projects. They say the authority will probably have to relinquish its role of being the housing provider of last resort for many of the poorest of the poor.
It may have to subcontract the job of operating its properties to nonprofit groups or private companies while also seeking to reap additional money from its buildings by leasing more space to commercial businesses. And while the authority's officials will not publicly discuss it, they say they will eventually have to examine selling some buildings, an idea long considered taboo.
The cuts in Federal subsidies come when there is already a severe shortage of housing for poor and working-class people in New York City. At least 130,000 people, for example, are on the waiting list for the authority's apartments. The authority, which houses 600,000 people, is also under pressure from the overhaul of the Federal welfare law last year, which could end up reducing the amount of money that some tenants receive to pay rent.
"For the Housing Authority to meet its public purpose and to be in a position to insure that it can provide safe and sanitary housing," Mr. Martinez said, "it is absolutely imperative that the authority look at a different way of doing business."
He stressed that the authority had not yet made any decisions on major policy shifts, adding that its board would begin mulling options in April.
Like New York City's, most other housing authorities, including those in Boston, Washington and Newark, are grappling with the same problems: how to cut costs and take in more revenue to make up for dwindling Federal money. The challenges are even greater for authorities that have been poorly run.
Many are scaling back renovations on aging buildings that were never particularly well maintained in the first place. They are forming partnerships with nonprofit groups, and they are re-examining one of the most sensitive subjects in public housing: what percentage of units should be set aside for poor people who have little means to pay.
By law and tradition, housing authorities have devoted most of their space to the poorest of the poor. Across the country, the percentage of tenants with jobs for most authorities is only about 15 to 20 percent. New York City's has one of the highest, at 30 percent -- one reason, housing experts say, that it has been relatively successful.
But with so many budget pressures, New York City's and other housing authorities say they want to move more people with jobs to the top of the waiting lists.
"We now have to say to some of those poor people, 'Sorry, we need to house more working people,' " said Sandra B. Henriquez, administrator of the Boston Housing Authority. "We have to worry about income."
Some tenant leaders said such changes might leave poor people with nowhere to go. And they said they were already seeing the effects of the cuts in Federal subsidies for renovating and running buildings. At the Drew-Hamilton Houses in Harlem, a tenant leader, Barbara G. Barber, said the authority had eliminated a custodian's job recently, leaving hallways dirtier and reducing pickups for garbage.
"These budget cuts are going to wipe out public housing if someone does not listen," Ms. Barber said. "This is going to be very devastating to residents."
The New York City authority, which is a quasi-independent agency that is controlled by the Mayor, pays for only about half of its costs from the rents it charges. The rest are covered by government subsidies, 90 percent of which come from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
The New York City authority's annual HUD subsidy for renovations and repairs has dropped by more than 25 percent, from $435.1 million in 1994 to $320 million this year. The authority's HUD subsidy for operating costs has stayed largely flat in recent years, even as its expenses continue to grow. And city officials said they believed the cuts would get worse by the end of the decade.
Two of the leading Republicans in Washington on housing policy, Representatives Rick A. Lazio of Long Island and Jerry Lewis of California, said they realized that the reductions might be hard for the authorities to shoulder. But they said that with Congress trying to balance the Federal budget, housing agencies had to operate differently.
"The way the Federal Government goes about assisting communities with housing and other services is largely irrational," Mr. Lazio said. "It is based upon a model that is largely obsolete, especially considering the fiscal stresses that we are under."
The New York City Housing Authority has already experimented with turning over a few of its smallest buildings to nonprofit groups to manage. The question now is whether it can save money by letting such groups manage its many high-rise buildings, which are where the vast majority of its tenants live. Or, further down the line, whether it should sell some of the buildings to nonprofit groups or private companies.
Otherwise, if the subsidies continue to decline, the authority might have to focus its resources on keeping up the buildings that are in the best condition.
"The alternatives are to evaluate our projects and try to find alternative places for people and then raze those projects if they can't be maintained," said Roy Sinclair, chief financial officer at the authority.
The average rent in the authority's projects is just under $300 a month, officials said. For an apartment being rented for that amount, the authority currently receives a subsidy of about $300 a month from HUD, giving it a total income for the unit of nearly $600 a month.
For now at least, the authority must abide by a Federal rule that limits the tenant's rent to a maximum of 30 percent of the tenant's income. But if the authority rented the same space for which it had received a total of nearly $600 for a nonworking family instead to a working one, it might be able to charge that family more than $600. Such a move might be even more financially beneficial for the authority if its HUD subsidies continue to drop.
Mr. Martinez, the authority's deputy general manager, said its leaders understood that many tenants were fearful of this new era. He said that the authority would never force people out of their apartments and that by bringing in more working tenants and giving them the opportunity to choose which developments they can live in, it would create a better atmosphere in its properties.
"The major catalyst for all this is the impact of what we see happening at the Federal level in terms of reduction of subsidies," he said. "But the overriding concern is that we have a commitment to maintain the number of public housing units in the community, and to try to enhance a greater quality of life for people."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Fossils as the Focus of an Ethics Debate

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Tyrannosaurus rex is causing trouble again. Only this time, as tomorrow's offering from "Nova" explains, it is not as predator but as the object of conflicting affections.
"Curse of T. Rex" tells of a battle out West, the main source these days of dinosaur skeletons, over what the narrator calls "the finest specimen of Tyrannosaurus rex ever found." Skirmishing began in 1990 when commercial fossil hunters unearthed a remarkably preserved dinosaur, courteously named Sue for its discoverer, on a ranch on a Sioux reservation in South Dakota. 
 That set off a suit by the ranch owner against the Black Hills Institute of Geological Research, the biggest fossil dealer in the world, which had paid him $5,000 for digging rights; claims by a Sioux tribal council that anything found on Indian land was Indian property; criminal charges by Federal agencies, and lamentations from museum and university paleontologists that commercial operators were getting in the way of scientific research.
All parties are heard from tomorrow night as the program digs into the issues. The entrepreneurs maintain they are serving science by locating remains that would otherwise go uncollected. One says, "The best way to insure the preservation of fossils is to collect them and to get as many people out there looking for these fossils as possible."
The paleontologists complain they are being priced out of some digs and warn that information is being lost because private companies, freelance poachers and black-market operators are too intent on making a quick profit from the remains to preserve clues that give the bones context and meaning. "Once we can't trust the data, we can't trust the science that comes from that data."
In the current climate of deregulation, the narrator notes, "Congress is more likely to open up Federal land to market-driven collecting than to toughen laws against it." The hour ends on an upbeat note with an example of cooperation between commercial collectors and researchers.
In the courts, the ranch owner emerged victorious: Summam rex, or, in roughly excavated Latin, king of the bottom line. As for Sue, you'll have an opportunity to take her home from Sotheby's in April. Her owner expects a bid of $1 million.

'Freeloaders'
ABC, tonight at 10
In tonight's ABC News special, John Stossel makes a case that everybody in America, poor, rich and middle, wants a handout. Panhandlers prefer to eat without having to work. Sports moguls get rich on public subsidies. Politicians and corporations collude to rip off the Treasury. The equal treatment of small fry and big cheeses is silly, and its resort to conservative economic theory is strained, but some points are scored.
Particular attention is given to Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland Company, known for its political muscle, its illegal price-fixing and its uplifting commercials on the Sunday talk shows. Mr. Stossel suggests to Mr. Andreas, who gives millions to both political parties and benefits mightily from Government programs for which consumers pay, that he is a hog at the trough. Mr. Andreas grants that's one way to look at it.

HEADLINE: Free On-Line Time for a Price: Ads That Just Don't Go Away

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Just a few years ago, when cyberspace was young, most on-line service providers charged their customers by the hour. These days, offering unlimited access for a set monthly price is practically a necessity for any consumer on-line business.
Now, a small but growing group of Internet access companies is taking the next step: doing away with monthly fees altogether while aiming to make money almost exclusively from advertising. 
 "It was bound to happen," said Evan Neufeld, an analyst in New York for Jupiter Communications, an on-line market research firm. "Internet service providers are not making money at $19.95 all-you-can-eat access, and it seems like prices are going to go down. Unless you're AT&T and can absorb huge losses, you have to look for other revenue streams."
At least three new on-line service providers are no longer charging monthly rates: Cyber Freeway (http://www.cyberfreeway.com/) and Bigger.net (http://www.bigger.net/), both based in San Jose, Calif. and serving the Bay Area, and Smart World Communications Inc. (http:// www.smart1.net/), based in Danbury, Conn., which is aiming to offer Internet access across the country.
Free advertiser-supported E-mail service is available from some other companies, including Juno Online Services L.P. (www.juno.com). Juno's president, Charles Ardai, said his company, based in New York, had more than 1.5 million customers.
But unlike Juno, the three newcomers are offering access to all facets of the Internet, including the World Wide Web.
Getting started on Smart World's system generally costs about $90 upfront, while Bigger.net, a unit of TGGH Inc., promotes itself as "the $59.95 lifetime Internet provider," charging that amount to begin service plus $10 a year to maintain an electronic mail account.
Cyber Freeway, which is being financed by the American subsidiary of Hyper Net Inc., a Japanese company, is now free of any charges for consumers, according to its general manager, Donald L. Tuttle. Mr. Tuttle said Cyber Freeway, which has attracted "a few thousand customers" since opening in December, would begin charging new subscribers a one-time $29.95 fee once the service attracts 20,000 users.
Steven B. Daum, chief executive of Smart World, which expects to have 1,500 high-speed telephone access lines available in 50 metropolitan markets by the end of this week, said, "The model simply is to get the same amount of revenue from the advertisers as we would get from subscribers."
But on-line industry analysts said bringing that model to profitability would not be simple. Bill Bass, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc., a market research firm based in Cambridge, Mass., expects on-line advertising spending to increase from an estimated $400 million this year to almost $5 billion in 2000. Nonetheless, he said: "That's a speck in the advertising universe, an insignificant speck. There just aren't enough advertising dollars out there to support everyone on-line."
Kate Delhagen, another Forrester analyst, is skeptical about the services' prospects for success. "I'm of the school of thought that you get what you pay for," she said, "and the reliability of these networks and service providers remains to be proven."
For now, Smart World's only advertising revenue comes from banners on its World Wide Web home page that disappear when a user begins surfing to other sites. Customers seem happy with that approach.
"I would not go any other way," said Thomas R. McDowell, an on-line consumer who is also a technical support representative for an AT&T subsidiary in Jacksonville, Fla. "You pay one time and that's it."
But Smart World is developing access software that will place advertisements on the user's computer screen for as long as the customer is on line, regardless of where they roam in cyberspace. Cyber Freeway already uses a similar program.
Contemplating that possibility, Mr. McDowell was less enthusiastic.
"I would not like that," he said. "I wouldn't want it to be always on the screen. That would be very obtrusive."

HEADLINE: Radcliffe Women, Once Docile, Prod Harvard Sharply on Equality of Sexes

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 23

 BODY:
The men at Harvard have always been educated to lead the world. Peggy Schmertzler recalls a different set of expectations for her and her classmates at Harvard's neighbor, Radcliffe, in the 1950's.
"I remember the deans' telling us an educated person made the best mother," recalled Mrs. Schmertzler, Class of '53. "She could sing French songs to her children." 
 On graduating with a history degree from one of the finest schools in the country, Mrs. Schmertzler promptly enrolled in a private summer secretarial school that was conveniently located on the Radcliffe campus. And, also as expected, she married a Harvard man.
Now Mrs. Schmertzler and a group of other Radcliffe women -- many of them having raised their children, survived divorce, carved out careers despite society's barriers, having been bolstered by the women's movement that most of them did not participate in at the time, having come of age, belatedly, in their 50's and 60's -- are turning their attention toward Cambridge.
Concerned about their grandchildren, who might one day attend the university, and about a younger generation of academic women, Mrs. Schmertzler and her classmates are challenging Harvard for the first time in their lives.
The university has changed dramatically since their day, when they lived in Radcliffe Yard but took classes at Harvard where the men outnumbered them 4 to 1. Radcliffe officially merged with Harvard in 1977, and today the dorms are coed, and women make up 44 percent of the undergraduate student body. But Mrs. Schmertzler and the other members of her group say more change is needed.
In the midst of Harvard's $2.1 billion capital fund-raising campaign, they have mounted an organized challenge to what they see as evidence of the university's persistent sexism: its unimpressive record of hiring tenured women as faculty members.
They have so far persuaded alumni to divert nearly $500,000 in gifts into a protest escrow account to try to force Harvard to act. And though the amount may be relatively small, Harvard is smarting at the unwelcome attention.
Neil L. Rudenstine, the university president, sent Mrs. Schmertzler a letter 10 days ago, stating his strong commitment to hiring more female faculty members, outlining the university's progress in that area and saying that he and others wished it could occur more rapidly.
The women of the 1950's are out of patience. "Harvard has been educating brilliant women for over 100 years," Mrs. Schmertzler said. "The women are available."
"Do it now, Harvard," she added. "If you think we're going to send our grandchildren here, we're not."
The women's transformation can be charted by their reunions. At first, they talked about their husbands and their children. At the 25th, the stars talked about their professional success. At the 30th, the subject was divorce, the deaths of parents, troubled children.
Finally, at the 35th reunion, the women were ready to look beyond themselves. They wanted to know what Harvard is for women today.
"Maybe it's because we had older daughters we were concerned that women had more opportunities," said Mrs. Schmertzler, who worked as a waitress and as a secretary before going back to college and becoming a job placement director for a nonprofit organization.
They learned that in 1988 women accounted for only 7 percent of the arts and sciences faculty. They formed the Committee for the Equality of Women at Harvard, with Mrs. Schmertzler its chairwoman.
Being Radcliffe women, they did their homework, thoroughly researching Harvard's record on women. Mrs. Schmertzler reported their findings at her 40th reunion, in 1993. "I felt I was going to be arrested," she said. "I had never asserted myself. And here I was going against Harvard."
Word of Mrs. Schmertzler's report spread to the Radcliffe Class of 1958, which was on campus for its 35th reunion. Many of its members joined the committee, including Ann R. Shapiro, who returned to college in her 40's and now is an English professor at the State University of New York in Farmingdale, and Millie Marnin, who earned her Ph.D. in economics from Northwestern University in 1966, becoming the first woman in the department in 30 years.
From another class, Lilli S. Hornig, who received a Ph.D. in chemistry from Harvard in 1950 despite the male professors who she said tried to discourage her, was a staff scientist at Los Alamos, N.M., in World War II and later helped found an organization at Wellesley College to improve opportunities for academic women, became the committee's research policy analyst.
Today, Mrs. Schmertzler says, the committee has nearly 2,000 alumni members, men as well as women.
The Radcliffe women have become advocates for a younger generation of academic women at Harvard. Because of the intensely political world of the university, many of those women say they do not feel free to speak out.
Mary Waters, a 39-year-old sociology professor, was willing to talk for the record. "They're incredibly courageous," she said of Mrs. Schmertzler's group. "These women are unique in their position in being able to speak up. They're not worried about their jobs or their future careers."
Prompted in part by the efforts of the committee, Seyla Benhabib, a professor of political theory and a former chairwoman of the arts and sciences faculty's Standing Committee on the Status of Women, said she and a small group of other senior faculty members were looking into ways that the atmosphere for female junior faculty members at Harvard could be improved and the ranks of tenured women increased.
The members of the committee acknowledge that Harvard had made progress. Today, of 418 senior faculty members of the faculty of arts and sciences, 48, or 11.5 percent, are women. From 1991 to 1996, the number of tenured women in the faculty of arts and sciences increased by 26 percent, to 48 from 38, while its tenured faculty as a whole grew by 6 percent, Mr. Rudenstine wrote in his letter.
Harvard's record is not unusual in the Ivy League. At Princeton, the rate of tenured women in the arts and sciences faculty is 14.7 percent; the rate at Yale is 11.5 percent.
Nationally, however, women hold 24.5 percent of tenured professorships in faculties of arts and sciences, the American Association of University Professors says.
Harvard officials argue that the university's record cannot be compared with other schools because, unlike the overwhelming majority of schools, it does not grant tenure to associate professors.
Mr. Rudenstine explained in his letter to Mrs. Schmertzler that while a "university-wide master plan" that would rapidly accelerate the number of women might be appealing, power over the recruitment and promotion of candidates remained within the individual departments of the university's nine faculties.
The women's movement was nowhere in sight when Mrs. Schmertzler and her classmates arrived at Radcliffe. And many of them were suspicious of the movement when it did begin.
"I was very fearful of being a feminist," said Mrs. Schmertzler, whose father, a prominent Baltimore doctor, believed college was wasted on his daughters. "I thought it was a dirty word. I fell for the myth. I prided myself on being reasonable and sensible."
Mrs. Schmertzler had been returning to Cambridge for her reunions since 1963, the class's 10th reunion. Recently divorced and with three young children, she attended only after a friend talked her into it. "I thought it would be too horrible," she said. "I was feeling disgraced.
"It was just God's gift," recalled Mrs. Schmertzler, who has since remarried. "There was this group of fabulous women. Nobody came with spouses, or with children. We were there as ourselves. Being with other women, just on our own, was a thrill."
Books like Marilyn French's "The Women's Room" provided yet more solace. "It was a revelation to find that I wasn't just isolated, and a misfit," Mrs. Schmertzler said.
She was talking at the Harvard Faculty Club the other day with Dr. Hornig and another committee member, Betsy Hatfield, Class of '53, who started out as a high school English teacher but is today a banker.
They were joined by one of their student supporters, 19-year-old Lamelle Rawlins. It is not only among the faculty where change occurs slowly: in December, Ms. Rawlins was elected the first female president of the Harvard undergraduate student body. For her, Ms. Rawlins said, the members of the committee are role models.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Committee for the Equality of Women at Harvard, from left, Lilli Hornig, Betsy Hatfield and Peggy Schmertzler met with Lamelle Rawlins, right, the first female president of Harvard's student body. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Differing View of the Spread of Technology

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Disputing earlier conclusions that the Information Revolution is bypassing much of rural America, a new study financed by the National Science Foundation argues that information technology is becoming more and more equally distributed across the country.
The new study takes issue with one released last fall by researchers at the Taub Urban Research Center of New York University. That study showed that 50 percent of all United States Internet host computers were in just five states: California, Massachusetts, New York, Texas and Virginia, and that 90 percent of all Internet host computers were in just 21 states, primarily on the East and West Coasts and in a Midwest belt. 
 But Shane Greenstein, an economist at the Institute for Government and Public Affairs at the University of Illinois and one of the authors of the new report, criticized the Taub report for focusing on the Internet at only a single snapshot in time.
The new study, which will be published as a report of the National Bureau of Economic Research, purports to show a broader picture of communications and computer technologies and indicates that between the mid-1980's and early 1990's, such advanced technology became more equally distributed across the United States.
"The Cassandras are definitely wrong," Mr. Greenstein said. "Communication and computer technologies are becoming more geographically diffused."
The data are significant, the researchers said, because if private investment in advanced networks is quickly reaching most of America, there will be less need for Government intervention with public investment.
The report, "The Evolution of Advanced Large-Scale Information Infrastructure in the United States," was also written by Mercedes M. Lizardo, a researcher in the department of economics at the University of Illinois, and by Pablo Spiller, an economist at the Walter A. Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.
The study relied on data, collected between 1986 and 1992, on the deployment of fiber optic communication networks and the installation of large business computers. The data were originally gathered by the Federal Communications Commission and by Computer Intelligence Infocorp, a market research firm based in La Jolla, Calif.
The deployment of fiber optic network connections is a good indicator of the availability of a wide range of advanced data and voice communications services, the researchers noted.
The data, which show the number of miles of fiber optic cable deployed in each region of the country and computer capacity measured in terms of MIPS, or millions of instructions per second, indicate that computer and communications capacities have increasingly become more evenly distributed.
Mr. Greenstein said fiber optic mileage in the United States jumped from 265,472 to 6,316,436 miles during the period of the study. Over the same six years, national computing capacity expanded from 112,000 to 553,231 MIPS.
In addition to measuring the absolute increase in computer and communications capacity, the researchers used a series of statistical techniques to measure changes in concentration over time. They found strong evidence of decreasing concentration of what they call the "advanced backbone information technology."
"With normal market forces things have gotten better for the vast majority of locations in the United States," Mr. Greenstein said. For example, in 1986 about 28 percent of the nation's local telecommunications providers did not have fiber deployed in their regions. Six years later only about 4 percent did not.
Mr. Greenstein said the group's data showed that there were still some pockets that had been excluded from access to advanced communications and computer networks, but added that they were the exception.
He said that by and large the deployment of fiber optic networks had followed the same routes carved out first by telegraph and then by long-distance telephone networks. These communications lines have generally been laid down along railroad rights-of-way.
Underlying the rapid dispersion of information technology capabilities is their use by industries like finance, insurance and real estate, which tend to rely more heavily on computers than traditional manufacturing industries but also tend to be more evenly distributed geographically, Mr. Greenstein said.
Mr. Greenstein predicted that the Internet would eventually follow this pattern as well. He said his research group is now conducting a study of the geographic dispersion of Internet service providers.

HEADLINE: Union Is Losing Battle With an Island Resort

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C.

 BODY:
Three years ago, the housekeepers, drivers, cooks and waiters of the Melrose Club, a luxurious private resort on South Carolina's isolated Daufuskie Island, won an epochal victory by voting to form the first trade union in Beaufort County.
That vote, and the union's attainment of wage and benefit concessions last summer after two years of arduous contract negotiations, reverberated across Calibogue Sound to the hotels and resorts here on Hilton Head. Before long, the union's victory had echoed throughout the burgeoning hospitality industry in America's least-unionized state. 
 But less than five months after the club's 165 employees celebrated the ratification of their first contract, most of them are out of work and the union is fighting for its life. On Dec. 31, new owners took control of the resort. Just before the sale, all the workers were dismissed; few have been rehired by the new owner.
The union's precipitous descent serves as an object lesson about the halting nature of labor organizing these days, a lesson that has particular resonance in the hard-to-unionize South. While the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has focused new attention on the region, unions here continue to face serious obstacles, and groundbreaking advances are often followed by demoralizing defeats.
"Here they played by all the rules," said George W. Hopkins, a labor historian at the College of Charleston in South Carolina. "They made the case to the workers, they had an election, they won and now they find the victory snatched out from under them. It's got to be tremendously dispiriting to the workers to have this happen after a long campaign."
In general, the last decade has been a dispiriting one for organized labor, and nowhere more so than in the South. Here, the combination of right-to-work laws that allow workers to refuse to pay dues to unions that represent them, and a historical antipathy toward unionization have helped lure large employers and contributed to rapid job growth.
From 1985 to 1995, a period when employment in private business rose 23 percent in the 11 states of the former Confederacy, the number of private-sector union members in the region dropped 19 percent, according to statistics from the Bureau of National Affairs, a private research organization. In that period, the proportion of all private-sector workers unionized in those states dropped to 4.7 percent from 7.1 percent.
The decline in unionization in the South, measured both in the number of workers and in their percentage of the work force, has exceeded the drop throughout the nation as a whole. The proportion of the private-sector work force that is unionized nationwide dropped to 10.3 percent in 1995 from 14.3 percent in 1985.
There have been some notable successes for labor in the South in recent years, but not enough to offset the economy's transformation from manufacturing to service industries, which are less prone to unionization, said Bruce S. Raynor, the Southern regional director of the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, or Unite.
In South Carolina, where just 2.3 percent of private-sector workers are unionized, the employees of only 34 companies have voted on whether to unionize in the last three years, with management winning in 21 elections and labor winning 13, according to the State Chamber of Commerce.
That is what made it so remarkable that in October 1994, the Melrose employees voted 98 to 45 to join Local 465 of the International Union of Operating Engineers. Fed up with erratic management and a gradual erosion of their benefits, the workers said, they embraced the union. Then they settled in for two years of negotiations, demonstrations and charges of unfair labor practices that produced a contract last August. The contract granted raises that averaged 13 percent over two years.
Predictably, the unionization battle on Daufuskie, a moss-draped island accessible only by boat that did not get telephone service until 1977, has taken on racial overtones.
Both the new and former owners of the 772-acre resort are wealthy and white. Shortly after the resort opened in 1987, with a golf course designed by Jack Nicklaus, an elegant inn, tennis courts and an equestrian center, its memberships sold for $75,000 and annual dues ran to $2,300.
By contrast, many of the displaced workers are poor and black. Some are the progeny of slaves who harvested indigo and Sea Island cotton on these barrier islands. Now, the descendants often earn meager wages trimming the greens and making the beds at rich people's resorts, many of which, they caustically note, have "plantation" as part of their names.
In the contract battle, labor organizers played on Old South imagery, circulating handbills that depicted cotton-picking slaves and described the Melrose Club as "a plantation where they treat workers like they own them."
Now that they must rally their dejected members, union organizers have dusted off that theme. "I think it's a case of white people who want black people to be servants, and in the Southern United States I think it's hard not to see it in stark racial terms," said Simon B. Greer, a white New York native hired by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to help organize workers at Melrose and elsewhere in South Carolina.
Black employees who were dismissed from Melrose seem less eager to paint the conflict in racial terms. But many are at a loss to explain why they were dismissed from jobs that often required great sacrifice for modest pay.
Annette Y. Campbell, who worked as a cook for $8.56 an hour, said she would rise at 3 A.M. to complete the 45-minute drive from her home in Savannah, Ga., in time to catch the 5:30 A.M. ferry from Hilton Head to Daufuskie. Eric L. Coney, a bus driver with seven years of experience who was earning $10.18 an hour, said he particularly resented picking up the newspaper and finding a classified advertisement seeking applicants for his job.
The management of the resort, now named Daufuskie Island Club and Resort, which is owned by the Club Corporation of America, based in Dallas, maintains that it has not rehired many of the Melrose workers because it wants a fresh start for a development that had been plagued by financial problems. Part of that process, said Arch Y. Stokes, the Atlanta lawyer who represents the resort in labor matters, is seeking the best qualified employees for every position.
That hiring process has created a new work force that includes only a minority of union members. Under Federal law, a union can claim to represent workers only if it has the support of a majority of the company's nonmanagement employees.
"It is illegal for an employer in America to recognize a union that has not lawfully established itself as representing a majority of the employees," Mr. Stokes said.
David K. Miller, an international representative for the union, estimated that 141 Melrose workers had been dismissed at the end of the year and that only 37 had been rehired. Mr. Miller said he believed the new owners clearly intended to break the union.
On Jan. 24, he filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board accusing the resort of unfair labor practices, including its refusal "to hire former Melrose Club Inc. employees to avoid its bargaining obligation and in retaliation for their union representation and activity." If the union does not win its fight against the resort's hiring practices, it will have to decide whether to give up or begin another organizing drive with the new workers.
Willie L. Clark, Southern regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, said the new company would be guilty of unfair labor practices if it is found to have deliberately not hired former unionized employees in an effort to kill the union. If the board rules in favor of the union, the agency could force the resort to rehire workers and pay them lost wages.
"If you're going to hire a new work force, generally it's easier to hire somebody who already knows the job than somebody who you have to train," Mr. Clark said. "Why would you do a wholesale dismissal?"

(Photographs by Greg Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CHINA AFTER DENG: DIPLOMACY;
U.S. AND CHINESE SEEN NEAR A DEAL ON HUMAN RIGHTS

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 23

 BODY:
After seven months of secret diplomacy, American and Chinese officials seem to be within striking distance of a breakthrough in their longstanding dispute over human rights. At issue is the fate of thousands of Chinese political and religious dissidents held in prisons, labor camps or just at home under heavy guard or surveillance.
Under the terms of a deal that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will seek to nudge toward agreement when she arrives in Beijing on Monday for her first official visit, China would agree to sign two important United Nations covenants on human rights, release a representative group of up to eight political prisoners and restart talks with the International Committee of the Red Cross aimed at establishing a program of prison visits to determine the status of the thousands of prisoners of conscience in China. 
 In return, China could expect to bring an end to the annual confrontation over its human rights record at the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva.
For President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin, this prospective breakthrough comes at a time of extraordinary opportunity and risk.
With the death last week of Deng Xiaoping, it accords the new generation of Chinese leaders an early chance to end the period of harsh repression that has followed the Tiananmen massacre of 1989.
[Ms. Albright arrived in Beijing on Monday, stepping off her plane only hours after the body of Mr. Deng arrived at the Babaoshan cemetery for cremation.]
To emerge from their long "defensive crouch," as a former American Ambassador, J. Stapleton Roy, once called it, China's new leaders would have to stand up to the hard-line forces in the Communist Party. Those forces see any act of political tolerance or human rights concessions to Washington as appeasing those who would like to topple Communist rule here.
It is anyone's guess as to whether the Chinese feel confident enough to go forward. But American officials point to two important factors.
First, the leading hard-liner, Prime Minister Li Peng, has predicted in internal leadership discussions that he can pull off an acceptable deal with the Americans that would help China's case before the Human Rights Commission in Geneva.
The commission meets from March 10 to April 18 this year and will again take up a resolution calling for an investigation into human rights conditions in China. Beijing has defeated the resolution each time, often by narrow margins.
Chinese officials say such an achievement by Mr. Li would boost his campaign to gain a prestigious party post and retain supervision of China's foreign affairs after he steps down as Prime Minister next year.
The second factor is that both Chinese and American officials have known since November that Wang Dan, a student leader of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement who was sentenced to 14 years in prison last fall, is willing to go into exile in exchange for his freedom.
Mr. Wang is one of the best known of the eight dissidents on the list presented in July by Anthony Lake, who was then Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, in talks with Communist Party leaders. Mr. Wang's release and arrival in the United States, which has already privately conveyed a willingness to provide him asylum, would be a dramatic 11th-hour concession by China.
Since November, China has released three other political prisoners on the list, apparently in response to the American requirements: Chen Ziming, sentenced as one of the "black hands" behind the 1989 demonstrations; a dissident from Inner Mongolia named Ulan Shovo, and Xi Yang, a journalist.
For Mr. Clinton, who took political risks in breaking the link between China's human rights performance and its trade status that was imposed by his predecessor, a demonstration of tangible gains would vindicate his policy of engagement.
But Mr. Clinton, whose Presidency now faces an extended investigation into Asian fund-raising efforts during his re-election campaign, will need concessions that are able to withstand Congressional scrutiny.
One difficult issue for Mr. Clinton is deciding how many prisoners among the eight cases raised would have to be released to declare progress. One is Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known dissident, who has served 17 years of a total of 29 years and for whom Mr. Clinton once showed great public concern.
With both China and the United States constrained by domestic political considerations, Ms. Albright appeared to be lowering expectations for her first meeting with Chinese leaders since she became Secretary of State. Her senior aides indicated that she was maneuvering to give the Chinese an opportunity to get through the period of Mr. Deng's funeral before the final hard bargaining on the Geneva resolution.
"The emphasis in China over the coming weeks and months is likely to be on continuity, on stability within the leadership, on building consensus within the leadership," said a senior official who briefed reporters traveling with Ms. Albright. "In other words, nothing risky."
"Our expectations are not too high," he said, adding, "Based on the current situation, we expect to proceed with the resolution."
Last week, the State Department sent cablegrams to the 53 nations on the Human Rights Commission saying that without a breakthrough in the talks, Washington intended to go forward with plans to sponsor the resolution in Geneva calling China to account for human rights abuses.
But Administration officials have been careful to say the final decision to go forward will be made closer to the Geneva meeting. American officials also hope that the brinksmanship in the talks, or recriminations over failure, will not disrupt the visit of Vice President Al Gore to Asia in March, but Beijing has withheld final dates for his stay.
"While one can always hope for human rights progress, we shouldn't expect any dramatic movement forward in the next few days," the official traveling with Ms. Albright said. "We obviously would welcome a gesture now or at any point in next few months."
Mike Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of Human Rights Watch, said: "Mrs. Albright is hoping that the Chinese will make significant enough concessions that the Administration could credibly back off on going forward in Geneva. For the Chinese, they want to avoid the kind of loss of face that would arise from another debate and from a vote in Geneva."
John T. Kamm, a former president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong who regularly travels to Beijing on behalf of political prisoner cases, said that for the Chinese, "with the passing of Deng, a new beginning is possible."
"There is now a window of opportunity for China to demonstrate that it intends to live by international standards of human rights," he said. "If Jiang Zemin were to make this decision, it would demonstrate to the outside world and especially to Hong Kong that he is stepping in and being very decisive. But there is going to be considerable opposition in the party to doing this."
A crucial issue this year has been whether China would sign and then ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and a similar document on economic, social and cultural rights. Together, they would obligate China not only to uphold freedom of speech, assembly and religious worship while also adhering to due process of law, but also to report on its human rights situation to the international community.
"We think signing the covenants would be an extremely important step forward for China," said a French diplomat here.
China has said only that it will sign the documents without committing itself to a specific date and has used that vague commitment to try to split the American and European alliance that has formed each year in Geneva. Last year China tried a similar tactic, but after "consideration," did not sign the covenants.
Similarly, while China has invited a senior Red Cross official to visit Beijing, it has refused to make a specific commitment to go ahead with the agency's prison visit program, which has been the subject of many fruitless negotiations.
"We look for progress on various issues," said the official with Ms. Albright. "We don't expect the visits themselves to be merely symbolic. We want them to provide evidence of an improvement in relations."
Stanley Roth, who is expected to become Ms. Albright's assistant secretary of state for Asian affairs, told an interviewer in Washington this weekend that "the relationship cannot be a one-way street."
"If there is no improvement in all the issues the United States cares about," Mr. Roth said, it will be "very hard to create support for a broad relationship."
