LENGTH: 961 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Making of a Myth Who Rode Into the Sunset

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

JOHN WAYNE'S AMERICA
The Politics of Celebrity
By Garry Wills
380 pages. Simon and Schuster. $26.
Gen. Douglas MacArthur thought he was the very model of the American soldier, even though he never served in the military. The critic Eric Bentley thought he was "the most important man in America," the man who helped start the Vietnam War. The young Newt Gingrich tried to imitate his walk; and the mature Ronald Reagan tried to imitate his manner. Richard Nixon thought a lot of America's social problems could be solved if more people took this actor as a role model, and Oliver North and Pat Buchanan borrowed their battle cries -- "Saddle Up!" and "Lock and Load!" -- from one of his movies. 
 The man, of course, was John Wayne.
As Garry Wills observes in his discursive new book, Wayne became for many Americans a "conduit they used to communicate with their own desired selves or their own imagined past." "When he was called the American, it was a statement of what his fans wanted America to be," Mr. Wills writes. "For them, Wayne always struck an elegiac note. He stood for an America people felt was disappearing or had disappeared, for a time 'when men were men.' "
In "John Wayne's America: The Politics of Celebrity," Mr. Wills sets out to examine "the complex idea conveyed on the screen" in the course of Wayne's career, "a compound idea of what American manhood is in the minds of the vast majority of Americans." Although Mr. Wills brings his usual acumen and fluency to this discussion, the long-winded volume he has produced is really little more than a modest essay, padded out to book length with biographical asides, tired analyses of Wayne's movies and detailed assessments of his work with the directors John Ford and Howard Hawks. The central focus of the book is often lost, as though Mr. Wills felt compelled to use all the research he'd accumulated along the way or simply wanted to showcase his abilities as a film critic.
Much of the factual material in "John Wayne's America" retraces ground covered by earlier books like "John Wayne: American" by Randy Roberts and James S. Olson and Tag Gallagher's "John Ford: The Man and His Films." As for Mr. Wills's ideas about Wayne, they, too, tend to range from the familiar to the predictable. We are told that Wayne's screen persona embodied the American myth of the frontier, and that it also embodied "a politics of large meanings" -- "a politics of gender (masculine), ideology (patriotism), character (self-reliance) and responsibility."
Like many writers before him, Mr. Wills points out the contradictions in Wayne's life. He notes that the big-screen warrior, who denounced those who refused to serve in Vietnam as "soft," got out of serving in World War II so he could focus on his career; that the star of so many horse epics actually hated horses; that the indomitable man of the West was born in Iowa with the very unmacho name of Marion Morrison. Indeed this volume's central narrative traces John Wayne's creation of a mythic persona: an invented self that projected an aura of authority, autonomy and slumberous power.
"Wayne was careful about the persona, not accepting things that would endanger it," Mr. Wills writes. "He refused to play a coward for Howard Hawks. He refused to shoot a man in the back for Don Siegel. He would be villainous, but not weak."
The raw materials for John Wayne the persona were Wayne's imposing physique and an economical, purposive body language, which combined with the famous Wayne voice (stop-and-go phrasing, melodic rhythms and an easy timbre) to convey an air of inevitability and control. Like so many things, this physical presence was consciously crafted -- shaped by the lessons Wayne learned from Yakima Canutt, the veteran cowboy stuntman, and Harry Carey, the cowboy star of Ford's early silent films.
Though Ford would later take credit for inventing John Wayne, Mr. Wills notes that the director Raoul Walsh was the one who first spotted Wayne moving props on the Fox set back in 1929 and decided to make him a star. As for Wayne's mature persona -- as a middle-aged authority figure radiating command -- it came to fruition in Hawks's 1948 classic, "Red River," in which he played the brutal cattle owner Dunson. The character of Dunson, in turn, would inform many of Wayne's most powerful later roles, including Stryker, the tough Marine sergeant in "Sands of Iwo Jima" (1949) and Ethan Edwards, the implacable avenger in "The Searchers," Ford's 1956 masterpiece.
By 1948, Wayne had become a fierce anti-Communist, and many of his subsequent pictures evinced a distinct political subtext. By waging World War II in "Sands," Wayne's character was, in effect, waging the cold war; and in Ford's three Seventh Calvary pictures ("Fort Apache" (1948), "She Wore a Yellow Ribbon" (1949) and "Rio Grande" (1950), Wayne became, in Mr. Wills's words, "the cool but determined model for Americans living with continual danger." The image in those films of United States Cavalry units surrounded by hostile Indians not only served as a metaphor for what was perceived as America's embattled place in the world, but also helped to ratify imperial ambitions.
In the wake of confusion over Vietnam, the ideological certainties purveyed by these films -- and brought to an absurd culmination by "The Green Berets" in 1968 -- had begun to fray, and Wayne's career was in danger of reaching a dead end. What he did in movies like "True Grit" (1969), "Big Jake" (1971) and his final movie, "The Shootist" (1976), Mr. Wills argues, is recognize "that his success would now depend on becoming a living anachronism."
He had become a living monument to a West that had been tamed, a frontier that had closed.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
A Case of Rape, Memory and DNA

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The script is not unknown to real-life television: a wrongful conviction, a long stay in prison, final exoneration. Tonight's absorbing "Frontline" uses such a case to inquire into the vagaries of memory and the fallibility of eyewitness testimony.
"What Jennifer Saw" goes back to a summer night in 1984. Jennifer Thompson, then 22 and a college student in Burlington, N.C., tells of being raped by a black man who broke into her apartment. She believes she retained images of his face in "little brief pieces of light that I could piece together." Following up on an anonymous tip, the police show her several photographs, from which she chooses Ronald Cotton; later she picks him out in a police lineup. 
 This carefully reported hour takes pains to make clear that this was not a stereotypical case of old-fashioned Southern justice. Mr. Cotton was a plausible suspect. He had a police record, including a conviction for rape, and a shaky alibi. But given little physical evidence, the prosecution relied on Ms. Thompson's identification during the trial. A lawyer comments: "It is incredibly powerful evidence, and jurors want to believe the victim. They identify with the victim and especially when there's really no motive for the victim to lie. It is very hard evidence to overcome."
By Ms. Thompson's own account to the program's interviewer, she was determined to give a face to her tormenter, glimpsed in the dimness and through the emotions of that horrific night. There is no suggestion here that she purposely lied, but a psychologist who has studied memory (but was not deemed sufficiently expert by the judge to testify at the Cotton trial) gives examples of how shaky eyewitness testimony can be.
Elizabeth Loftus, another student of memory, who has appeared on "Frontline" before with criticism of the way so-called memories have been extracted from children in sex-abuse cases, maintains that eyewitness accounts are subject to all manner of influences and often seem more definitive in the courtroom than they are in fact.
Convicted and sentenced to life, Mr. Cotton spent 11 years in prison before his innocence was proved by DNA evidence and the real rapist was arrested and confessed. The narrator notes, "Ronald Cotton was only the latest in a string of prisoners released because DNA had shown that they were wrongfully convicted." (Among the experts heard from affirming the scientific credibility of DNA tests are Peter Neufeld and Barry Scheck, known to followers of the O. J. Simpson criminal trial for casting doubt on the DNA evidence presented against their client.)
A troubled Ms. Thompson does not quarrel with the DNA results, but for her the image remains: "I still see Ronald Cotton."
 
'Black America'
'Facing the Millennium'
PBS, tonight at 10
(Check local listings)
This attempt to grapple with the deepest concerns of black Americans -- political, economic, cultural -- is too ambitious to ignore but too spotty to recommend. The essays and discussions by black academics, writers and others provide as many slogans as original insights, as much hot air as fresh air.
The production, credited to three producers with very different techniques, adds to the hour's clutter. If you tune in, my advice would be to stay alert for the comments of Glenn Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University; he has a reputation as a conservative, but he's a lot more interesting than that.

HEADLINE: A Dam Open, Grand Canyon Roars Again

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
LAST March, in a precedent-setting effort to turn back the ecological clock, Federal officials unleashed four roaring jets of white water from a Federal hydroelectric dam on the Colorado River. The objective was to mimic the annual floods that for millenniums, until the dam was built, had set the terms of life at the bottom of the Grand Canyon.
The plants and animals of the river and its Grand Canyon shores evolved with the West's spring and summer floods and were superbly adapted to them. These floods not only poured nutrients into the ecosystem, but they also carved its architecture by redistributing sand from the river bottom, shaping it into sand bars and creating backwaters where fish could breed and grow. 
 The advent of the Glen Canyon Dam in 1963, 15 miles above the Grand Canyon, short-circuited this process, initiating an ecological decline that pushed several of the canyon's unique species to the brink of extinction.
So when 45,000 cubic feet of water thundered out of the dam's flumes each second for a week, the first experiment of its kind at a big Federal dam in the West, the air was filled with hosannas to a new era.
But has the experiment really panned out? The formal reports from a corps of scientists are only now coming in, and the picture is decidedly mixed.
The flood did build many new beaches, sand bars and backwaters. Some of the beaches made superb camp sites for the canyon's abundant river rafters. But the deluge was not strong enough to flush non-native species from the system, as had been hoped. Among these intruders are carp and catfish that compete with and prey on endangered natives like the humpback and bony-tailed chubs, the Colorado squawfish and the razorback sucker. Experts say that a natural flood, on average more than twice as powerful as the controlled one, would have swept away the non-natives, while the natives, more suited to watery cataclysm, survived.
Short of partly renovating the dam to allow it to pass more water safely, the full restorative effects of flooding cannot be exploited, some experts say. Furthermore, the effects of a restorative flood are not permanent. Many of the new beaches and sand bars have been steadily eroding. That was expected, but now nature has thrown a curve: high water caused by heavy snows in the last two winters forced the Government last week to increase somewhat the normal flow from Lake Powell, behind the dam. Rather than building the beaches and bars, this flow is expected to speed their erosion.
All this testifies to the difficulty of restoring natural processes once human activity has drastically altered them. In this case, the experiment has shown that controlled flooding "is only a tool, it's not a panacea," said David L. Wegner, an aquatic ecologist and engineer who directed the Glen Canyon scientific experiment for the Federal Government until recently. He now heads a private consulting company, Ecosystem Management International Inc., in Flagstaff, Ariz.
Still, whatever its ecological outcome, the experiment is widely seen as a breakthrough in another arena, that of politics and policy. In the past, Western dams like the one at Glen Canyon have been operated with only two considerations in mind: producing electrical power and providing water to farms and cities downstream. Protecting nature was nowhere in the picture. Now it is, along with a whole range of human activities that depend on it, like angling, boating, camping and nature study -- all the tourist-related activities that economically define what is called the New West.
So while the Grand Canyon experiment is only a beginning, many say its main importance may be that it has shown that widely divergent interests, all of whom took part in the planning, can compromise in trying to give nature freer rein.
With the Grand Canyon flood, "we're taking a whole new step toward restoring river systems and not just destroying them," said Pam Hyde, the southwestern regional director for American Rivers, a national environmental group.
Federally licensed private hydroelectric dams in the East are increasingly attuning their operations to nature's requirements. But the Grand Canyon experiment is said to be the first involving a big Federal dam in the West. There are scores of these, and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who pushed the button to start the Grand Canyon flood, said in an interview that the experiment "has enormous implications for river management all over the West" and that the lessons of Glen Canyon will be applied to other rivers.
Before the Colorado was dammed, the big floods that created and refurbished habitat for native fish worked mostly on the downstream side of tributaries, which pushed boulders out into the main stream, narrowing it and creating rapids. Where the river widened again just below the tributary's mouth, circular eddies formed and the flood waters slowed. This allowed sand scoured from the river bottom to settle and create a submerged bar thrusting out into the main stream. After the flood subsided, a calm backwater formed behind the now-exposed sandbar.
During the deluge, native fish that had evolved with flooding "would go right against the side wall of the canyon, where the velocity is lowest, and put their noses right into the wall and ride out the flood," said Dr. Edmund D. Andrews, a geophysicist who is co-leader of a team of experts at the United States Geological Survey office in Boulder, Colo., who have extensively studied the 1996 controlled flood. The non-native fish stuck to mid-stream and were carried away, leaving the backwater spawning habitat to the natives.
The flood also pumped new energy into the ecosystem by stirring up vast deposits of nitrates, phosphates and carbon, in the form of decaying vegetation and other organic matter, that had been trapped in the bottom sediments. These liberated nutrients fed algae and microscopic animals at the bottom of the food chain and re-nourished native streamside plants like honey mesquite, cat's-claw acacia and coyote willow.
The Glen Canyon Dam interrupted this life-giving cycle. Sandbars eroded. Backwaters dried up. Widely distributed invasive species like the catfish and carp ate the scarce, isolated natives and competed with them for food and spawning habitat. Invasive plants like the tamarisk, a native of Egypt, crowded out natives along the shoreline. Nutrients remained locked away, useless.
The objective of the "spike flow" last March was to re-establish the natural process while avoiding serious harm to a blue-ribbon trout fishery just below the dam, to endangered species like the Kanab ambersnail and to 4,000-year-old Native American archeological, cultural and religious sites near the water's edge.
The scientific papers now emerging show that the flood heightened and slightly widened existing sandbars, built scores of new camping beaches, liberated large quantities of nutrients and created 20 percent more backwater area for spawning fish. No endangered species were significantly harmed, it was found. Nor was the trout fishery, although some experts are unsure what would happen to it if floods became routine. No archeological sites were damaged; indeed, some were actually protected from erosion damage by a new blanket of sediment.
But the sandbars and beaches were found to be eroding not long after the flood, and higher everyday water releases made necessary by the heavy runoff of melting snow rendered the backwaters unusable for spawning. Non-native fish species and large, invading shoreline plants were scarcely affected.
All in all, Mr. Wegner said, "It's a little early to claim success."
As things stand now, experts say, going very far beyond the March 1996 flow level would probably require releasing water through its spillways rather than through special conduits around the dam, as is ordinarily done. Some of the experts say they fear that the force of a historic-size flow could damage or even destroy the dam. Dr. Andrews, for one, suggests that for about $120 million in dam renovations, it would be possible and economically feasible to restore floods of historic velocity. Long-term recreation revenue might help offset costs.
A Government analysis calculated the cost of last spring's flow at $1.8 million in foregone electrical generating capacity. The Government absorbed this cost rather than pass it along to consumers of electricity. Some experts suggest that in the future, consumers should bear part of the cost, since the ecological damage is caused by the need to supply power.
Future controlled floods might not be as expensive as the first, however. One important scientific finding was that most of the Grand Canyon flood's ecological effects were felt in the first 48 hours of the weeklong flow. This suggests that a substantially shorter and therefore less costly flood might achieve the same results. Dr. Andrews said the consensus of his group was that several new, short spike flows might be an ecologically healthier way to dispose of this year's heavy runoff of melting snow than a steady, somewhat heightened everyday flow.
In the meantime, officials, scientists and water managers are hoping that the 13-year research project leading up to last spring's controlled flood has answered enough questions so that any future floods in the Grand Canyon or elsewhere would be easier to carry out as well as less costly. Nevertheless, the process of getting all interests to the table and coming up with a plan that all can live with is not expected to be easy. So if a new era has dawned, it may not unfold very rapidly. "It will be a slow process," Secretary Babbitt said.

HEADLINE: Panel Pushes For Revival Of Spending On the Arts

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
A nonpartisan Presidential committee has warned that cuts in public, private and corporate spending on the arts and humanities are undermining cultural and educational institutions in the United States. In a report to be released today, the panel recommends wide-ranging measures to confront what it calls growing threats to the nation's cultural heritage.
The 35-page report of the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities, headed by John Brademas, a former Democratic Congressman from Indiana and president emeritus of New York University, recommends that President Clinton lead a "millennium initiative" to revitalize public and private support for culture. 
 Goals of the initiative, which President Clinton is said to support, would be restoring funds for the arts in schools and requiring arts instruction for all high school students; forming private-public partnerships to make American works accessible through new technologies; fostering philanthropy through tax reform, and expanding international cultural contacts by, among other things, requiring competency in a foreign language for graduation from high school or admission to college.
The report urged Congress to enact or to preserve several tax measures that encourage individual and corporate donations to nonprofit groups. Such donations now provide 90 percent of the nation's cultural financing, the report says, and given pressures to balance the Federal budget, educational and cultural institutions will have to tap the private sector further to survive.
In implicit criticism of Congressional conservatives who have cut public subsidies for the arts and humanities and who favor abolishing those national endowments, the committee, which includes Republicans and Democrats, strongly endorses a Federal role through direct public subsidies, tax breaks and other incentives, particularly for art that highlights "our ethnic and cultural differences." It also criticizes what it calls "a climate of intolerance for challenging works and ideas."
Mr. Brademas said he had presented a copy of the report on Friday at a meeting with President Clinton and Hilary Rodham Clinton, the committee's honorary chairwoman.
Both the Clintons, he said, were enthusiastic about the committee's recommendations, particularly the proposal that the President lead a national initiative to galvanize private support for the arts. Mrs. Clinton, a supporter of increased public funding for culture, has scheduled a news conference to discuss the report's conclusions at the Library of Congress today.
The report surveys the strengths and failings of the complex support system that sustains the nation's 8,000 museums, 30,000 libraries, 3,665 institutions of higher learning, 2,000 local preservation commissions, 351 public television stations, 548 public radio stations, 7,000 community theaters and 1,800 symphony orchestras.
Among the steps the committee recommends to strengthen support for culture are the following:
*Congress should restore Federal funds for the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, and the Institute of Museum and Library Services and insure that they receive appropriations equal to $2 for each person in the country by the year 2000, compared with the 88.5 cents a person committed in fiscal 1997.
*Congress should retain the charitable deduction in the Federal tax code for gifts to all nonprofit organizations and should make permanent the deductibility of gifts of appreciated publicly traded stocks to private foundations, a provision set to expire in June.
*Fourteen states and the District of Columbia should abandon efforts to bolster revenues by challenging the tax-exempt status of non-profit institutions or by imposing payments on them in lieu of taxes.
The committee expressed particular concern about the "disturbing signs of a weakening philanthropic spirit," including a decline in the average size of gifts from the wealthiest Americans. Citing other studies, the report noted that even as all charitable giving increased by 11 percent in 1995 over the previous year, private contributions to the arts and humanities did not increase, when adjusted for inflation.
This trend is particularly worrisome for cultural institutions, since the arts and humanities are more dependent on private giving than many other segments of the nonprofit sector, the committee said. Performing arts groups, for instance, receive as much as 40 percent of their total income from donations, compared with 3 percent to 5 percent for hospitals and an average of less than 20 percent for many other nonprofit groups.
The report also concludes that increases in corporate donations to the arts and humanities over the past two years, which account for about 7 percent of all philanthropic donations, "mask a long-term decline in corporate giving" when measured as a percentage of pre-tax income. In addition, the report criticizes the trend among businesses of tying contributions to specific marketing objectives.
It cites as a positive development the 40 percent rise in foundation support for the arts in the 1980's, "the only source of sustained increased giving to cultural organizations" in the past decade. Particularly striking is the explosion of community foundations, whose assets jumped from $1 billion to more than $13 billion in just over 20 years.
But at the same time, the reports adds, foundation giving, which tripled from $3.4 billion to $11.3 billion from 1980 to 1994, is both highly concentrated and unevenly distributed. Citing a study by the Foundation Center in New York City, 505 foundations with assets of more than $50 million were responsible for half the grants to charitable causes.
The committee has 13 members who hold key Administration cultural posts, as well as has 31 members from outside the Government, among them the performers Isaac Stern and Rita Moreno and business executives including Terry Semel, the chairman of Warner Brothers; Harvey Golub, chairman and chief executive officer of American Express, and Robert Menschel, a limited partner of Goldman Sachs and Company.

HEADLINE: Russia Atom Aides Buy I.B.M. Supercomputer Despite U.S. Curbs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 24

 BODY:
In an effort to circumvent United States export controls, Russia's nuclear weapons establishment says it has obtained a powerful I.B.M. supercomputer through a European middleman.
Russian nuclear officials, who disclosed the purchase, said they planned to use the computer to simulate nuclear tests. 
 "If we see something we can buy on the European market, we buy it," Vladislav Petrov, the head of the public affairs department for Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy Affairs, said in an interview.
Mr. Petrov said the computer had been purchased for $7 million.
The purchase of the supercomputer, an I.B.M. RS/6000 SP, underscores the vein of distrust that still colors relations between the United States and newly democratic Russia.
Even as Washington talks of partnership between NATO and Russia and supports Russia's efforts at economic reform, the two sides are still at odds over Moscow's access to sophisticated American technology.
Russian officials insist that supercomputers are needed to maintain the reliability of their nuclear stockpile now that Moscow has agreed to a ban on nuclear tests.
"Computer modeling is very important to us," Viktor N. Mikhailov, the Minister of Atomic Energy Affairs, said recently.
But American officials say supercomputers could help Russia design new weapons. The United States does not want to help Russia insure the effectiveness of its nuclear arsenal.
"We have made a policy decision not to assist the Russians in their stockpile stewardship program," a senior American official said. "Even though relations with the Russians are good, we are potentially a target for their nuclear forces if relations change."
The Clinton Administration is also concerned about the political ramifications in Congress of aiding the Russian military establishment.
Under United States law, American computer manufacturers are required to consult with the Commerce Department before selling computers to Russia that are capable of performing between two billion and seven billion calculations a second. The sale of faster computers generally requires a license.
The Administration turned down applications last year from I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard to sell supercomputers to Russia. The Russians said the computers would be used for research on pollution and nuclear safety, but suspicions were aroused because they were to be shipped to nuclear weapons design centers.
Recently, the head of Silicon Graphics, a California-based company, acknowledged that his company had made a mistake by selling two small supercomputer systems to Russia. The United States Attorney in San Jose has opened an investigation into that sale.
The I.B.M. supercomputer is even more powerful and can perform 10 billion calculations a second, Russian officials say. They say it is 10 times more effective than the computers now on hand.
Russian officials decline to say precisely which middleman sold the I.B.M. supercomputer. But they have not hesitated to publicize the acquisition, perhaps calculating that this may undermine the rationale for continued American export controls.
Russian nuclear officials say they want to purchase even more powerful supercomputers to maintain Russia's status as a nuclear superpower, with Washington's blessing.
Stressing the need for nuclear research, Mr. Mikhailov touted Russia's nuclear arsenal as a means of offsetting its weakness in conventional weapons. "The only protection throughout this period will be nuclear weapons," he said.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Supreme Court to Review Sharp Limits on Membership in Credit Unions

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower-court ruling that placed sharp limits on the membership of federally chartered credit unions. The Federal agency that regulates credit unions, urging the Justices to hear the appeal, warned that the decision "threatens the survival" of credit unions, which have millions of members throughout the country.
The issue is whether the agency, the National Credit Union Administration, properly interpreted Federal law when it reversed longstanding policy in 1982 and permitted credit unions to include employees of more than one company. 
 Half of the more than 7,000 Federal credit unions in the country have taken advantage of the expanded membership definition, and those organizations, with 32 million members, are now presumably invalid under the ruling in July by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The case is being closely watched by the banking industry, which has found itself increasingly in competition with credit unions for consumer banking services like car loans, mortgages and checking accounts and which brought the legal challenge to the new policy. The loser in the case in the Supreme Court is likely to seek help from Congress.
The Depression-era statute that established the nonprofit employee savings associations limited memberships to "groups having a common bond of occupation or association" or to "groups within a well-defined neighborhood, community or rural district." For nearly 50 years the "common bond" language was interpreted by Federal regulators as limiting each credit union to the employees of a single company.
But faced with having to bail out credit unions of small companies that were failing in the recession of the early 1980's, the agency reinterpreted the Federal Credit Union Act to permit separate employee groups to join together in one credit union. As long as the employees within each separate group had a "common bond" with one another, multiemployer credit unions met the legal definition.
A result was a rapid consolidation and expansion of credit unions. Most of the 200 largest now have members from multiple employers. Under the ruling by the appeals court, no credit union in the country can accept new members who do not fall under the former "common bond" definition. The banking industry has asked the appeals court to order the retroactive divestiture of employee groups that have been added since 1982.
The decision "threatens nationwide instability and losses in the credit union industry affecting millions of persons," the Clinton Administration said in urging the Court to hear the appeal, National Credit Union Administration v. First National Bank & Trust, No. 96-843.
The case was brought by the First National Bank and Trust Company of Asheboro, N.C., to challenge the charter that the National Credit Union Administration issued to the AT&T Family Credit Union in Winston-Salem, N.C. The credit union was chartered in 1952 to serve employees of the Western Electric Company in North Carolina. Under the new policy, it received authorization to add employees of a Coca-Cola bottler, the Duke Power Company, the American Tobacco Company and other companies.
The credit union has also expanded to all 50 states and now includes more than 150 occupational groups.
The bank lost its case in Federal District Court here in 1994 before prevailing in the appeals court. One question for the Justices is whether, regardless of the legal merits of the case, the appeals court should have permitted the bank to pursue its suit.
The Administration and the credit union, which is also appealing the ruling, argue that a bank does not have legal standing to challenge a regulatory decision involving credit unions because banks do not fall within the "zone of interests" that Congress intended to protect when it passed the Federal Credit Union Act.
There were these other developments at the Court today:
 
Term Limits
The Supreme Court refused to involve itself in the latest legal battle over term limits for members of Congress. The Justices, without comment, declined to hear a case on the validity of states' voter referendums that instruct members of Congress to support a term-limits constitutional amendment and that essentially invite voters to retaliate against senators and representatives who do not follow the instructions.
Voters in nine states adopted such measures at the polls in November, and court challenges have been filed in most of those states. The appeal today asked the Justices to decide the constitutionality of a referendum adopted by Arkansas voters, but found by the Arkansas Supreme Court to be an illegitimate effort to amend the Constitution by means other than those provided for by the Constitution itself.
The Justices' refusal to hear the appeal means that the Arkansas referendum is now dead, despite its approval in November by a margin of 61 to 39 percent. The action has no legal effects in the other states that adopted similar measures. It is possible that the Supreme Court will take up the issue after the high courts of other states have addressed it, particularly if a difference of opinion develops among the state courts.
The other states are Alaska, Colorado, Idaho, Maine, Missouri, Nebraska, Nevada and South Dakota.
The Arkansas referendum was typical of the others in instructing the members of the Arkansas Congressional delegation to support the version of a term-limits amendment supported by U.S. Term Limits, a main lobbying group on the issue. The measure had called for limiting Congressional terms to six years, or three terms, for House members and two six-year terms for senators.
Members of Congress who failed to support that version, or who supported any other version, were to be identified on the ballot in future elections with the label "Disregarded voter instruction on term limits."
The Arkansas Supreme Court, ruling two weeks before election day on a challenge brought by an Arkansas voter, declared the referendum an unauthorized, and thus unconstitutional, means of amending the Constitution. As the state court said, the Constitution can be amended through a convention called by two-thirds of the state legislatures or through passage by two-thirds of each house of Congress, followed by ratification by three-quarters of the state legislatures.
In neither case did the Constitution contemplate direct action by the voters, the Arkansas court said.
Acting on an urgent appeal by the state, the United States Supreme Court granted a last-minute stay, on Nov. 2, allowing the referendum to proceed, with its constitutionality unresolved. The stay was intended to expire if, on considering the state's formal appeal of the ruling, the Justices decided not to hear the case, which is what occurred today. The case was Arkansas Term Limits v. Donovan, No. 96-903.
The term-limits issue appears, in any event, to be dead for this session of Congress, after a vote on Feb. 12 in which series of proposals failed to win a two-thirds majority in the House. After those votes, U.S. Term Limits put out a list of 18 House members from the nine states with term-limits referendums, who voted against the organization's preferred version or voted in favor of a different proposal.
In the states where the term-limit initiatives have taken effect, it will be up to election officials to place the negative labels next to those members' names the next time that they run for election.
 
Justice Stevens
The Court announced that Justice John Paul Stevens was treated at Georgetown University Hospital late last week to clear an obstruction of a coronary artery. The 76-year-old Justice was on the bench today and did not miss any arguments last week.
The Court's announcement said that Justice Stevens suffered mild chest pain on Wednesday. Tests showed that he had not had a heart attack but that he had had an obstruction that was relieved through angioplasty. The statement said he recovered at home over the weekend and was now "symptom free."

Abortion Clinics
After its ruling last week on the permissible scope of measures to protect access to abortion clinics, the Justices set aside rulings from Colorado and Arizona that had upheld an approach that the Court found in a case from upstate New York to have violated the free-speech rights of anti-abortion demonstrators.
The approach, sometimes known as a "bubble zone," involves an area within which a demonstrator may not approach a patient as she makes her way to the clinic's entrance. A Colorado law, which a state appeals court upheld in 1995, barred an approach, without the person's consent, within eight feet for the purpose of passing out a leaflet or "engaging in oral protest, education or counseling." A Phoenix ordinance, upheld in 1995 by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, upheld a similar eight-foot "bubble."
The lower courts have to now reconsider those decisions in light of last week's ruling in Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network, in which the Supreme Court upheld a 15-foot buffer zone around abortion clinics in upstate New York but found the indefinite and movable quality of a 15-foot "bubble zone" to be too restrictive of the demonstrators' First Amendment rights.
That decision does not necessarily invalidate the approach of the lower courts in the cases today, Sabelko v. Phoenix, No. 95-1415, and Hill v. Colorado, No. 95-1905. That is because the New York case concerned a court-ordered injunction, which the Supreme Court subjects to more searching review than a law or ordinance that has been adopted through a normal legislative process.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Slip On Caution By Investors

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices slipped yesterday as bond investors looked cautiously ahead to testimony this week from the Federal Reserve chairman as well as to looming supply.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 6/32, to 99 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.65 percent, from 6.64 percent on Friday. 
 Traders also pointed to a slumping dollar as a reason for lower bond prices, since a weak dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like United States securities less attractive to foreign investors.
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to appear before the Senate Banking Committee tomorrow and the House's panel on Thursday to give his semiannual testimony on the state of monetary policy and the economy.
Mr. Greenspan's appearances and the pressures of new securities coming to market "could keep the Treasury market on the defensive, with the testimony capturing center stage and the two-year and five-year note auctions providing the warm-up acts," said Larry J. Wipf, a vice president and economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
"While a tightening bias will no doubt be maintained, recent favorable inflation news will likely deter the Fed from tightening anytime soon," Mr. Wipf said. "Barring shocking economic news during the next month, Fed policy will likely remain on hold at the March 25 meeting."
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said that recent data had suggested continued, but cooler, economic growth compared with the fourth quarter last year, when the economy grew at a 4.7 percent pace. "Despite the latest numbers showing that housing and autos have peaked, industrial production has slowed, and the trade deficit has deteriorated," she said, "there is still no clear sign that the economy has cooled enough to eliminate totally the concerns about future inflation and a possible pre-emptive strike against it by the Fed."
Ms. Cooper said signs of a tightening in the labor markets were of increasing concern, noting that for the first time since 1989 new claims have fallen below the 310,000 level for two consecutive weeks. "Accelerating wage growth and the potential follow-through to the general price level is an issue on the minds of the Federal Open Market Committee members," she said.
Market participants also took note of the Treasury's $17.5 billion sale of two-year notes today and $12.5 billion of five-year notes tomorrow. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 5.86 percent and the five-year maturity at a price to yield 6.17 percent, both up a basis point from Friday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
At yesterday's regular weekly Treasury bill auction, the average rate for a three-month maturity rose three basis points from last week, to 5.01 percent; the rate for a six-month bill remained unchanged at 5.03 percent. Analysts said the results were generally in line with expectations, though they thought the six-month rate was a little weak.

HEADLINE: Green Fades From a Blueprint;
In Trump Revision, Highway Stays and Park Goes

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The lambs were roaring in 1991 and the lion was bleating a bit.
So it did not seem entirely implausible when they lay down together; when a band of civic groups, fresh from several anti-development victories, allied themselves with Donald J. Trump, then battling for his financial life. Together, they formed the Riverside South Planning Corporation to oversee the design of the 16-building project that is to stretch along the Hudson River from 59th to 72d Street, on the old Penn Central rail yards. 
 What Mr. Trump was to get from the deal was a smooth ride through the often bumpy governmental review process. What the civic groups were to get was a role in shaping one of the largest developments in recent New York history and, far more important, a generous new riverfront park in place of the ugly elevated West Side Highway, which was to curve inland to open the water's edge. Six years later, having gained the approvals and won the backing of Hong Kong investors, Mr. Trump says he will begin construction next week on the first Riverside South building, a 46-story apartment tower between 69th and 70th Streets.
But the highway is not budging yet. And it may not for a long time, if ever. The political will needed to dismantle the viaduct and reroute the road has practically evaporated.
Even Mr. Trump, who once called himself the "No. 1 fan of getting the highway down," now says he would be better off economically and logistically if it remained in place.
Did the lambs get fleeced?
"Everybody has gotten what they bargained for except the civics," said Richard A. Kahan, chairman of the Riverside South Planning Corporation. "The city and state never guaranteed that the highway would be relocated, but everybody agreed to use good faith and their best efforts to see that it would proceed. There never would have been a project if people had known then what they do today: that government would change its mind."
The "civics" are the Municipal Art Society, the Parks Council, the Regional Plan Association, the Riverside Park Fund and a neighborhood group called Westpride. The Natural Resources Defense Council was an original member of this coalition but resigned in 1993, once the government review was completed.
"Ultimately, the reason everybody is in this is because everybody wants to see the riverfront park," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society.
If the highway were moved inland, it would be covered for a stretch of several blocks by an ample lawn sloping gently down to the Hudson River, so people could walk directly to the water's edge. Were the highway to stay in place, parkgoers would have to pass under the brooding, noisy viaduct to reach the water. "Nothing matters as much in this whole process -- to us and the future of the city -- as the future of that park," Mr. Sexton said. "At this moment, it's just plain uncertain."
In fact, at this moment, the political odds are stacked against it. Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani favor the general idea of opening up the waterfront but contend that there are better ways to spend $200 million in Federal and state transportation funds than tearing down an elevated viaduct that was recently rehabilitated at a cost of more than $70 million.
Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter said that by agreeing to the highway relocation, the Dinkins administration raised unrealistic expectations. "You shouldn't do that," she said. "Big projects can't be arbitrarily subject to changes in administration. But that doesn't mean you support something stupid. We had to say no. To do this now makes no sense to us."
Nor does it make sense to the Pataki administration, said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "To do it now would be -- how can I put it? -- a luxury," he said. "And we certainly can't afford luxuries these days."
Federal dollars for highway projects do exist but New York's most influential political officials do not count the highway relocation among their top priorities. Today is the deadline for members of Congress to submit projects for money from the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, and the Congressman whose district includes Riverside South -- Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, Democrat of Manhattan -- is among the project's strongest foes.
As a practical matter, this means that Riverside South is likely to look much different from the vision the groups offered in 1990 when they were fighting Mr. Trump's proposal for a development of 14.5 million square feet on the Penn yards. That was to be called Trump City and feature the world's tallest skyscraper among 60- and 70-story towers.
The civic groups proposed a waterfront park minus the highway-on-stilts, lined with buildings about one quarter of the height proposed by Mr. Trump. The groups filed a lawsuit in December 1990 to prevent reconstruction of the viaduct until alternatives were studied.
Mr. Trump and the civic groups announced the current, compromise plan in March 1991: an 8.3 million-square-foot project with a 23-acre waterfront park and buildings from 30 to 40 stories.
The civic groups dropped the suit in the understanding that the city, state and Mr. Trump would push for the highway relocation. And they formed the planning corporation, which has been financed by Mr. Trump, his partners and the Chase Manhattan Bank, the mortgage holder.
Essentially, the corporation took over the role of the City Planning Commission, effectively limiting the voice of local opponents in the review process and alienating some longtime civic advocates who mistrusted any alliance with Mr. Trump.
One of those was Joyce Matz, who resigned as spokeswoman for Westpride in the wake of the deal.
"What makes civic groups important is their independence," she said. "If we'd all held firm, not compromised and not joined the enemy, that project could have been made smaller."
But Linda Davidoff, who was executive director of the Parks Council at the time, said she believes that Trump City might have prevailed had the civic groups kept up their fight. "David Dinkins walked in the door the day the recession started," she said. "As Mayor, he would have approved of any big development."
Those who sat at the table with Mr. Trump point to several things besides the relocated highway that they say will make Riverside South far preferable to the Trump City plan: fewer apartments in smaller buildings, design controls meant to assure a variety among the towers, guidelines to address energy conservation and other environmental issues, a street plan that adheres to the existing city grid and a 750-foot recreational pier.
"We're getting better than we would have gotten," said Roberta Brandes Gratz, a founder of Westpride, a writer on urban affairs and a board member of the planning corporation. "But it's clearly not the best. No one on the inside fooled themselves for a minute thinking they'd get the best, knowing that Trump was the developer."
To some, the Upper West Side is winding up with the worst of both worlds: the highway is still elevated, there is no unimpeded access to the river, and the buildings, while smaller than originally proposed, are far from demure.
Mr. Nadler does not mourn the passing of the park, however, calling it a $10 million-an-acre "private backyard for the people who live in these buildings."
He also asserts that he has at least hobbled the Riverside South project. Indeed he is not entirely convinced that he has not stopped it, likening the many announcements of its impending construction to those that once heralded Westway, the highway project along the Hudson River that was never built.
The beginning of Riverside South does seem to be on an ever-shortening but ever-receding horizon. In July 1994, Mr. Trump said construction could start within a year. In June 1996, he said construction could start within four months. In January, he said it could start within a week. So far, it has not.
A spokesman for the Buildings Department said the first Riverside South tower, designated Building C, had the necessary permits to begin. Besides Mr. Trump, the development team, Hudson Waterfront Associates, includes Henry Cheng, Vincent Lo, Charles Yeung, Edward Wong and David Chiu of Hong Kong.
Because Building C would rise from a rail yard about 30 feet below street level, it would have three basements so that its first floor would be level with the existing grade. Part of the building would be directly above an Amtrak right-of-way. Adjoining the tower on the west would be an elevated viaduct carrying a southern extension of Riverside Drive.
Kent L. Barwick, former president of the Municipal Art Society, believes the political winds may shift in favor of highway relocation once the towers of Riverside South emerge. "It will dawn on people that the developer is building what he wants anyway," Mr. Barwick said, "and they'll begin to ask what are they going to get out of it."
Having planned to step down from the chairmanship once construction began, Mr. Kahan finds himself asking the same question.
"I never would have wanted my name attached to a project that would leave an elevated highway standing along the Hudson River," he said. "This was a deal to get a park. I don't consider a piece of grass with an eight-lane highway running over it the kind of park we envisioned."

HEADLINE: TALKING BUSINESS WITH: CHARLES MILLARD;
Is Harbor Tunnel Worth the Billions?

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Even before the first million is spent or the first public hearing is scheduled, the city's harbor project seems a bit like a pipe dream. The proposal, by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is to revive heavy industry with a freight-rail tunnel under the New York Harbor and a container port for deep-hulled ships, all of which will cost billions of dollars.
While critics may find the idea an easy target for sniping -- reminders of the failed Westway project abound -- advisers to the Mayor say the plan demonstrates his ability to embrace planning on a huge scale and could provide a critical test of his standing in Albany and Washington, as well as with New York City voters. They say Mr. Giuliani is prepared to put every political muscle behind the proposal. 
 Chief among his economic advisers on the harbor project is Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. He readily acknowledges that political and financial hurdles loom large. A 39-year-old Republican and fiscal conservative, Mr. Millard served two terms on the City Council before being appointed head of the development agency in December 1995. He discussed the harbor plan in an interview.
Q. Various proposals for a harbor tunnel and expanded port have been around for more than 50 years. Why press the issue now?
A. The Mayor recognizes that the city's future cannot be built solely on white-collar jobs, and that not everyone can be an investment banker or new-media guru. We have the opportunity to capture maritime industry because of the dredging crisis and the increase in world trade. But we have got to seize the moment and build our infrastructure.
Q. What is the dredging crisis?
A. A new generation of supertankers will soon be in operation with drafts that require dredging down to 50 feet. New York City's advantage is that you can do that in Brooklyn and Staten Island much more cheaply than they could in Elizabeth, where you hit bedrock at 35 feet and the cost becomes astronomical.
Q. What would it cost?
A. It depends on what we build. Our consultants' study said it could go as high as $4 billion for a very large container port in Brooklyn and the tunnel. A more realistic first stage would be a smaller port in Brooklyn and the tunnel for about $2.5 billion. We could also theoretically put the port in Staten Island for about $1 billion, but that would be without a tunnel.
Q. Why do we need both?
A. The best synergy would be to go forward with both the hub port and tunnel, since it would capture the new generation of maritime industry and provide the city with its first freight-rail link with the rest of the country. But since we don't yet know where the port would be built -- in Howland Hook or Stapleton on Staten Island, or at various locations in Brooklyn -- it is probably too early to assess all the variables. A port in Staten Island could probably survive without a rail tunnel. But in Brooklyn, it probably could not.
Q. How would you pay for them?
A. We would need substantial Federal funding, and there is justification for it in the progress we would make in cutting down pollution and congestion. Everyone sees the benefit of taking trucks off the road. Our chances of getting Washington to pay for the hub port are not as good as for the tunnel. Our competition for the new generation of ships will be Norfolk and Halifax, both of which are already served by good rail links. But of the three, New York is best positioned because the huge market it serves in the tri-state area.
Q. Won't Congress see this as a battle between Norfolk and New York?
A. Our best hope is persuading Congress that there is only going to be one major hub port, and New York provides the best chance of beating out Halifax. It is clearly in the national interest to have more world trade in a United States port than in a foreign port. In any case, Federal funding is not going to happen without the cooperation of all elective officials.
Q. Who in particular?
A. Susan Molinari [Republican of Staten Island], who heads the House Rail Subcommittee, can play a critical role. She was one of the first public officials to be briefed on this project, and she understands that it is a complex undertaking in which not every detail has been worked out.
Q. But she has not said that she will support the plan. And Governor Pataki has been lukewarm.
A. This clearly can't be accomplished without the Governor. But the decision to fund it is still a couple of years away, and by then, we hope we can demonstrate that both the city and the state would be enriched. The tunnel and port would generate enough revenue in taxes and tolls to cover the cost of construction, and the overall benefits in jobs and reduced traffic congestion would far outweigh the costs.
Q. Does any of this stand a chance in a Republican Congress with little inclination to finance big projects in big cities?
A. If this was easy, it would have been done already. But the Federal Government is still supporting transportation projects. Witness the Alameda Corridor rail project in Los Angeles that the feds are pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into. There will be a lot of competition from other cities and states with projects of their own, but the Mayor has a tremendous amount of credibility in the White House and Congress that should work to our advantage.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, says the city should build both a port and a harbor tunnel. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Quarterly Edition of Money Planned for Asian Readers

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Seeking to capitalize on what it says is an era of growing interest in personal financial planning in Southeast Asia, Time Inc. plans a quarterly Asian edition of Money magazine.
The 28-page, English-language quarterly, which will hit newsstands in the region on May 26, will be produced in Hong Kong by freelance journalists, bound into the Asian edition of Time and presented as Time Money, said Caroline Donnelly, an executive editor at Money in New York, who will be moving temporarily to Hong Kong to direct the coverage. 
 "It will be 100 percent local," she said. "Most American magazines publishing over there use essentially domestic content with a thin overlay of local content. This will all be produced by Asian reporters and writers."
Time's Asian edition has 133,494 readers in Southeast Asia, Ms. Donnelly said, almost half of the edition's total paid subscribers. In the six months ending Dec. 31, Time, a unit of Time Warner Inc., had 288,063 paid subscriptions for its Asian edition, said Ginny Sexton, communications director for the Audit Bureau of Circulations in Schaumburg, Ill.
The decision to produce Time Money comes at a time when workers and professionals in the region are feeling less secure about their futures and are also more willing to take on some investing matters themselves, Ms. Donnelly said. "All over Asia, planning for retirement has become an issue," she said. "The state is not there to take care of you as it once was. Real estate is so hideous that there is no room to put your elderly parents in your home."
She added: "This generation is in much more of a self-help mode. These are people who are young, with big ambitions for themselves and their families, who don't see prosperity or even security quite guaranteed to them the way it might have been in another time."
That may be, but one publishing expert in the region cautioned that an English-language publication would encounter obstacles.
"For that kind of magazine to have an impact, it has to be localized, and in the local language of whatever country it's in," said one media analyst in Hong Kong who works for a large Wall Street firm and spoke on the condition of anonymity. The South China Morning Post, a major daily newspaper in Hong Kong, plans to publish a personal-finance magazine called M, the analyst said. It will be written in Chinese, which is spoken by the majority of Hong Kong's 6.3 million people.
At the same time, other English-language financial magazines are written and sold in Southeast Asia, including Asia Inc. and the Far Eastern Economic Review, both of which run features on personal finance and investing topics.
Ms. Donnelly said publishing in every language spoken in the seven countries where Time Money will be sold -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore and the Philippines -- would not be possible economically. And an analyst in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, said Time Money might do well in Asian countries with no comparable, local personal-finance publication.
John Marcom, publisher of Time's Asia edition, said English-language publications were complementary to other media in the region and were attractive to advertisers because they were read by people who used English on the job -- generally, better-educated professionals. "We never pretend we're reaching the bulk of the Asian population," he said.
Articles in the planning stages include preparing for buying a house, paying for education and establishing retirement funds, Ms. Donnelly said. All of the articles will discuss the specifics of doing so in each of the countries where the magazine will be sold. The newsstand price for the Asian edition of Time, $35 (Hong Kong), or about $4.50 (United States), is not supposed to rise when the Money insert is included, Mr. Marcom said.
"Because this is a market that is more interested in certain topics than the market in the U.S., I expect we'll write a bit more on things like real estate, currency trading, small business and family businesses," Ms. Donnelly said. "We hardly ever write about family business."

HEADLINE: Face-to-Face Meetings Fill In Cyberspace Gaps

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 24

 BODY:
There was chatter of virtual this and virtual that, talk of "tele-presence" and the diminishing need to go anywhere but on line, mention of a future in which colleagues will meet as holographic projections around computer-generated conference tables.
But here is the paradox: The scientists and scholars doing the chatting, brought together in Seattle last week by the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, were doing it, primitive as it is coming to seem, in the flesh. 
 They had got together in part to talk about not needing to get together. And they and many other groups have been gathering bodily like this in growing numbers over the last three years, in the very period when the explosion of Internet traffic has led some of the digerati to increasingly question the necessity of -- and here the voice often drops in light contempt -- "being" in any particular place.
In fact, the convention business in the United States is booming, industry spokesmen say, and the boom is coming not only from the robust economy but also from an unexpected byproduct of the Internet: the growing desire of people who connect in on-line communities to gather in what some call "meatspace," the opposite of cyberspace, if only once a year.
William J. Mitchell, dean of the architecture school at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said it was as if the ancient Greek agora -- the marketplace where people rubbed shoulders and gossiped -- is becoming a movable, temporary one, assembled in part to fill needs the Internet cannot.
"The more electronic communication expands and diversifies our circle of contacts, the more we're going to want to add the dimension of face-to-face," said Mr. Mitchell, author of "City of Bits," (M.I.T. Press, 1996), which explores how cyberspace is replacing real space in institutions like colleges and libraries.
On-line talk can be wonderfully cheap and convenient, he said (in an E-mail interview), but is even better when supplemented by "periods of face-to-face which serve to build trust and commitment."
That and other irreplaceable advantages of the flesh have many faces beaming in the convention industry.
The American Society of Association Executives estimates that the number of conventions, expositions and meetings held each year by members rose 11 percent from 1992 to 1995, to an annual total of well over 200,000, with particular growth in technology-related fields. And members expect the number of meetings to increase 39 percent this year over last, based on bookings and plans. Over all, meetings and conventions make up an $82 billion industry that is the 22d biggest contributor to the gross domestic product, according to the Convention Liaison Council, an industry group in Washington.
The number of people attending each meeting is multiplying, as well, prompting a scramble to expand convention centers in cities from Seattle to Boston. Comdex, the premier computer industry convention, drew more than 200,000 to its meeting last fall, and the National Restaurant Association convention recently attracted more than 100,000.
The initial worry among convention planners that the Internet might cut into business is just a memory.
"It boils down to the fact that nothing will ever replace the face-to-face peer interplay for which meetings are famous," said Ken Sommer, a spokesman for the American Society of Association Executives, which has more than 23,000 members and draws more than 5,000 to its annual convention. "The networking, the high-level learning, interacting with colleagues, exchanging information, doing business. Technology is merely enhancing meetings, not decreasing them."
Technology helps conventions by encouraging attendance through World Wide Web announcements or jazzing up sessions with fancy satellite video conferencing or laser pointers. On top of that, technology changes so rapidly that professionals flock to seminars, trade shows and conventions just to keep up, particularly in fields like medicine and consumer electronics.
Roy B. Evans is chief of the Professional Convention Management Association, in Birmingham, Ala., which teaches meeting management -- at meetings -- and has a major textbook. When he got into the business 37 years ago, Mr. Evans said, "the American College of Cardiology could have met in my bedroom. Today only three or four cities could handle it."
Mr. Evans backs the idea of quizzing participants after conventions and seminars to prove how useful the sessions have been. But he also agrees with "the old cliche that you learn more in the cocktail parties and hallways than at the sessions."
The power of the hallway could be observed at the science meeting in Seattle, where more than 5,000 scientists and science enthusiasts hobnobbed, lectured and listened for six days in a program so varied that the schedule was an inch thick.
Attendees were obviously well-wired; the remark most commonly overheard in conversation was "Send me an E-mail about it." But they also took such obvious pleasure just being in each other's company that most of the organized excursions to see the sights of Seattle were canceled.
And then there were the celebrities.
"There is no substitute for going to a meeting and being able to come back and say, 'Bill Gates came to my meeting,' " said Michael Strauss, the association's program director, referring to a talk given at the convention last Monday by Mr. Gates, the multibillionaire chief of Microsoft.
Dr. John Cantwell Kiley, a medical doctor with a Ph.D. in philosophy, took full advantage of that talk. He stood up afterward in the hall of 1,500 people and asked Mr. Gates whether, if he were blind, he would trade all his billions for sight. Mr. Gates said he would -- and offered his E-mail address for further discussion.
Dr. Kiley had made a point about the nature of true wealth directly to one of the wealthiest people in the world. But what he was really excited about was a long philosophical discussion with Benjamin Peng, a materials scientist who complimented him on his question.
"You get more activated, more excited, you see a whole world of possibilities when you meet in person," Dr. Kiley said. "We could have had an E-mail discussion, but I couldn't have seen the look in his eyes. There's something about it that's colorless and lifeless. You have to touch the flesh."
Though a boon for convention planners, the appeal of the flesh is an obstacle for the growing number of businesses whose employees work from home or in teams that collaborate over long distances.
At the science convention's session on such "virtual organizations," speakers discussed recent research showing that some virtual businesses fail simply because workers cannot develop trust in each other when they have never shared lunch and office chat.
Albert M. Erisman, director of technology at the Boeing Corporation, which used a virtual team to build its 777, noted that psychologists had found that co-workers needed to be less than 70 feet apart to share information casually. The challenge, Mr. Erisman and others said, is to create that "shared casual environment" over distance, perhaps through constant video connections.
But for now, he said, nothing beats "the old thing about hanging around the water cooler.
"Maybe we should encourage that," Mr. Erisman said, "so people can build trust and then go back and do their work in a decomposed environment."
He then paused at the podium for the applause, which came with no audio delay.

HEADLINE: President Asks Experts for Advice on the New Reality of Cloning

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Reacting to what the White House called the "very startling news" that scientists in Scotland had successfully cloned a mammal, President Clinton today asked a Federal bioethics advisory commission to review the research implications for human beings and report to him in 90 days.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said the commission, which was appointed last summer to review questions of biogenetic research, had not been asked to reach any conclusion or make specific recommendations for legislation or regulation, only to "review the legal and ethical implications of this technology." 
 Mr. McCurry said the President had been moved to act after reports that an embryologist at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh had replaced the genetic material of a sheep's egg with the DNA from an adult sheep and created a lamb that is a clone of the adult.
Mr. McCurry said he was not aware of any existing regulations that would ban such research on animals in this country.
Earlier in his Administration, Mr. Clinton signed an executive order banning the use of Federal money to create human embryos for research purposes, and Congress has also banned such financing.
In his letter to the commission today, Mr. Clinton said the Scottish breakthrough "represents a remarkable scientific discovery but one that raises important questions."
Mr. Clinton asked for "a thorough review of the legal and ethical issues associated with the use of this technology," and "recommendations on possible Federal actions to prevent its abuse."
"While this technological advance could offer potential benefits in such areas as medical research and agriculture," the President said, "it also raises serious ethical questions, particularly with respect to the possible use of this technology to clone human embryos."
Mr. McCurry said the commission, which is headed by Harold T. Shapiro, an economist who is the president of Princeton University, could consider a host of questions, including whether the current ban on federally financed human embryo creation should be expanded to cover private institutions.
"The advisory commission will be in a position to look at the issue of whether those doing private research through their own academic pursuits ought to be sensitive to these issues, or whether there are any policy implications that arise from these developments," Mr. McCurry said.
The commission was formed to look into biogenetic research, animal husbandry and the general area of biotechnology.
The lamb in Scotland was cloned from a 6-year-old ewe, using tissue taken from the ewe's udder. Most scientists had not thought that a whole mammal could be regenerated from mature body cells that were specialized for something other than reproduction.
While the research suggests that cloning humans might some day be possible, many genetic experts have said it would be unethical to try.
Others on the 15-member advisory commission include Alexander Capron, a professor of law at the University of Southern California; Eric J. Cassell, a professor of health at Cornell Medical College and an attending physician at New York Hospital; James Childress, a professor of religion and medical education at the University of Virginia, and David Cox, a professor of genetics and pediatrics at Stanford University and an expert on genetic defects, including Down syndrome.

HEADLINE: Colombia Lengthens a Drug Baron's Jail Sentence

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 24

 BODY:
A prison sentence for one of the leaders of Colombia's notorious Cali drug cartel has been extended, judicial officials said today.
The cartel leader, Miguel Rodriguez Orejuela, 53, had received a light prison term Jan. 17 that would have allowed him to leave prison in as little as five years. But a judge in Bogota sentenced him to 23 years over the weekend and his final sentence may be as high as 30 years, judicial officials said. 
 His original sentence, which prompted protests by the United States, was handed down in Cali.
The new sentence, handed down on Saturday, involves the shipment of 330 pounds of drugs to Tampa, Fla., in 1989.
The United States will decide by late this week whether to certify that Colombia's effort to fight drug production and trafficking has been effective. It is widely expected not to certify Colombia for the second consecutive year, continuing and perhaps expanding economic sanctions as a result.
An estimated 80 percent of cocaine used in the United States is grown or processed in Colombia, and the leaders of drug organizations have repeatedly received light sentences or have been suspected of operating their drug businesses from prison.
Mr. Rodriguez and his older brother Gilberto are leaders of the Cali drug cartel, which allegedly helped finance President Ernesto Samper's 1994 election campaign and once controlled up to 80 percent of the world's cocaine trade. Gilberto Rodriguez's five-year sentence is being appealed by the Government and may also be increased substantially.
A governing party lawmaker said today that Colombia should take reprisals against American interests in the country if the United States imposes economic sanctions.
Senator Amilkar Acosta of Mr. Samper's Liberal Party said he and other lawmakers had drafted a bill that would allow Mr. Samper to take unspecified action against American interests throughout Colombia.
"For every measure that the United States adopts affecting the country's economy, the Colombian Government ought to respond in kind with respect to U.S. interests in Colombia," he said. "We're talking about investments and exports."
