HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bondholders Win a Round At Marvel

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Score one for the bondholders in the fight over Marvel Entertainment. But the final victor remains unclear.
The bondholders, who include Carl C. Icahn, the former chairman of Trans World Airlines, have been fighting to seize control of a dominant block of Marvel stock from Ronald O. Perelman, the financier whose empire includes Revlon. 
 Mr. Perelman, through holding companies, owns 80 percent of the stock in Marvel, the comic book and trading card company that is now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law proceedings. Those shares are pledged to secure junk bonds issued by Mr. Perelman's companies. Yesterday, Judge Helen Balick of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware gave the bondholders permission to foreclose on the bonds, and thus take possession of the shares.
"The bondholders now have the power, if they choose to exercise it, to change the Marvel board and to compel that the current reorganization plan be withdrawn," said David Friedman, a lawyer for the bondholders committee. "But there has been no decision made to exercise that right," he added.
Mr. Friedman said he hoped that "this power will be significant to prompt meaningful negotiations toward a fair plan," with Mr. Perelman making concessions to the bondholders. "The ability of the bondholders to replace the board, hopefully, will be sufficient to impose some discipline on the board to act for the benefit of all parties, not just Perelman," he said.
Marvel's board and Mr. Perelman have proposed a complicated plan in which the Andrews Group, one of Mr. Perelman's companies, would buy the outstanding shares of Toy Biz Inc., a toy maker in which Marvel already owns a 27 percent stake; Andrews Group would then contribute them to Marvel in return for 80 percent of the shares of a new Marvel. Bondholders have denounced that plan.
A spokesman for Mr. Perelman, Michael Freitag of Kekst & Company, said that many legal avenues remained open to Marvel, which argued in court yesterday that the existing Marvel shares were worthless and thus there was no point to letting the bondholders seize them.
"We don't expect today's decision by the court to affect the ultimate consummation of the Andrews Group plan of reorganization for Marvel Entertainment," Mr. Freitag said. He declined to comment on whether negotiations were possible.
Mr. Freitag said that it was possible the plan would still be approved, with control of the company passing to bank creditors of Marvel, which would allow the reorganization plan to proceed.
The ruling came after trading ended yesterday, with Marvel shares down 12.5 cents each, to $1.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares in Toy Biz, a company with an exclusive license to make toys based on Marvel characters, rose 12.5 cents, to $18.75. Under its reorganization plan, Andrews Group is to buy those shares for $22.50, but that is contingent on the Marvel reorganization plan being approved. If it is in jeopardy, Toy Biz shares could suffer.
The fight for Marvel has been one of the most extraordinary in recent years, largely because of the odd way Mr. Perelman arranged to own it, with his shares pledged to support junk bonds. Effectively, he has no economic stake in the company but was still able to use those shares to control the company and get approval of his reorganization plan that would let him keep control.
By selling the bonds, Mr. Perelman has taken a profit of more than $50 million on his investment in Marvel, and could choose to walk away with a profit, leaving it to the bondholders to find a way to revive the company. Instead, he has proposed to recapitalize the company through the Toy Biz transaction, a deal that effectively lets him buy new Marvel shares for about 85 cents each.
Whether or not a better plan for existing shareholders could be financed if Mr. Perelman did not have control has not been clear. Mr. Icahn has said he would be willing to underwrite a superior reorganization plan, but details have been scarce.
Yesterday's ruling makes it at least possible that a superior plan could prevail, if people are willing to put up the money. At the least, it has made the fight a lot more interesting.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Albright Comes Home

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
"I'm deeply hurt that people think I'm lying," said Madeleine Albright yesterday afternoon, an hour after her plane touched down in Washington, bringing her home from her 11-day international tour. "I have never been secretive about anything in my life. If a shrink wanted to deal with me, it would be primarily about the fact I talk too much."
Ms. Albright had been pained to read in this space a week ago that I and others questioned the credibility of her account of how recently she discovered both her Jewish origins and her grandparents' fate as Holocaust victims. Calling to speak her piece -- "It may not make sense but it's the truth" -- she attributed the contradictions some of us heard in her previous public statements about her new-found history to her casual use of different adjectives. 
 "I didn't have a lawyer," she said. "I haven't written out my answers. I'm trying to piece it together myself. I am deeply regretful of having caused confusion on this. . . ." Then she addressed what many have found to be the fault lines in her story so far.
Ms. Albright said that though she had received letters from Czechoslovakia alluding to her Jewish background while she served as the United Nations delegate, she discounted them because they were factually inconsistent or contradicted either her parents' own accounts or their official papers. Other letters were from "Serbians who hated my guts and said I was a whore and I was Jewish; I figured that was invective. . . .
"Finally I stopped reading the mail," she said, citing the huge volume flooding her U.N. office. She says she simply never received the conclusive letters about her origins sent by the Mayor of her father's hometown -- or the letter her first cousin, Dagmar Sima, recently tried to give her bodyguards when Ms. Albright visited Prague. When Ms. Albright and her cousin met in Prague after the Berlin wall came down, Ms. Albright says, Ms. Sima never mentioned either the family's religious background or its concentration-camp casualties.
It was only in mid-November of last year that Ms. Albright says she saw new and more persuasive letters -- and "stuff in the Jewish press" -- detailing her family's roots. And so on the subject of her Jewish ancestry, she was not quite as shocked by The Washington Post's revelations as her first public statements suggested. "Was I totally surprised about my Jewish background? No. I had hints along the way. . . . I feel pretty stupid. It's like seeing a bunch of dots and when a person puts it all together, it makes sense. . . . I had not been sensitive enough to signs that my background was different than I thought it was."
But she says she was shocked to learn from The Post's Michael Dobbs that a number of members of her family had died in Terezin and Auschwitz. Given that she had already surmised her ancestors' Jewishness, and that the Holocaust has been central to her public world view, why didn't she immediately investigate or even guess the most likely cause of their wartime deaths? "I feel stupid and deeply regretful at not having seen things that are obvious, and I'm going to do my damnedest to make it up. . . . Had I not been immersed in the work I was doing, I probably would have put this two and two together. I wish to God I had. If I'd been a professor or unemployed, I would have looked at this."
Last night she met with her sister and brother to learn of their findings in Czechoslovakia, where they traveled last week to meet with Ms. Sima and others to gather facts. "I would like the definitive story to be written," Ms. Albright said, and then despaired whether anything she says now will put her "incredibly sad and complicated story" to rest.
Perhaps no closure is possible. Theodore Rabb, a historian at Princeton who is a Czech Jewish emigre born the same year as Ms. Albright, points out that the Holocaust's pull is deepening throughout the culture -- as seen everywhere from the international rise of university chairs for Holocaust studies to the struggle over Swiss gold to Sunday night's extraordinary network audience of 65 million Americans for "Schindler's List." Judging from my own response and those of so many vocal readers, even those well versed in the Holocaust have been roiled by the Albright affair in one way or another. The violent reactions to her story demonstrate that it's not only her relationship to the Holocaust that remains painful and unresolved.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
New Tenants for a Popular Silicon Alley Building

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
In July 1995, amid much hoopla, the Rudin Management Company renamed a nearly 400,000-square-foot office building at 55 Broad Street the New York Information Technology Center.
The idea was to spend $15 million on renovations to the vacant building, install telecommunications equipment and attract companies in the world of computers and the Internet, to revitalize an area that had been commercially moribund since the recession of the early 90's. The goal was to invigorate Silicon Alley as a counterpart to Silicon Valley. 
 It seems to be working. William C. Rudin, president of Rudin Management, said 57 leases have been signed and 8 others are about to be, totaling 315,000 square feet, more than 80 percent of the building.
Earlier leases had annual rents in the high teens a square foot, but Mr. Rudin said annual rents on more recent leases were from the high teens to the low $20's a square foot in the base of the building to the mid- to high $20's in the tower.
Among the more recent tenants are these:
I.B.M., an original proponent of the center, has taken a five-year lease for 10,000 square feet on the 27th floor to house the content and technical team for the I.B.M. home page on the Internet and for its internal Intranet network for its own employees. Fifteen to 30 employees from the headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., will work in the new space.
Certco, which develops software and legal contracts that enable banks to offer electronic products, has signed a 10-year lease for 20,000 square feet, the 21st and 22d floors, and will be moving from 280 Park Avenue, at 49th Street.
Spearhead Systems Consultants has signed a 10-year lease for 10,000 square feet on the 24th floor. Spearhead, which designs business software, will be moving its headquarters from Port Washington, L.I., but will keep the Port Washington office for administrative and support staff.
N2K, which operates a music-entertainment site on the Internet and was the building's first tenant, has taken two more floors, 25 and 26, for a total of 40,000 square feet.
Mr. Rudin has credited Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan, which gives tax breaks to encourage development, for contributing to the leasing success. The building is eligible for the tax breaks, saving tenants money.
The 30-year-old building, at Beaver Street, south of the New York Stock Exchange, had housed Drexel Burnham Lambert. But after that firm went bankrupt, the building was vacant for more than five years.
Studio Archetype, a San Francisco company that develops and designs Web pages, whose clients include I.B.M., American Express and Nintendo, already has a small lease in the building, for 1,500 square feet. Now it is taking an additional 10,000 square feet on the 29th floor.
"We heard about the building from I.B.M.," said Amanda North, Studio Archetype's president. "They described the place as a collaborative environment, designed to attract technology companies and create a community to share ideas and network. We've always enjoyed the free and easy collaborative spirit in Silicon Valley, and 55 Broad tries to recreate some of that spirit."
 
Office Space Sublet
Two major companies, the Loews Corporation and Bank of America, have sublet large amounts of office space they no longer need.
Loews Corporation has sublet 95,000 square feet at 1 Park Avenue, the entire 15th floor and most of the 14th, to PSM Insurance Companies. Bank of America has found two subtenants: Instinet Corporation, an electronic stock-trading exchange that is a subsidiary of Reuters, and IBES Inc., a provider of investor information services, for 93,000 square feet at 1 World Trade Center.
Loews is giving up two of its three floors at 1 Park Avenue, a 20-story, 852,000-square-foot office building at 32d Street. The company recently leased 49,200 square feet at 655 Madison Avenue, at 60th Street, in a 15-year deal valued at almost $25 million, and plans to connect the space to the adjacent 667 Madison, its corporate headquarters.
Howard F. Fiddle of the Insignia/ ESG real estate company, who represented PSM with Glenn Isaacson and Peter Turchin, said the lease was for five and a half years. John Malino, vice president for real estate at Loews, said the average annual rent on the sublease was in "the low $20's" a square foot. Loews is keeping one floor at 1 Park Avenue for its computer installation.
In the Bank of America deals, Instinet has sublet 49,000 square feet, including the 12th floor, and IBES has taken 44,000 square feet on the 18th floor. IBES will be moving from 345 Hudson Street, Instinet from 757 Third Avenue.
Robert A. Constable of Cushman & Wakefield, who represented Bank of America in the transaction with Lawrence S. Tannenbaum, said that the bank had leased 343,000 square feet in the 110-story, 4.76-million-square-foot trade center building in 1993 for "various trust and processing-related operations," but at the end of 1995 it sold off several of the operations and put 230,000 square feet back on the market.
"These are the first two big leases for the space," Mr. Constable said. The subleases were valued at $20 million, $8.5 million for IBES and a just over $12 million for Instinet.

HEADLINE: Big Demand for Executives Last Year

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

 BODY:
The good times are definitely rolling for executive recruiters. But new industry statistics have a decidedly "good news, bad news" cast for the executives that recruiters place in jobs throughout corporate America.
The number of executive searches in the United States grew 14 percent last year, showing that executives are clearly in demand -- particularly high-priced ones destined for corner offices -- according to statistics that will be released today by the Association of Executive Search Consultants. But that increase is also an indication of increased pressure to perform. 
 The biggest demand was for chief operating officers, with that category showing a 56 percent increase over 1995 in the number of searches conducted by association members. Searches for chief executives increased 36 percent and for chief financial officers, 37 percent. Recruiting for board members jumped 43 percent from the 1995 level.
Nearly 90 percent of the jobs came with six-figure salaries, while more than a third offered annual pay topping $200,000.
And 46 percent of the searches were for newly created jobs, down a bit from 51 percent in 1995, the first year the association conducted its survey.
In part, the surge reflects the economy's continued expansion. But it is also a product of higher executive turnover, which is caused by the increased pressure on senior managers to produce results quickly, said Sheila Arvin McLean, president of the association.
The trend is alarming to some people. "A few years ago, the average tenure of a C.E.O. or C.O.O. was 5.5 years," said Thomas Kuczmarski, a consultant with his own firm in Chicago. "Now that has dropped, I'm sure. Executives have to make their numbers each quarter, and the implication is that we continue to focus too much on the short term."
Higher executive turnover is also occurring because a different kind of manager is needed now, according to Hank Conn, a vice president at A. T. Kearney, a large management consulting firm. "You can't tell people what to do anymore, you have to motivate them," he said. "Companies are looking for people that have the soft skills to manage and technological skills and leadership traits. They're looking for much more complete people."
The results of the association's survey accord with those of a global executive demand index compiled recently by Korn/Ferry International, the world's largest search firm. A survey of 2,600 Korn/Ferry clients in 38 countries found that the hiring of senior executives earning $100,000 or more a year grew 10 percent in 1996.
Korn/Ferry's report said that executive demand boomed most in the Asia-Pacific region, which showed a 15 percent increase. Growth in Europe came to 11 percent, while in both Latin America and North America it was 8 percent.
In the United States, according to the 125 member firms of Ms. McLean's association, the Northwest is the hottest region, with searches increasing by 114 percent from 1995. The Southwest came next, with a 24 percent increase. The Northeast (14 percent), North Central (13 percent), Southeast (6 percent) and Pacific states (4 percent) followed.
In terms of sheer volume, however, most of the job-hopping in both 1995 and 1996 was occurring in the Northeast, which accounted for a third of all recruiting assignments. The North Central states came next, with 20 percent, followed by the Southeast (17 percent), the Pacific (16 percent), the Southwest (10 percent) and the Northwest (4 percent).
Over all, the executive job market was strongest in service businesses and at transportation and utility companies, with searches in both growing by 15 percent for the year. Not far behind, demand for manufacturing executives increased by 13 percent. The communications industry showed a 5 percent overall decline in searches during 1996, though some segments of the business posted gains.
As for compensation, the newly created jobs are paying the most. While only 4 percent of all jobs in the survey fetched more than $500,000, 44 percent of the newly created positions paid that much or more.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Clear Channel in Deal To Buy Billboard Company
Clear Channel Communications, a big broadcaster, agreed to buy Eller Media, a closely held billboard advertising company, for $1.15 billion in cash and stock.
The transaction, which analysts said had been rumored for weeks, was announced after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of Clear Channel rose 5.4 percent. [Page D3.]
 
Retail Results Above Forecasts
Several retailers announced earnings that were generally higher than expected, though forecasts had been lowered during the holiday shopping season. The stocks of many retailers, including Wal-Mart, whose earnings rose modestly, were sharply higher. [D3.] 

The retailers' strong performances helped lift stock prices over all, with the Dow industrials gaining 30.01 points, to 7,038.21. [D8.]
 
A Big Potential Competitor to Cable
Rupert Murdoch's agreement to invest $1 billion in a new satellite television service startled cable and satellite companies around the country. The new service could be a full-fledged competitor to cable. [A1.]
 
Kimberly-Clark to Sell Three Mills
Kimberly-Clark said it would sell three pulp mills to lower costs of obtaining pulp for paper making and strengthen its competitive position against Procter & Gamble. Kimberly, which makes Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, also announced a stock split. [D2.]
 
Managers to Take Over Gruntal
Robert P. Rittereiser, the chairman of Gruntal, said that he was leading a group of senior managers in a $235 million leveraged buyout of the brokerage firm. [D21.]
 
Consumer Confidence Stays High
The Conference Board said that consumers remained remarkably upbeat about the economy. The group's consumer confidence index stood at 118.4 in February, slightly below January's level but above expectations. [D21.]
 
America Online in Marketing Deal
America Online announced a $100 million marketing deal with Tel-Save Holdings, a reseller of long-distance telephone service. Analysts said America Online would rely more on on-line commerce and advertising revenues and less on subscriber fees. [D8.]
 
Newsletter Writer Settles Charges
The author of the Hot Stocks Internet newsletters on investing settled charges that he had misled readers by making false claims about several companies and failing to disclose that he was getting paid to promote more than 150 stocks. [D8.]
 
Reverse Route to Investor Interest
Centennial Technologies' chief executive is in jail, charged with falsifying its books, and the stock is to be delisted from the Big Board. Yet the company's shares have risen in two days from $2.50 to $14.75. [D8.]
 
Former Archer Official in Plea Deal
As part of an agreement to testify against fellow conspirators, a former Archer Daniels executive pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to steal more than $300,000 from the company. The plea is the first public admission of criminal wrongdoing by an executive with the company since a series of scandals began to swirl around it in 1995. [D3.]
 
S.E.C. to Revise Fund Documents
The S.E.C. plans to revise mutual fund prospectuses, Arthur Levitt Jr., the commission's chairman said, to better detail the risks and investment styles of funds. [D5.]
 
Produce or Perish
Search firms are busy as companies seek more and more top executives and offer higher compensation. But the downside of the demand is that executives are being pressured for more immediate results. [D2.]
 
A Proposal to Sell London's Tube
Britain's Conservative Government proposed privatizing London's Underground, the oldest rapid-transit system in the world, as a way to restore the ailing and cash-starved network to its past glory. [A3.]

HEADLINE: 2 Democrats Say Mexico Is No U.S. Ally In Drug War

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill objected today to the prospect that the Clinton Administration might certify Mexico as an ally in the war on illegal drugs as pressure to decertify Mexico grew. And even some senior Administration officials acknowledged that drug corruption had become so endemic throughout the ranks of Mexican law enforcement as to make cooperation difficult if not impossible.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, wrote separate letters saying Mexico deserved to be decertified, but with penalties waived in the vital national interest. 
 The President is required to notify Congress every year as to which countries are cooperating with the United States to fight drugs. Those who have failed to do so are consigned to a pariah status that renders them no longer eligible for investment credits from the United States and makes them subject to other trade penalties. The President's decision is due by March 1.
In a letter addressed to Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the Administration's director of national drug control policy, Mr. Gephardt said that "our 2,000-mile common border with Mexico demands that we get more support from the Mexican Government and that greater support for rooting out corruption be implemented."
And Ms. Feinstein wrote President Clinton, "I believe the evidence is overwhelming and can lead to no decision other than the decertification of Mexico."
Their concerns were motivated in part by the arrest last week of Mexico's senior counterdrug official, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, on charges of collaborating with the head of a major drug syndicate.
In announcing the latest national drug strategy today, President Clinton and General McCaffrey both avoided saying whether Mexico would be certified. Mr. Clinton said the Administration was committed to cooperating with its Latin American friends.
"We want to cooperate with them, but we want them to cooperate with us, as well," Mr. Clinton said. "We want to reduce our demand for drugs, but we are determined to reduce the supply as well."
General McCaffery said that the Administration was still discussing the question of certification. "This is not a cooked deal," he said. "There is going to be an intense analysis of the law."
But he stressed that the Administration wanted to keep working with the Mexican Government. "It is our belief that the United States and Mexico are trapped, economically, culturally, politically and because of drug crime, in the same continent, and we'd better figure out a way to work on it together," he said.
A bleaker picture was presented at a hearing on counternarcotics efforts in Mexico. Testifying before the House Subcommittee on National Security, International Affairs and Criminal Justice, Thomas A. Constantine, the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said General Gutierrez's arrest illustrated how deeply rooted corruption has become in Mexico. As a result, Mr. Constantine said, "There is not one single law enforcement institution with whom D.E.A. has a really trusting relationship."
Because General Gutierrez inherited the files of his predecessors as head of Mexico's National Institute to Combat Drugs, Mr. Constantine said, it had to be assumed that anything shared with the Mexicans had been passed by General Gutierrez to the drug traffickers.
Asked in an interview later about the state of cooperation, Mr. Constantine said that "virtually everything is frozen right there, in terms of sharing information."
In his testimony, Robert S. Gelbard, the Assistant Secretary of State responsible for matters related to drugs, described Mexico as "one of our most important allies in the struggle against international crime and drug trafficking." But he too spoke of "persistent and widespread official corruption."
When Representative Thomas M. Barrett, Democrat of Wisconsin, asked how much damaging material had been given to General Gutierrez," Mr. Gelbard replied, "I do not know." He said that investigators were still trying to find out.
Several members of Congress argued that Colombia, which looks likely to be decertified for a second year, had done more to fight drug trafficking than Mexico.
The subcommittee chairman, Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said that if Colombia was not certified and Mexico was, "I, for one, will have a hard time not seeing this as a double standard -- a double standard that undermines the role of certification in our international drug strategy." If that happened, Mr. Hastert warned, "a close examination of this decision by Congress will follow."

HEADLINE: Mexico Says Critical Report On Drugs Would Hurt Ties

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Mexico warned today that any move by the United States to downgrade this country's standing as a partner in the effort to fight narcotics smuggling would jeopardize Mexico's future cooperation in the drug war.
Faced with a growing clamor in Washington about the corrupting influence of Mexican drug lords, Foreign Minister Angel Gurria issued a strongly worded appeal to President Clinton today, asking him to renew Mexico's certification as a cooperative ally in the fight against drugs when he files an annual progress report to Congress this week. 
 The Mexican Government believes it has made major advances in the war against drug cartels, Mr. Gurria said, and a negative rating would awaken keen frustration and resentment against the United States.
"The Mexican people would question the whole concept of cooperation," Mr. Gurria said.
Since the arrest of Mexico's chief drug-fighting official on narcotics charges, American officials have begun reconsidering the almost automatic endorsement of Mexico since the certification program began.
Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House drug coordinator, said the Administration is now contemplating a qualified endorsement that would stop short of the economic sanctions levied against uncooperative countries but would be a sharp diplomatic slap at Mexico.
Today a number of senior Congressional Democrats also called for downgrading Mexico.
Mexican officials regard the United States' annual reports on the drug campaigns of foreign countries, which are mandated by Congress, as unwanted intervention and normally do not comment on the process.
Mr. Gurria broke with past practice, acknowledging that a qualified American assessment of Mexico's anti-narcotics effort would seriously hurt the country's image.
In the past Mexico was easily certified without conditions, but Clinton Administration officials are hesitating this year because of the arrest on drug charges this month of Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, the head of the national anti-drug agency.
Mr. Gurria warned that a diminution of Mexico's status would "make us doubt whether cooperating with the United States will bring anything other than a lot of grief."
In the past year United States cooperation with Mexico on drug issues improved with the creation of a contact group that brings together top officials from both countries, and a series of working groups. Mr. Gurria suggested that if Mexico receives an American rebuke it will be forced by political pressure to reconsider its participation in those groups.
Describing relations with the United States as "the best we've ever had," he called on Washington "not to sour the whole thing."
According to a joint report signed by Mr. Gurria and General McCaffrey as recently as a week ago, the Clinton Administration was in accord with with Mexico on its drug program. The two countries canceled the public release of the report after General Gutierrez's arrest.
"We know our achievements so far are significant," the two men wrote in the introduction. The report cites record seizures of heroine, cocaine and methamphetamines by Mexico in 1995 and 1996, as well as a record for destruction of marijuana crops. It points to more effective Mexican laws against organized crime and to the arrests of a number of cartel barons, including Juan Garcia Abrego, who was sentenced in January to life in prison in the United States.
In a separate initiative, Mexican officials today announced the start of a "top-to-bottom overhaul" of the justice system ordered by President Ernesto Zedillo, including the drug agency General Gutierrez headed.
Saying that Mexico faces "the worst crisis in the history of its justice system," Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar said his office and the federal police he controls would be reorganized to stem corruption. While checks of the records of all employees continue, police and prosecutors' salaries are being increased to dampen the temptation to take bribes.
Forensic laboratories and intelligence-gathering offices will be modernized and isolated from the influence of prosecutors and outsiders, the Attorney General said.
Mr. Madrazo said the justice reform was not related to the United States certification.
In the central state of Jalisco, where General Gutierrez had been the top military commander, 300state police officers have been dismissed since last week in a purge of all security agents who worked with the general, Gov. Alberto Cardenas Jimenez announced today.
Hostility toward the United States has been amplified this week by two state Governors who were identified by The New York Times in an article on Sunday as having ties to drug traffickers.
The two Governors, Manlio Fabio Beltrones of Sonora and Jorge Carrillo Olea of Morelos, have dominated the Mexican press for several days with angry responses in which they charged that United States drug and intelligence agencies released unfounded information about them to discredit Mexico in advance of President Clinton's report.
Governor Carrillo called the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the Central Intelligence Agency "the eternal enemies of Mexico's national interest."
Mr. Beltrones said the allegations against him were suspect because they were based on "things said in a foreign country."
To bolster his case, Governor Beltrones released a 1993 legal document showing that state authorities in Sonora sought federal help to close down several residences in Hermosillo, the state capital, belonging to associates of Amado Carrillo Fuentes, a notorious cocaine trafficker.
In a full-page paid advertisement today in newspapers across Mexico, several hundred businessmen from Sonora said they were "indignant at attempts to sully the name of Governor Beltrones from outside of Mexico."

HEADLINE: New Report Indicates Consumers Remain Optimistic on Economy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Americans' confidence in the economy remained extremely high this month, a report by the Conference Board showed.
The research group said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence stood at 118.4 in February. Although that was slightly below January's level -- which was revised upward to 118.7 from 116.8 -- it exceeded expectations. 
 And the index that tracks consumers' assessment of present conditions advanced to 143.4, a 27-year high, from 141.2.
The consumer expectation index fell to 101.7 from 103.8, however, suggesting the respondents were wary about the coming months.
"Consumers continue to view current business activity as strong," said Lynn Franco, associate director of the New York group's consumer research center. The latest consumer readings "signal positive economic growth ahead."
Still, said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, an attitude of "cautious optimism" will prevail when it comes to buying. With the economy in its sixth year of economic expansion, much of the pent-up demand has been exhausted, while financial institutions are tightening lending standards and news of layoffs still shakes Americans' confidence in the job market.
"Things are hot in the labor market, but I suspect consumers may be taking somewhat of a breather in coming months," Mr. Chan said.
 Indeed, a survey released Monday by the National Association of Business Economists found that respondents expected economic growth to slow during the first quarter to a 2 percent annual rate from the 4.7 percent pace of the final three months of 1996.
Still, yesterday's report suggested that consumers were confident enough about their financial prospects to keep the economy moving forward in the months ahead. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity.

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
Clock Ticks Louder For Kings' Richmond

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

 BODY:
The best pro basketball player with the lowest national profile finished another shoot-around in another arena on another road trip in another season leading nowhere. Mitch Richmond dropped into a front-row seat under the basket for an afternoon chat yesterday at Continental Arena, still the heart and soul of a bunch of court jesters also known as the Sacramento Kings.
Bleeding heart, lost soul. 
 "I'm 31," Richmond said before pouring in 32 points in a 97-90 loss to the Nets last night. "The clock is ticking."
Another trade deadline came and went last week, with the most desirable shooting guard west of Michael Jordan still burying his jumpers, along with his championship dreams, at Arco Arena. Richmond heard about the trade winds from Miami, where Pat Riley was reportedly blowing hard to reunite Richmond with Tim Hardaway, his onetime running mate at Golden State. Riley wound up dealing instead for Jamaal Mashburn, missing out on Richmond, as he did when he was coaching the Knicks.
"The year they wound up with Rolando Blackman, Pat was trying to get me," Richmond said. "Draft day, I thought it was done."
How might history have been written had Patrick Ewing taken Richmond -- who has never averaged less than 22 points and shot less than 45 percent in 9 pro seasons -- to the 1994 N.B.A. finals instead of John Starks? Riley might still be ordering his post-game pasta at Elaine's. Richmond might be the most celebrated winter sport athlete in New York, as opposed to stretching his considerable professionalism to the limits while his biological clock ticks away, Pacific Standard Time.
Like Chris Mullin at Golden State (and unlike so many other National Basketball Association brats), Richmond made no public demands, didn't whine. He just crossed his fingers earlier this month. He happens to be from South Florida, but he also realized it was wishful thinking. In a Western Conference laden with losers, the 24-31 Kings are currently a playoff team. And as the trade deadline approached last Thursday, they were struggling for much more than the chance to lose in the first round this April.
The team's owner, the Los Angeles businessman Jim Thomas, had recently gone to Sacramento city leaders in the familiar pose of the contemporary sports owner: his hand out. His losses were mounting, Thomas said; he needed relief from the Arco Arena debt he inherited, and from the limitations of the small, luxury box-less Sacramento market.
"He had an offer to sell the team to a group that would have moved it to Nashville," said Bill Farley, the Sacramento economic development manager. "He said he needed a public subsidy."
That wasn't going to happen, Farley said, not in conventional terms. It hadn't been long ago that the city provided several million dollars to its struggling symphony. The symphony closed, anyway. The city council took up the issue of Sacramento's only major league sports team knowing that an unqualified handout was out of the question. Out of that came the proposal earlier this month of a 30-year, $70 million loan with the arena and a $20 million team note to be held as collateral, plus an agreement by Thomas to not move the Kings for at least 10 years.
Thomas liked this idea, especially when he bargained to repay the 7 1/2 percent interest loan mostly from a surcharge on tickets to the 200 annual arena events.
In other words, the taxpayers will front the Kings $70 million and pay themselves back by shelling out more for tickets. The litigation charging the city council with providing a subsidy via a tax has predictably begun. What it meant for Richmond is another lost season, for how could the Kings have traded their one All-Star, their 1996 Olympic gold medalist, while they were promising quality basketball in exchange for the city's largess?
"The timing wasn't very good," Richmond said. "But more and more you hear people in Sacramento say, 'Mitch deserves the chance to win a championship.' "
He has two years remaining on his contract, nothing but nice things to say about his teammates, the fans, the city. He is still tired of going to All-Star Games and having Charles Barkley chide him about endorsements, about what a hick town he plays in. He wants to go compete for a title.
That is not going to happen in Sacramento. Even Bill Farley, after looking over Thomas's books, said Sacramento will never truly compete with the big boys. "The salary cap is going up to $30 million and you can go as high as you want for your own players," he said. "These small-market teams don't have a chance."
Moribund as they have been, much as their home has been mocked, that is what keeps the Nets from bailing out of densely populated Northern New Jersey. There is revenue-generation potential the likes of Sacramento will never have. The N.B.A., Farley said, may very well be one slump, the next Jordan retirement, away from a small-market meltdown.
"It would be sad if the N.B.A. couldn't make it in Sacramento, because the fans come out every night," Richmond said. "I hope they stay."
He said "they." Not him.

HEADLINE: Piggy Banks With Muscles;
As Credit Unions Boom, Financial Rivals Cry Foul

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

DATELINE: FORT WORTH

 BODY:
As the Carswell Air Force Base shrank to the vanishing point, its credit union, set up in 1956 with $35 in assets and seven members, was growing into one of the biggest financial service providers in the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area.
Nearly six years ago, the announcement that Carswell was going to be shut, a victim of the end of the cold war, stunned the community and sent shock waves through the economy. But the announcement did not faze the Carswell Federal Credit Union. It simply changed its name to OmniAmerican and kept expanding. 
 Today, it counts 137,100 members employed at 1,300 businesses and organizations, ranging from the Boy Scouts of America to Pier One Imports. At the end of 1996, assets totaled $517.7 million, and OmniAmerican currently boasts 12 branches, from the original office at what is now the Fort Worth Joint Reserve Base to a spiffy $3 million office, complete with a baby grand player piano, abutting one of the city's toniest residential neighborhoods.
At a time of immense turmoil in financial services, credit unions -- once backwaters of American finance -- have moved aggressively to supplant commercial banks in many of their traditional businesses. They pay more interest on deposits, charge less on loans and provide free many of the services that banks have tacked fees on.
All in all, America's Depression-era experiment with financial socialism is thriving in these bullishly free-market times -- and bankers don't like it one bit. For years, they have been fighting, in the courts and in the halls of Congress, to turn back the credit unions' invasion of their territory. The threat to them is real: Since 1980, the cooperatives' membership has surged to 70.4 million, from 44 million, while assets have exploded to $316 billion from $69 billion.
[The conflict reached a new level on Monday with the Supreme Court's announcement that it would review a lower court ruling that placed sharp limits on membership in federally chartered credit unions, which number more than 7,000. The Court is expected to hear arguments in the fall and render a ruling sometime next year. And the issue will be on full display in Washington Wednesday, when a House subcommittee led by Marge Roukema, a New Jersey Republican, is scheduled to hold hearings.]
The stakes for both sides -- and for the American public -- are high. Credit unions like OmniAmerican promote themselves as friends of the consumer, grass-roots organizations that offer higher interest on deposits and lower rates on loans than commercial banks. But the banks do not see it that way. To them, credit unions are exploiting their tax-exempt status to grab market share.
Banks view their predicament as a result of the 1982 ruling by the National Credit Union Administration to allow credit unions to accept members from any number of employee groups instead of just one. The banks complain that the Federal regulatory agency's liberal reinterpretation of the Federal Credit Union Act of 1934 in effect gave credit unions carte blanche to sign up just about anyone, thereby transforming themselves into financial octopuses that threaten the banks' livelihoods.
And the bankers' view has found sympathy in the Federal courts. Thomas P. Jackson, a court of appeals judge, characterized the credit union agency as a "rogue Federal agency" and accused it of colluding with industry groups to evade a court order restricting credit union membership.
David L. Tapp, president and chief executive of Overton Banchares Inc., a $760 million institution with 14 branches in the Fort Worth area, sees the situation this way: "I think credit unions have a place in this world. But they should either be allowed to have a common bond or be forced to pay taxes and compete with us. If credit unions paid taxes and have the same regulatory burden banks do, I'll compete with them every day of the week."
Not surprisingly, the credit unions play on popular distrust of the banking industry as a profit machine indifferent to the needs of the little guy. "This movement is about serving people, not stockholders," said Dan Mica, a former Congressman from Florida who is now president of the Credit Union National Association, an industry group. "Our motto is people first, profit second."
OmniAmerican is one of the biggest and most efficiently managed of the nation's 11,900 credit unions, most of which remain what they always were: back rooms in small companies where employees deposit $50 a week in their savings account and take out car loans at below-market interest rates.
But banks fear that unless they prevail in court, or Congress steps in, sprawling credit unions like Omni-American will become the wave of the future -- a wave that could swamp the more vulnerable banks.
"On the consumer banking side, they are eating the banks' lunch," said Bill Strunk, chairman of Strunk & Associates, a financial consulting firm in Houston. "What they have done in this state is establish branch offices all over a city. In essence, they are like a consumer bank."
According to Mr. Strunk's figures, from 1991 to 1995 deposits at commercial banks in Texas shrank by $3.4 billion, while deposits at savings and loans in the state contracted $6.3 billion. In the same period, credit union deposits rose $4.6 billion.
Larry E. Duckworth, OmniAmerican's chief executive, is unmoved by banks' pleas for regulatory relief. He said Texans had grown "very, very scared" of banks and savings and loans. Besides, he says, credit unions are only providing a service -- banking for workers -- that banks refuse to touch.
"Many companies don't have the mass to make a credit union of their own commercially sound," Mr. Duckworth said. "If this ruling stands, most credit unions won't suffer. But these small and medium- sized companies will."
To attract and hold customers, institutions like OmniAmerican are offering an increasingly diverse array of products and services, from mortgages and auto loans to credit lines to automated teller machines. Two years ago, OmniAmerican began making business and commercial loans to its employer groups. In a promotional book, the list of products and services it offers is nine pages long.
"If credit unions transform into broader-based financial services cooperatives, then they start to become the low-cost competitive alternative to banks," said Edward E. Furash, chairman and chief executive of Furash & Company, a financial services consulting firm based in Washington. "That is where some of them are headed."
OmniAmerican has shown itself to be a master of marketing. In its literature, it says its potential membership exceeds 500,000 "locally, nationally and worldwide." At a number of its branches dotted throughout the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area an electronic message flashes across outdoor screens 24 hours a day: "For the Truth . . . Ask About . . . Financial Freedom of Choice . . . Come Inside for Details . . . Join OmniAmerican."
It is hard for some people to sympathize with the banks in the dispute. After all, the industry enjoyed record profits in 1996 for the fourth consecutive year. And the banks' prosperity has not deterred them from adding fees for services and otherwise pumping up profits in ways -- such as First Chicago's experiment in charging customers for using human tellers -- that have outraged consumer groups. .
Moreover, with combined assets of $4.4 trillion as of last June, the nation's 10,000 banks dwarf their upstart nonprofit rivals.
But a disproportionately large percentage of those assets -- and profits -- are held and earned at a comparatively small number of banks. And while most credit unions are quite small, a growing number are not; roughly 1,000 have assets of $75 million or more. As these institutions have expanded, bankers say, they are unfairly taking business away from small banks that historically have been the backbones of local economies.
The American Bankers Association says the credit unions' tax exemption gives them the equivalent of a $1-billion-a-year subsidy.
According to some consultants to the financial industry, the tax break is one of several factors that provide credit unions with a cost advantage of as much as 2.50 percentage points compared with banks, an edge that enables them to charge lower rates on products like auto loans and home mortgages and to offer higher rates on things like certificates of deposit.
Credit unions say the cost to taxpayers is more than offset by the social good they create. A 1996 study by the Credit Union National Association, for example, calculated the benefits of membership in credit unions at anywhere from $200 to $500 a year, depending on the size of the account, mostly from lower fees. With the credit unions having 70.4 million members, that would mean a savings of $14 billion to $35 billion.
The advantage is not necessarily that clear cut, though. As of yesterday, OmniAmerican was offering to pay 5.75 percent on one-year certificates of deposit, beating the 5.25 percent at its commercial banking rival, Overton Bancshares. But rates for new-car loans were identical at 7.75 percent, though of slightly different durations. As for home buyers, they might be better off going to Overton, where a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage with a one point origination fee was offered at 7.125 percent, rather than OmniAmerican, with a fee of one and a half points and a rate of 7.375 percent.
Converts to credit unions sometimes have more than numbers on their minds, of course. Wendell Geiger, a former Air Force physician who now teaches at Texas Christian University, said bureaucratic intransigence at Bank One drove him and his wife into the arms of OmniAmerican a few years ago.
"My wife had an account at Bank One, and was charged all the fees and what not," he said inside an OmniAmerican branch on a recent morning. "But when she went for a loan, they needed me to co-sign it. That's when we said forget it. It's not like she works at McDonald's."
For all the plaudits credit unions get from their own customers, some financial analysts wonder whether they have not outlived their usefulness in an age when boundaries between financial institutions are tumbling, when H & R Block can offer home mortgages and when banks can sell insurance and brokerage houses can make commercial loans.
"The United States has a long, long history, particularly since the turn of the century, of forming financial institutions every time a special financial need had to be dealt with," Mr. Furash of Furash & Company said.
"None of these institutions have been subjected to a sunset, even though their social purpose may have disappeared or been replaced a long time ago," he said. "Is the social purpose of credit unions to become like banks, or is it to continue to service the special needs for which they should be created? That should be the basis of the issue."

HEADLINE: Evolving China Merely Resembles a Dynasty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You describe the Chinese Communist regime as a "dynasty" interested only in power ("The Communist Dynasty Had Its Run. Now What?" Week in Review, Feb. 23).
In fact, like other 20th-century regimes but unlike previous dynasties, the Communists have sought to enrich, strengthen and discipline China as a modern nation-state. And if some of the techniques of rule have not changed much (playing bureaucratic factions off one another, exiling opponents), others have (the highly centralized military, a national school system, the party apparatus). 
 Nor does it seem useful to call China "fascist," if only because that term implies a level of order and discipline currently beyond the Government's ability to achieve, even if it wanted to. As you point out, economic changes are leading slowly to a new kind of society. Already, while it tolerates a Government monopoly over political discourse, China's civil society accepts few other restrictions.
 
PETER ZARROW
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 24, 1997
 
The writer is a member of the Institute for Advanced Study.

HEADLINE: Evolving China Merely Resembles a Dynasty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You assert that China's leaders still abide by the historical lesson that "a ruler can kill peasants to his heart's content, but tangles with students at his peril" (Week in Review, Feb. 23). In fact, Chinese rulers have become clever enough not to trifle with the welfare of the masses, whether peasants or workers.
Beijing's policy reformers have interpreted human rights in terms of jobs or other income-earning opportunities for everyone rather than political dissent. Whatever the tilt toward marketization and however flat-footedly, the Communist Party has tried to minimize unemployment. China's state-owned enterprises have restructured, but less by downsizing than by expanding fast enough to absorb the work force. 
 You predict that the next Communist dynasty will be doomed if it is unable to respond to the yearnings for political participation. Perhaps, but these alleged yearnings themselves will wither unless growth is kept up and unemployment is kept down by a policy mix of market and state.
 
ALICE H. AMSDEN
Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 23, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of political economy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: The London Tube, in the Dumps, Could Be Put Up for Sale

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Britain's Conservative Government today proposed selling off London's subway system, the oldest in the world and the transportation lifeline of a city built more for grace than for mobility.
Speaking in the House of Commons, Sir George Young, the Transport Secretary, said that letting private enterprise take over was the only way to restore the ailing and cash-starved network known as the Tube to its past glory. 
 Last week London Underground said it was shelving hundreds of restoration and improvement projects worth $1.2 billion scheduled over the next three years because of a lack of Government financing.
With a general election only months away, the announcement was seized on for political advantage by both Government and opposition speakers.
"What we have in mind will be very popular with voters, very popular with passengers because it will improve the quality of public transport here in London," Sir George told Parliament.
But Andrew Smith, transportation spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, derided the proposal as "more fortunes for the few, more misery for the many."
Tony Blair, the Labor leader, said the Government would be abandoning a key public service "at a fraction of its true value so that a few people make a vastly inflated profit with no guarantee of a proper service for the future."
"No, you're wrong," Prime Minister John Major said, asserting that the action would give the capital a "world class" subway network.
Then, to the laughter of Tory backbenchers, he added, "I find it extraordinary that the only two places in the world where privatization is reviled and state ownership preferred is the Labor Party and North Korea."
Labor, which is ahead by more than 20 points in the polls of voters for the election expected in May, has said it would like to maintain Government control of the Underground but to attract private investment through partnerships.
Fighting a battle for economic survival common to urban transportation systems, the London Underground charges riders roughly 30 percent more in fares than other cities and manages that way to cover all its operating and maintenance costs. New York, by comparison, pays only 88 percent of those same expenses with the sale of its tokens, Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit advocacy group, said in a telephone interview.
London has regularly seen its capital budget slashed, with equipment breakdowns and derelict station conditions the result. Still the grumbling over the discomforts of traveling the Underground would seem positively quaint to New Yorkers. Asked today about crime on the Underground, one rider looked surprised and then chuckled, saying, "Nothing more than the occasional spot of bother."
When Mr. Blair mentioned the Government's past privatization performance, he was alluding to evidence that it greatly undervalued lines and rolling stock in the just completed selloff of Britain's railways, allowing investors and management buyout teams to resell the properties within months at multi-million-dollar profits.
Labor has asserted that the Government sold $30 billion worth of assets for less than $4 billion. Mr. Blair said today that the Underground might be worth as much as $20 billion but that the Government might let it go for as little as $1 billion.
Coincidentally, today was the day that the last train company in the 11,000-mile British Rail network -- Scotrail -- passed into private hands, marking the end to a busy 14-month period in which all 25 of Britain's train companies were sold to private concerns. Among the new owners are Richard Branson's Virgin Group of Companies, two large British bus companies, the shipping company Sea Containers and the French Compagnie General des Eaux group.
There have been immediate cosmetic improvements on the newly privatized lines, with conductors, porters and ticket takers in smart new uniforms and some preliminary statistics showing that the trains are running more punctually and attracting more passengers. The new owners are already turning profits and promising vast capital investment during the next five years.
Unions and passenger groups have protested the numbers of layoffs, and the first line to be sold off, South West Trains, caused a furor this month when it eliminated 39 commuter trips from its timetables because it had dismissed too many drivers to pilot its trains.
In their 18 years in office, the Tories have returned to the private sector the state-run industries in steel, water, gas, buses, electricity, telephones and coal. They have recently backed off rumored plans to sell the Royal Mail.
The notion of turning the London Underground, in public hands for the last 63 years, back to private owners was leaked to newspapers last month along with a memo from Sir George saying it "will be a unique and very difficult privatization to sell to the public." Today he argued that it would be a major part of the Conservative Party's agenda in the coming election.
The Underground, the oldest part of which dates to 1863, operates 20 hours a day over 255 miles of track and comprises 248 stations on 11 lines that provide 2.7 million rides a day. Most fares fall between $1.90 and $5.15. Londoners' complaints have grown in recent years at the increasing failures of signals and rolling stock and the deterioration of track and stations that 30 years of cutting capital investment to hold down spending has produced. A lot of attention has been paid in particular to problems on the Northern Line, which goes to neighborhoods of some prominent newspaper columnists.
In last week's announcement, the Underground warned passengers to expect congestion, delays and no station improvements. In recent months there have been a power breakdown that stranded passengers for two hours in darkness, a derailment that caused 200 theatergoers to walk to safety along a tunnel platform, a fire that led to the evacuation of two major stations and some overcrowding on platforms because of construction projects.
A rider of the New York system could be forgiven for asking what else is new. London stations remain cleaner than those in New York, announcements are audible, its well-known circle-and-horizontal-line logo is lighted and visible from blocks away and its passengers can even be courteous. Trains are more frequent, and electrified signs signal their arrival, destination and the location of trains behind them in the minutes before they reach the station.
The Underground gained a passenger this morning when Sir George left his ministerial limousine at Parliament and traveled one stop from Westminster to the St. James Park headquarters of the Tube to brief directors there on his upcoming talk in Commons. His eventful day almost came to a halt on the platform, but a quick-witted inspector got it back under way by pointing out that he was inserting his exit ticket in the wrong turnstile slot.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 27, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday with an article about a British Government plan to privatize the London Underground, comparing the sizes of London's and New York's subway systems, misstated the size of New York's in some editions. The New York system has 238 miles of routes; 714 is the figure for miles of track, with every route having at least two tracks.

HEADLINE: Fence-Sitter Will Support Amendment On Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana, one of two Senators who had not declared a position, announced today that she would vote for a balanced-budget amendment, meaning that the outcome of the vote in the Senate will probably be decided by the last holdout, Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey.
Mr. Torricelli, who, like Ms. Landrieu, is a freshman Democrat, seemed to enjoy being the center of attention and refused today to say how he would vote on a Republican proposal to amend the Constitution to require a balanced Federal budget. He scheduled a news conference for Wednesday. 
 Two years ago, when Mr. Torricelli was in the House of Representatives, he voted for an almost identical amendment. But he has said recently that he now had serious reservations about the matter.
Senate approval of a constitutional amendment would require a two-thirds' majority, or 67 votes, assuming that all 100 senators vote. All 55 Republicans and 11 Democrats have announced their support for the Republican measure. The other 33 Democrats, besides Mr. Torricelli, have declared their opposition.
At Ms. Landrieu's first individual news conference since she became a Senator, she said a constitutional amendment was probably the best way to impose the "fiscal discipline" she thought the country needed. But she conceded that the main reason for her decision was that she had promised in her campaign to support a balanced-budget amendment.
Asked whether that promise had been an educated one, she replied, "I know a lot more about the subject now than I did in the campaign."
Did that mean she would have decided against the amendment if it had not been for her campaign commitment?
"You could read that between the lines," she responded.
The proposed constitutional amendment would require a balanced budget two years after its ratification -- but not before 2002 -- and every year after that. It would have to be ratified by three-quarters of the state legislatures. If the amendment were ratified, the balanced-budget requirement could be overridden only by a three-fifths' majority in the Senate and the House.
The amendment has been an important part of Republican doctrine for years. In 1995, it was approved by the House, but it failed in the Senate by one vote. This year, the situation is even more problematic in the House than it is in the Senate.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said today he hoped that a final Senate vote could be taken next Tuesday.
The amendment's sponsors hold that a constitutional amendment is the only way to curb the tendency of politicians to overspend and run chronic budget deficits. The opponents counter that such an amendment would make it harder to respond to emergencies and would jeopardize Social Security benefits.
Mostly, the debate in the Senate has seemed driven more by politics than economics. Opinion polls show that when people are asked simply whether they favor a balanced-budget constitutional amendment, about 80 percent say they do. But fewer than half say they support such an amendment if it would require lower Social Security benefits.
Tonight, the Senate rejected in a 65-to-35 vote a substitute amendment offered by Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, that would have required a balanced budget but would have excluded Social Security from the budget calculations. That amendment never had a chance of approval, but it provided political cover for Democrats who want to be able to say they favor a balanced-budget amendment but are determined to protect Social Security.

A proposal by Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, to exclude Social Security receipts and expenses from budget calculations was rejected by a vote of 55 to 44, not 65 to 35.

HEADLINE: Making a Star of Key's Spangled Banner

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
How do you clean a huge old piece of cloth that is a national symbol, the subject of the anthem that is sung, if with some difficulty, by every American?
Very carefully. Very slowly. And in Washington, you start by convening a conference of experts. 
 The object of all this attention is the very Star-Spangled Banner that waved over Fort McHenry and inspired Francis Scott Key to write the poem that became the national anthem.
Since that day in 1814 when Key saw the American flag from the deck of a ship in Baltimore's harbor and knew the British had not captured the city, it has lost a star and several yards of stripes. In fact, it is now 270 square feet smaller, mostly because proud citizens have snipped pieces from it over the years.
But it has also gained a benign but mysterious red "V" sewn on a white stripe. And it has become a mat for dust, pollen, bits of leaves and soil, and errant fibers from paper, mops and the like. This is what Suzanne Thomassen-Krauss, a textile expert at the Smithsonian Institution, where the flag is displayed, calls "normal indoor pollution."
The flag has also put on weight, going from 80 pounds when it flew over the fort to about 135 pounds now, mostly because of a linen backing added to protect it years ago.
Ronald E. Becker, the Smithsonian official responsible for the cleaning project, described his problem this way: "What's the best approach to maximizing the life of the flag and still have it on display?"
So how do you clean a national icon? That's what Mr. Becker and his group are studying. They do know they aren't going to put it in a washing machine. But they may use a gentle vacuum cleaner.
In 1812, the young United States got into a war with Britain over trade and territorial disputes. Today, probably the most lasting memory of the war was that it gave birth to "The Star-Spangled Banner," and not that it resulted in the burning of the White House, which occurred just before the attack on Baltimore.
The flag that inspired Key was ordered in 1813 by Maj. George Armistead, the commander of Fort McHenry, who wanted an extraordinarily large flag that could be seen from a great distance. He hired Mary Pickersgill, a Baltimore flag maker, to sew the 42-by-30-foot flag for $405.60. Given the year of the contract, that might seem an enormous amount, but Prof. Robert Sahr, an Oregon State University political scientist who has studied the relative value of money, put it at about $3,000 in 1996 dollars because the War of 1812 caused a period of great inflation.
Ms. Thomassen-Krauss, the Smithsonian textile conservator, said of Mrs. Pickersgill: "She's an interesting lady, and her mother made a flag for George Washington's headquarters in Cambridge, Mass."
Mrs. Pickersgill may have bought the fabric from Capt. Jesse Fearson, her brother-in-law, who had a dry-goods store in Baltimore, Ms. Thomassen-Krauss said. She kept the flag-making even more of a family project by enlisting her 13-year-old daughter, Caroline, to help her with the sewing, which took place on the floor of a local brewery. And she probably got advice from her mother, Rebecca Young.
Except for the cotton stars, the flag was made of wool bunting that presumably originated in England, then the world's wool center. Perhaps the wool was seized from a British ship by an American privateer or was bought in a third country after being shipped there from England, Ms. Thomassen-Krauss speculates.
"Wool was typical material for flags in this country up until the Civil War," she said. "Cotton at that time -- before the invention of the cotton gin -- was a luxury item. Wool is good for a flag, being elastic and durable under wear and tear."
What's fairly certain is that the flag didn't shrink at Fort McHenry, because forts didn't fly their prized flags in the rain. Instead, in bad weather they flew a smaller and less valuable banner called a storm flag.
The blue dye for the star field was made of indigo, probably from India or Southeast Asia. The red dye was made of cochineal, which comes from the bodies of female insects of the same name, and madder from a plant probably grown in the Netherlands or France.
Bunting is a textile term for an open-weave fabric. For the flag, the warp (the yarn stretched on the loom during weaving) and the weft (the filling yarn that is woven into the warp) are roughly 30 threads per inch for the blue field and 41 for the stripes.
The flag has 15 white stars -- when the flag is hung vertically, they are in six horizontal rows of two or three each -- and 15 stripes (8 red and 7 white), instead of the 13 in the current flag.
Last November, Mr. Becker, who is the associate director for capital programs at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History, brought together 50 experts -- textile scientists, conservators, historians, curators, designers and flag specialists -- from the United States, Canada and Britain to discuss the flag's conservation.
It is hung vertically under low light near the museum's second-floor entrance. A reproduction has been added at the bottom to represent the missing area. It serves as the backdrop for a pendulum that demonstrates that the earth rotates, and many people are so intent on watching the pendulum swing back and forth that they do not even notice the huge flag behind them.
The scientists will decide on the proper micro-environment for the flag. They will also determine a level of light that will be bright enough for the public to see the flag but not enough to damage it.
Mr. Becker estimated that it will cost about $15 million to construct a new display area for the flag, including the costs of replacing the air-conditioning system and changing the linen backing if necessary. Another $15 million will be sought to establish an endowment to care for the flag in the future.
Some of that money will come from the Government, since the Smithsonian is a quasi-Federal agency. The museum is hoping that individuals, corporations and foundations will provide the balance.
The flag once had a huge protective cover that was raised with some ceremony every hour on the hour, accompanied by "The Star-Spangled Banner." But the cover broke in 1994.
Mr. Becker said, "We saw it as an opportunity to not just replace it but to renew our conservation efforts and study the condition of the flag today."

SECTION: Section D; Page 7; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 370 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls and Then Rallies Against the Yen and the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied yesterday even as stock and bond markets slumped after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the central bank might raise interest rates to thwart inflation.
The unusual bluntness of Mr. Greenspan's message in Congressional testimony took currency traders by surprise. Many who had sold dollars on fear of a Wall Street selloff scrambled to buy the currency, accelerating its rebound in what is known as a short-covering rally. 
 "This was much wilder than anticipated," said Roger Chapin, foreign-exchange manager at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio. "People had trimmed back and gone the other direction with the dollar. Then they found themselves short dollars and had to rush out and cover that stuff."
The dollar traded as low as 1.6700 marks before rising sharply to settle in New York trading at 1.6902 marks, up from 1.6719 marks on Tuesday and the highest level in a week.
Against the yen, the dollar traded just below 121 yen before rebounding to settle in New York at 122.13 yen, up from 121.60 Tuesday. The British pound traded at $1.6343, down from $1.6350.
The dollar initially weakened in Asian and European dealings on fear of increased Japanese corporate repatriation of yen into dollars before Japan's fiscal year ends March 31.
Further pressuring the dollar were remarks by two senior members of the Bundesbank that dampened prospects for lower interest rates in Germany.
Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, a member of the central bank's policy-making council, said lower rates would not help stimulate the German economy. Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, Bundesbank vice president, said lower German rates would make the dollar excessively strong.
But the main focus for currency traders was Mr. Greenspan's appearance in Congress to report on the Fed's monetary policy. Many traders were predisposed to sell the dollar ahead of his testimony.
But Mr. Greenspan said the United States economy was remarkably healthy and inflation was tame, which are underlying components of the dollar's strength. He further suggested the Fed may raise short-term interest rates soon in a pre-emptive move against inflation. Higher rates would attract investment flows into dollars.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 840 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Surprises for everyone in a new analysis of affirmative action.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH California's initiative against affirmative action, Proposition 209, on the books and other states pondering rollbacks in their own affirmative action programs for public higher education, you'd think policy makers clearly understand the consequences of the contemplated changes.
Wrong. Apart from rudimentary inferences about how many nonwhites would make the cut if California's universities adopted race-blind admissions policies, a lack of hard evidence has left both critics and defenders of racial preferences free to exercise their imaginations. That's why an analysis by Thomas Kane, an economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is so striking. 
 Mr. Kane's as-yet unpublished analysis has some surprises for everyone. Affirmative action, he argues, has really had significant impact on racial composition only in the nation's elite universities and colleges, not the schools that educate the vast bulk of young Americans.
That's one surprise. Another is that diversity through affirmative action has produced some clear payoffs in the job market. Most important, perhaps, Mr. Kane debunks the voguish idea that affirmative action based on class rather than race could serve as a palatable means to the same end.
It has long been assumed that affirmative action drove admissions policies from the top of the higher education pecking order to the bottom. The gap in admissions standards in the most academically selective fifth of colleges is, indeed, large. Here Mr. Kane found that other factors held equal, black and Hispanic students with combined S.A.T. scores of 1,100 had the same chance of admission as whites with scores of 1,400.
Step down a notch, though, and race seems to play little part in the probability of admissions or in racial composition of the student body. Of course, much of the reason is that most colleges simply cannot afford to be picky about academic qualifications if they wish to fill their classes. In Mr. Kane's sample of some 36,000 students from 1,000 high schools, fully 90 percent who applied to schools in the bottom three-fifths were admitted.
This would hardly satisfy critics of affirmative action -- notably Charles Murray, co-author of "The Bell Curve" -- who argue that asking poorly prepared minorities to compete in the very best colleges reinforces racial stereotypes. Mr. Murray argues that affirmative action actually harms the intended beneficiaries by increasing their chance of failure. But here again, what seems obvious is apparently not true. While the nonwhites in Mr. Kane's sample did underperform their white counterparts at elite colleges even after adjusting for socioeconomic factors, the performance gap was smaller than at unselective schools. Black or white, students from similar backgrounds who attended elite schools were more likely to finish school and had higher earnings if they did finish.
But that doesn't mean there aren't losers. Affirmative action may help nonwhites going to Berkeley or the University of Virginia, but perhaps at a cost to whites who must therefore settle for lesser schools. And no mainstream politician is eager to explain the virtues of racial diversity to parents of white applicants whose places are taken by nonwhites with lower test scores. That goes a long way toward explaining why "class based" affirmative action has become the moderate politician's policy flavor of the month.
The idea is simple. Discrimination is more palatable when it is linked to tangible economic disadvantage rather than to less tangible racial disadvantage. Thus many Americans who take the 14th Amendment literally would still be willing to give admissions preferences to children -- black, white, Hispanic -- from families with low incomes.
Class-based affirmative action would still favor nonwhites as a group because they are, on average, much poorer. But Mr. Kane throws cold water on the idea that it would serve as a substitute for racial preference. That's because so many of the minority students attending highly selective colleges are from the middle class.
Indeed, Mr. Kane's figures suggest that in order to replicate the current level of nonwhite admissions, elite colleges would have to grant preferences to six times as many low-income students. And this would fundamentally change the character of the colleges, sharply lowering average test scores and displacing huge numbers of high-scoring middle-income whites.
Where, then, is the middle ground? For Mr. Kane, "a more workable compromise" would be to maintain race-based affirmative action, but only for nonwhites who also qualify as economic minorities -- that is, those from poor families or poor neighborhoods. But that would certainly mean fewer members of minority groups would enjoy the advantages of an elite public education.
In the end, the much misused aphorism about free lunches applies here. Places in top colleges are limited. No amount of ingenuity can eliminate the sting of affirmative action for everyone.
